projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE LAW OF Obligations and Conditions, OR An Accurate TREATISE, wherein is contained the whole Learning of the LAW concerning Bills, Bonds, Conditions, Statutes, Recogniz ‚Ä¢ nces and Defea≈øances; as al≈øo Declarations on Special Conditions, and the Pleadings thereon, I≈ø≈øues, Judgments and Executions, with many other u≈øeful Matters relating thereunto, dige≈øted under their proper Titles.
To which is added A TABLE of References to all the Declarations and Pleadings upon Bonds, &c. now extant.

ALSO Another TABLE to the Forms of ≈øpecial Conditions which lie ≈øcattered in our Pre≈øident BOOKS. Being a Work nece≈ø≈øary for all that Study the Law, or follow the Practick Part thereof. With an INDEX of the Principal Matters therein contained.
By T. A. of Grays-Inn E≈øq.
LONDON, Printed for I. Walthoe at his Shop in Vine-Court, Middle-Temple. 1693.

div.head: TO THE STUDETNS OF THE Common Law.
div.p:
I Have often admired, as well at the Confidence as the ≈øcribling Fatigues of any particular Per≈øons, who pretend to write Abridgments of the whole Common Law of England; Non e≈øt res unius aetatis; ≈øuch Per≈øons by
an impertinent Citation of a Multitude of Ca≈øes, not duly examined, either rai≈øe a Confu≈øion in the Minds of Students, or el≈øe ≈øoften them into a carele≈øs Humour; it being more ea≈øie to turn to Hughes or Shepherd, than to ≈øearch into the true Rea≈øons of the Judgment in Ca≈øes maturely reported; be≈øides, the≈øe Per≈øons are ≈øeldom curious about Declarations and Pleadings; their e≈ø≈øential Forms and apt Notions, which is the very Soul of the Law, that pla≈øtica vis, without which all their Volumes are void of Life and regular Motion, a meer rudis indige≈øta
que moles.
Some indeed have merited well by their particular Treati≈øes, and for that they have kept them≈øelves to one Subject, have proved very u≈øeful.

This particular Title which I here pre≈øent to you, hath not been hitherto fully and de≈øignedly handled; and yet there is no Title more frequent in our Books than that of Obligations and Conditions. The Method I have u≈øed is as exact as a Treati≈øe of this Nature is capable of; yet in this I have not been over-curious and ≈øy≈øtematical.

I have not treated at large on Arbitration Bonds; the Learning of Arbitraments being a large Title of it ≈øelf, and Mr. March hath been very exact therein; and for the ≈øame Rea≈øon I have been very ≈øparing about Bonds ≈øued by or again≈øt Executors or Admini≈øtrators, that being a peculiar Learning of it ≈øelf, (though hitherto I confe≈øs but lamely handled.)
I have added a Reference-Table of Declarations and Pleadings, both Ancient and Modern, a thing u≈øeful for entring Clarks, who may at any time compare their own Manu≈øcripts with the≈øe.

I have al≈øo added a Table of ≈øpecial Conditions ≈øuch as are extant, though that mu≈øt generally be left to the Students own Improvement, as the nature of the Ca≈øe will be; and its very ea≈øie to change any Covenant into a Condition.

Some Ca≈øes I have cited more largely for the benefit of ≈øuch who may not have the Books at hand, but e≈øpecially where the Rea≈øons of the Re≈øolutions are Learned and Curious; and I have corrected ≈øome Ca≈øes which have been mi≈øtaken in ≈øome Reports, as Croke Eliz. and others: I have ventured to in≈øert
many of the Ca≈øes reported by Mr. Keble, though in ≈øome of them I confe≈øs I am a little confounded, but they are ≈øet down in his own Words.

Gent. If this Piece prove u≈øeful to you either in it ≈øelf, or in in≈øtructing you in the Method of your Studies as to other Titles of Law, I have my De≈øign; And if you plea≈øe to pardon my Mi≈øtakes, it will lay a farther Obligation on your Humble Servant

div.head: THE LAW OF Obligations and Conditions.
The Nature of an Obligation, and with what re≈øpect it ≈øtands in the Eye of the LAW.
div.p: AN Obligation is taken in the Common Law for a Bond, containing a Penalty with a Condition for payment of Mony, or to do or ≈øuffer ≈øome Act or Thing, &c. And a Bill is a ≈øingle Bond without a Condition. Co. Lit. 172. a. How they differ farther, vide infra Tit. Bill.

Its not a Debt ≈øimply by the Obligation, but the performance or breach of the Condition makes it to be a Debt, for the Obligation is guided by the Condition, Yelv. pag. 192. 1 Brownl. p. 109. Neal and Sheffield.
A ≈øingle Obligation is taken mo≈øt in favour of the Obligee; but an Obligation with a Condition is taken mo≈øt in favour of the Obligor, 10 H. 7. o. 16.
Its a Debt pre≈øently upon the ≈øealing and delivery; it is debitum in prae≈øenti, though ≈øolveur dum in futuro.

It is a cho≈øe in Action. Therefore if a Bond be made for payment of Mony to a Feme Sole, Feme takes Husband and dies, the Debt due upon the Bond becomes not a Debt due to the Husband, but
to him that admini≈øters, Stiles Rep. 205. Cowley and Lock≈øon. Nov 149. Norton and Glover.

A Bond is to be paid before a Statute for performance of Covenants not broken, 5 Rep. 28. Harri≈øons Ca≈øe. When none of them were, nor ever perhaps ≈øhall be broken, ≈øuch po≈ø≈øibilities ≈øhall not bar pre≈øent Debts, Cro. Eliz. p. 467.
A Bond for a long continuing Duty, will not hinder payment of a Legacy, 2 Keble 759. Davis Ca≈øe.

It is a Debt where the Obligation is (at the time of the decea≈øe of the Obligee) and not where the Obligee inhabits, and accordingly ≈øhall be accounted bonae not abilia, 1 Sanders 274. Cro. Eliz. Byrons Ca≈øe.

By grant of omnia bona & ontalla felonum Obligations do pa≈øs by the Kings Grant; but by a particular Per≈øons Grant of omnia bona & catalla Obligations do not pa≈øs, 1 Keble 417, 467, 497. Corporation of Southampton again≈øt Richards, 1 Siderfin 142. me≈øme Ca≈øe.

If a Man grant to J. S. all his Goods and Chattels in ≈øuch a Box, and in this Box are Obligations, there the Obligations pa≈øs, by rea≈øon of the ≈øpecial Reference expre≈øt by the Grant, Yelv. p. 69. Chanels Ca≈øe.

Two Executors to J. S. one Executor had a Bond wherein A. B. was bound to their Te≈øtator, he in ≈øatisfaction of his own proper Debt to C. D. by word dedit & deliberavit the Obligation to C. D. and dies, the Plaintiff being ≈øurviving Executor, brings Do ‚Ä¢ e again≈øt C. D. per three Ju≈øtices, the Executor may give away the In≈øtrument, as well as relea≈øe a Debt; but is a≈øcribed
to the Deed before the ≈øealing, its a good part; if after ≈øealing, its a Condition per Crew. Bul≈øt. 3. p. 302. Tomp≈øon and Butchor.
As for Declarations on Bills Obligatory, and Pleadings, ≈øee in their proper places.

In re≈øpect of
Obligors,
Obligees.

I ≈øhall con≈øider Obligors

By what Name.
Who are bound though not named.

div.head: What per≈øons may or may not make Obligations.
div.p: EVery natural Per≈øon or Body politick not prohibited by the Law may bind them≈øelves.
But ≈øome per≈øons are incapacited by the Law to bind them≈øelves, and ≈øome Obligations are void, and others only voidable.
If a Monk make an Obligation, it is void, 14 H. 4.30.

div.head: Feme.
div.p:
IF a Feme Covert make an Obligation it is void, 14 H. 4.30. and ≈øhe ≈øhall plead ≈øhe was Feme Covert, and conclude i≈ø≈øint non e≈øt factum, becau≈øe it is void: But an Infant ≈øhall not do ≈øo, becau≈øe his Bond was only voidable, and he ≈øhall conclude Judgment ≈øi actio,
1 H. 7. 15. Donn's Ca≈øe. Vid. pluis po≈øtea ≈øub tit. plead. non e≈øt factum.

Debt brought again≈øt J. S. and Elianor his Wife upon Bond made by the Wife. Defendant pleads quod tempore confectionis, and ≈øhews the day ≈øhe was Feme Covert. The Plaintiff confe≈ø≈øeth this, but ≈øaith, ≈øhe ≈øealed the ≈øame Deed the ≈øame day of her marriage before the E≈øpou≈øals in the morning. Defendant demurs: The Plaintiff had Judgment, 2 Rolls Rep. 431. Jack≈øon's Ca≈øe.

Debt on Bond by Baron and Feme. The Defendant pleads the Wife had another Husband living. The Plaintiff replies, the Wife ad annos nubiles di≈øagreed to the former marriage, and good, Moor n. Warner and his Wife ver≈øus Babbington.
Feme Obligor of full age takes Baron within age, in Debt on Obligation, they pray his age, but denyed, Noy p. 69.

div.head: Infants.
div.p: IF an Infant make an Obligation, this is not void, but voidable.

If an Infant ≈øeal a Bond, and he be ≈øued thereon, he cannot plead non e≈øt factum; but it mu≈øt be avoided by ≈øpecial pleading, and conclude Judgment ≈øi actio; for the Bond was not void but voidable, 5 Rep. 119. Whelpdale's Ca≈øe, 1 H. 7.15. Donn's Ca≈øe, Vid. po≈øtea.

An Obligation or Covenant of an Infant for his Apprenti≈øhip ≈øhall not bind him, neither at Common Law, nor by the words of 5 Eliz. yet the Indenture ≈øhall bind him, becau≈øe he is compellable
Yelv. 225. contra. Octogenta libris, with Condition of payment of 40 l. it was adjudged good for octogint. though it is minus Latinum, 10 Rep. 133. Fitzhughes Ca≈øe cited in James O≈øborns Ca≈øe, Hob. p. 19. contra. The Record of this Ca≈øe is ≈øet forth at large in Hobart, but there is no mention of the Condition, the Obligation was in ≈øeptungenta libris, with Condition of payment of 350 l. and good, 10 Rep. 133. cited in James Osborns Ca≈øe, ≈øo in vigint, libris, this is a good Obligation for 20 l. in Osborus Ca≈øe.

If a Man be bound in quingint. duabus libris this is a good Obligation for 52 l. the Condition being for the payment of 36 l. it cannot be taken for 500 l. becau≈øe it is not genta ‚Ä¢
but it ≈øhall be taken as an abbreviation of quinquagint. this was adjudged upon a ≈øpecial Verdict, where the Plaintiff declared upon a Bond de quinquagint. duabus libris, and the Defendant pleaded non e≈øt factum, Cro. M. 11 Jac. 416, 418. Downs and Haithwait.

A Man is bound in octoge≈øimo libris (pro octogint. libris) its good, 2 Rolls Abr. 147. Moor n. 1123. 1 Brownl. 60. Vernon and On≈ølow, in quinquage≈ø≈øimis libris pro quinquagint. libris, good, being all of one ≈øen≈øe; ≈øo fiftieth and fifty pounds, Cro. M. 9 Jac. Els and Clark.
Debt upon a Bill Obligatory for thirty two pounds, and upon Over of the Bill it was threty two pounds, adjudged pro quer' Cro. Jac. 607. Hulbert and Long.

The Obligation was in centem libris, and upon non e≈øt factum pleaded on a ≈øpecial Verdict; the que≈øtion was, whether it was his Deed or not, becau≈øe
it was centem (for where a Deed is void non e≈øt factum is a good Plea) but adjudged it was all one with centum, and the Condition ≈øhewed it to be an 100 l. Stiles Hill. 1653. fol. 438. Yorkhur≈øt and Scot.
One is bound in vigint. nobulis, its good, 2 Rolls Abr. 146. Cro. Jac. 203. 1 Brownl. 95. Durchin and Vaughan.

Debt is brought for 600 l. on Bond, on Oyer it was ≈øexagint. for this Variance the Defendant demurs; per Cur. this Obligation doth not warrant the Declaration, becau≈øe it is another Sum, and cannot be taken for ≈øexcent. Cro. M. 5 Jac. fol. 203. Greggs Ca≈øe, One is bound in ≈øexgint. libris for ≈øexcent. libris, this is not good, its not a Latin word, Yelv. p. 105. 2 Rolls Abr. 147. Grey and Davis. In terengentate liberis its a void Bond, for both words are in≈øen≈øible, Cro. M. 18 Jac. 603. Hills and Cooper. In quint aginta libris is ill, but there is a good remedy in Equity on this mi≈øtake, 3 Keble 644. P. 28 Car. 2. Strange and Greenhill.

Note, There is a difference when the Condition is to pay a Sum of Mony, for then the intent of the Sum may more ea≈øily be collected, ut ≈øupra, and a Condition to do a Collateral Act. Debt on Bond de quingent. libris; Defendant demands Oyer, and it was in quemquegent libris, the Condition was to do a collateral Act, Defendant pleads an in≈øufficient Plea, and the Plaintiff demurring thereon prayed his Judgment: but becau≈øe the Plaintiff had declared upon a Bond that appeared to be variant, and the word was in≈øen≈øible,
and had not any other thing to expound it, per Cur. the Obligation was void, and Writ ≈øhall abate, Hill. 4 Jac. p. 146. 2 Rolls Abr. 146. Yelv. 95. Parry and Dale. So,

A. is bound in a Bail Bond pro quadragent. libris, the Plaintilf declares pro quadragint. libris, for this variance Defendant demurs to the Declaration, per Cur. genta, refers to centum, and ≈øo its rather 400 l. than 40 l. and the Condition being collateral doth not ≈øhew the intent of the Parties; adjudged again≈øt the Plaintiff, Stiles p. 241, 257. 2 Rolls Abr. 147, 148. Feilder and Tovey. So Condition to appear was novemgint. (for honagint.) and the Defendant pleaded in Abatement, 3 Keble 255. Scots Ca≈øe.
An Engli≈øh Bill is made ≈øe ‚Ä¢ teen for ≈øeventeen pounds, and adjudged good, in 10 Rep. 113. James Osborns Ca≈øe.
Tenerie & firmit. Obligarie, yet good, Yelv. 193. Dod≈øon and Keyes.
In viginti litteris (for libris) its void, Partro≈øe's Ca≈øe cited in Cro. Jac. 603. Cooper and Hills Ca≈øe, But the Attorny who made the Bond was committed to the Fleet for Knavery.
In viginti lib'is, with a da≈øh, its an in≈øufficient Bond; liba ≈øignifies a Cake, and the da≈øh doth not help it, Noy p. 109, Shet ‚Ä¢ et and Mallet.
One is bound in viginti liveris (for libris) it is not good, Cro. Jac. fol. 203. cited in Durchin and Vaughans Ca≈øe.
A Man is bound in an Obligation, in libris, without ≈øaying how much, its a void Obligation, Yelv. p. 225. in Loggins and Tethertons Ca≈øe.
An Obligation was made for the payment of 10 l. 8 s. and 8 (not ≈øaying pence) Action of Debt lies for the 10 l. 8 s. 1 Brownl. Rep. p. 61.
Obligation to pay 5 l. puri auri, i. e. fine gold, Quaer. 9 H. 7.6.

div.head: In re≈øpect of the Frame of the Obligation or Bill.
div.p: NOte the Opinion in Yelverton, Dod≈øon and Key's Ca≈øe, p. 193. When the parties and the ≈øum are well expre≈ø≈øed to the Conu≈øance of the Judges, ≈øuch words by which the party doth intend to bind him≈øelf ≈øhall ≈øerve.

Memorandum, That I Ben, have received 20 l. of C. which 20 l. I Ben. promi≈øe to pay to D. in witne≈øs whereof I have hereunto ≈øet my Seal, this is a good Obligation, 22. E. 4.22. cited in Roll. 2. Abr. 146. If it be, I ≈øhall pay to you 20 l. In witne≈øs, &c. I put my Seal, its a good Obligation, 22 E. 4.22. So the≈øe words, Concedo vobis, &c. makes a good Bond, 22 E. 4.22. Hatley's Ca≈øe. If a Man by his Deed, ≈øay, that I owe to C. 20 l. to be paid at Ea≈øter next, or, I had of C. 20 l. of which I owe him 10 l. or, to be repaid him again; or, I A. B. do bind my ≈øelf to C. that he ≈øhall receive 20 l. and ≈øuch like, the≈øe are all binding.

Obligation was made in ≈øuch manner: Be it known to all Men, that I doe owe unto Oliver 26 l. to be paid ≈øuch a ≈øum at Michaelmas, and ≈øuch a ≈øum at Lady-day; and in truth the particular Sums do not amount unto 26 l. this was not a good Obligation for 26 l. Rolls 2 Rep. Tr. 18 Jac. B. R. Oliver's Ca≈øe.

If A. acknowledge by a Bill Obligatory him≈øelf to owe 10 l. to B. to be paid at a day to come; and by the ≈øame Bill binds him and his Heirs in 20 l. and ≈øaith not, to whom he is bound; yet it is good, and it ≈øhall be intended to be bound to B. adjudged upon demurrer, Rolls 2. Abr. tit. Oblig. p. 148. Franklin and Turner.

Obligation was written in this form: Know all Men, &c. that I H. W. am bound to W. Gore, &c. in the Sum of, &c. for the payment of which Sum I give full power and authority to the ≈øaid Gore to levy the ≈øaid Sum upon the profits of, &c. until the ≈øame be paid. Defendant pleads, the Plaintiff had levied part of the ≈øaid Sum, and ≈øhews not how, ill Plea. Per Curiam, the Plaintiff may at his liberty bring his Action upon the ≈øaid Obligation, or levy the ≈øaid Monies according to to the Clau≈øe afore≈øaid, 3 Leon. fo. 223. Gore and Winckfeild.

An Obligation of 200 l. to two Solvend. the one hundred pound to the one, and the other to the other; it is a void Solvend. 18 Eliz. Dyer. 350. Hob. p. 172. in Stukeley's Ca≈øe; yet Brownlow ≈øeems contra, 2 Rep. p. 207. Obligation to two, ≈øolvend. 10 l. to the one, and 10 l. to the other; both ought to join in Debt on this Obligation. But an Obligation made to three, ≈øolvend. to one of them, is good.

Memorandum, I John B. have agreed to pay J. S. 20 l. though it be in the Preterperfect Ten≈øe, and wants the word In cujus rei te≈øtimonium; yet is a good Bill, 1 Leon. p. 25. Bedowes Ca≈øe. And per Wray dedi & conce≈ø≈øi are u≈øed as words of a pre≈øent Conveyance.

This Bill witne≈ø≈øeth, that I R. S. have received of T. P. 40 l. to the u≈øe of Robert and Jane Shaw Children of, &c. equally to be divided between them; which Sum I confe≈øs to have received to the u≈øes afore≈øaid, and the ≈øame to repay again at ≈øuch a time, as ≈øhall be thought be≈øt for the profit of the ≈øaid R. S. and J. S. R. S. dies inte≈øtate, his Admini≈øtrator brings Debt for 20 l. and counts that the Defendant by his Bill Obligatory (≈øhewn in Court) acknowledged ≈øe recepi≈ø≈øe 20 l. of T. P. to the u≈øe of the inte≈øtate, ≈øolvend. at ≈øuch a time, quod videtur opportunum pro proficuo of R. S. the inte≈øtate, and ≈øhews that at ≈øuch a time videbatur opportunum, &c. and he demanded it. Upon Oyer, the Defendant demanded Judgment of the Writ and Count as not warranted by this Bill; per Curiam. 1. This is a good Bill Obligatory, and ≈øhall be intended to be delivered to the u≈øe of the Plalntiffs inte≈øtate; the Plaintiff hath ≈øuppo≈øed it in his Declaration, and the Defendant hath admitted it, otherwi≈øe he ought to have pleaded non e≈øt factum. 2. The Receipt of this Mony ≈øhall be made to R. S. and J. S. and not to T. P. 3. It is as ≈øeveral Bills of 20 l. apiece, and are divided Debts, by the words equally to be divided, and ≈øo ≈øhall not ≈øurvive, Crook M. 41 Eliz. fo. 729. Shaw and Sherwood.

Be it known, &c. I Tho. J. do bind my ≈øelf to J. M. to pay unto him all ≈øuch Monies as my Brother owes him. In witne≈øs, &c. And in the end of the Bill was written, that Will. the Brother of Tho. J. owed to M. 40 l. with this Averment in the Declaration; it is a good Bill and Action lies; for it is reduced to a certainty, Crook Eliz. p. 561.
Morgan and John≈øon, and yet p. 758. dubitatur.

Be it known that I Tho. D. do owe unto A.B. 50 l. to be paid him, 10 l. at ≈øuch a day, and ≈øo at five ≈øeveral days 10 l. until 50 l. were paid; and for payment hereof I bind me, &c. in 10 l. nomine poenae. Obligee after five days pa≈øt brings Debt for 50 l. and good; for it is a ≈øeveral Bill for the 50 l. and a Bill al≈øo for the 10 l. Crook El. p. 771. Anonymus.

Memorandum, I do owe and promi≈øe to pay to A. 10 l. at any time after the Fea≈øt, &c. when ≈øhe ≈øhall require it; for payment whereof I bind my ≈øelf, &c. to J. H. by the≈øe Pre≈øents. It is a good Bill to A. by the words of the fir≈øt part, and the words which oblige. him to J. H. are void, Crook Eliz. 886. Hardman's Ca≈øe.
Bill Obligatory written in a Book with the Defendants Hand and Seal to it, good, Crook Eliz. p. 613. Fox and Wright.

Be it known, that I do owe unto P. 14 l. to be paid at, &c. together with 6 l. which I owe him upon Bill and Recognizance ≈øub≈øcribed under my Hand. Plaintiff brings Debt for 20 l. and adjudged again≈øt him, becau≈øe the Bill made him Debtor only for 14 l. Moor n. 670. Parry and Woodward.

The Defendant by Deed acknowledged he had received of T. 40 l. to the u≈øe of his Ma≈øter, to be paid at Michaelmas following, and ≈øealed it. In Debt the Defendant demurs, ≈øuppo≈øing this was only a Deed te≈øtifying the Receipt to anothers u≈øe, and not to charge him≈øelf. Curia contra, for the Clau≈øe of the repayment is general. Aliter, If the Bill had recited the Repayment to be made by the Ma≈øter,
then it had been but a Receipt, and meerly to anothers u≈øe, Yelv. p. 137, 147. Talbott and Godholt.
Now I ≈øhall put a Ca≈øe or two, how words written in a Bill after the In cujus rei Te≈øtimonium ≈øhall be expounded whether as parcel of the Bill or not.

My Lord Cook in Hamond and Jethro's Ca≈øe, 1 Brownl. Rep. 59. held that what≈øoever comes after the≈øe words (In witne≈øs, &c.) is no part of the Bill, but may be a Condition, and mu≈øt be pleaded and not demurred upon.

Debt upon a Bill of 6 l. 13 s. 4 d. and upon Over, after the In cujus rei Te≈øtimonium, this Clau≈øe was added in nature of a Provi≈øo; Provided that the ≈øaid 6. l. 13 s. 4 d. is not to be paid until ≈øuch an one hath had a Recovery in ≈øuch an Action or Suit, which he hath hanging again≈øt the Plaintiff upon a Bond of 200 l. conditioned for ≈øaving harmle≈øs, or hath made an end of the ≈øaid Suit. Conclu≈øion was, dat' ii≈ødem die & anno; and all this upon Oyer entred of Record. Defendant pleads, no end was made of the ≈øaid Suit, and ≈øo the time of payment not yet come. The Plaintiff replies a compo≈øition of 20 l. in di≈øcharge of the ≈øaid Suit; and I≈ø≈øue pro Quer' per Curiam the 20 l. may be given in ≈øatisfaction of the ≈øaid Suit, though not of the Obligation. This Provi≈øo is part of the Bill; for it expre≈ø≈øed the time of payment of the 6 l. 13 s. 4 d. If the Provi≈øo be no parcel of the Bill then it is in nature of a Condition. Per Dodderidge, Its parcel of the Bill, and the words In cujus rei, &c. are not nece≈ø≈øary to a Deed. If it be put in and ≈øub≈øcribed
a Deva≈øtavit in him, Cro. El. 478, 496. Kel≈øook and Nichol≈øon.

div.head: By what words an Obligation may be made, and what ≈øhall be good, and what not.
div.p:
In re≈øpect of
Fal≈øe Latin or Engli≈øh.
The Frame of the Obligation.

div.head: As to Faux Latin or omi≈ø≈øion.
div.p: THE Law doth make a rea≈øonable and favourable con≈øtruction of Mens Deeds and Conveyances, and will ≈øupport them (as much as it may) according to the intent of the Parties; but it abhors Non-≈øen≈øe, Repugnancy and In≈øen≈øibility, and will reject any thing which introduceth Incertainty and Confu≈øion, upon which no ≈øolid Judgment or weighty Authority can be founded.
I ≈øhall briefly lay down two or three Rules or Adverti≈øements contained in our Books, about the con≈øtruction of Faux Latin in Obligations, and then come to particular Ca≈øes.

Faux Latin ≈øhall abate a Writ, for that the Party may purcha≈øe a new Writ, but it ≈øhall not de≈øtroy an Obligation, for the Party cannot have a new Obligation when he will, 9 H. 7.16.10 H. 7. Yelv. p. 194. in Dod≈øons Ca≈øe, 1 Brownl. Rep. 110. ≈øo in James Osborns Ca≈øe, 10 Rep. 133. Faux Latin nor Faux Engli≈øh ≈øhall not make void a Bond or other Deed, when the meaning of the Party appeareth.

An Obligation ≈øhall not be avoided for vicious Writing or Incongruity, the Bond was Johem A. without a da≈øh, yet good, and the Declaration upon it was Johannes H. Cro. Car. p. 418. Downs and Haithwait.

There are two principal Things contained in an Obligation. 1. The Parties. 2. The Sum in which one Party is bound; and when both the≈øe are ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed to the Conu≈øance of the Judges, as the Obligor and Obligee are well named, and the Sum well expre≈ø≈øed, or ea≈øily without ≈øtraining under≈øtood to be the intent, and by ≈øuch words by which the Party doth intend to bind him≈øelf, it ≈øhall ≈øerve, if it be well executed, Yelv. p. 193. Brownl. Rep. 110. Dod≈øon and Keyes, and therefore in that Ca≈øe tenerie & firmit. obligarie, was held good; ≈øo if a Bond be Obligamus me haeredes, &c. it ≈øhall be good.

One is bound in Triginti libris (for Triginta) its good, Rolls Abr.
‚Ä¢ . p. 146. Taylor and Thorp, in ≈øexigint. pro ≈øexagint, yet good, 2 Bul≈øtr. 241. 1 Rolls Rep. 47. Hob. p. 20. Mar≈øhall and Jolly. Septuagent. for ≈øeptingent. was holden to be good, ≈øeptua being ea≈øily under≈øtood for ≈øeptem, and the Condition was for payment of Mony le≈øs than the Penalty, Hob. p. 116. Yelv. p. 95. 2 Rolls Abr. 147. Walter and Piggot. If a Man is bound in ≈øexingentis for ≈øexcentis libris, this is a good Obligation, for ≈øexingent, is good Latin, 2 Rolls Abr. 147. A Bond was made in Italian, and it was ≈øe≈ø≈øanta libris for ≈øexagint. and good, Cro. Jac. 208. Hob. 19. Parker and Kennedy. A Man is bound in trigintata (for triginta) yet its good, Hob. p. 18. 2 Rolls Abr. 147. Loggins and Tetherton
by the Statute to be bound; and upon misbehaviour, Remedy lies by Correction of the Ma≈øter, or the Ju≈øtices, Crook Hill. 5 Cor. fo. 179. Gilbert and Fletcher.

The Plaintiff had paid Mony for the nece≈ø≈øaries of the Infant, and took Bond in double the ≈øum, its void; otherwi≈øe, if he had taken Obligation for the very Sum, Crook Hill. 45 Eliz. fo. 920. Aileff and Archdale.

If the Bond be of exce≈ø≈øive value, the Infant may traver≈øe ab≈øque hoc that it was for nece≈ø≈øary Apparel, and the Plaintiff mu≈øt reply ≈øpecially, and ≈øhew the Bond to be ≈øuitable to the price of the things. Qu ‚Ä¢ r. If the Jury ought to find in ≈øuch ca≈øe non e≈øt factum, 1 Keb. M. 14 Car. 2. f. 416, 423. Ru≈ø≈øel and Le ‚Ä¢ .

An Infant ≈øubmits him≈øelf to an Arbitrament, its voidable, for he may wave it, if it be to his prejudice during his Minority; but if he do any thing which amounts to an Agreement at his full age, it ≈øhall bind him, Noy pag. 93. Stone and Knight.

The Bond beareth date when the Defendant was within Age, but it was ≈øealed and delivered at full age. The time of making the Bond, ≈øhall be when the Bond is ≈øealed, and not when it bears date, 1 Brownl. Rep. p. 3 ‚Ä¢ .

Debt on Bond dated 10 June, and delivered the 18th of the ≈øame month; the Defendant pleads by Prote≈øtation it was delivered the 18th day, ab≈øque hoe, that at that time, he was of full age Noy p. 34.

If an Infant make an Obligation and being „Äà‚óä„Äâ upon it, an Attorny without Warrant ≈øuffers a
Judgment by non ≈øum informatus; if he were within age, he ≈øhall have a Writ of Error; if he were not, he ≈øhall have a Writ of Di≈øceit again≈øt the Attorny, but no Audita Querela, Winch p. 114. A≈øhly and Collings.

div.head: Non compos mentis.
div.p: IF a non compos mentis ≈øeal a Bond, he ≈øhall not avoid it him≈øelf, 4 Rep. 124. Beverleys Ca≈øe. For no Man of full Age ≈øhall by Plea ≈øtultifie him≈øelf; but privy in Blood, as Heir, or privy in Repre≈øentation, as Executor or Admini≈øtrator ≈øhall plead the di≈øability of him, Ibid.

div.head: By Body Politick.
div.p: THEY mu≈øt be named by the true Name of their Corporation; and yet if the e≈ø≈øential part of a Corporation be named, it is ≈øufficient in an Action; as ad re≈øpondend' Majori & Burgen≈øibus de Lyn Regis in Com' N. and found they were incorporated, Majores & Burgen≈øes Burgi de Lyn & non per aliud; per Cur', the omi≈ø≈øion of the word (Burgi) ≈øhall not bar the Plaintiff, 1 Brownl. Rep. 57. Major and Burge≈ø≈øes of Lyn again≈øt Pain.

div.head: By what Names bound.
div.p: IF a Man bind him≈øelf in a faux Sirname, he ≈øhall be e≈øtopped to avoid this; ≈øo if by a faux Proper-name, 3 H. 6.25. b.

None can make an Obligation or other Writing by a contrary name of Bapti≈øm. Admini≈øtrator of Elianora brings Debt upon Bond, the Defendant pleads the Inte≈øtate in her Life by the name of Ellen relea≈øed, &c. The Plaintiff replied non e≈øt factum Elianorae, which was found ≈øo by Verdict, and well, More n. 1192. Panton and Chowles.

Obligation by the name of John, and the Condition by the name of James; the Declaration is that James per nomen Joh'is became bound, it is not good; for John cannot be James, Crook El. p. 897. Field and Winlow.

The Plaintiff declared in Debt again≈øt Edmond Watkins alias Edward Watkins, that he by the name of Edmund, was bound &c. The Condition was, that if Roger W. paid 50 l. to the Plaintiff at a day, then &c. The Defendant pleads Payment by Roger, and I≈ø≈øue and Verdict pro Quer' and Judgment: But it was rever≈øed by Error; for Edward is bound, and Edmund is ≈øued, which cannot be intended one and the ≈øame per≈øon, and no averment can help it; for one cannot have two Chri≈øtian Names, and here is no E≈øtoppel. Aliter, if the Condition had been if Edward W. pay the 50 l. and the Verdict found for the Plaintiff, then the Verdict ≈øhould make it an E≈øtoppel, Crook Jac. 558. Watkins and Oliver.
Debt on Bond brought again≈øt him by the name of Jacob; he pleads he was called and known by the name of Jaacob and not Jacob, it was overruled, Mod. Rep. 107. Aboabs.

div.head: Who are bound though not named.
div.p: IF a Man bind him≈øelf, his Executors are bound, though not named; not ≈øo of the Heir; for the Executor doth more actually repre≈øent the per≈øon of the Te≈øtator, Cook Lit. fo. 209.
The Ordinary ≈øhall be bound if he admini≈øters, 2 Rolls Abr. 149.
In re≈øpect of Obligees.
To whom Obligations may be made, and the Effect.

div.head: To Baron and Feme.
div.p: A. Makes a Bond to Baron and Feme, Baron dies, Feme admini≈øters and brings Debt upon the Obligation as Admini≈øtratrix; ≈øhe dies before Judgment, and her Executor brought Debt upon that Obligation: It lies not; it was in her a ≈øufficient Election and Waver; and that per≈øonal duty being a cho≈øe in action may well lie in jointure between Baron and Feme. Aliter of other per≈øons, Noy p. 149. Norton and Glover.

div.head: To Feme Covert.
div.p: IF Bond be made to a Feme Covert, and the Husband di≈øagree, the Obligor may plead n ‚Ä¢ e≈øt factum: For by his di≈øagreement the Obligation is no Deed, 10 Rep. 119. Whelpdale's Ca≈øe.

div.head: To Feme ≈øole.
div.p: THE Husband (after ≈øhe marries) mu≈øt join with her in the Suit; for if cau≈øe of Action ari≈øe before Coverture, though but Tre≈øpa≈øs, where damages are only recoverable, they mu≈øt joyn, 1 Keb. 440. Hardies Ca≈øe.

div.head: To Alien.
div.p: AN Alien born under the Obedience of an Enemy may have Debt on Bond for per≈øonal things, More n. 852. Walford and Mar≈øham.

div.head: To Corporations.
div.p: A Bi≈øhop, Par≈øon, Vicar, Ma≈øter of an Ho≈øpital, or other ≈øole Body politick cannot take a Recogni≈øance or Obligation, but only to their private, and not in their politick Capacity; and therefore no Chattel either in Action or Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øhall go in Succe≈ø≈øion, but the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of the Bi≈øhop, Par≈øon, &c. ≈øhall have them. This is regularly true, except a Cu≈øtom enable it to go in Succe≈ø≈øion, as in the Ca≈øe of the Chamberlain of London for Orphanage Mony, there it goes to the Succe≈ø≈øor. But in ca≈øe of a Corporation aggregate of many, as Dean and Chapter, Major and Comminalty, &c. it goes to the Succe≈ø≈øor, for they in Judgment of Law never die, 4 Rep. 65. Fullwood's Ca≈øe, Crook Eliz. p. 480. Bird and Wilsford.
A Man cannot bind him≈øelf to two ≈øeverally in a Bond; but a Man may covenant with two ≈øeverally, for that ≈øounds in damages, March. Rep. p. 103.

I ≈øhall in the next place come to the Dates of Obligations; and though it may be good without a Date, yet when it is dated, there is good Learning in our Books concerning the Juries finding, pleading, &c.

div.head: Date.
div.p: OBligation is good though it wants a Date, or hath a fal≈øe or impo≈ø≈øible Date, 2 Rep. Goddard's Ca≈øe.

Declaration ≈øur Obligation made ultimo die Augu≈øti anno, &c. upon Oyer of the Bond, it bore date 19 Aug. an. &c. The Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum. Jury found it his Deed. Judgment pro Quer': For the Count was not of the date, but of the making, and the Jury have found the Deed, Hob. p. 249. Thorp and Taylor.

One brought Debt, and declares the Defendant 4 Apr. 4 Eliz. made a Bond bearing date the ≈øame day and year, and the Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum, and its found that the Deed was delivered at another day before or after than the Plaintiff hath declared, yet Judgment ≈øhall be for the Plaintiff, for the date is not material, and the Defendant cannot be twice charged, 2 Rep. 5. Goddard's Ca≈øe.

If it be a mi≈øtaken date as to the King's Reign, or no King's Reign be in, or an impo≈ø≈øible date, or if it want a date, its good; and the party may
≈øurmi≈øe a date in the Declaration, and it is good, and the party ought to an≈øwer to the Deed and not to the Date, Yelv. 194. Dob≈øon and Keyes, Crook Jac. 261. id. Ca≈øe.
The Obligee cannot alledge the Delivery before the Date, yet the Jury may find the truth; and tho there wants in cujus rei Te≈øtimonium, yet its good, 2 Rep. Goddard's Ca≈øe.

Obligation bears date in France, it may be ≈øued in England, and it ≈øhall be alledged to be at I≈ølington in France, for its not traver≈øable whether there be ≈øuch a place as I≈ølington or not, Cook Lit. 261. b. Latch. p. 77. Ward's Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads quod factum prae ‚Ä¢ , was made and delivered ≈øans Date, and afterwards the Plaintiff put a Date thereto and ≈øo not his Deed, ill Plea upon demurrer; for the Defendant fir≈øt confe≈ø≈øeth it to be his deed by ≈øaying factum praed. and then concludes its not his deed, Crook Eliz.
„Äà‚óä„Äâ 800. Co≈øpes ver≈øus Turner.

In det ≈øur obligation fait 1 Novemb. 12 Jac. the Defendant pleads in Bart an Indenture of Defea≈øance, and ≈øhews not the date of it, but by the≈øe words ii≈ødem die & anno, referring this to the Plea of the Defendant (viz.) to the date of the Obligation alledged in the Count; the Bar is in≈øufficient for the uncertainty; for this ≈øhall be intended to bear date before the Obligation, for that every deed ≈øhall be taken mo≈øt ≈øtrongly again≈øt him that pleads it, Doct. pl. 29.

If a Man plead factum ≈øuum dat. primo Jan. & deliberat. quarto Jan. he ought to ≈øay primo deliberat. 4to die Jan. otherwi≈øe the word ≈øuum
imports that this was his deed the fir≈øt day of Januar. per Dyer 5 Eliz. 221. b.

I ≈øhall now, treat of the delivery of an Obligations being an E≈ø≈øential part or circum≈øtance required thereto, and what amounts to a good delivery to the party him≈øelf; and where the delivery of a deed is traver≈øable; and of the Delivery as an E≈øcrow; and how non e≈øt factum may be pleaded thereon.

div.head: Delivery.
div.p: THE Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum; The Jury found the Defendant cau≈øed the Obligation to be written and ≈øigned and ≈øealed it, and then laid it upon a Table, and the Plaintiff came and took it; per Curiam, this was not the Defendants Deed without other Circum≈øtances found by the Jury. Had the Obligor ca≈øt it on the Table and ≈øaid this will ≈øerve, and the other took it, it had been good, Crook Eliz. p. 122 1 Leon. n. 193. Chamberlain and Staunton.

If an Obligation be delivered to another to the u≈øe of the Obligee, and the ≈øame is tendred to him, and he refu≈øeth it, then the Delivery hath lo≈øt its force, and the Obligee can never after agree to it, and therefore the Obligor may ≈øay it is not his Deed, 5 Rep. p. 119. Whelpdales Ca≈øe.

Obligation dated 3 Sept. 1 Jac. Condition was that if the Defendant 4 Sept. 2 Jac. pay 100 l. to J.S. at ≈øuch a place and al≈øo ≈øave the Plaintiff harmle≈øs from any Suit &c. The Defendant pleads true it was, that he by his Obligation bearing date
3 Sept. 1 Jac. did become bound in 200 l. but further ≈øaid, that the ≈øaid Obligation was not delivered as the Defendants Deed until the 17th day of Sept. 2 Jac. and then fuit primo deliberat. Upon demurrer adjudged pro Quer. for the Bond mentioned in the Declaration is not an≈øwered, For the Plaintiff ≈øhews the Defendant was obliged to him by his Obligation bearing date the ≈øame day, &c. which is laid to be a perfect Bond the ≈øame day as the Plaintiff counteth; and then for the Defendant to come, and ≈øay that it was fir≈øt delivered 17 Sept. 2 Jac. which is a year after, is no good argument, but naught without taking a Traver≈øe, ab≈øque hoc that it was made the 3d of Sept. 1 Jac. 1 Brownl. p. 104. Green and Eden, Yelv. p. 138. id. Ca≈øe.

Debt on Bond 18 Car. 2. to pay 300 l. in ≈øix Months next after the Defendants Marriage. The Defendant pleads primo deliberat. 22 Car. 2. and that no Marriage was, Po≈øt 22 Car. 2. hucu≈øque: per Curiam though there can be no primo deliberat. before the day of the date, yet after it may, on Goddard's Ca≈øe, Coke. But Condition to pay Mony three Months after the precedent Marriage is impo≈ø≈øible, and ≈øo the Condition ≈øingle and good, 3 Keb. 332. Newland and Dendy.

In Debt ≈øur Bond which in truth was made to A. H. of London Merchant, to the u≈øe of A. H. his Factor beyond Sea now Plaintiff; the Defendant pleads that A.J. ≈øealed and delivered a Bond to A. H. of London Merchant, ab≈øque hoc that he ≈øealed to A. H. the Plaintiff; the Plaintiff demurs being but the general I≈ø≈øue, Not guilty; if Evidence be that its ≈øealed to the u≈øe of the Plaintiff,
it is all one as if ≈øealed and delivered to him, 3 Keb. 738. Hawtry and White.
If the Defendant plead the Delivery after the Condition impo≈ø≈øible to be performed, then is the Obligation become ≈øingle, Yelv. p. 138. Green and Eden.

The day of the Delivery of a Deed is not traver≈øable, unle≈øs it be upon a ≈øpecial Cau≈øe, as if one be bound in an Obligation dated primo die Octobris, to pay 10 l. at the Fea≈øt of All-Saints next after the delivery of the Obligation; and the Obligation is not delivered till the 2d day of November. In Debt upon this Bond the Plaintiff declaring of a Deed delivered primo Octob. the Defendant pleads that it was primo deliberat. 2 do Novemb. and that he tendred the 10 l. at the Fea≈øt of All-Saints then next en≈øuing, ab≈øque hoc that the Deed was delivered primo Octob. Jones Rep. 66. Bi≈øhop of Norwich ver≈øus Conrwallis.
If Evidence be that it was ≈øealed to the u≈øe of the Plaintiff, its all one as if ≈øealed and delivered to him, 3 Keb. 739. in Hawtry's Ca≈øe.

div.head: Delivery as in E≈øcrow.
div.p:
AN Obligation cannot be delivered as an E≈øcrow unto the Obligee him≈øelf, but it may be delivered to another to the u≈øe of the Obligee, as an E≈øcrow. For the delivery of it to the Obligee him≈øelf and his receiving it, makes it work as a Deed in the very in≈øtant of the delivery of it according to the effect of the Deed; but being delivered to another to the u≈øe of the Obligee, it cannot operate ≈øo, becau≈øe he is no party to the Deed,
nor can take any thing by it, and doth but only take it as an E≈øcrow, and as an In≈øtrument to deliver to the Obligee at ≈øuch time and in ≈øuch manner as the Obligor ≈øhall direct; and if he deliver it otherwi≈øe, the Obligor may plead non e≈øt factum, Stiles Pr. Reg. 222.

Therefore an Obligation may not be delivered as an E≈øcrow to the party him≈øelf upon Condition to be his Deed upon ≈øpecial delivery, for this is ab≈øolute, being made to the party him≈øelf; for delivery is ≈øufficient without ≈øpeaking words, and when the words are contrary to the Act, they are of no effect, Cook Lit. 36. a. 9 Rep. 136, 137. Thoroughgood's Ca≈øe. Vid. Hob. p. 246. Holford and Parker. More n. 836. Williams and Green.

Though the Plea, that he delivered it to the Plaintiff as an E≈øcrow to be his Deed upon performance of Condition; be not good; yet being pleaded and replyed to, and admitted for good, and I≈ø≈øue being joyned and found fal≈øe, the Verdict is good and Judgment well given, Vid. Crook Jac. 85. Blunden and Wood.

If the Deed be delivered to the party him≈øelf fir≈øt, as his Deed upon Condition, the Deed is ab≈øolute; but when it is fir≈øt delivered as an E≈øcrow though to the party him≈øelf, it is not his Deed till it be performed. One brings Obligation to me and prays me to deliver it as my Deed, and I ≈øay, do ≈øuch a thing and take it as my Deed, otherwi≈øe not: It is clear, it is not my Deed until the thing performed; here the Condition is precedent, ≈øo as it was not his Deed until it was performed; and therefore a Conditional Delivery may be averred ≈øans writing; but if once delivered as his
Deed, it cannot afterwards be defeated, it the Condition be not in writing, Quaer. Crook Eliz. 835. Hawk≈øland ver≈øus Gatchel, contra. Crook El. p. 884. Williams and Green.

The Defendant pleads the Writing was his, and delivered to one W. as a Schedule until certain Conditions performed, and then to deliver it to the Plaintiff ut ≈øcriptum, and ≈øaith not ut factum; yet per Curiam all is one in Con≈øtruction of Law, 2 Keb. 690, 733. Twiford and Barnard.

The Defendant pleads it was delivered as an E≈øcrow on future Condition, and ≈øo non e≈øt factum, & hoc paratus e≈øt verificare. The Plaintiff demurrs ≈øpecially quia minus apte conclu≈øit. Per Curiam, ≈øic non e≈øt factum is a full I≈ø≈øue, and the hoc paratus is ill, Judment pro Quer. 2 Keb. 805. Go≈ølin and Broad, id. p. 836. Edwards and Web.

Of later time it is adjudged that he mu≈øt conclude to the Country. Et i≈ø≈øint nient ≈øon fait, & de hoc ponit, &c. 3 Keb. 26, 30. Forth and Fletcher, Edwards and Webb, ib. p. 142. Manning & Bucknal, contra.
Per Hale, An E≈øcrow may be given in Evidence on non e≈øt factum, as well as Su≈øpen≈øion on nil debet, in Manning and Bucknal's Ca≈øe, 3 Keb. 142.
If a Man be obliged to perform things in ≈øuch a Deed, it is no Plea to ≈øay, he delivered this as an E≈øcrow, &c. & i≈ø≈øint non e≈øt factum, 1 Rol. Rep. per Cook 84. in Fletcher and Tarrer's Ca≈øe.

div.head: Sealing.
div.p: THE Plaintiff declares, that the Defendant per ≈øcriptum ≈øuum obligatorium conce≈ø≈øit ≈øe teneri, &c. without ≈øaying, ≈øigillo ≈øuo figillat. and good in the Common Bench, for there the Pre≈øidents are ≈øo. Delivery is never alledged, ≈øo neither is it nece≈ø≈øary to alledge the Sealing. When he ≈øaith per Scriptum ≈øuum obligatorium, all nece≈ø≈øary Circum≈øtances are intended to concur, Crook Eliz. p. 738. Pen≈øon and Hodges.

div.head: Witne≈ø≈øes.
div.p: ONE ought not to be allowed to be a Witne≈øs to prove an Obligation or other Deed, which he takes in the name of another: For if he might be ≈øo admitted, this is on the matter to ≈øuffer him to prove a Deed or Bond made to him≈øelf, Stiles Pract. Reg. 221.

Obligations are either
Single, called a Bill.
Joynt.
Joynt or Several.

div.head: Bill.
div.p: A Bill penal is called a ≈øingle Bond; and a Bill may be without a penalty.
In Debt on Obligation (no Oyer being demanded) it is intented a ≈øingle Bill.

As to the Frame of the Bill, and by what Words and in what Form it ≈øhall be good, I have ≈øhewed
before, in Title, The Frame of Obligations. Now I ≈øhall ≈øet down ≈øome Ca≈øes as to Declarations and Pleadings on Bills.
A Bill Obligatory written in the Plaintiffs Book, and the Defendants Hand and Seal to it is good, Crook Eliz. p. 613. Fox and Wright.

I acknowledge my ≈øelf to owe, and be endebted to J. F. and W. S. in the ≈øum of 91 l. 1 s. 8 d. to be paid the fir≈øt of Novemb. following; for which payment to be made I bind my ≈øelf to J. S. in 100 l. Qu. Whether F. ought to bring the Action for the 100 l. or both of them for the 91 l. 12 s. 8 d. Crook Jac. 291. Foxal and Sands ver≈øus Corderoy.

A Bill was made in this manner: Memorandum, That I Will. Jethro do owe and am indebted to Edmond Hamond in the Sum of Ten Pounds for the payment whereof I bind my ≈øelf &c. In witne≈øs; and after the (In Witne≈øs) it was thus ≈øub≈øcribed, Memorandum, That the ≈øaid Will. Jethro be not compelled to pay the ≈øaid 10 l. until he recovers 30 l. upon an Obligation again≈øt A. B. &c. And in the Count no mention was made of this Sub≈øcription; but this appears when the Defendant prays Oyer of the Bill, the which was then entred verbatim on Record: Upon which the Defendant demurs, becau≈øe it is not mentioned in the Count, it being a Condition precedent; aliter of a Condition ≈øub≈øequent. But per Curiam, this which is after (in witne≈øs) is not part of the Deed, but may be a Condition or Defea≈øance, and ≈øo need not be contained in the Count; but then the Defendant ought to have pleaded ≈øo, and not demurred; for this makes the Bill conditional;
Judgment pro Quer. 2 Brownl. 97. Hamond and Jethro. Bill of 68 l. with Covenant to pay it when ≈øuch Bills be ≈øtated, &c. the Covenant being in the ≈øame Deed works as a Defea≈øance, 2 Keb. 624. Holday and Otway.

Debt for 40 l. upon a Bill Obligatory, and declares that the Defendant by his Bill dated, &c. confe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf to be indebted to the Plaintiff in 20 l. ≈øolvend. at Michaelmas next following, ad quam quidem ≈øolutionem, he bound him≈øelf in 40 l. and for Non-payment of the 40 l. the Action brought: The Declaration is ill, becau≈øe it is not therein alledged that the 20 l. was not paid at the day; for if otherwi≈øe, the 40 l. was not due; for it is not an Obligation with a Condition, Crook M. 1 Car. 515. Bains and Brighton, 1 Rolls Abr. 414. M. 14 Car. Me≈øme Ca≈øe, Danes and Brett. But in Stiles p. 23 Car. B. R. Debt on a Bill, Penal and Verdict pro Quer. It was moved in Arre≈øt of Judgment, that the Plaintiff ≈øhewed not, that the Defendant did not pay the Mony at the day limited in the Bill, but only ≈øaith, non ≈øolvit, &c. 2. He declares the Defendant was bound to pay ≈øuch a Sum legalis monetae, and doth not ≈øay Angliae, the Court over-ruled both Exceptions, and the Plaintiff had Judgment.

Bill of 70 l. to be paid on demand; it is a duty pre≈øently, and there needs no actual demand, Cro. Eliz. p. 548. Cap and Lanca≈øter. If the Plaintiff declares generally, that he often reque≈øted, &c. and the Defendant demur to the Declaration, per Cur. he ought to plead; yet if the Defendant had demanded Oyer of the Bill, and upon that have demurred, it had been a good demurrer, becau≈øe
a ≈øpecial demand was in the Bill, and no ≈øpecial demand alledged in the Declaration, 1 Brownl. Rep. 56. On a collateral promi≈øe to pay mony on demand, there mu≈øt be a ≈øpecial demand; but between the Parties it is a debt, and ≈øufficiently demanded by the Action. Aliter, if the Mony be to be paid to a third per≈øon, or where there is a penalty, 3 Keb. 176. A≈øhenden's Ca≈øe.

Debt on Bill to pay 50 l. on demand; and on Non-payment the Defendant to pay an 100 l. Action is brought for the 100 l. the Defendant pleads there was no demand; the Plaintiff demurs, per Cur. the Action is a demand for the 50 l. but no cau≈øe to forfeit the 100 l. the Defendant ≈øhould plead tender of the 50 l. & uncore pri≈øt. But where the Condition of an Obligation is to pay on demand, that is a di≈øtinct deed from the Bond, and there is no Title to the Forfeiture without demand. But the debt here of 50 l. is not lo≈øt by not demanding; therefore in Bar the Defendant mu≈øt ≈øay uncore pri≈øt. Judgment pro Quer. 3 Keb. p. 577. Ram≈øey and Rutter.

Debt on a Bill penal with the≈øe words, To be paid as I pay my other Creditors. The Plaintiff declares generally, that he was indebted to him in 5 l. ≈øolvend. upon Reque≈øt. The Defendant demands Oyer of the Bill, and it was entred in haec verba, and pleads an in≈øufficient matter; upon which it was demurred. And this Exception was to the declaration for variance from the Bill, for per Cur. he ought to declare ≈øpecially according to the Bill. Judgment for the Defendant, Crook El. 256. Bright and Metcalfe.

The Defendant demands Oyer of the Bill, by which
it appears the Defendant and two others are bound. The Defendant demurs, per Cur. pro Quer. The Defendant ought to have pleaded two others ≈øealed the Bill Obligatory, who are in full life, Jones p. 303. Vid. Obligation.

In Debt ≈øur ≈øingle Bill of 50 l. the Defendant after imparlance pleaded that after the la≈øt continuance he had paid the Plaintiff 5 l. parcel of the 50 l. and demanded Judgment of the Bill (petit quod billa ca≈ø≈øetur) the Plaintiff demurs. It is an in≈øufficient Plea, becau≈øe the Defendant did not alledge he had an acquittance which he ought to produce, if he had an acquittance he might have pleaded in Bar or Abatement; but this Plea is not peremptory becau≈øe it concludes in Abatement, & re≈øpondeas ou≈øter awarded, Allen 63. Loder and Hamp≈øhire. Allen 65. Beaton and Forre≈øt. Stiles 212. Hollingworth. 15 H. 7.10.

Payment without Acquittance is no Plea to a ≈øingle Bill, Crook Eliz. 157. And yet if ≈øuch Payment be pleaded upon a Bill, it being admitted and tryed again≈øt him who pleaded it, the tryal is good, and Judgment ≈øhall be given thereupon, as in Blunden and Wood's Ca≈øe, Crook Jac. 85. For though Payment without Acquittance be no Plea, and I≈ø≈øue is joined upon a thing not material (for if the Defendant hath paid the Sum without Acquittance, yet the ≈øingle Bill doth remain in force) But in as much as there was an I≈ø≈øue joyned upon an affirmative and a negative, which is found pro Quer. it is expre≈øly helped by the Stat. 32 H. 8. and 18 Eliz. Judgment pro Quer. 5 Rep. 43. Chamberlain and Nichol's Ca≈øe. The Plaintiff might have demurred upon the Plea, and good,
Crook Eliz. 455. me≈øme Ca≈øe, and More n. 908. As in Debt the Defendant demands Oyer, which was to pay Mony 31 Sept. the Defendant pleads ≈øolvit ad diem; and upon I≈ø≈øue joyned, found for the Plaintiff. The Condition being impo≈ø≈øible the Obligation is pre≈øently due, and it was an I≈ø≈øue upon an in≈øufficient Bar, which being found for the Plaintiff is aided by the Stat. Jones p. 140. Jiggon and Purchas.

Debt upon a Bill, whereby the Defendant acknowledged he had received 7 l. of the Plaintiff ad emendum a pair of Bellows, &c. to the u≈øe of the Plaintiff, and avers that he had not bought the things nor paid the Mony. The Plaintiff in this Ca≈øe may have Debt or Account, Cro. Eliz. p. 644. Earl of Lincoln ver≈øus Topcliff.

list.item: Joynt and Several.

div.head: By what Words or when an Obligation may be ≈øaid to be Joynt or Several: Actions and Declarations thereon.
div.p:
FOUR are bound in an Obligation by the≈øe words (& utrum
que no≈øtrum) the Obligee may charge any of the≈øe ≈øeverally. But if he will have a joint Action of Debt again≈øt two of the four, the Writ ≈øhall abate; for if the Plaintiff will charge them joyntly, the other two which are not named ≈øhall be charged al≈øo with them joyntly by the ≈øame Deed, 10 H. 7.16. 34 E. 3. Dyer 129.
Two are bound per joint Words, and every of them by him≈øelf puts his Seal to the Deed, this ≈øhall not make the Obligation ≈øeveral, 10 H. 7.16.
Two bind them≈øelves vel alter eorum, this makes the Obligation joint or ≈øeveral, 7 H. 4l 6. b.
Two bind them≈øelves & quemlibet no≈øtrum, this is joint or ≈øeveral, 2 Rolls Abr. 148.

Two bind them≈øelves vel utrum
que no≈øtrum, this is joint or ≈øeveral, for this word (vel) makes it ≈øeveral at Election, 2 Rolls Abr. 148. Hanker≈øon, and Sir Tho. Sandelon me≈øme Ca≈øe, vide 1 Brownl. Rep. p. 121. Cro. Jac. 322. ‚Ä¢
Bul≈øt. 70.

Three are bound jointly and ≈øeverally in one Bond; the Obligee brought Debt again≈øt two, this he cannot do, but he may have one Precipe again≈øt the Three, or ≈øeveral Precipes again≈øt every one, 27 H. 8.6. & ≈øingulos no≈øtrum, 1 Brownl. 121. is joint or ≈øeveral.

Three were bound in a Bond by the≈øe words Obligamus nos & quemlibet no≈øtrum conjunctim. Its a joint Bond and not ≈øeveral, for the word quemlibet is expounded by the word con≈øunctim, 3 Leon. p. 206. Wigmore and Wells, More p. 390.

Uter
que recognovit makes a joint Bail Bond, or ≈øeveral, at election, Cro. Jac. p. 45. Hargrave and Rogers.

Noverint univer≈øi nos I. B. A. K. & H. F. teneri &c. ad quam quidem ≈øolutionem &c. Obligamus nos Haeredes Executores & Admini≈øtratores no≈øtros ≈øigillis no≈øtris ≈øigi ‚Ä¢ at. Plaintiff declares again≈øt the Defendant ≈øo ‚Ä¢ e; Defendant demurs upon
Oyer, becau≈øe it appears upon Oyer that they are joint. Per Cur. The two others are named, yet it appears not that they put their Seals to it, and ≈øo the Obligation is ≈øingle; but if the truth were that the other two had ≈øealed as well as the Defendant, then the Defendant if he would take advantage of this, ought not to have demurred upon the Oyer, but he ought to have pleaded in Abatement, that the other two Per≈øons ≈øealed the Obligation, who are yet in full Life, and ≈øo pray Iudgment of the Bill, 1 Sanders Trin. 21 Car. 2. fol. 271. Cabel and Vaughan.

Though ≈øundry Per≈øons may bind them≈øelves, & quemlibet eorum, and ≈øo the Obligation ≈øhall be joint or ≈øeveral at the election of the Obligee, yet a Man cannot bind him≈øelf to three, and to each of them to make it joint or ≈øeveral at the election of ≈øeveral Per≈øons for one and the ≈øame cau≈øe, for the Court ≈øhall be in doubt for which of them to give Judgment, which the Law will not ≈øuffer, 5 Rep. p. 18. b.

If Merchants in a Charter-Party covenant with the Owners, ≈øeparatim, that one Merchant ≈øhall pay 3 l. another 3 l. and ≈øo of the re≈øt, the words are conveniunt ≈øeporatim, and at the end there is ≈øuch a Clau≈øe, Et ad performation omnium & ≈øingular' convention' ex parte praedict' Mercator' perimplend' quolibet Mercator praedict' ≈øeparatim obligat ≈øeip≈øum praefato Majori & pro Proprietariis en double le fraight, the Covenant is ≈øeveral, and ≈øo is the la≈øt part (videlicet) the Obligation, 5 Rep. Mathew≈øons Ca≈øe, 2 Rolls Abr. 149.

In an Indenture there are three of the one part, and two of the other part, in which the two
covenant jointly and ≈øeverally to do a certain thing, and the third covenants jointly and ≈øeverally with the ≈øaid two, after the performance of the ≈øaid thing by the two, to pay to the ≈øaid two a certain Sum for each particular, &c. and after en≈øue the≈øe general words, Pro vera & reali performatione omnium articulorum & agreamentorum praedictorum alternatim utra
que partium praedictarum obligavit ≈øe Haeredes Executores, &c. in & ≈øubter penalitatem 60 l. Sterlingorum. This Covenant is joint and not ≈øeveral, and an Action on the la≈øt Clau≈øe cannot be brought again≈øt one of the ≈øaid three only, 2 Rolls Abr. 149.
If an Obligation be writ in the Name of two, joint and ≈øeveral, and they ≈øeverally deliver the Obligation at ≈øeveral times and places, this is yet joint and ≈øeveral, 8 H. 6.31.

Debt on joint Obligation ver≈ø. Survivor, Defendant pleads one of the Obligors died, and the Plaintiff afterwards relea≈øed to his Executor, the Relea≈øe is void, alit; had the Obligation been joint and ≈øeveral, 1 Keble 936. Scot and Littleton.

Joint Bond by three, and Count General, the Jointure appearing upon Oyer demanded, the Court will intend they are dead, or not ≈øealed; had the Declaration been on a joint Bond, the Plaintiff mu≈øt aver the death of the others, or that they never had ≈øealed, 1 Keble 936. Tr. 17 Car. 2. Osborn and Cro≈øsland, vide plus Doct. Placit. 268.
Two are bound jointly, and one is only ≈øued, he may plead this matter in abatement of the Writ; but he may not plead non e≈øt factum, Co. L. 283.

Two are jointly bound in an Obligation, Action is brought again≈øt one of them only; upon this the Defendant cannot demur, but may plead in Abatement, Siderfin 2.12. And if one of the Obligors die, the Obligee in his Action of Debt again≈øt the other that ≈øurvives, mu≈øt ≈øet forth in his Declaration that the other is dead.

Four were bound conjunctim & divi≈øim to B. B. had Judgment again≈øt them, and one of them dies, B. ≈øues forth a Sci. Fac' again≈øt the four, its ill, Stiles, Trin. 23 Car. p. 50. Blackwell and A≈øhton.

When two are jointly bound in an Obligation, though none of them is bound by him≈øelf, yet none of them ≈øhall plead non e≈øt factum, but he may plead in Abatement of the Writ, for they had ≈øealed and delivered it, and every of them is bound in the entire; therefore if they two are ≈øued, and one appears, and the other makes default, and by Proce≈øs of Law he is Outlawed, he which appeared ≈øhall be charged with the whole, 5 Rep. 119. Whelpdales Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads he was bound ≈øimul cum R. G. to whom the Plaintiff had relea≈øed all Actions the ≈øaid fir≈øt day of May, (that being the date in the Declaration.) the Plaintiff by Replication ≈øhewed, that after the Obligation ≈øealed by R. G. he relea≈øed to him, and after, i. e. the ≈øame day the Plaintiff ≈øealed the Bond, ab≈ø
que hoc quod ≈øimul tenetur cum R. G. The Defendant demurs; this Relea≈øe doth not di≈øcharge the Defendant, and per Cur. the Traver≈øe is ill, becau≈øe R. G. was bound with the Defendant; but becau≈øe the Defendant had not taken advantage of it to ≈øhew it on
the Demurrer, but confe≈øs it; Judgment pro quer' Cro. Eliz. p. 161. Mannings and Town≈øend.

Two brought Debt on Bond, the Defendant pleads that the Obligation was made to them, and to one Bellamy, and that they three had an Action of Debt depending again≈øt him; Judgment ≈øi Actio and demur: Adjudged pro quer. becau≈øe an Obligation made to two, on which they counted, cannot be intended an Obligation made to three; and if it be a Plea, its in Abatement of the Bill, Cro. Eliz. p. 202. I≈øan and Hichcock.

Debt on Bond by three, brought again≈øt one without ≈øhewing the other two are dead, the Plaintiff ought to ≈øhew the others were dead; but in Whel ‚Ä¢ dales Ca≈øe this advantage was waved on non e≈øt factum pleaded; al≈øo the Obligation being Obligamus nos, it ≈øhall not be intended the others did not ≈øeal, but if they had not, the Count ≈øhould have one Writing by three, whereof two did not ≈øeal, 1 Keb. fol. 840. Osborn again≈øt Cawthorns Executors.

list.head: Conditions of Obligations.
list.item: 1. The Nature of ≈øuch a Condition.
2. The di≈øtinct re≈øpects or differences thereof in our Law.
3. What ≈øhall be ≈øaid a good Condition of an Obligation, and what not.
4. The Expo≈øition of Conditions, or when a Condition ≈øhall be ≈øaid to be performed, and when not.
5. How a Condition and Obligation may be di≈øcharged, and gone by matter ex po≈øt facto.

div.head: The Nature of a Condition.
div.p: WHen an Obligation is clogged with a Condition, its called a Bond conditional or double Bond; when it is in another Deed or In≈øtrument, its called a Defea≈øance; but it is commonly ≈øub≈øcribed under the Obligation, or included within the Body of it, or indor≈øed upon the back of it; and if the Condition be performed, the Penalty is ≈øaved, if not, the Penalty is forfeit.

The Condition is always for the benefit of the Obligor, 1 Sanders 66. Butler and Wig, and ≈øhall be con≈øtrued favourably for his advantage: Cro. El. p. 396. Greninghams Ca≈øe, 1 Leon. p. 142. Condition to perform an Award, the Arbitrator made Award 24 March, that the Defendant ≈øhould pay to the Plaintiff 10 l. at Michaelma≈øs next; the Defendant pleaded the Plaintiffs Relea≈øe of all Actions and Demands made the 10th of April: Per Cur. the Relea≈øe is no bar to the Plaintiffs Action; difference is, where Obligation is entred for payment of Mony at a day to come, there its a Debt pre≈øently, and may be di≈øcharged by ≈øuch Relea≈øe before the day of payment; but not ≈øo in ca≈øe of Annuity, Rent and an Action of Debt for non performance of Award to pay Mony at a day to come, Cro. Jac. p. 300. Tyman and Bridges.

list.head: The ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Conditions.
list.item:
Some are in the Affirmative, to
do an Act,
≈øuffer an Act.
Some in the Negative.

div.p: Some are to pay Mony, and ≈øome are to do a collateral Act. Debt on Obligation to ≈øtand to the Award of J. S. the Defendant pleads no Award. Plaintiff replies, and ≈øhews the Award, but a≈ø≈øigns no Breach, its ills, for the Obligation is not for any Debt, but this is guided by the Condition, which goes in performance of a collateral thing, (viz.) of an Award, Yelv. fol. 152, 153. Barret and Fletcher, Cro. Jac. 220.

Some Conditions are Precedent and executed, and ≈øome are Sub≈øequent and executory. If A. acknowledge by his Bill obligatory, that he owes to B. 20 s. and for the payment of this at a day, he binds him≈øelf in 40 s. by the ≈øame Bill, in debt upon this Bill for 40 s. he ought to aver that A. had not paid the 20 s. otherwi≈øe its not good, 1 Rolls Abr. 414. Danes and Bret.

An Award is made by Arbitrators between A. and B. that A. ≈øhall pay 10 l. to B. and in con≈øideratione inde B. ≈øhall be bound in an Obligation to A. to relea≈øe all his Right in certain Land, &c. In this Ca≈øe B. is to be bound in the Obligation, though A. had not paid the 10 l. for it is not a Condition precedent; and there is a mutual remedy of each Party, if the Award be not performed, 1 Rolls Abr. 415. Vivian and Shipping.

If the Condition of an Obligation be in ≈øuch manner, The Condition of this Obligation is ≈øuch, That if the above bounden A. B. do di≈øcharge the Obligee of ≈øuch Recognizance, &c. And whereas al≈øo the above bounden A. B. hath agreed to free and di≈øcharge the ≈øaid Obligee from two ≈øeveral Obligations, &c. Now the Condition of this Obligation is ≈øuch, That if the ≈øaid A. B. do ≈øave and keep harmle≈øs the Obligee, of and from the ≈øaid two ≈øeveral Obligations, then this pre≈øent Obligation to be void; the la≈øt words do not re≈øtrain the Condition to the la≈øt part only (to wit) of the two Obligations, but do extend to the Recognizance, per the fir≈øt words, The Condition of this Obligation is ≈øuch, and per the word (al≈øo) in the la≈øt Clau≈øe, 1 Rolls Abr. 409. Ingoldsby and Steward.
For the Matter and Sub≈øtance of the Condition.

div.head: What Conditions are good, and what not.
div.p: A Condition to do any lawful or po≈ø≈øible thing, is good; as to make a Relea≈øe, perform Covenants, not to play at Cards and Dice, not to be Surety, &c.

But when the matter or thing to be done by the Condition is unlawful or impo≈ø≈øible, or the Condition it ≈øelf is repugnant, in≈øen≈øible or uncertain; the Condition is void, and in ≈øome Ca≈øes the Obligation al≈øo.

div.head: Conditions again≈øt Law are void.
div.p: Again≈øt the Law of God, of Nature; to do a thing that is malum in ‚Ä¢ ≈øe; as to kill a Man, or do any other Felony, &c. in ≈øuch Ca≈øes the Condition and Obligation are both void, Co. Lit. 206.

Conditions again≈øt
Common Law.
Statute Law.

Note, This difference between a Bond made void by Common Law, and a Bond made void by Statute Law. If a Bond be made void by Statute Law, its void in the whole; as upon the Statute 23 H. 6. If a Sheriff take a Bond for a thing again≈øt that Law, and al≈øo for a due Debt, the whole Bond is void; for the Letter of the Statute is ≈øo, 2 Rolls Rep. 116. But the Common Law doth divide, and having made void that that is again≈øt Law, lets the re≈øt ≈øtand; Carters Rep. fol. 230. in Pear≈øon and Humes Ca≈øe. A Bond to perform Covenants, one is void, and the other good; the Bond is good for tho≈øe that are agreeable to Law; as in Sir Daniel Nortons Ca≈øe, Hob. p. 14. Cro. Eliz. p. 529. 2 Ander≈øon 116. Lee and Cole≈øhill. 3 Rep. 82, 83. Lee and Cole≈øhill cited in Twines Ca≈øe.
If the Condition be to do a thing contrary to Law, the Obligation is void, 2 H. 4.9. Co. Lit. 206. b.
But here is another Diver≈øity.

A Condition to a do a thing again≈øt the Law of God, of Nature, a malum in ≈øe, or again≈øt Law and Ju≈øtice; in ≈øuch Ca≈øes the Obligation and Condition are both void; as for unlawful Maintenance, for a Sheriff not to execute Proce≈øs, and the like.

But when the thing to be done, or not to be done by the Condition, is not malum in ≈øe, but again≈øt ≈øome Ground of the Law; as that a Man ≈øhall make a Feoffment to his Wife, or is but malum prohibitum only; as that a Man ≈øhall erect a College contrary to the Statute of 31 Eliz. or a Man is bound to alien certain Lands to a Religious Hou≈øe, or repugnant to the E≈øtate, as Feoffee of Land ≈øhall not alien or take the Profits, or that Tenant in Tail ≈øhall not ≈øuffer a Recovery, &c. In the≈øe Ca≈øes the Conditions are only void, and the Obligations remain ≈øingle, and yet Equity will relieve again≈øt them; yet if a Feoffment be made of Land on Condition to kill J. S. the Condition is void, but the Feoffment is good; for the ≈øtate of the Land is ≈øetled, and executed in the Feoffee, and cannot be taken back but by the performance of the Condition which is void.

If a Man make a Feoffment in Fee, on Condition that he ≈øhall not alien, this Condition is repugnant, and again≈øt Law, and the ≈øtate of the Feoffee ab≈øolute; but if the Feoffee be bound in a Bond, that the Feoffee or his Heirs ≈øhall not alien, or take the profits, this is good; for he may notwith≈øtanding alien, or take the profits, if he will forfeit his Bond, Co. Lit. fol. 206. a. b.

A Man is bound to do a thing unlawful at pre≈øent, which in time may be made lawful; as a Feoffment of a Strangers Lands, or of the Lands of an Alien, &c. in the≈øe Ca≈øes he is bound to do it, and at his peril he mu≈øt obtain Power to do them, Lit. Rep. 86.

Condition was, That if the Defendant ≈øhall procure one J. S. to make rea≈øonable Recompence to the Plaintiff, for certain Bea≈øts which he wrongfully took from the Plaintiff, that then, &c. the Defendant ≈øaith de facto J. S. had ≈øtollen the Bea≈øts, and was indicted, and ≈øo the Condition being again≈øt Law, the Obligation was void: Per Cur. where the Condition ≈øhall be ≈øaid again≈øt Law, and therefore the Obligation void, the ≈øame ought to be intended where the Condition is expre≈øly again≈øt the Law in expre≈øs words, and not for Matter out of the Condition, as it is here; Judgment pro quer. 1 Leon. Ca≈øe 99. Brook and King.

div.head: Conditions again≈øt Common Law.
div.p: Be≈øides what hath been ≈øaid before in general, take ≈øome few Ca≈øes of Conditions again≈øt Common Law.

div.head: Maintenance.
div.p: A Condition to maintain any Suit unlawfully, though no Act be done; for if it be unlawful to be done, the Bond is void.

The Condition is, If J. S. the principal, and J. H. and J. M. do pay, &c. all ≈øuch Sums which are due, and ≈øhall be due in ≈øuch Suits‚ñ™
„Äà2 pages missing„Äâ

The Under-Sheriff makes a Bond to the High-Sheriff, that he ≈øhall not return Venire Fac. not intermeddle with Executions until he be acquainted, it is naught and again≈øt Law, 1 Brownl. Rep. 64, 65. Hobart p. 14. Norton and Sims. That the Under-Sheriff ≈øhall not execute any Proce≈øs of Execution without ≈øpecial Warrant and A≈ø≈øent of the Sheriff, the Bond is void, 2 Brownl. Rep. p. 280 Chamberlain and Gold≈ømith. 1 Rolls Abridg. p. 417. Norton and Sims.
A Bond to ≈øave J.S. harmle≈øs from ≈øuch a ‚Ä¢ Appeal of Robbery as B. had again≈øt him, is void, 18 E. 4.28.
A Condition to renounce an Admini≈øtration is good, 25 E. 4.30.

A Condition that he ≈øhould not mole≈øt or hurt the Obligee in his Lands or Goods ratione alicu ‚Ä¢ rei cuju≈øcunque, it ≈øhall be intended he ≈øhall not hurt tortiou≈øly; but not to re≈øtrain him from pro≈øecuting the Obligee for Felony, or other ju≈øt cau≈øe, and ≈øo not again≈øt Law, Crook Eliz. fo. 705. Dol≈øon and Crew.
Conditions again≈øt Statute-Law.

div.head: Again≈øt the Stat. 32 H. 8. Of Leu≈øes made is Aliens.
div.p:
DEbt upon Bond to perform Covenants in an Indenture, which was to pay Rent. The Defendant pleads Stat. 32 H. 8. which maltes Lea≈øes to Alien Artificers void, and ≈øaith that the Defendant was an Alien born at Paris, and av ‚Ä¢ s the three points of the Statute. 1. That the
Hou≈øe was a Man≈øion Hou≈øe at the time. 2. That ‚Ä¢ e, (viz.) the Defendant was an Alien. 3. That ‚Ä¢ e was an Artificer. The Plaintiff replies, the Defendant was an Alien Artificer; demurr. Per Cur. the Replication not double; but becau≈øe he ‚Ä¢ ad not ≈øaid the place where he was born in En
‚Ä¢ land, it was ill, Siderfin p. 357. Freeman and King. The Form of the Plea, Vid. 1 Saunders 5. Jevens
‚Ä¢ nd Harwich, Vid. Keble.

div.head: Again≈øt Stat. 5 & 6 E. 6. c. 16. Of buying of Offices.
div.p: THE Office of Armourer is within that Statute, Stiles Rep. f. 29. Hill and Farmer.

The Office of Secretary of Barbadoes, which is ‚Ä¢ verred to be an Office of Ju≈øtice, and being by „Äà‚óä„Äâ Grant by Patent under the Great Seal, is within the Statute; ≈øo if it were an Office in the Admi
‚Ä¢ alty or Spiritual Court, 3 Keb. p. 26. Dawes and Painter.

A Condition to perform Articles. That he before Ea≈øter Term next following, at the Reque≈øt of the Plaintiff, would ≈øurrender to the Plaintiff his Letters Patents of the Steward≈øhip of Bromes Grove, to the intent that he might renew the ≈øaid Letters Patents in his own name. Adjudged that the Steward≈øhip of a Court-Leet is within the Statute 5 E. 6. and ≈øo an Agreement to Surrender, 1 Brownl. Rep. 71. William≈øon and Barn≈øley.

Debt ≈øur Bond. Cole≈øhil the Te≈øtator had the Office of Surveyor of Cu≈øtoms by Letters Patents to him and his Deputies; and by Indenture between him and Smith for 600 l. paid and 100 l.
per annum to be paid during the Life of Cole≈øhil makes Deputation of the ≈øaid Office to Smith, and Cole≈øhil covenants with Smith that if Cole≈øhil die before him, that then his Executors ≈øhall repay to him 300 l. and Cole≈øhil was bound to Smith for performance: Per Cur. the Bond was void, 2 Ander≈øon p. 55, 107. Lee and Cole≈øhil, cited in Twine's Ca≈øe. 3 Rep. 82, 83.

The Bayliff of the Savoy is an Office in fee; he deputed Ellis for 30 years, who for Rent re≈øerved ≈øub≈øtituted the Defendant, who replyed this matter. This is not within the Statute, or if it be, its excepted by the Provi≈øo. The Franchi≈øe it ≈øelf being in Fee, Priviledge doth protect all inferious Grants; as the Mar≈øhal may grant Under-Mar≈øhal, &c. for Precepts. The accounting for the Profits will be no ≈øelling within the Statute; and the making a Re≈øervation is no more. And the King may grant this Office of Bailiff, and there is 40 l. per annum re≈øerved by the King. And the Bailiffwick of Southwark is granted for Mony, 1500 l. was paid for it: And the Bailywick of We≈øtmin≈øter is ≈øold re≈øerving Rent, 3 Keb. 659. Ellis and Nel≈øon. The Statute 27 H. 8. c. 24. is indeed a general Statute, but the King is out of that Statute, as well as out of 23 H. 6. c. 10.3 Keble 679.

The Plaintiff made the Defendant Deputy-Searcher, and allows him one half of the Profits, re≈øerving the other to him≈øelf, good: Had it been to render a Rent or pay a ≈øum in gro≈øs, it were within the Statute; but Sheriffs, Chyrogra≈øs and mo≈øt other Officers that make Deputies, do it to account of Fees, 3 Keb. 717, 718. Wel≈øh and Baden.

div.head: Against Stat. 16 Car. 2. cap. 7. Of Gaming.
div.p: A Bond upon Articles of an Hor≈øe-race for 300 l. It was to run four heats, on reque≈øt for 40 l. and again the ≈øame day for 100 l. The Action is only for the 100 l. The Bond is forfeited, though there is not above 100 l. lo≈øt at any one time. As a Bond to run three ≈øeveral days, it is forfeited on the fir≈øt lo≈øs, and though no more be played or lo≈øt, yet the Bond is void or any other Security that is entire; for it is lookt upon according to the fir≈øt contract, and not to the contingent, whether more or fewer times be played. Al≈øo a Bond of 1000 l. to pay all ≈øuch Mony as is lo≈øt by Gaming at ≈øuch a time, though only an 100 l. be lo≈øt; this Bond is within the Statute, 3 Keb. Hill. 25 & 26 Car. 2. p. 254, 259. Edgbury and Ro≈øindale. So where it is to game at ≈øeveral days, and the one day the Plaintiff wins of the Defendant 100 l. and the other the Defendant wins of the Plaintiff 100 l. this is void, ibid.

If A. lo≈øeth to the Plaintiff 90 l. at Mo≈øt at three throws, and at the ≈øame time he lo≈øt to B. at Cards 30 l. and to C. at Bet 60 l. more, and gives Bond, the Bond is void, though the≈øe are not Parties together, or in Tru≈øt one for another. It is not material to whom the party comes indebted; for the Statute is that the party ≈øhould not lo≈øe more than an 100 l. at one time or meeting upon Ticket, and per Cur. all plaid for on Ticket is void, 3 Keb. 671. Hud≈øon and Malins.

There was lo≈øt at play a Ring of 20 l. value which was paid, and there was al≈øo lo≈øt at play at
the ≈øame time 100 l. upon Credit, for which Bond was given, this 100 l. is not within the Statute; and Judgment for the Plaintiff, Siderfin p. 394. Danvers and Thi≈øtlethwait, 2 Keb. 369, 389.451. If 500 l. be paid down, and not above 100 l. be≈øides upon Credit, it is not within this Law. Per Keeling and Twi≈øden, If one lo≈øeth a 1000 l. pre≈øently, and lo≈øeth an 100 l. in Rings pre≈øent, yet he may lo≈øe 100 l. on Ticket, 2 Keb. id. Ca≈øe.

div.head: Again≈øt Stat. 31 Eliz. cap. 6. Concerning Simon ‚Ä¢ , and what is not.
div.p: THE Patron takes an Obligation of the Clerk (which he pre≈øented) that he ≈øhould pay 10 l. to the Son of the la≈øt Incumbent yearly, ≈øo long as he ≈øhould be a Student in Cambridge unpreferred, per Cur. this is not Simony. So to pay 5 l. yearly to the Wife and Children of the la≈øt Incumbent. Aliter, if it had been to pay it to the Son of the Patron, Noy p. 142. Abigael Baker ver≈øus Mountford.

If a Man be bound to a Stranger to pre≈øent J.S. to a Benefice, and he pre≈øents him upon a Simoniacal Promi≈øe with another Stranger, yet the Bond is forfeited, by Hobart p. 167. in Winchcomb's Ca≈øe.

A Condition for performance of Covenants. The Defendant demands Oyer of the Condition and pleads performance. The Covenants were in con≈øideration of a Marriage, M. was to pay 300 l. and other Covenants; and there was one, that M. will procure B. to be pre≈øented, &c. into
≈øuch a Benefice upon the next avoidance, and the Breach was a≈ø≈øigned in this: Per Cur. had it appeared that on con≈øideration of the Marriage he covenanted this, &c. it had been a Simoniacal Contract, and had avoided the Obligation: But this is a meer Covenant by it ≈øelf, and without ≈øpecial ≈øhewing or averring it was upon a Simoniacal Contract, it ≈øhall not be ≈øo intended, Cro. Car. 425. Byrt and Manning.

A. is bound to B. on Condition, That whereas A. is in a ≈øhort time to be pre≈øented, in≈øtituted and inducted to the Church of D. if A. after his Admi≈ø≈øion, In≈øtitution and Induction at all times on the reque≈øt of B. his Heirs, &c. re≈øign the ≈øaid Rectory and Church to the Ordinary or Guardian of the Spiritualty for the time being, by which A.B. &c. may pre≈øent anew to the ≈øaid Church. This is a good Condition in it ≈øelf without averment that it was for a Simoniacal purpo≈øe, 1 Rolls Abr. p. 417. Mich. 14 Car. B. R. Cary and Yeo.

J. had a Son which he intended to be a Clergy-Man, and having obtained a Pre≈øentation from Queen Eliz. for the Church of S. agreed with the Defendant that he ≈øhould be pre≈øented, ≈øo that he would re≈øign when the Son of J. was qualified. Whereupon the Defendant entred into a Bond of 1000 Marks on Condition (having fir≈øt recited the Agreement) that if the Defendant within three Months after reque≈øt ≈øhould ab≈øolutely re≈øign the ≈øaid Benefice, that then, &c. In Debt on this Bond the Defendant pleads non requi≈øivit, which was found again≈øt him. And in Arre≈øt of Judgment it was moved, that this Bond was made on Simoniacal Contract, and ≈øo void: But the Court
gave Judgment for the Plaintiff, 1. Becau≈øe there was no Averment of the Simony. 2. That it was not material as to the Bond, becau≈øe that Statute doth not make the Bond or Contract void, but only the Pre≈øentation. The ≈øen≈øe of the Court in that Ca≈øe was, that in truth, if a Man be preparing a Son for the Clergy and have a Living in his di≈øpo≈øal, which falls void before his Son be ready, he may lawfully take of ≈øuch per≈øon, as he ≈øhall pre≈øent, a Bond to re≈øign when his Son is become capable of ≈øuch Living. But if a Patron take a Bond ab≈øolutely to re≈øign upon Reque≈øt without any ≈øuch cau≈øe as the Pre≈øentment of a Son, or to avoid Pluralities or Non-Re≈øidence, or ≈øuch rea≈øonable cau≈øe, but only to a corrupt end to exact Mony by this Bond from the Incumbent, or attempt it; tho the Bond may be good again≈øt the Obligor, yet it makes the Church become void, and gives the Pre≈øentation to the King. It ≈øeems in this Ca≈øe, if Simony had been averred, it would have been left to a Jury to have adjudged what the intention of the corrupt Patron was, Crook Trin. 8 Jac. 248, 274. John and Lawrens, Sir Simon Degg p. 54, 55, 56.

Such a Condition was in Wood and Babington's Ca≈øe, to re≈øign into the hands of the Bi≈øhop of London. Upon Oyer of this Bond and Condition the Defendant demurred. Judgment pro Querente. But per Cur. If the Defendant had averred that the Obligation had been made with intent to exact Mony, make a Lea≈øe, &c. which in it ≈øelf had been Simony, then it might have been a Que≈øtion, whether this Bond had been good or not; but upon this Demurrer it doth not appear
there was any Simoniacal Contract, and ≈øuch Bonds might be for good and lawful ends, ut ≈øupra, Crook Car. 180.

A Condition to re≈øign on Reque≈øt; which was, If Jo.
