Wat≈øon do and ≈øhall upon the fir≈øt of Octob. next, or before, if the ≈øaid William Baker at the Par≈øonage-Hou≈øe of Cowley ≈øhall reque≈øt the ≈øame, and before John Wat≈øon ≈øhall take another Benefice, in due manner re≈øign the ≈øaid Rectory, Par≈øonage or Benefice of Cowley afore≈øaid unto the Bi≈øhop or Ordinary of the Dioce≈øs, whereby the Rectory may become void, and the ≈øaid William Baker may lawfully pre≈øent to the ≈øame; then this Obligation to be void. The Defendant after Oyer pleads Re≈øignation; the Plaintiff replies he did not re≈øign. Et hoc petit &c. The Defendant demurs, for that the Condition is void. Per Cur. it hath been above a dozen times adjudged that the Condition is good. Quaere, if the Re≈øignation ≈øhall be tryed per pais or by Certificate, 2 Keb. 446. Siderfin p. 387. Baker and Wat≈øon. M. 20 Car. 2. B. R.

In Debt on Bond for payment of Mony at a day certain. The Defendant pleads it was made upon a Simoniacal Contract for the Pre≈øentation to a Benefice, &c. per Cur. it is no Plea, becau≈øe it was averred by matter debors, and appeared not within the Deed; and an Averment ≈øhall not be, that it was paid for other cau≈øes than the Obligation expre≈ø≈øeth, More n. 729. Noy p. 72. Gregory and Older.

The Condition was, if Web the Patron pre≈øented the Defendant, and if the Defendant continued Incumbent for a year, and after the year
at all times within three Months after Notice and Reque≈øt was ready to re≈øign, and did re≈øign the Benefice to the Ordinary to be pre≈øented thereto again by Web, and ≈øhould not before re≈øign, that then, &c. The Defendant pleads Stat. 13 & 14 Eliz. and that after he was inducted, he made a Lea≈øe to the Plaintiff of the Benefice for 21 years, and averred the Obligation was made for enjoying the Land by Lea≈øe. The Plaintiff demurs. Per Cur. the Plea was good, but the Averment not ≈øufficient. Judgment pro Quaer. More n. 835. Web and Hargrave.

div.head: Again≈øt Stat. 13 Eliz. c. 20. 14 Eliz. c. 11. Of Non-Re≈øidence.
div.p: NO Lea≈øe to be made of any Benefice or Eccle≈øia≈øtical Promotion or any part thereof, and not being impropriated, ≈øhall endure any longer than while the Le≈ø≈øor ≈øhall be ordinarily re≈øident and ≈øerving the Cure of ≈øuch Benefice without ab≈øence above 80 days in any one year. And all Bonds and Covenants for ≈øuffering any ≈øuch Par≈øon to enjoy any ≈øuch Benefice with Cure ≈øhall be void, 13 Eliz. c. 20. 14 Eliz. c. 11. either by Par≈øon or Curate; the Lea≈øe was made to the Curate who lea≈øeth over. Qu. If the ab≈øence of the Par≈øon ≈øhall make the Lea≈øe void, 1 Leon. p. 100. St. John and Petit's Ca≈øe.
Upon the Statute 13 Eliz. of Lea≈øes made by Par≈øons, that upon Non-Re≈øidence for 80 days the Lea≈øe ≈øhall be void; this Statute voids Bonds for Non-Re≈øidence.

If the Condition be, that after In≈øtitution and Induction he ≈øhall at all times after be ordinarily re≈øident, and ≈øerve the Cure without being ab≈øent 80 days during any one year, that he ≈øhall be Par≈øon of the ≈øaid Church; this is a good Condition without Averment taken to be for a Simoniacal purpo≈øe, 1 Rolls Abr. 417. Cary and Yeo.

The Condition was, that if the Defendant be not ab≈øent 80 days from his Benefice, nor re≈øign without the a≈ø≈øent of his Patron, then, &c. The Defendant pleads Stat. 13 Eliz. That all Lea≈øes of Par≈øons made of their Benefices where they are ab≈øent 80 days, & ultra, and all Obligations for enjoying them ≈øhall be void; and ≈øaith he was ab≈øent by the ≈øpace of 80 days, and ≈øaith not & ultra, it was held an incurable fault in the Plea, Cro. Eliz. p. 88. Go≈ønal and Kindlemar≈øh. Such another Ca≈øe in Crook Eliz. p. 490, Earl of Lincoln ver≈øus Hoskins. Such a Plea was naught. 1. The Statute was mi≈ørecited tam diu (where the words are tam cito.) 2. Becau≈øe it is not alledged that he was ab≈øent; for otherwi≈øe neither Lea≈øe nor Bond are void.

div.head: Again≈øt Statutes of U≈øury, 13 Eliz. c. 8. 21 Jac. 12 Car. 2. c. 13. How and when ≈øuch Obligations become void or not, and the Pleadings thereon.
div.p:
IF the Contract be not u≈øurious, it ≈øhall not be made U≈øury by mater ex po≈øt facto. A Bond for 60 l. and gave Bond to pay it and 6 l. Intere≈øt at the end of the year; and before the end
of the year, the Obligor pays 6 l. for Intere≈øt, it is not U≈øury, 1 Bul≈øtr. 17. Anonymus.

A Condition to pay 20 l. per annum during Life, it is no U≈øury, but an ab≈øolute Bargain; had there been any provi≈øion made for Re-payment of the principal, although not expre≈ø≈øed within the Bond, it had been an u≈øurious Contract, 1 Leon. 36. Crook Jac. 252. Fountain and Grimes.

Debt ≈øur Bond of an 100 l. dated 12 July, with a Condition for the payment of 54 l. at the end of ≈øix Months. The Defendant pleads the Statute 21 Jac. of U≈øury. The Plaintiff replies, he lent the 50 l. for one year, and that the Defendant ≈øhould pay 8 l. for the forbearance for a year; and by the Scriveners mi≈øtake it was made payable at half a years end; and he being illiterate and not knowing thereof, accepted the ≈øaid Bond. The Defendant rejoins the Lending was only for half a year, and that he was feign to pay 8 l. for it for that time, and traver≈øeth that on the ≈øaid 12th of July that he ≈øhould forbear it for one year. The Plaintiff demurred; Bar ill, becau≈øe he ≈øaith not corrupte agreeat. And per Cur. this Allegation may well be made again≈øt the words of the Condition; for it is the ≈øhewing of the true Agreement, which was according to Law: And the Rejoynder is not good, becau≈øe he makes the day thereby to be parcel of the I≈ø≈øue, which ought not to be, but he ought to have traver≈øed the Agreement only, Crook Car. 501. Jones 396. Nevi≈øon and Whitly.

Debt ≈øur Bill. The Plaintiff declares, the Defendant 20 Apr. 1633. by his Bill became bound to him in 7 l. to be paid 21 Apr. 1634. and if default payment was, he granted to pay 3 s. 4 d.
for every month it ≈øhould be in arrear. The Defendant pleads that upon the lending of the 7 l. to be paid at the end of the year, it was corrupte agreed to pay 3 s. 4 d. ut ante. Had it been well pleaded it had been good; for it is not averred that the Agreement was to pay 3 s. 4. d. for every Month pro lucro intere≈ø≈øe & diem dando ≈øolutionis; nor doth he aver the words of the Statute, that ultra 8 l. per cent. ≈øhall be taken for U≈øury, Jones p. 409. Swales and Bateman.

In Debt ≈øur Bond made at S. the Defendant pleads the ≈øame was made upon a corrupt agreement at another place; the Plaintiff replied, that it was made bona fide, and traver≈øeth the corrupt Contract. V ‚Ä¢ nue was from the place where the corrupt Contract was laid to be, and good; and not from both places, 2 Bul≈øtr. p. 34. Stanton and Barton. Not from the place where the Bond was made, 1 Leon. p. 148, 149. Crook Eliz. 195. Kiner≈øly and Smart.

The Condition if he pay (for 100 l.) 20 l. at half a years end, if J. S. be then living, and if not, then but a le≈øs Sum than the Principal, it is u≈øurious (he averred the 20 l. amounted to above 10 l. per Cent.) for by the ≈øame rea≈øon he may add 20 Lives, 2 Ander≈ø. 15. 5 Co. Rep. 70. b. Clayton's Ca≈øe, More n. 497. Crook Eliz. p. 642. Button and Downham.

The Defendant pleaded quod corrupte agreeat. fuit, & quod quer' corrupte recepit; and on I≈ø≈øue on them found for the Defendant in both, and good; for one is not material, More n. 750. John≈øon and Clark.

A. lent B. an 100 l. for a year, and took an Obligation for 10 l. Intere≈øt (Mony being then at 10 l. per Cent.) payable 5 l. half yearly: Per Cur. it is not U≈øury deins Stat. More n. 842. Worley's Ca≈øe, Noy p. 171. Cro. Jac. 25.

Debt upon an Obligation of 100 l. the Ca≈øe was, Warnes was indebted to Alder in 100 l. upon an u≈øurious Contract; and Alder was indebted to Ellis the Plaintiff in 100 l. the ju≈øt Debt for which Warnes and Alder were bound to Ellis. The Defendant pleads this U≈øury between him and Alder to avoid the Bond. The Plaintiff replies, Alder was ju≈øtly indebted to him 100 l. and the Defendant and Alder became bound for this Mony, and that he was not privy to the U≈øury between Warnes and Alder, and good; and the u≈øurious Contract between Warnes and Alder ≈øhall not prejudice the Plaintiff, Yelv. p. 47. More n. 981. Crook Jac. 32. Ellis and Warnes. 1 Brownl. 85.

A Condition to ≈øave the Plaintiff harmle≈øs from one Obligation, wherein the Plaintiff was bound as Surety for the Defendant to J. S. The Defendant pleads that the Bond to J. S. was upon u≈øurious Contract, and pleads the Statute & ≈øic non damnificat. it is no Plea, for he ought to ≈øave his Surety harmle≈øs, and it ≈øhall not be intended the Surety knew of the u≈øurious Contract, Crook Eliz. 643. Button and Downhan. 3 Leon. 63. Potkin's Ca≈øe. Contra Crook Eliz. 588. Robin≈øon and May, 2 Leon. 166. Ba≈ø≈øet and Browns Ca≈øe.

If there be an Agreement after the Forfeiture of a Recogni≈øance, and the ≈øecond Defea≈øance is for more than 10 l. per Cent. according to the
principal Debt, yet it is not deins Stat. 13 Eliz. but before the Forfeiture, it had been otherwi≈øe; and it is not for forbearance of the fir≈øt principal but of the penalty, Noy p. 2. Hollingworth and Parkhurst.

If a Debt be brought on an Obligation, and it is found for the Plaintiff; now the Defendant ≈øhall not have Audita Querela upon a Surmi≈øe that it was an u≈øurious Contract, for he might have pleaded that, Noy p. 123. Cook ver≈øus Wall. Or if he be condemned on nil dicit, Crook Eliz. p. 25. Fi≈øher and Banks.
If an Executor pay an u≈øurious Bond, other Creditors may make a Deva≈øtavit of it, per Hob. p. 167.

The Condition was to pay the principal Debt at the end of the year with Intere≈øt that ≈øhould be then due. It was a Quaere, if any Intere≈øt ≈øhould be paid, and not re≈øolved. See there Noy's Argument of the odious Sin of U≈øury, 2 Rolls Rep. p. 239, 240. Sander≈øon and Warner.

The Defendant pleaded the Statute of U≈øury to a Bond, and ≈øheweth that a Ship went to fi≈øh in Newfoundland, and that the Plaintiff delivered 50 l. to the Defendant to pay 60 l. on the Return of the Ship to Dartmouth; and if the Ship never returned, he ≈øhould pay nothing, it is not U≈øury, Cro. Jac. p. 208. Sharply ver≈øus Hurrel, 1 Brownl. Rep. p. 52.

The Defendant pleads the Statute of U≈øury made 6 Febr. 13 Eliz. (whereas the Parliament began 2 Febr. 15 El.) and that the Obligation was taken by U≈øury. The Plaintiff replies it was not made for U≈øury contra formam Statuti modo &
forma praed. and at I≈ø≈øue found for the Plaintiff, yet a Repleader was awarded after Verdict; for the Court held no Judgment could be given for the Plaintiff, as well knowing there was no ≈øuch Statute, Cro. El. p. 245. Love ver≈øus Wotton.

Debt on an Obligation with a Condition of Bottomree to pay 130 l. when the Ship ≈øhould return from Norwey. The Defendant after Oyer pleads corrupt Agreement for lending 50 l. to pay according to the Condition. The Plaintiff demurred: Per Cur. it is not U≈øury, 1 Keb. 711. Appleton ver≈øus Bryan.

In Debt upon an Obligation, after Oyer the Defendant pleaded an u≈øurious Contract to receive more Intere≈øt than due, to which the Plaintiff demurred, becau≈øe it is not ≈øaid that at the time of making the Bond it was corruptly agreed; and the other doth but incur the penalty of the Statute, but doth not avoid the Security, which the Court agreed, 2 Keb. 525. Farrel ver≈øus Shaw.

The Defendant pleads an u≈øurious Agreement, that the Plaintiff lent the Defendant 10 l. and if the Ship return, to pay him 3 l. The Plaintiff demurred: Per Cur. this is good and bare bottom ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , 3 Keb. 62. Cham and Taylor.

The Defendant pleads Stat. 12 Car. 2. c. 13. and ≈øaid the Contract was u≈øurious; but per Cur. being made after the Bond forfeited to receive Intere≈øt according to the penalty which was double the principal, it avoids not the Obligation which was good at fir≈øt, but only ≈øubjected the taker to other Penalties, 3 Keble 142. Redly and Manning.
The Defendant pleads 12 Car. 2. cap. to which the Plaintiff demurred, becau≈øe in recital of the Statute, the word made is left out, and Plea ill, 3 Keble p. 618. Gilmore and I≈øles.

Debt on Obligation to pay 100 l. on Marriage of the Daughter, and if either Plantiff or Defendant die before, then nothing; the Defendant pleads that of U≈øury, and that this was for the Loan of 30 l. before delivered; the Plaintiff demurred: Per Cur. this is plain Bottom-ree, 3 Keb. p. 304. Long and Wharton.

The Condition, was, If ≈øuch a Ship go to Surat in the Ea≈øt Indies, and return ≈øafe to London, &c. or if the Owner or the Goods return ≈øafe, &c. that the Defendant ≈øhall pay to the Plaintiff the Principal, and 40 l. for every 100 l. but if the Ship peri≈øh by unavoidable ca≈øualty of Sea, Fire or Enemies, then the Plaintiff to have nothing: Per Cur. this a good Bottomree Contract, and not U≈øury; and Bridgman took the difference between a Bargain and a Loan, for where there is a Bargain de plano (as here) and the Principal hazarded, this is not within the Statute of U≈øury; aliter of a Loan which is intended where the Principal is not hazarded, Siderfin p. 27. Soame and Green. Cro. Jac. 252. Fountain and Grimes.

There are two Clau≈øes in the Statute of U≈øury, 12 Car. 2. If there be a corrupt Agreement at the time of the lending the Mony, then the Bond and all A≈ø≈øurances are void; but if the Agreement be good, and afterwards he receives more than he ought, then he forfeits the treble value, Per Twi≈øden, Mod. Rep. 69. 1 Sanders p. 294. Ferral and Shaen Knight and Baronet, and the Pleadings.

Debt on Bond 24 May, 19 Car. 2. The Defendant prays Oyer of the Condition, which is for 300 l. to be paid 25 Febr. 20 Car. 2. and upon Oyer the Defendant pleads in Bar, quod po≈øt confection' ≈øcripti obligatorii praed' ≈øcil. 10 May, 20 Car. 2. The Plaintiff corruptive recepit de Defendente 30 l. pro differendo diem ≈øolutionis praed' 300 l. pro uno anno integro (videlicet) &c. quod e≈øt ultra ratam 6 l. per cent. per annum, contra formam Statuti per quod ≈øcript' obligator' praed' vacuum devenit, & hoc, &c. The Plaintiff demurs: Plea is not good, for the new Statute of U≈øury 12 Car. 2. cap. 13. ≈øaith, That all Bonds for payment of any Mony for any U≈øury; and here the Bond is not for payment of Monies upon U≈øury, for it might be for a ju≈øt Debt, and the u≈øurious Contract after ≈øhall not hurt it; but its puni≈øhable. 1 Sanders page 274. Ferrall and Shaen.

If in truth the Contract be u≈øurious again≈øt the Statute, no Colour nor ≈øhew of Words will ≈øerve, but the Party may ≈øhew the ≈øame, and ≈øhall not be concluded or e≈øtopped by any Deed, or any other Matter what≈øoever; for the Statute giveth averment in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, 5 Rep. 69. b. Burtons Ca≈øe.
5 Rep. 70. Claytons Ca≈øe, uncertain, and yet U≈øurious, and Burtons Ca≈øe, Moor n. 497. id. Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleaded the Statute of U≈øury, alledging that agreeatum fuit, that the Plaintiff ≈øhould have ≈øo much Mony pro donatione diei ≈øolutionis; the Plaintiff traver≈øed ab≈øque hoc quod agreeat' fuit, and found for the Plaintiff; it was
moved in Arre≈øt of Judgment, that the word (corrupte) was not pleaded in the Bar; re≈øolved, the Bar was made good by the Replication; and the Declaration being good, Judgment pro Quer. Moor n. 624. Rogers and Jack≈øon.
Where (per Twi≈øden) the Contract was not U≈øurious, but a Purcha≈øe of an Annuity for three years, Siderfin p. 182. Rowe and Bella≈øs.

div.head: Again≈øt Stat. 23 H. 6. cap. 10. Sheriffs Bonds void.
div.p: THE intent and rea≈øon of this Statute.
This Statute hath three notable Branches.

1. Commandment and Authority to the Sheriff to let to bail ≈øuch Per≈øons as are mainpernable; ≈øo Coroners, Stewards of Franchi≈øes, Bailiffs, Keepers of Pri≈øons; and this is in affirmance of the Common Law.

2. A re≈øtraining Branch, that they ≈øhall not let to bail ≈øuch Per≈øons as be in their Ward by Condemnation, Execution, Capias Utlegatum, or Excommunication, Surety of the Peace, and ≈øuch as ≈øhall be committed by ≈øpecial commandment of the Ju≈øtices, and Vagabonds; this is in affirmance of the Common Law.

3. The third is to make Obligations taken in any other form than the Statute limits, to be void. That no Sheriff, nor any of his Officers and Mini≈øters, afore≈øaid, ≈øhall take or cau≈øe to be taken, or make any Obligation for any Cau≈øe afore≈øaid, or by colour of their Office, but only to them≈øelves
of any Per≈øon, nor by any Per≈øon which ≈øhall be in their Ward by the cour≈øe of the Law, but by the Name of their Office, and upon Condition written, that the ≈øaid Pri≈øoners ≈øhall appear at the day contained in the ≈øaid Writ, Bill or Warrant; and in ≈øuch places as the ≈øaid Bill, &c. ≈øhall require; and any Obligation taken by them in other form ≈øhall be void.
The de≈øign of this Statute is to provide again≈øt the Extortion of Sheriffs, Plow. Dive and Manninghams Ca≈øe.

div.head: Explication del Statute.
div.p: THe≈øe words (for any cau≈øe afore≈øaid) refer to all that went before, as well tho≈øe contained in the Exception, as in the fir≈øt Branch; therefore a Bond taken of a Man in Execution is void by this Statute; and the Surety may plead this, and the words colore officii make it void, for he was taken by him in Execution as Sheriff, and he lets him to bail, which is not mainpernable, Plow. 69, 80. Dive and Manningham.

This is a particular Law, and ought to be pleaded, Dive and Manninghams Ca≈øe, Plowd. Parker and Weblyes Ca≈øe in Siderfin, and Siderfin p. 24. Allen and Robin≈øons Ca≈øe. Hobart p. 13. contra 3 Keble 320, 361. Oakes and Cell. The Statute is not as in Print, that the Sheriff nor any de ≈øes, but any des Officers or Mini≈øters of Ju≈øtice, 3 Keble 71. Munday and Frogat.
A Covenant is not within this Statute, Hob. p. 13. Sir Daniel Nortons Ca≈øe.

This Statute hath two parts, one for the Benefit of the Sheriff, (viz.) That he ≈øhall take Obligations with ≈øingle Sureties, which is for his Indempnity, that if he be amerced for non-appearance of the Party, he ≈øhall have his remedy; the other for the benefit of the Party, ≈øo the Statute pre≈øcribes the Form, and that the Sheriff under colour of his Office, ≈øhould not oppre≈øs the Party to make him any other manner of Obligation, for the Statute makes the Obligation void, for not per≈øuing the Form, but not in the Matter thereof; therefore the Sheriff may take one Surety, or two, one being a Stranger that hath nothing in the County, Cro. El. 808. Sir George Clyfton ver≈øus Webb.

At the Common Law the Sheriff was not compellable to take Bail of any; and the Statute compels him to let to bail, and therefore no Action lies again≈øt the Sheriff for not having the Body at the day; the Statute ≈øaith ≈øufficient Sureties, but that is for his own indempnity, which he may wave, and take what Sureties he thinks fitting. The Statute ≈øaith, The Obligation taken in any other Form than is there pre≈øcribed ≈øhall be void; and within the Statute are three Froms to be ob≈øerved, 2 Leon. fol. 78. Seckford and Woolverton.
1. That it ≈øhall be made to the Sheriff him≈øelf.
2. That it ≈øhall be made to him by the Name of his Office.

3. That it ≈øhall be only for appearance at the day; but the in≈øufficiency of the Sureties is Matter, and not Form, and the Obligation is not void, Cro. El. p. 862. Mich. 43 El. 1. Cotton ver≈ø. Wale, me≈øme Ca≈øe, 2 Ander≈øon 175.
The Statute was made for the Pri≈øoners benefit; for the Mi≈øchief before was, That the Sheriff not being compellable to bail him, would extort Mony from him to be bailed, Modern Rep. p. 228.
At Common Law if the Sheriff had taken any Man by Writ of the King, he might not be delivered but by breve de homine replegiando, 2 Sanders 60.
This Statute does not extend to Fees or other Collaterals, only matter of Impri≈øonment colore Officii is taken in malam partem, as Extortion is, &c. 2 Keble 422.
One in Execution e≈øcapes, and is retaken, and then a Bond is made for his enlargement; this is colore officii, and deins Stat. 2 Leon. 118. Philips and Stone.
If a Sheriff take a Bond for a true Debt, its good, becau≈øe not colore officii.
The Warden of the Fleet, and the King Palace at We≈øtmin≈øter, are excepted out of this Act.

If the Statute be mi≈ørecited, it may be demurred to, as he recited, if any Sheriff aut ejus Officiarii, where it ≈øhould be alii Officiarii, Cro. Eliz. 108. Tru≈ø≈øel and Aston. Q. if the Court will take notice of this by the printed Book, or by the Record, or otherwi≈øe, Siderfin p. 356. Holby and Bray. As to mi≈ørecital, vide 2 Keble 278. Pench and Woodnoth.

div.head: The Sheriffs Return upon this Statute.
div.p: ACtion upon the Ca≈øe brought again≈øt the Sheriff, becau≈øe he took J. S. and returned at the day, Cepi Corpus, and yet had not the Party at the day, but ≈øuffered him to e≈øcape, but he returned paratum habeo (which was fal≈øe,) The Defendant pleads he being arre≈øted, put in J. B. and J. C. Sureties, and pleaded Stat. 23 H. 6. and ≈øo let him at large; the Plea is good, for the Sheriff is compellable to take Bail, but what Bail is left to his di≈øcretion, and for his fal≈øe return of paratum habeo, he is amercible to the Court, and that is nothing to the Party, Cro. El. p. 624. Barton and Aldworth. And this is a good Plea for the Sheriff to plead not guilty in ≈øuch a Ca≈øe; but if the Sheriff demurs to the Declaration, then the Action lies again≈øt him, for the Declaration ≈øhall be taken to be true upon the Demurrer, for the Statute is private, and the Court will not take notice of it unle≈øs it be pleaded, Siderfin H. 21 and 22 Car. 2. Parker and Webly, 1 Rolls Abr. 92. Mod. Rep 244. Page and Tul≈øe. Mod. Rep. 57. But if the Defendant had pleaded this ≈øpecially, or had pleaded non cul. he might have had advantage of the Statute, and ou≈øted the Plaintiff of his Action, Moor n. 428. Cro. 3. 460. Langton and Gardners Ca≈øe.
After this Statute the Sheriff may not make a Special Return, but only Cepi Corpus, or non e≈øt Inventus, Franklin and Andrews Ca≈øe, cited in Siderfin in Parker and Welbyes Ca≈øe, p. 23.

If the Sheriff return Languidus, yet if he took Bond according to the Statute, no Action upon the Ca≈øe lies again≈øt him, but he is amercible, Cro. Eliz. 852. Boles and La≈ø≈øels. The Sheriff, ≈øhall be amerced until he a≈ø≈øign the Obligation to the Plaintiff, Siderfin p. 23.

If Bail be taken by the Statute 23 H. 6. and the Sheriff return Cepi Corpus, and the Party appear not at the day of the return (being in mean Proce≈øs) the Sheriff ≈øhall not be charged in Action ≈øur Ca≈øe, for this would be to fru≈øtrate the Statute 23 H. 6. but then it mu≈øt appear to the Court on the Record, that it is on the Statute 23 H. 6. and not a return at Common Law, Siderfin 22. Allen and Robin≈øon.
If the Sheriff refu≈øe to take rea≈øonable Bail, Action upon the Ca≈øe lies again≈øt him; and if he refu≈øe to take Bail, he is liable to an Action of fal≈øe Impri≈øonment, Siderfin p. 23.

An Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt the Sheriff pro E≈øcape; the Defendant pleads the Statute 23 H. 6. that he let H. to bail, and took rea≈øonable Sureties, A. and B. Per≈øons having ≈øufficient within the County; the Plaintiff replies, ab≈ø
que hoc, That he took Bail having ≈øufficient within the County; the Defendant demurs, Judgment pro Defendente, Mod. Rep. 227. Ellis and Parborough.

An Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt the Sheriff for not taking rea≈øonable Sureties, nor having ≈øufficient E≈øtates in the ≈øaid County, and returning Cepi Corpus, and yet had not the Bodies at the day, it lies not, for he is compellable to let to bail, and if he have not the Body he ≈øhall be amerced; and becau≈øe he ≈øhall be amerced the
Statute gives him advice to take ≈øufficient Sureties for his own Indempnity, 2 Sanders p. 59. Po≈øterns Ca≈øe. Vide the Declarations and Pleadings in that Ca≈øe there.

An Action upon the Ca≈øe for taking in≈øufficient Bail; the Defendant pleads he had taken ≈øufficient Security; he need not ≈øay where, nor need he traver≈øe the intent to deceive the Plaintiff of his Debt, Siderfin p. 98. Bently and Hore. Q. of this Ca≈øe.

div.head: What Obligations and Conditions ≈øhall be void by this Statute, and what not.
div.p: IF the Obligation had one part of the Condition according to the Statute, and the other not, all ≈øhall be void, Plow. Dive and Manningham p. 68. b. Vid. Palmer Rep. 378. Noel and Cooper, Vic. in Com. perdit. pro praedict. its void.

An Obligation to the Sheriff to appear and an≈øwer, &c. is void by the Statute 23 H. 6. aliter to appear to an≈øwer, for the Party by the Law may appear, and yet Judgment may be given by default, Noy p. 54. Lord Evers Ca≈øe.
The Condition to make an appearance; Q. if good, Noy p. 172. Rowles and Fow.
Obligation taken by the Sheriff after the day of the return is void by the Statute 23 H. 6. Siderfin p. 301. Rods Ca≈øe. 3 Keble 260. and ≈øo not a ≈øingle Obligation.

Obligation taken by the Sheriff for an appearance at We≈øtmin≈øter, and the Term was adjourned to St. Albans, and the Party appeared there, he had not forfeited his Obligation, Moor n. 578. Corbet and Downing.

Ad re≈øpondend. de placito debiti in general, without mentioning the Sum is good; the Bond ought to be made to the Sheriff by the name of his Office, and ought to expre≈øs the day and place of his Appearance; and the≈øe Circum≈øtances being ob≈øerved, though it be variant in other Circum≈øtances, its not material, Cro. M. 9 Jac. 286. Villers ver≈ø. Ha≈øtings.
The taking of a Bond of 40 l. by the Sheriff, is ≈øufficient cau≈øe to excu≈øe him from a mi≈øtake; yet he may take Bond for a greater Sum, Cro. Jac. 286. Villers and Ha≈øtings.

Debt ≈øur Bond, the Writ was ad re≈øpond. H. G. nuper Vic. Norff. and the Count was, quod conce≈ø≈øit ≈øe teneri praefat. J.H. in praedict. 40 l. and ≈øaith not tunc Vic. Norff. exi≈øten. and per Cur. ≈øur. Demurrer ≈øur le bar (where the Statute was pleaded) the Count was in≈øufficient, Cro. Eliz. p. 800. Guibon and Whytoft contra, 3 Keble 191, 201. Twi≈øleton and Druthin, for no advantage can be taken again≈øt the Bond except it were entred.

The Condition was, If the ≈øaid J. D. per≈øonally appeared, &c. a die Pa≈øc. in 15 dies, to an≈øwer to J. H. as ≈øhall appertain, and farther, to do and receive as the Court therein of him ≈øhall con≈øider in that behalf, that then, &c. its a void Bond, Cro. El. p. 672. Scriven and Dyther.

The Condition was, That if the Defendant do appear in B. R. ≈øuch a day, then the Condition of the ≈øaid Obligation to be void, yet per Cur. both good, for if tho≈øe words were omitted its but ≈øurplu≈øage, Siderfin 456. Maleverer and Hawksby, 2 Keble 625.

The Writ is placito Tran≈øgr. the Condition of the Bond is to an≈øwer the ac etiam Billae 100 l. in placito debiti is void, being another Writ; but if the Writ were in placito debiti, or the Bond taken only to an≈øwer the Writ in placito Tran≈ø. it were well enough; and a nil Cap. per Bill. awarded ≈øur demurrer by the Plaintiff, upon the Defendants Plea upon the Statute it being in alia forma, 3 Keble 164. Mildmay and Cage, and p. 711. Moor and Finch.

A Writ out of B. R. returnable out of Term, the Sheriff takes the Party, and takes Bond to appear at the day of the return, and for non-appearance brought Debt upon this Obligation, this Bond was void per Statute, and the Sheriff ≈øhall not be amerced for the non-appearance, nor liable to any faux Impri≈øonment by the Party, 2 Siderfin p. 129. Jenkins and Hatton.

The Bond not being taken by the Sheriff in the name of his Office, in Debt ≈øur Obligation the Defendant demurs upon Oyer, ≈øed non allocatur, for the Statute is not pleaded, and it may be for a ju≈øt debt, 2 Keble p. 620. Jaques and Reyner.

A Condition to appear before his Maje≈øties Ju≈øtices of B. R. in We≈øtmin≈øter, the Defendant pleads the Statute 23 H. 8. and that this was ali ‚Ä¢ forma, it ≈øhould be coram Dom. Rege ubicun
que
&c. yet adjudged good; the Statute is not to be avoided by ≈øuch mi≈øtakes of returns, 3 Keble 611, 551, 627.

The Condition is, If ≈øuch a one who was arre≈øted ≈øur Lat. appeared per≈øonally and an≈øwered, &c. in regard his appearance is nece≈ø≈øary to put
in ≈øpecial Bail, if the Party requires it, the Bond is good, Cro. Eliz. p. 776. Bowels and Hear≈øter.

If Obligation be taken by the Sheriff after the day of the return its void by the Statute, and is not a ≈øingle Obligation, for the Party ≈øo taken after the return may not be bailed without coming before a Judge, and he may not do this out of Term without con≈øent of the other Party, Siderfin p. 301. in Courtney and Phelyn.

A Bond or Covenant for Fees is void; a Bond for true Impri≈øonment is not void, prima facie, without Circum≈øtances, &c. a Bond for Chamberrent is void by Common Law, becau≈øe the Party is contra voluntatem re≈øtrained, and ≈øhall be impri≈øoned till payment, to which the Court agreed; al≈øo the Statute extends only to the Mar≈øhal for ≈øuch Bonds as they may take virtute officii, 3 Keble 133. Mo≈øedale and Midleton.
An Obligation taken with one Surety is good, Sir William Drurys Ca≈øe, Lit. Rep. 110.

A Bond for Tuition of a Child as Curator, and to give account to the Ordinary, is but a voluntary undertaking of the Guardian, and ≈øo not deins Stat. 23 H. 6. and at Common Law its good, notwith≈øtanding 3 In≈øt. 149. A Bond for due Admini≈øtration may well be taken by the Ordinary, 3 Keble 671. Bi≈øhop of Carli≈øles Ca≈øe. The Plea that the Bond is taken colore officii, will not avoid a Bond taken of the Party to do what he ought, 3 Keble 790.

div.head: What Obligations and Conditions are good or not, in re≈øpect of the Per≈øons and Officers, to whom made, and in what Courts.
div.p:
L. gives Bond to the Sheriff, being arre≈øted by Attachment out of the Chancery; the Condition was, That the Defendant ≈øhould appear ≈øuch a day in Chancery apud We≈øtm. ubicunque fuerint, this Bond is within the Statute; but here is a material variance in the Bond which makes it void; for the Defendant to be preci≈øely bound to appear at We≈øtmin≈øter, and then to add ubicun
que fuerint, Stiles p. 234. Burton and Low cited in 3 Keble 614. Kirby and Curwin, 3 Keble p. 599. Kirkby and Dicer.
The King is not deins Stat. 23 H. 6. 5 Rep. Whelpdales Ca≈øe, 3 Keble 678. in Ellis's Ca≈øe, Dyer 119.
A Serjeant at Arms of Wales is not within the Statute, Stiles 234. Burtons Ca≈øe.
A Serjeant at Arms to the Hou≈øe of Commons not deins Stat. 1 Keble 391. Norfolk and Ailmer.
Such Bond given to a Deputy of a Bailiff of a Franchi≈øe is void, or to an Under-Sheriffs Deputy; it mu≈øt be to the Bailiff or Sheriff him≈øelf, Noy p. 69. Tavernors Ca≈øe.
A Serjeant at Arms attending on the Pre≈øident and Councel of the Mar≈øhes of Wales, is not an Officer within this Statute, Cro. Car. p. 9. Car. B. R. Johns and Stratford.

If the Mar≈øhal of the Kings Bench takes Bond for the ea≈øment and delivery of a Pri≈øoner in Execution, its void by this Statute, though he is not
named; and ≈øo many others, Cro. Eliz. p. 66. Bracebridge ver≈ø. Vaughan.

The Sheriff by vertue of Attachment under the Privy Seal of the Court of Reque≈øts, took the Defendant, and for his Enlargement made the Obligation to appear before the Queens Councel, &c. per Cur. here is no Warrant to take the Body or the Obligation; for that Court hath not any Power by Commi≈ø≈øion, by Statute or by Common Law; but the Sheriff ought to obey the Proce≈øs out of the Dutchy Court, for that is appointed by Act of Parliament, and ≈øo this is not within the Statute, for the Statute ≈øpeaks of ≈øuch who are in their Cu≈øtody per Cour≈øe of Law; and ≈øo this Obligation taken by Dure≈øs is avoidable, Cro. El. p. 646. Stephens and Floid, me≈øme Ca≈øe, 2 Ander≈øon 122.
If a Bailiff of an Hundred (which is a Franchi≈øe) take Bond, he mu≈øt do it in the Sheriffs Name, 3 Keble 71, 117, 127. Monday and Frogat.
The Bond mu≈øt be taken to the Sheriff him≈øelf, and not to another, Plow. Com. 68. a. b.
The Statute doth not extend to a Bond made to the Plaintiff him≈øelf, Allen p. 58. Leech and Davis.
The Mar≈øhal of the Kings Bench is deins this Statute, 1 Keble 391. 9 Co. 98.

On Oyer it was to appear on Proce≈øs out of Chancery; the Defendant pleads 23 H. 6. that Attachment was out of Chancery delivered to the Sheriff, retorn. Tres Trin. and this Obligation was for Ea≈øe and Favour; the Plaintiff ≈øhews the Defendant was arre≈øted, and gave this for appearance
on another Writ, ab≈ø
que hoc, that it was for Ea≈øe; the Defendant demurs, becau≈øe the Sheriff cannot take Bond to appear on any other day than in the Writ; ≈øed per Cur. the Plea layeth a return that never was, and the Plaintiff ≈øets forth true Bond, and traver≈øeth the Ea≈øe, which is as well as can be; Judgment pro Quer. 2 Keble p. 526, 596. Maleverer and Red≈øhare.

Plaint in Court Baron of 39 s. and Attachment again≈øt the Defendants Goods, and detained till the Bailiff cau≈øed 40 l. Bond to be made to the Plaintiff him≈øelf, to appear and an≈øwer with, and Condemnation by a day; and pleaded Stat. 23 H. 6. this Bond is void at Common Law; its void al≈øo for the unrea≈øonablene≈øs of the Sum extorted, 1 Keble 873.

A Condition to appear in B. R. according to cu≈øtom at the Suit of M. on Oyer the Defendant pleads there is no ≈øuch Cu≈øtom in B. R. as the Plaintiff hath alledged to appear to an ac etiam Billae, and ≈øo the Obligation void; the Plaintiff demurs, Judgment pro quer. becau≈øe the Statute 23 H. 6. which is a particular Statute, is not pleaded, ≈øo the Plea ill; but it might be pleaded the Bond was by Dure≈øs, being in other manner than the Statute allows, and that Statute makes the Bond void for the whole, 3 Keble 160, 181. Forth and Walker.

Debt on Obligation taken per the Plaintiff, Sheriff of the Defendant his Clerk, upon Condition to pay the Kings Silver into the Exchequer within 14 days after he received it; the Defendant pleads Stat. 23 H. 8. and averred it was taken colore Officii; upon demurrer adjudged pro quer. for the
Statute doth not intend ≈øuch Obligation taken of them, which are not to appear, nor are in Cu≈øtody, Moor n. 685. Cartwright and Dale ‚Ä¢
worth.

The Sheriffs Bond for appearance at a day certain, at which day the Party did not appear; but two days after he appeared: Per Cur. this appearance, though after the day, ≈øhall be allowed of for a good appearance, and ≈øhall be a di≈øcharge of the Bond; for the whole Term is but one day in Law; ≈øo it is in C. B. and B. R. 2 Bul≈øtr. p. 255. Daly and Fryar.

div.head: Pleadings.
div.p: J. S. puts him≈øelf in a ≈øpecial Bailiff, and Arre≈øts J. D. and takes Bond, &c. this is by Dure≈øs, and the Defendant might plead that; yet its not within the Statute, nor aided by it, for J. D. was never in the Sheriffs Cu≈øtody after the Arre≈øt, and the Bond was taken out of the County where he was arre≈øted, and ≈øo by Dure≈øs, but not deins Statute, Cro. Eliz. p. 746. Brown and Adams, 3 Keble 756, 760. Earl of Bristol and Lord Burks Ca≈øe.

On the Sheriffs Bond it mu≈øt be averred, that there is a Record in the Rejoinder, as well as in the Bar, 2 Keble 250, 278. Knight and Pits Ca≈øe, If one plead appearance, he mu≈øt conclude prout patet per Record. Cro. Eliz. fol. 466. Corbets Ca≈øe.

Though the Defendant nor Bail have any thing in the County, nor are Inhabitants in the County, yet the Bond is good; for the Statute doth not
make void any Bonds, but what are made in other manner, in oppre≈ø≈øion to the People, which the Statute appoints to be void; and the words in other manner and form are to be intended of the matter of the Bonds as to the Sheriff, and not for the ≈øufficiency of the Sureties; therefore if he take Bond with one Surety it is good enough, Crook M. 43 Eliz. pl. 9. Blackburn ver≈øus Michelborne. The Sheriff is Judge of the ≈øufficiency, and it is no Plea to ≈øay, he took Bond of in≈øufficient per≈øons, More n. 818. Cotton and Wade.

A Condition that J. S. appear in B. R. &c. The Defendant on Oyer demurred, becau≈øe it is not taken by the Sheriff in the name of his Office. Sed non allocatur, the Statute being not pleaded, 2 Keb. 620. Jackes and Reyner.
If the Sheriff take an Obligation for the appearance of J. S. before Proce≈øs comes to him to arre≈øt J. S. and after the Proce≈øs comes, this Obligation is good, Siderfin p. 151. Anonyinus.

A Statute of 200 l. was acknowledged to the Defendant to J. S. and this was extended by the Plaintiff being Sheriff, and that it was agreed by C. E. Brother to the Plaintiff and the Under-Sheriff, before the Liberate executed, that the Defendant ≈øhould enter into the ≈øaid Bond to the u≈øe of the Plaintiff: Per Cur. this Obligation is not within Stat. 23 H. 6. for the party was not in the Ward of the Sheriff; and ≈øo it was re≈øolved in Beufages's Ca≈øe, Winch. 20, 50. Em≈øon and Bathur≈øt.

A Bond to Neel Sheriff of Warwick; and the Bond was to Neel Vic. Com. praed. and Warwick was put in the Margent; per Dodderidge, this is not a good Bond; he ought to be named Sheriff
and of what County, 2 Rolls Rep. fol. 365. Neel ‚Ä¢
and Cooper, vide ≈øuch a Ca≈øe in 3 Keble fol. 422. Bri≈øco and Richard≈øon. Q. If it ≈øhall be taken by Pre≈øumption in this Ca≈øe, the Writ being directed to the Sheriff of Cumberland, and the Bond by R. and S. of Carli≈øle in that County.
Bail Bond was to appear at We≈øtmin≈øter die Sab' proxim' po≈øt Purif. to an≈øwer, its ill, 3 Keble 260, Rod and Huans.

The Condition was Stare mandatis Eccle≈øiae, on Pre≈øentment for not receiving the Sacrament, whereon he was excommunicated, and gave this Bond for Ab≈øolution. Q. if this be a good Bond, for per Cur. 9 Jac. the Bi≈øhop can only take a Pledge in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, and not Bond. 3 Keble p. 219. Bi≈øhop of Exeter and Star.

A Condition to appear in B. R. where the Proce≈øs is returnable, &c. the Defendant ≈øaid in facto, that he had appeared ≈øecundum formam, &c. Et hoc petit, &c. there was a Repleader awarded, for it mu≈øt be tried per the Record; A. is bound to appear ≈øuch a day, &c. and A. at the ≈øaid day goes to the Court, but there no Proce≈øs is returned, then the Party may go to one of the chief Clerks of the Court, and pray him to take a Note of his appearance. Vide the Form of Entry in ≈øuch Ca≈øe; if the other Party pleaded nul tiel Record, it behoveth that the Defendant have the Record ready at his peril; for this Court of Common Pleas cannot write to the Ju≈øtices of the Kings Bench to certifie a Record hither, 1 Leon. p. 90. Bret and Shepard.

Debt upon a Sheriffs Bond; Jones for the Bail prayed the Principal being now in Per≈øon,
may be admitted to plead di≈øcharging th Amerciaments, (which is the cour≈øe of the Court) where the Pro≈øecution is fre≈øh; but where the Defendant in the Original Action, i. e. the Principal is become in≈øolvent, per Cur. the Bail Bond is the only remedy, and they will not di≈øcharge that on the ordinary Rules; but in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe the Bail appeared on the very day of the return, and the default is the Plaintiffs own, and the Bond not above a year old, paying the Amerciaments and Co≈øts the Bail was di≈øcharged, and the Principal admitted to plead, 2 Keble 545, 553. Flood and Williams.

If the Defendant appears not to the Sheriffs Bond according to the Condition thereof, the Plaintiff may by leave of the Sheriff ≈øue the Bond in the Sheriffs Name; but its at the Plaintiffs Election to amerce the Sheriff, Stiles Pract. Regi≈øter p. 221.

When Bail is put in de bene e≈ø≈øe (as Bail taken in a Judges Chamber is) the Plaintiff cannot ≈øue the Sheriffs Bond, till it be refu≈øed or ≈øet a≈øide, but he ought to except again≈øt it in the Judges Chamber, 1 Kebl ‚Ä¢
478. Anonymus.

The Court cannot compel a Sheriff to a≈ø≈øign his Bond; the Party was arre≈øted, and through his default in not returning his Writ, the Defendant died, Per Cur. in this Ca≈øe he ≈øhall not take advantage of his own wrong, but ≈øhall now a≈ø≈øign the Bail Bond, or pay the utmo≈øt Amerciaments, 2 Keble 388. Hill and Browning.
A Bail Bond was di≈øcharged upon motion, the Mony being paid before the return of the Writ, and appearance ordered, 3 Keble 316. Randuls Ca≈øe,

In Det ≈øur Bond, the Defendant pleads Stat. 23 H. 6. and ≈øhews that V. was in Execution, and the Bond made for his deliverance again≈øt the Statute. The Plaintiff replies, tempore confectionis of the ≈øaid Bond, V. was at large, ab≈øque hoc that he was in Pri≈øon tempore confectionis, &c. The Traver≈øe is not good; for one may be in pri≈øon and make a promi≈øe to make a Bond for which he is enlarged, and within an hour after he makes the Bond, the ≈øame is within the Statute, it ought to be ab≈øque hoc that it was made pro deliberatione, 2 Leon, 107. Bowes and Vernon. 2 Keb. 512. Die and Adams.

The Condition was if Thomas Manningham keep the Sheriff without damage again≈øt our Lord the King and one Th. P. and at all times be at the Commandment of the ≈øaid Sheriff as a true Pri≈øoner, and appear before the Ju≈øtices, &c. then the Obligation to be void. The Defendant pleaded the Statute of 23 H. 6. and that the Body of Tho. Mannigham was in Execution upon a Recogni≈øance, and that the Sheriff made the Obligation for the Delivery of the ≈øaid Thomas Manningham, and demanded Judgment ≈øi actio, i. e. if the Plaintiff ought to maintain his Action; this is no good Conclu≈øion of the Plea, he ought to have concluded i≈ø≈øint nient ≈øon fait. For the Statute ≈øaith it ≈øhall be void, and if it ≈øhall be void, then it is void from the beginning, and then it is not his Deed. And farther, the Defendant had not wi≈øely concluded his Plea, for this ≈øpecial Conclu≈øion had ≈øtraitned the Defendant ≈øo, that if the Obligation be void for any other cau≈øe the Defendant ≈øhall not have benefit of it; and yet
becau≈øe it appeared to the Judges on the matter in Law, that the Plaintiff had no cau≈øe of Action, the Court gave Judgment again≈øt him, for the Obligation is void by the Letter of the Statute, for it makes void Obligations taken in other manner, which extends to avoid Obligations for bayling tho≈øe which are contained in the 2d Branch, as tho≈øe in Execution, &c. Plowd. 66, 67. Dive and Manningham. Yet the Condition was that the Defendant ≈øhould appear in B. R. to an≈øwer in a Plea of Tre≈øpa≈øs and ≈øatisfie the Damages. The Defendant pleads the Statute of 23 H. 6. that the Bond was made for his enlargement and i≈ø≈øint not his Deed. The Plaintiff demurs ≈øpecially upon the Conclu≈øion of the Plea, which ought to be Judgment ≈øi actio, and agreed the Plea to be naught, Allen p. 58. Leech and Davies.

Det ≈øur Obligat. dated 25 Sept. The Defendant pleads a Ca. ≈øa. was awarded again≈øt B. who was taken on it 30 Sep. and that the Obligation was made for the enlargment of B. The Plaintiff demurs, and had Judgment becau≈øe it appears the Bond was made before the Arre≈øt and ≈øo could not be avoided by 23 H. 6. but he ought to have pleaded that with a primo deliberat. after the Arre≈øt, Noy 23. Collins and Phillips.

Det ≈øur Bond by the Sheriff dated 13 Junij, the Defendant demanded Oyer of the Condition, which was that if he appear here Veneris prox. po≈øt tres Trin. and pleads Veneris prox. po≈øt tres Trin. was 14 Junij, and that he was impri≈øoned by the Plaintiff till 19 Jun. and that the Obligation ≈øupra fuit primo deliberat. per le def. 19 Junij, ab≈øque hoc that this was delivered as his Deed before
the 19th of June. The Defendant demurs: Per Cur. this is not a good Traver≈øe, it ought to have been, ab≈øque hoc that this was delivered as his Deed before die Veneris prox. po≈øt tres Trin. For if the Traver≈øe ≈øupra be allowed, the Plaintiff ≈øhall be excluded from an≈øwering to the time alledged of the Return, although it be fal≈øe, Siderfin p. 300. Courtney and Phelps, 2 Keb. p. 108, 109, 122. me≈øme Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads to the Sheriffs Bond, that that there was no Writ ever delivered to the Sheriff, and ≈øo would avoid it per Stat. 23 H. 6. The Sheriff after the Writ ≈øent out, but before delivery, takes Security, which per Cur. he may if the Defendant will give it, 1 Keb. 554. Brumfield ver≈øus Penhay.

The Defendant pleads Stat. 23 H. 6. and that he was in Cu≈øtody by Warrant of a Writ returned Veneris po≈øt Oct. Pur. The Plaintiff replied, the Defendant was taken by a Warrant on a Writ returned Sab. po≈øt Oct. Pur. and not by any Writ returned Veneris, &c. The Defendant rejoined that he was in Cu≈øtody by Vertue of a Writ returned Veneris po≈øt Oct. Pur. ab≈øque hoc, that he was taken by any Writ returned Sab. po≈øt Oct. The Plaintiff demurs: Per Cur. this is no Traver≈øe upon a Traver≈øe; and there would be no Traver≈øe in the Replication, which would make an end, but in the Rejoinder it doth, 2 Keb. 105.94. Benn√©t and Philkens, 1 Sanders p. 20. id. Ca≈øe, 3 Keb. 656. Gold and Cutler, 791. Sturges Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads to a Sheriffs Bond taken for his appearance in B. R. die Sab. prox. po≈øt Oct. Sancti Martini, and that he appeared at the day,
and the Court of Common Pleas gave him a day to bring the Record of his appearance by Mittimus out of the Chancery; the Record was certified (viz.) that he appeared Lunae prox. po≈øt 15 Martini, which was after the day, and adjudged good; for if the appearance be the ≈øame Term, it is good, 1 Brownl. 58. Statfield and Grony, 1 Brownl. 74. Carter and Freeman.
To plead an appearance, and not to ≈øay prout patet per Record. is naught, 1 Brownl. 91. Andrews and Robins.

A Condition to ≈øave harmle≈øs a Serjeant at Mace for letting the Defendant go on a Protection of the Lord of Bath. The Defendant pleads the Statute of H. 6. and mi≈ørecites it. The Plaintiff replies he was Bail for the Defendant, and for ≈øaving harmle≈øs of that, it was given the Plaintiff is e≈øtopp'd by the Bond to plead it was in another manner, 2 Keb. p. 278, 334.

The Defendant pleads the Statute, and that it was for Ea≈øe and Favour and not for a ju≈øt Debt. The Plaintiff ≈øaith, it was for a ju≈øt Debt, ab≈øque hoc that it was for Ea≈øe and Favour. Judgment pro Quer. for not joyning I≈ø≈øue, 2 Keb. 554.

Debt on a Bail Bond to appear. Defendant pleads before the day he was taken by Cap. Utl. and deteined till after the day, and ≈øo could not appear. The Plaintiff demurred: Per Cur. it is an ill Plea; for the Party may remove him≈øelf by Habeas Corpus; and all Bail Bonds may be thus avoided, 2 Keb. 622. Jeoffries and Cooper. And the Plaintiff doth but his duty, Siderfin p. 406. id. Ca≈øe.

div.head: A Bond to be a true Pri≈øoner for Fees, &c.
div.p: THE Mar≈øhal takes Bond of one in Execution to be a true Pri≈øoner, who e≈øcapes; Action brought again≈øt him, it is a good Bond, Latch. 143. Sir G. Reynel ver≈øus Elworthy, Poph. 165. Sir G. Reynel's Ca≈øe. The Mar≈øhal≈øey ruled to be enlarged, and this ≈øhall be called within the Rules; and if the Mar≈øhal take a Bond to tarry there it is good, ibid.

A Bond to the Mar≈øhal to ≈øave harmle≈øs from E≈øcapes is void and within the Statute, becau≈øe not a Bond that he ≈øhall continue a true Pri≈øoner, Vid. the Condition, Record and Pleadings, 1 Sanders 160, 161, 162. Lenthale and Cook, 2 Keb. 422. Siderfin 382. me≈øme Ca≈øe.

The Defendant demands Oyer of the Condition, that the Defendant being a Pri≈øoner and in the Cu≈øtody of the Plaintiff, ≈øhall be a true Pri≈øoner, and ≈øhall not make any E≈øcape. The Defendant pleads Stat. 23 H. 6. and ≈øaith, that this Obligation was taken by the Plaintiff colore officii ≈øui, and that it was for ea≈øe and favour to the Defendant. The Plaintiff replies, the ≈øaid Obligation was taken for the better Security of the Defendant, ab≈øque hoc that it was for ea≈øe and favour; the Defendant demurs; Judgment pro Quer. For the intention of the Obligation was for ea≈øe and favour; but traver≈øing this had taken this away, and when the Defendant had ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue offered, and refu≈øed it, and demurs, the Defendant agreed it was not for ea≈øe and favour: a little Evidence in ≈øuch ca≈øe would ≈øerve to prove ea≈øe and favour, Siderfin 283.
Lenthal and Cook. From Queen Eliz. time ≈øuch Bonds have been u≈øually taken, after I≈ø≈øue ≈øuch Bond is good, 2 Keb. 423. To be a true Pri≈øoner, and to pay Fees is void; for it is entire, 10 Cook 100. b.

A Bond to the Warden of the Fleet to be a true Pri≈øoner. Defendant without pleading the Statute ≈øaith, it was for ea≈øe and favour. The Plainiff demurs. This Bond is void at Common Law; this is a publick Law and need not to be pleaded. The Plaintiff ≈øhould have traver≈øed the Ea≈øe. Judgment pro Def. 3 Keb. 320, 361. Oakes and Cell.

The Warden of the Fleet takes a Condition for true Impri≈øonment of M. and to pay all Fees and Chamber Rent. The Defendant pleads the Statute that it was for Ea≈øe. The Plaintiff replies the Provi≈øo, which excepteth the Warden and traver≈øeth not the true Impri≈øonment, it is ill. The Obligation is void at Common Law, and the Defendant need not plead the Statute. The Warden or other Gaoler cannot impo≈øe what Rents they will on their Chambers, 3 Keb. 133, 603. Duckenfield and Wood.

Since 13 Car. 2. c. 2. per≈øons arre≈øted by Proce≈øs out of the Kings Bench or Common Pleas, not expre≈ø≈øing the Cau≈øe out of the Action in the Writ, Bill or Proce≈øs, ≈øhall give Bail-Bond not exceeding the Sum of 40 l. and an appearance entred ≈øhall di≈øcharge a Bail-Bond; yet if the Sheriff take 150 l. Bond in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, it is a Mi≈ødemeanour, but the Bond is not void, 2 Keb. 287, 311. Yet he may bring an Action upon the Statute again≈øt the Sheriff, ibid. p. 311.

Upon a Statute acknowledged and Extent ≈øued, the Sheriff takes Bond of 20 l. for the payment of 10 l. for his Fee, and this was before the Liberate, adjudged the Bond was void; for the Statute of 28 H. 8. gives him an Action of Debt for his Fee, and he mu≈øt not have a double Reward. 1. Becau≈øe he took the Bond before the Liberate. 2. He took his wages before he had done his work, Latch. 10. Ep≈øon's Ca≈øe. A Leafe of a Bailywick contra, 23 H. 6. cap. 10. 3 Keb. p. 678. Ellis and Nel≈øon.

div.head: A Condition repugnant or not.
div.p: IF the Condition be repugnant to the Obligation it ≈øelf, there the Condition is void, and the Obligation is good: As if the Condition be, that the Obligee ≈øhall not ≈øue for the Mony in the Obligation; The Condition is void and the Obligation is ≈øingle; and yet this may be done by a Defea≈øance made after the Obligation, 7 H. 6.44. 21 H. 7.24, 30.

If the Condition be that if the Obligee ≈øhall pay to J. S. 10 l. at ≈øuch a day, then the Obligation being 100 l. ≈øhall be void, otherwi≈øe not, although this was not the intent of the parties, yet the Condition is good; for if the Obligee do not
pay the 10 l. the Obligation is forfeited, 36 H. 6.9. b.

So if the Condition be, that if the Obligor do not pay to the Obligee at ≈øuch a day 10 l. then the Obligation being 100 l. ≈øhall be void, this is a good Condition, and the Obligor may ≈øay in an Action on the Obligation, that he did not pay the 10 l. and ≈øo avoid the Obligation; for though the intent was not ≈øo, yet the words were ≈øo, and it ought to be adjudged upon the words, 39 H. 6.10. cited, 1 Rolls Abr. 419.

A Condition, if the within bounden J. B. ≈øhall happen to dye without I≈ø≈øue of his Body, that then if the ≈øaid J. B. by his la≈øt Will or otherwi≈øe in writing in his life time ≈øhall lawfully a≈ø≈øure, &c. Per Dodderige this is repugnant and impo≈ø≈øible; he ought to dye without I≈ø≈øue fir≈øt and then make the Conveyance; but three Judges contra. The Condition being made for the Benefit of the Obligor ≈øhall have Con≈øtruction according to the intendment of the Parties, and the intention was, that a Conveyance ≈øhall be made by the Obligor in his Life by Will or otherwi≈øe, ≈øo that they ≈øhall remain and be a≈ø≈øured to, &c. Jones Rep. p. 180. Eaton and Laughter.

The Condition was, if the Defendant pay the Plaintiff 2 s. per Week until the full Sum of 7 l. 10 s. be paid (≈øcilioet) on every Saturday, and if he fail of payment at any one day, that then the Bond to be void. The Defendant pleads, he did not pay at ≈øuch a day, the Plaintiff demurs: Per Cur. the Condition is repugnant and void, and the Obligation ≈øingle, Siderfin H. 14 & 15 Car. 2. pl. 14. Vernon and Al≈øop, Vid. Siderfin 456. Maleverer and Hawksby contra, 1 Keb. 356, 415, 451. Vernon's Ca≈øe.

div.head: A Condition impo≈ø≈øible. What ≈øhall be ≈øaid a Condition impo≈ø≈øible, and the Effect of it.
div.p: IF the Condition of an Obligation be, that the Obligor ≈øhall a≈ø≈øign to the Obligee a Commi≈ø≈øion of Bankrup≈øy, this is an impo≈ø≈øible Condition and therefore void, and the Obligation ≈øingle, for it is impo≈ø≈øible to a≈ø≈øign the Commi≈ø≈øion, 1 Rolls Abr. p. 419. Street and Daniel.
If a Condition be quod debet pluere cras, this is a good Condition, for he hath taken it upon him at his peril, and it is not impo≈ø≈øible in it ≈øelf, 22 E. 4.26.
If a Condition be that the Obligor ≈øhall go from St. Peter's Church in We≈øtmin≈øter to St. Peter's Church in Rome within three hours, this is impo≈ø≈øible and void, Co. Lit. 206. b.

If the Condition be to ≈øave harmle≈øs the Obligee again≈øt a Stranger of an Obligation in which the Obligee ≈øtood bound to the Obligor, this is a good Condition; for although by no po≈ø≈øibility the Stranger may have to do with this, yet if he will ≈øave harmle≈øs again≈øt him, it is within the Condition, for it may be he had ≈øome fear of damage by him, Quaere de hoc, 1 Rolls Abr. p. 420.
Where the Condition is impo≈ø≈øible the Bond is ≈øingle, contrary where a man is charged by Act in Law, 2 Leon. 189. in Wood's Ca≈øe.

If the Condition of an Obligation or Feoffment be impo≈ø≈øible at the time of the making it, the Condition is void and the Obligation ≈øingle, becau≈øe
the Condition is ≈øub≈øequent; but if a Condition precedent be impo≈ø≈øible at the time of the making, there all is void, becau≈øe nothing pa≈ø≈øeth before the Condition performed, Co. Lit. 206. 1 Rolls Abr. 420.
Ca≈øualties that hinder performance ≈øhall not excu≈øe, as Floods hindring appearance, or being impri≈øoned, Lit. Rep. 88, 97, 115. Melvin's Ca≈øe, 41 E. 3. double pl. 77. 2 E. 4.2.

div.head: The Effect of a Condition impo≈ø≈øible, and how it ≈øhall excu≈øe.
div.p: IF the Condition of a Bond or Recogni≈øance, &c. be impo≈ø≈øible at the time of the making the Condition, the Obligation, &c. is good and ≈øingle, as a Condition to go to Rome in three hours, the Condition is void and the Obligation is good. So if I am bound in an Obligation with a Condition to ≈øtand to the award of J. S. provided that the Award be made before the 10th day of May next, and provided I have warning 15 days before the 10th day of May, and this Obligation is made the 9th day of May, this is a void Condition. So the Condition is that I will be non≈øuited in ≈øuch an Action, or a≈ø≈øure ≈øuch a piece of ground, when in truth there is no ≈øuch Action or piece of ground, this Condition is void, and the Obligation remains ≈øingle and good.

But in all Ca≈øes when the thing to be done by the Condition of a Bond or Recognizance, &c. is po≈ø≈øible at the time of the making the Condition, and before the ≈øame can be performed the Condition becomes impo≈ø≈øible by the Act of God, or of
the Law, or of the Obligee, in this ca≈øe the Obligation is ≈øaved; and the Obligation and Condition are both become void.

1. By the Act of God. If a Man be bound with a Condition that he ≈øhall appear the next Term in ≈øuch a Court, and before the day the Obligor dieth, hereby the Obligation is ≈øaved, Cro. Eliz. p. 277. Trop and Bedingfield. Pleaded before the ≈øaid Fea≈øt J. dies, Judgment ≈øi actio, a good Plea, the Condition is di≈øcharged and the Obligation void, 15 H. 7.2.13. If J. H. had been bound with him, then he mu≈øt have done it, Qu. So the Act of God may di≈øcharge the performance of the Condition. If he that is let to Mainpri≈øe be dead before the day, his death excu≈øeth the Mainpernors, Water Plaintiff Perry and Spring Defendants, 1 Rols Abr. p. 449. If A. recovers det vers B. en Bank, and B. brought a Writ of Error, and found Mainpernors to pro≈øecute with Effect, and after dies before the Return of the Writ, this Act of God ≈øhall excu≈øe the Mainpernors, 1 Rolls Abr. tit. Condition, p. 450. Middleton and Twine. If a Man becomes Bail for another in an Action, and after the Plaintiff recovers again≈øt the principal, and the Capias again≈øt him is returned non e≈øt inventus, and this is filed, and after the principal dyes before any Scire Fac. ≈øued out again≈øt the Bail, yet this ≈øhall not excu≈øe the Bail; otherwi≈øe, if he had died before the Capias returned and filed, 1 Rolls Abr. tit. Condition, p. 450. Timberly and Booth, and Calf and Davies, and Hobbes and Donca≈øter.

A Condition to pay yearly 40 l. during the Life of, &c. at the Fea≈øt of St. Michael and the Annunciation or within 30 days after every of the ≈øaid Fea≈øts; the Wife dyes within the 30 days, this ≈øhall di≈øcharge the payment due at the Fea≈øt before her death, Crook Eliz. p. 380. Price and Williams.

If a Condition con≈øi≈øts of two parts in the di≈øjunctive, in which the party had Election which of them to perform, and both are po≈ø≈øible at the time of making the Condition, and the one becomes impo≈ø≈øible after by the Act of God, the Obligee is not bound to perform the other part; for that otherwi≈øe his Election ≈øhall be taken away by the Act of God; and the Condition is for the advantage of the Obligor and ≈øhall be taken beneficially for him. One was bound, that if after Marriage he and his Wife ≈øold the Lands of the Wife, if then he did in his Life time purcha≈øe to his ≈øaid Wife and her Heirs Lands of ≈øuch Value, or el≈øe do and ≈øhall leave to her as Executrix, or by Legacy, or other good A≈ø≈øurance, as much Mony, &c. He married her and ≈øhe dyed and he ≈øurvived her, he is excu≈øed from the Bond, 5 Rep. 22. Laughter's Ca≈øe, Crook Eliz. 398. me≈øme Ca≈øe.

But if a Condition con≈øi≈øt of two parts, whereof one was not po≈ø≈øible at the making of the Condition to be performed, he ought to perform the other; as if the Condition be to enfeoff J. S. or his Heirs when he comes to ≈øuch a place, he is bound to enfeoff J. S. when he comes, for that the other is not po≈ø≈øible, for he may not have an Heir during his Life, and ≈øo he had not any Election, 21 E. 3.29. cited in Laughter's Ca≈øe.

If the Condition of an Obligation be to enfeoff two before ≈øuch a day, and one dies before the day, yet he ought to enfeoff the other, 1 Rolls Abr. tit. Condition, p. 451. Horn and May. Vid. contra Expre≈ø≈øement, Bendl. p. 8. n. 31. Dyer 347. pl. 10.15 H. 7.13. 5 Rep. 22, &c.
If the Condition be to enfeoff J. S. within a certain time, if J. S. dies before the time be pa≈øt, the Obligation is di≈øcharged, 1 Rolls Abr. 451.

I am bound to enfeoff the Obligee at ≈øuch a day, and before the ≈øaid day I dye, my Executors ≈øhall not be charged with it, for the Condition is become impo≈ø≈øible by the Act of God, for the Land de≈øcended to the Heir, 2 Leon. p. 155. Kingwel and Chapman.

2. By the Act of the Law. If a Man be bound in a Recogni≈øance for the appearance of another in a Scire-Fac. he ≈øhall not avoid this Recogni≈øance by ≈øaying, that he which ought to appear was impri≈øoned at the day, 1 Rolls Abr. p. 452. 2 Leon. p. 189. Wood and Avery.

If a Man be obliged to repair an Hou≈øe or build a Mill, he is excu≈øed, if the Obligee will not ≈øuffer him to do it; or if a Stranger by the Command of the Obligee di≈øturb him, and will not ≈øuffer him, 1 Rolls Abr. 453.3.4.5.

A Condition that the Son of the Obligor ≈øhall ≈øerve the Obligee ≈øeven years, if he tender the Son and the Obligee refu≈øe, it is no Forfeiture; 22 E. 4.26. 2 E. 4.2. So if he take him, and after within the Term command him to go from him, Vid. ibid. 1 Rolls Abr. 455.

If the thing to be performed by the Condition may not be performed without the pre≈øence of the Obligee, there his ab≈øence ≈øhall excu≈øe the performance, 12 H. 4.23. b. cited 1 Rolls Abr. 457. As if the Condition be to make a Feoffinent to the Obligee. Aliter, if it be to enter into a Statute to the Obligee, for that may be performed in his ab≈øence.

A Condition to enfeoff the Obligee, though the Obligee di≈ø≈øei≈øe him of the Land, yet this ≈øhall not excu≈øe the performance of the Condition, for he may re-enter and perform it; but if he keep it with force till after the day of performance, it ≈øhall excu≈øe, 1 Rolls Abr. 453, 454. Frances's Ca≈øe, 8 Rep. 92.
If the Obligor by his own Act hath made the Condition impo≈ø≈øible, it is a Forfeiture, 4 H. 7. 3, 4. Vid. Keilway p. 60. Abbot of Gla≈ø≈øenbury's Ca≈øe.
Where a Refu≈øal of one of the Obligors ≈øhall be a Refu≈øal of both.

Two are bound in a Statute with Defea≈øance, that they two ≈øhall make ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance as ≈øhall be devi≈øed, &c. If an A≈ø≈øurance be devi≈øed and tendered to one, and he refu≈øe to ≈øeal this, the Condition is broken by both; for he need not make Reque≈øt to both at one time, 1 Rolls Abridg ‚Ä¢
454.13.

The Condition is to pay 20 l. to the, &c. or before ≈øuch a day render the Body of a Stranger, &c. ≈øo as the Plaintiff may declare again≈øt him; the Defendant pleads, before the day the Stranger died, a good Plea, though the Obligor undertakes for a third per≈øon, which differs from Laughter's
Ca≈øe. Payment or Tender are to be at the ≈øame time, therefore a di≈øcharge of one, a di≈øcharge of both. Contra, if the Acts were to be done at different days. The Condition was to run a race, or pay by a day, and adjudged that the Defendant was di≈øcharged by the death of the Hor≈øe, 3 Keb. 738, 761, 770. Warner and White.

If one is bound to pay 20 l. before the 1≈øt day of May, or to marry A. S. before the 1≈øt of Aug. if he do not pay the 20 l. before the 1≈øt of May, and A. S. dies before Augu≈øt, ≈øo that it is become impo≈ø≈øible; yet the Obligation is for≈øelted. Quaere, He hath undertaken to do one, and it was in his power, Crook Eliz. p. 864. More's Ca≈øe.

3. By the Act of the Obligee. If A. be bound to B. that J. S. ≈øhall marry Jane G. by ≈øuch a day, and before the day B. him≈øelf marry with Jane G. hereby the Obligation is di≈øcharged, and B. ≈øhall never take advantage of it, Co. Lit. 206. a ‚Ä¢ b.
If the Obligee be party to an Act that hinders the performance of the Condition, it ≈øhall excu≈øe, 4 H. 7.4. b.

One is bound to ≈øtand to the award of, &c. he may countermand the Arbitrators; but then he forfeits his Bond, becau≈øe the Obligor by his own Act hath made the Condition of the Obligation (which was endor≈øed for the benefit of the Obligor to ≈øave him from the penalty of the Obligation) impo≈ø≈øible to be performed, and by con≈øequence his Obligation is become ≈øingle, and without the benefit or help of any Condition, becau≈øe
he hath di≈øabled him≈øelf to perform the Condition. If one be bound in an Obligation with a Condition that the Obligor ≈øhall give leave to the Obligee for the time of ≈øeven years to carry Wood, &c. though he give him leave, yet if he countermand it or di≈øcharge the Obligee, the Obligation is forfeited, 8 Rep. 82. b. Viniors Ca≈øe.
Refu≈øal at the day ≈øhall ≈øave the penalty, 1 Rolls Abridg. 448. Vid. Tender and Refu≈øal. Shep. Touchston p. 393.

One is obliged to another to the u≈øe of a third per≈øon to deliver a Che≈øt to the ≈øaid third per≈øon, who refu≈øed to receive it upon the tender at day, the Obligation is ≈øaved, it being to the u≈øe of the third per≈øon, and he ≈øhall not take advantage of his own act, Carne and Savery cited in Hui≈øh and Phillip's Ca≈øe, Crook Eliz. 754.

A Bond is delivered to J. S. to my u≈øe, and when it is tendered to me I refu≈øe, hereby it is become void and cannot afterwards be made good; ≈øo if an Obligation be made to my Wife and I di≈øagree to it, 5 Rep. 119. Whelpdale's Ca≈øe, Ander≈ø. 1 Rep. p. 4.

A Bond forfeited by the default of the Obligor, as a Surrender of a Term, Vid. Poph. p. 39. Forth and Holborough, Crook Eliz. 313. me≈øme Ca≈øe. The Condition was, whereas Dr. Drury had let Land to the Defendant for 17 years, if the Defendant or his Executors paid to D. G. (a Stranger) 10 l. yearly during the ≈øaid 17 years, if he or his A≈ø≈øigns ≈øhall and may ≈øo long occupy the Lands. The Defendant pleads, that he within five years ≈øurrendred the Lands to Dr. Drury. Action lies; for tho he ≈øurrendred, yet as to a Stranger, his E≈øtate is not determined.

div.head: Condition in≈øen≈øible and uncertain.
div.p: THE Condition was (upon Oyer) That whereas the above bounden, &c. ≈øhall and will, &c. where the ≈øame ≈øhould have been, if the above bounden, &c. ≈øhall and will, &c. this per Cur. is a void Condition, the ≈øame being in≈øen≈øible and not compul≈øory, as it ought, and ≈øo the Obligation is ≈øingle, 2 Bul≈øtr. 133. Marker and Cro≈øs.

If an Obligation be made by A. to B. with a Condition, that A. ≈øhall keep B. without damage again≈øt J. S. for 10 l. in which the Obligee is bound to the Obligor, this Condition is void and the Obligation ≈øingle. So if A. be bound to B. with a Condition to ≈øave him harmle≈øs, and doth not ≈øay for what, or again≈øt whom, 39 H. 6.10. 1 Sanders p. 65. Butler and Wig.

The Condition of, &c. is ≈øuch, That if, &c. then the Condition of this Obligation ≈øhall be void; the la≈øt words are in≈øen≈øible and void, and the Condition is good, though the≈øe words then this Obligation ≈øhall be void had been left out, 2 Sanders 78. Maleverer and Hawksby.

div.head: Condition Copulative.
div.p:
A Condition, that if the Plaintiff enjoyed ≈øuch Land till the full age of J. S. and if J. S. within a month after his full age made a≈ø≈øurance to the Plaintiff of the ≈øame Land, that then, &c. The Defendant pleads J. S. is not yet of full age, and becau≈øe he did not an≈øwer whether he had enjoyed it in the mean time, and the Condition is
in the copulacive; it was adjudged pro Querente, Crook Eliz. p. 870. Waller and Croor.

If the Condition be in the copulative, and it is not po≈ø≈øible to be ≈øo performed, it ≈øhall be taken in the disjunctive; as if he and his Executors ≈øhall do ≈øuch a thing, this is in the disjunctive, becau≈øe he may not have an Executor in his Life; ≈øo if he and his A≈ø≈øigns ≈øhall ≈øell certain Lands, 1 Rols Abridg. 444.

A Condition to make A≈ø≈øurance of Land to an Obligee and his Heirs, and after the Obligee dies, it mu≈øt be made to his Heirs, the Copulative ≈øhall be intended a Disjunctive, 1 Rols Abr. 450, 451. Horn and May.

div.head: Condition Disjunctive.
div.p: IF a Man be bound to perform all the Covenants in an Indenture, if all are in the affirmative, he may plead generally performance of all; but if any be in the negative, he ought to plead to them ≈øpecially, and to the re≈øt generally. So if any of them are in the Disjunctive he may ≈øhew which of them he had performed, and if any are to be done on Record, he ought to ≈øhew this e≈øpecially, Doct. pl. 58. Co. Lit. 303. b.

The Condition was, if he paid the Rent re≈øerved at the Fea≈øts mentioned in the Lea≈øe, or within ten days, or within ≈øix months (according to a later agreement) that then, &c. The Defendant pleads the Indenture verbatim, and that he hath performed all the Covenants, Payments and Agreements contained in the Indenture ≈øecundum formam & effectum Indenturae & Conditionis
praed. it is ill; for he cannot plead payment generally, for he hath Election to pay it at which of tho≈øe days he will, Crook Car. 421. Horn and Barber.

If the Condition be in the disjunctive he need not to an≈øwer but to one generally, and that is true where the Condition goes in defea≈øance of the Obligation. Aliter, where the Condition not being performed makes the Obligation good, there the Disjunctive ought to be perform on both parts, per Brian, 4 H. 7.12, &c.

Upon intention of Marriage. If Abigail ≈øurvive J. S. and if ≈øhe do not receive within two years after the death of J. S. 200 l. either by his la≈øt Will or by the Cu≈øtom of London, that then the Obligor ≈øhall pay to the ≈øaid Abigail within one year after the ≈øaid two years 100 l. Abigail ≈øurvived J. S. and ≈øhe died deins two years after his death; per Cur. pro Def. For Abigail dying within the ≈øaid two years, it became impo≈ø≈øible, that this part ≈øhould be performed, by the Act of God, and therefore the Obligor is not bound to perform the other part, Jones 171. Wood and Bates, Palm. Rep. 513. me≈øme Ca≈øe, 9 El. Dyer Elin and Laughter, 1 Rolls Abr. 451. Wood's Ca≈øe. Contra, ideo vide.

The Condition, when the Obligor ≈øhould come to his Aunt he would enfeoff the Obligee or the Heirs of his Body, and the Obligee, when the Obligor came to his Aunt, reque≈øted him to enfeoff him, which the Obligor refu≈øed to do, the Obligation is forfeited! For though the Condition was in the Disjunctive, and the Condition is always for the benefit of the Obligor, yet becau≈øe he was
alive when the Obligor came to his Aunt, and it was not po≈ø≈øible to enfeoff his Heir, therefore he ought to perform ≈øuch part of the disjunctive that then was po≈ø≈øible, 21 Ed. 3.29. b. cited 5 Rep. 112. Mallorys Ca≈øe.

A Condition if the Obligor pay ≈øo much Mony, then the Obligation to be void, or otherwi≈øe it ≈øhall be lawful for the Obligee to enjoy ≈øuch Lands. The Defendant pleads enjoyment, the Plaintiff demurs, adjudged pro Quer. the words concerning the Land being idle, Siderfin p. 312. 2 Keble 131. Ferrers and Newton 117.

div.head: Condition disjunctive.
div.p:
Election of
Obligor,
Obligee.

COndition if he paid to A. or his Heirs annually 12 l. at Michaelma ‚Ä¢
and Chri≈øtmas, or paid to him or his Heirs at any of the ≈øaid Fea≈øts 150 l. then, &c. and demurs, becau≈øe the Obligor hath any time to pay one or other, and that there is not any breach as long as he liveth; ≈øo Action is brought before breach; ≈øed per Cur. though the Obligor hath Election, yet he ought to pay the 12 l. yearly till he pay the 150 l. and becau≈øe he hath not alledged payment of the one or the other, the Bond is forfeited, Cro. Jac. 594. Abbot and Rookwood, and he hath lo≈øt his Election, 2 Rolls Rep. 215. me≈øme Ca≈øe.

Condition if Obligor before M. make a Le ‚Ä¢ ≈øe to the Obligee for 31 ans, if A. will a≈ø≈øent, and if
he will not, then for 21 years, &c. A. will not a≈ø≈øent; the Lea≈øe for 21 years ought to be made before M. Dyer 18 Eliz. 347. 1 Rolls Abr. 446.

Condition to enfeoff the Obligee of D. or S. Obligee hath Election, 18 Ed. 4.17. b. So if it had been upon reque≈øt, or to pay 20 l. or a Pint of Wine upon reque≈øt, ibid. 18 Ed. 4.20, 21. So if it be to go to York, or marry my Daughter upon reque≈øt; for in all the≈øe Ca≈øes the reque≈øt had no other effect but to appoint a time when the Obligor ≈øhould do the one or the other, ibid.

If I am bound to pay 5 l. at the Fea≈øt of P. next, or before, &c. at the reque≈øt of the Obligee; the Obligor hath given his con≈øent that the Obligee ≈øhall have the Election in this Ca≈øe, Dyer 1, 2. M. 108.32. Aliter if it had been to pay 5 l. before the Fea≈øt of P. at the reque≈øt of the Obligee, or at the Fea≈øt of P. there the Obligor had the Election, ibid.

Condition if the Obligor deliver certain Obligations to the Obligee before ≈øuch a day to be cancelled, or el≈øe if he ≈øeal a Deed of Relea≈øe of all Actions which the Obligee ≈øhall cau≈øe to be made by the advice of his Council, and ≈øhall deliver it to the Obligee to be ≈øealed before the day afore≈øaid, &c. both are in the Election of the Obligor, for if the Obligee doth not deliver him any Relea≈øe to be ≈øealed by him, he is not bound to deliver the Bonds, id. Ca≈øe, Cro. El. p. 396, 539. 1 Rolls Abr. 447. Greningham and Ewer, Moor n. 492. And if he had delivered him a Relea≈øe,
then he ought to have Election to deliver the Bonds, or to ≈øeal the Relea≈øe, ibid.

Condition is to deliver ≈øuch Obligation before ≈øuch a day, or to pay to him 10 l. if he reque≈øt this, if he doth not reque≈øt the 10 l. the Obligor ought to deliver the Obligation, for he had not Election until reque≈øt made; but after reque≈øt made he had Election which of them he would do, id. ibid.

Condition was that H. ≈øhould make a Conveyance when he came to twenty one years of Age, or in default thereof the Defendant ≈øhould pay 50 l. the Defendant hath not Election; if he do not the one, he mu≈øt do the other, 1 Keble 230. John≈øon and Bridges.

Condition to deliver to the Plaintiff before ≈øuch a Fea≈øt, ≈øuch a Ship and Tackle, or in default thereof to pay at the ≈øame Fea≈øt ≈øuch a Sum as J. S. ≈øhall value them to be worth; the Defendant pleads before ≈øuch a Fea≈øt J. S. did not value them; upon Demurrer, pro Quer. for though the Obligor hath Election to do the one or the other, yet the Condition being for his benefit, he ought to provide the value ≈øhould be a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, otherwi≈øe he is to deliver the Goods them≈øelves; ≈øo if one be obliged to make ≈øuch an A≈ø≈øurance of ≈øuch Land as the Councel of the Obligee before ≈øuch a day ≈øhall oblige, or to pay there, and then 100 l. If the Councel devi≈øe not any a≈ø≈øurance, he ought to pay the 100 l. Cro. M. 43 Eliz. pl. 42. More and Morecomb.

Condition that the Obligor ≈øhould pay to the Obligee, &c. at the choice and election of the Obligee within a month after the death of J. S.
30 l. or twenty Kine; the Defendant pleads that the Plaintiff within the month after the death, &c. did not make any choice or election: Per C ‚Ä¢ r. its a good Plea, for the Obligor is not boun ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ make a tender of both; and the Election of the Plaintiff ought to precede the Tender of the Defendant, 1 Leon. p. 69, 70. Ba≈ø≈øet and Ke ‚Ä¢ Ca≈øe.

The Defendant was bound to the Lord Li≈øle to ≈øhew his Evidences touching ≈øuch an Hou≈øe, to the ≈øaid Lord or his Councel; the Election was to the Defendant to whom he would ≈øhew them, 18 Ed. 4.15, 17, 20, 21.
Where the Condition is in the Disjunctive, before the day of performance, the Election is to the Obligor; but if at the day he make default, the Election is to the Obligee, 9 Ed. 4.36, 37.

If I am bound to you in a Bond, &c. to pay to you ≈øuch a day 10 l. in Gold or Silver, if you do not make your Election before the day, yet the Duty remains payable; for the thing to be paid is parcel of the Penalty, per Conce≈ø≈øum Curia, in 1 Leon. p. 70.

Condition, if the above bounden J. B. &c. ≈øhall within ≈øix months after the death of, &c. a≈ø≈øure unto the ≈øaid H. B. as the Councel of the ≈øaid H. B. ≈øhall advi≈øe, one Annuity of, &c. during H. B's Life, payable after M's decea≈øe, if the ≈øaid H. B. require the ≈øame at the Dwelling-hou≈øe, &c. or if he ≈øhall not grant the ≈øame, if then the ≈øaid J. B. ≈øhall pay unto H. B. within the time aforementioned 300 l. then, &c. The Defendant pleads the Plaintiff H. B. had not tendred any grant of an Annuity within the time of ≈øix months
after the death of his Mother: Per Cur. the Obligors Election is taken away by the Act of the Obligee him≈øelf, and the Plaintiff by his negligence hath deprived the Defendant of his Election; Judgment pro Defendante, Mod. Rep. 264. Ba≈ø≈øet and Ba≈ø≈øet.

Condition to pay 20 l. after demand, when L. had a Son that ≈øhall or can ≈øpeak the Lords Prayer in Engli≈øh: The Defendant pleads L. had not a Son after the Obligation made qui locutus fuit aut loqui potuit the Lords Prayer; the Plaintiff replied he had a Son qui loqui potuit, &c. its a good Replication, and a good I≈ø≈øue, for the Condition being in the Disjunctive, he may alledge the one or the other at Election; and the power of ≈øpeaking ≈øhall be proved by tho≈øe that have heard him recite it, Cro. El. p. 727. Lane and Goleman.

div.head: Obligation and Condition void by Dure≈øs, Minas.
div.p: DUre≈øs is not intended but where the Party was wrongfully impri≈øoned till he make the Bond, 3 Leon. 239. Knight and Norton.

Dure≈øs pleaded, the Ca≈øe on the Evidence was, Plaintiff charged the Defendant with Felony, for ≈øtealing an Hor≈øe, and procured a Warrant from a Ju≈øtice of Peace, whereby he was taken, and being in Cu≈øtody, upon promi≈øe of the Plaintiff to di≈øcharge him, ≈øealed the Bond, and thereupon was immediately di≈øcharged; and it appeared that the Hor≈øe was the Defendants own Hor≈øe; and Roll directed the Jury that the Bond was gotten by Dure≈øs, the≈øe Proceedings being but to cover the deceipt, Allen p. 92.

The Defendant pleads dure≈øs of Impri≈øonment; its no good Replication for the Plaintiff to ≈øay, that menac't to bring a Suit again≈øt him for Arrears of Rent according to Law, and by Proce≈øs of Law to impri≈øon him if he can, unle≈øs he would ≈øeal the Obligation, for this is not any an≈øwer to the Bar, 16 Ed. 4.7. b.
Its no Plea that it was done by dure≈øs, by a Stranger, without making the Obligee Party to the dure≈øs, Keil. 154. a.

If the Defendant pleads the Obligation was made by dure≈øs of Impri≈øonment, and by Menace of Impri≈øonment, its double, 1 Com. 140. a. 19 Ed. 4.4. declares that the Obligation was made to B. its a good Plea for the Defendant to ≈øay that the Obligation was made to S. by dure≈øs, without any Traver≈øe, for this is but matter of ≈øuppo≈øal, 22 Ed. 4.40. by Jenny.

The Defendant pleads that Roberts was impri≈øoned, and this Bond was given by him and the Defendant for enlargment; the Plaintiff demurred, Judgment pro Quer. this Roberts being no Father, Husband, Wife or near Relation, in which Ca≈øes the Bond would be void, 3 Keble 238. Warn and Sandowne, Dure≈øs. Br. 9.

The Husband may avoid the Deed that he hath ≈øealed by the dure≈øs of Impri≈øonment of his Wife or Son, but not of his Servant; ≈øo Mayor and Commonalty may avoid a Deed ≈øealed by dure≈øs of impri≈øonment of the Mayor, 2 Brownl. 276.

In I≈ø≈øue per Minas the Jury find it was per metum impri≈øonament'. Per Cur. the dure≈øs ought to be pleaded ≈øpecially, but the Verdict being, that the Plaintiff threatned quod impri≈øonaret defendent.
& crimen feloniae ei imponeret ni≈øi, &c. its ill, being no more than by Law he may charge him with, 1 Keble p. 516. Picard and Lawrence.

The Defendant after I≈ø≈øue de dure≈øs at the A≈ø≈øi≈øe, relicta verificatione quod ip≈øe non potest decere actionem, &c. vide the Form of the Entry, and the Error was decere for dedicere, and rever≈øt, Cro. Jac. 343. Anonymus.

Debt by H. I. Executor of S. the Defendant pleads per minas, and after I≈ø≈øue joined before the Ni≈øi prius confe≈ø≈øeth the Action; the Confe≈ø≈øion is in the debuit only, whereas it ought to be in the detinet; Per Cur. after the Defendant hath relinqui≈øhed the Bar, the Declaration remains without defence, and ≈øo pro Quer. Moor n. 921. Joyner, and Ognel.

The Defendant pleads dure≈øs; The Plaintiff ≈øaith to this he ≈øhall not be received, for that at ≈øuch a day after the date of the Obligation, the Obligation was enrolled in Chancery, Cur. pro Quer. in ≈øuch ca≈øe he may not deny his Deed, 16 H. 7.5.

Debt upon Bond in Inferior Court, dure≈øs was pleaded, and no place certain alledged; this may be ill upon a ≈øpecial Demurrer, but is well after a Verdict, there being a place where the Obligation was made infra juri≈ødictionem, and the Party cannot plead dure≈øs unle≈øs where the Bond was actually ≈øealed, 2 Keble 630. Cubit and Green.

The Defendant pleads he made it per minas de vita, &c. the Plaintiff ≈øaid he did it ≈øpontanea voluntate, and traver≈øed the minas. The Plaintiff cognovit Actionem, and vide the Entry, Cro. El. p. 840. Brown and Holland.

div.head: Expo≈øition of Conditions
div.p:
About
payment of Mony,
doing other Acts.

div.head: About payment of Mony.
div.p: Per≈øons to whom to be paid, or performance of other things.
By whom to be paid or performed.
Time of payment or performance.
Place of payment or performance.
