div.head: Per≈øons to whom payment is to be made, or who are a≈ø≈øigns for performance.
div.p: THE Condition is to pay 10 l. to ≈øuch a Per≈øon as the Obligee ≈øhall name by his la≈øt Will, and after the Obligee names none by his Will, the Obligor is not bound to pay this to the Executor, for the Condition hath reference to his nomination, 1 Rolls Abr. p. 421. Tit. Condition, Pea≈øe and Mead, Moor n. 1106. Hob. p. 9. vi ‚Ä¢ Hob. 1 Brownl. 77. contra.

The Condition of the Obligation is to le ‚Ä¢ certain Lands for three Lives to the Obligee of his A≈ø≈øigns, and after the Obligee demands a Le ‚Ä¢ e to be made to three Strangers for their Lives, „Äà‚óä„Äâ ought to do this, otherwi≈øe the Condition is broken, for by the word (A≈ø≈øigns) here is in ‚Ä¢
ed A≈ø≈øigns by nomination, for he may not have other A≈ø≈øigns, for the E≈øtate is not a≈ø≈øignable before
he hath it, 1 Rolls Abr. p. 421. Allen and Wedgwood.

If I am bound to pay Monies to two actually, I can pay this but to one, for that I cannot pay one and the ≈øame Sum to two ≈øeveral Per≈øons at the ≈øame time, per Glyn, 2 Siderfin p. 41. Abbots Ca≈øe.

A Condition to pay to B. and his A≈ø≈øigns 100 l. the Declaration was, that he had not paid this to B. to which exception was taken, for that he might have paid this to his A≈ø≈øigns, and adjudged a good exception, 2 Siderfin p. 41.
Payment to a Scrivener is ≈øufficient, e≈øpecially if he have the Bond in his Cu≈øtody, 3 Keble 471. Jacob and Searles. Q. in 2 Keble 249. Hicks and Loging.
A Condition to pay Mony to the Obligee, and the Pari≈øhioners of D. at ≈øuch a day; payment to the Obligee, and two of the Pari≈øhioners, is good, Moor n. 175.
A Condition is to pay 10 l. its a good performance if he pay this to his Deputy, 42 Ed. 3.13. b.

If Judgment be given in Debt, and the Mony is paid to the Attorny of the Plaintiff, though the Attorny mi≈øcarry with the Mony, yet the payment is good; but if a Scrivener is imployed generally to put Mony to u≈øe for a year, and the Monies are paid to the Scrivener, who breaks, this payment ≈øhall not excu≈øe the Party; but if he receive this by ≈øpecial command, its a good cau≈øe of Equity, Lit. p. 54. Cro. El. 313. Dr. Ford ver≈øus Hollingbrough, Lit. Rep. 156. Manningtons Ca≈øe, Lit. Rep. 173. Par≈øons and Evar.

div.head: What Per≈øons are to pay or do a thing by the Condition.
div.p: IF it be not ≈øet down in the Condition who ≈øhall do a thing, if the Obligee hath more skill he ≈øhall do, or el≈øe the Obligor if he have more skill ≈øhall do it. A Tailor is bound to me, that if I bring him three yards of Cloth which ≈øhall be mea≈øured and ≈øhaped, and if he make ‚Ä¢ e a Cloak of it, and it is not ≈øaid by whom it ≈øhall be ≈øhaped, it mu≈øt be done by the Tailor, Perk. ≈øect. 785.
A Condition of a Bond to pay Mony; if my Servant by my command tender this to the Obligee, this is ≈øufficient, 2 H. 6.3. b.

div.head: Of payment of Mony on a Bond in general.
div.p:
THE Defendant owed the Plaintiff Mony upon on Bond, and al≈øo Mony for Wares ≈øold; at the day of payment of the Bond he tendered the Mony according to the Bond; the Plaintiff accepted it, and ≈øaid it ≈øhould be for the Debt due upon the Contract, and ≈øo cro≈øt his Book; but in Debt upon the Bond it was adjudged again≈øt the Plaintiff, for payment mu≈øt be ≈øecundum ‚Ä¢
tem dantis, non accipientis, Cro. Mich. 29 and 30 Eliz. B. R. Anonymus. Stiles p. 239. Boy ‚Ä¢
and Cranckfield.

Debt is due by Bond, and another Debt is due by the ≈øame Debtor to the ≈øame Debtee of „Äà‚óä„Äâ Sum, and the Debtor pay one Sum generally; this
≈øhall be intended payment upon the Obligation, 2 Brownl. 107, 108.

A Condition to pay yearly ≈øuch Intere≈øt Mony as 20 l. ≈øhall amount to after the rate of 10 l. per cent. when it is ≈øecundum ratam of 10 l. per cent. the Court knows well that is 40 s. per ann. Cro. Jac. p. 378. William≈øon and Hunt.
Payment of a le≈ø≈øer Sum before the day, 2 Keb. 628. Chapman and Wyn. vide plus de hoc infra Tit. Pleading.

div.head: In what Ca≈øes a collateral thing may be given in ≈øatisfaction of a Condition, for payment of ≈øome other thing in lieu of Mony.
div.p: ACceptance of another Bond no good Plea, ≈øo of a Statute, Cro. Car. 85. vide 3 Bul≈øt. 148. 1 Rolls Rep. 266. Foorwood and Dickens.
The Defendant pleads he paid an Hor≈øe in name of the 20 s. or ≈øold Land to the Plaintiff for it; its a good performance, 11 H. 7.21.

If a Man be bound in 20 l. to do a collateral Act, as to make a Feoffment, to be bound in a Statute to render a true account, there Mony or any other thing given in ≈øatisfaction, is not any performance of the Condition, 9 Rep. Peyto's Ca≈øe, 1 Rolls Abr. 455.
But where the Condition is to pay Mony, there any other collateral thing will be ≈øatisfaction, id. ibid.
A Man bound in 200 Quarters of Corn on condition to pay 20 l. a Ring or Hor≈øe, or other thing collateral is ≈øatisfaction, 9 Rep. 79. Peyto's Ca≈øe.
But if the Condition were to pay 5 Quarters Mony or other collateral thing is not ≈øatisfaction, becau≈øe of the original Contract, ib. ibid.

If the Condition be to pay a le≈ø≈øer Sum at the day, if the Obligee agree he ≈øhall pay an Hor≈øe or other thing in ≈øatisfaction, yet if he refu≈øe this at the day, the Obligor ought to pay that le≈ø≈øer Sum at the day, 1 Rolls Abr. 456. vide plus ibid.

A Condition was to pay, &c. on the Birth day of the fir≈øt Child of the Obligee; the Defendant pleads after the Bond entred into, and before the Birth of the Child, the Plaintiff accepted of the Defendant one Load of Lime in full ≈øati≈øfaction of the ≈øaid Debt, and in full di≈øcharge dicti ≈øcripti Obligatorii, its no good Plea, but he might well have pleaded this Acceptance in full ≈øatisfaction of the Sum of Mony contained in the Condition of the Bond, 1 Bul≈øt. 66. Cro. Jac. 254. Yelv. p. 192. 1 Brownl. Rep. 109. Neal and Sheffield.
If a Condition be to build an Hou≈øe of ≈øo much in length, &c. he may not plead another Agreement in other manner in ≈øatisfaction of this, unle≈øs it be by Deed.

Entring a new Obligation with Surety is no di≈øcharge of the fir≈øt, for its but a thing in action, and not pre≈øent ≈øatisfaction, 1 Rolls Abr. 470. Hawes and Burch, Lovelace and Andrews, ≈øo entring into Obligation is no ≈øatisfaction of a Statute, ibid. 12 H. 4.23. b.

A Condition to pay 25 l. at Michaelmas, and the Obligor lets Land to B. the Obligee rendring 35 l. Rent at the ≈øaid Fea≈øt, and after, and before the day of payment concordat. & agreeat. e≈øt,
that the Obligee ≈øhall retain 25 l. of the ≈øaid Rent in ≈øatisfaction of the Bond; and for the re≈øidue he ≈øhall an≈øwer the Obligor; and the Obligor becau≈øe of the ≈øaid Agreement doth not pay the 25 l. at the day, the Obligation is forfeited; this Agreement can be no di≈øcharge, for the Rent at the time of the Agreement was not due, 1 Rolls Abr. 470. Harrington and Andrews.

A Condition to pay 10 l. at a day which is not paid, but after the day the Obligee accepts of a Statute-Staple in full ≈øatisfaction of the Obligation, yet the Bond is in force, and the Obligee had Election to ≈øue which he will, 1 Rolls Abr. 470. Bathaites Ca≈øe, 6 Co. 44. b. Higgens Ca≈øe.

A Condition to pay 100 Marks at a day, and at the day the Obligor and Obligee account together at another place, and for that the Obligee owes to the Obligor 20 l. by other Contract, the Obligee allows the 20 l. in the payment of the 100 Marks; this is a good ≈øatisfaction of the Condition, its payment by way of retainer, 1 Rolls Abr. p. 471, 475.

The Obligor and Obligee before the day of payment agree that the Obligor ≈øhall do ≈øeveral things, and among≈øt others, to a≈ø≈øign his Intere≈øt in the Farm of the Cu≈øtoms of French Wines, and he pleads he hath done all in particular, and ≈øhews how, and it appearing to the Court that he may not by Law a≈ø≈øign his Intere≈øt in the ≈øaid Cu≈øtoms, though the Obligee had enjoyed them, yet this is not a good di≈øcharge of the Obligation, in as much as this is like to an Accord, ≈øo that all ought to be performed, otherwi≈øe its not good, for that the Obligee had not any remedy for this
that is not performed, 1 Rolls Abr. 471. Simons and Mowl≈øtone.

A Condition to pay 20 l. at day, and a Stranger ≈øurrenders a Copy-hold to the u≈øe of the Obligee in ≈øatisfaction of the 20 l. which the Obligee accepts; this is a good ≈øatisfaction, and di≈øcharge of the Obligation, 1 Rolls 471. Grymes and Blofield, vid. cont. Cro. El. 541.

A Condition to appear before the Plaintiff at D. ≈øuch a day; the Defendant ≈øaith he appeared before the Plaintiff at S. before the day, which he accepted of: Cur. pro Quer. becau≈øe the Condition was to do a collateral thing, and the acceptance of another thing cannot di≈øpen≈øe therewith, Cro. Eliz. p. 474. p. 38 Eliz. Nortons Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads J. S. ≈øurrendred a Copy-hold Tenement to the u≈øe of the Plaintiff in ≈øatisfaction of the 20 l. which the Plaintiff accepted; no Plea, for J. S. is a meer Stranger to the Condition, and ≈øatisfaction by him not good, Cro. El. p. 541. Grimes and Blofield.

div.head: Time of payment, or performance, where time is limited.
div.p: IF I pay Mony due upon Bond before the day, I am di≈øcharged, for its a Duty pre≈øently, 9 H. 7.21. a.

The Defendant pleads payment at the day and place according to the Condition, upon which they were at I≈ø≈øue; the Jury find he paid it before the day, and at another place, and the Plaintiff accepted it; Verdict was found for the Defendant, for payment before the day, is payment
at the day, Cro. Trin. 31 El. Bond ver≈ø. Richard≈øon. 1 Leon. p. 311. id. Ca≈øe. 1 Ander≈øon pl. 233.

The Condition was to pay 100 l. on the 31≈øt day of Septemb. the Defendant pleads payment at the day, upon which I≈ø≈øue, and found for the Plaintiff, the payment being impo≈ø≈øible, it ≈øhall be paid pre≈øently; this I≈ø≈øue is aided after Verdict by the Statute 13 Eliz. Latch. p. 158. Gibbon and Purcha≈øe, Cro. Car. 78. Jones 140.

Debt for 300 l. the Defendant pleads he paid the Mony ≈øuch a day, whereas in truth the Ca≈øe was, there were two days of payment limited in the Obligation, and the Defendant had paid part of the Mony on one day, and the re≈øt on the other, and not all on one day; the Plaintiff replies, He did not pay the Mony at the day, &c. I≈ø≈øue and Verdict pro Quer. and in Arre≈øt of Judgment per Rolls, If you have two days of payment to plead, and you relie upon one day in your pleading, and I≈ø≈øue is joined upon that, and it be found again≈øt you, you mu≈øt be barred, Stiles p. 93. Anonymus.

If an Obligation be made the 17th day of November, Anno 12 Jac. And the Condition is to pay 5 l. the 21≈øt. day of November en≈øuing, and 5 l. the 20th day of December next after; the fir≈øt 5 l. ought to be paid the 21 Nov. 12 Jac. for it refers to the day and not to the month, 1 Rolls Abr. 442. Price and Coa.

If a Condition be to pay 10 s. when A. comes to his Hou≈øe, and 10 s. at the Fea≈øt of St. Michael, and then at the Fea≈øt of St. Andrew then next en≈øuing 10 s. the≈øe la≈øt Sums ought to be
paid at the ≈øaid next Fea≈øts or Time, and not at the next Fea≈øts after A. comes to his Hou≈øe, ibid.

If a Condition be to pay ≈øo much citra ≈øuch a Fea≈øt, it ought to be paid on the Eve of the ≈øaid Fea≈øt, and not on the Fea≈øt day; the ≈øame Law is, If it be paid infra Fe≈øtum, or ante Fe≈øtum, but if it be to be paid in Fe≈øto, it mu≈øt be on the Fea≈øt day, 1 Rolls Abr. Tit. Condition, p. 442.

Condition of an Obligation upon an Adventure to New-found Land, to pay ≈øo much Mony within 40 days next after the Ship ≈øhall make her fir≈øt return and arrival this Voyage from New-found Land into the Port of Dartmouth, or into any Harbor, Creek or Part of England where ≈øhe ≈øhall fir≈øt unlade her Goods, and after the Ship doth return to Plimouth, where ≈øhe unlades her Goods, the Obligor is to pay the Monies within 40 days after the arrival of the Ship, and ≈øhall not have 40 days after the unlading of the Goods; for this is not for Fraight, but for an Adventure; and the unlading of the Goods is only mentioned to de≈øcribe the Haven where the Arrival ≈øhall be, and not to put a limitation of payment of the Monies to have 40 days after the di≈øcharge; but perhaps it might be ≈øome doubt, if the unlading was not within 40 days; the Plaintiff ≈øaith, He paid not the Mony within 40 days after the Arrival of the Ship, and avers that the Ship was unladen of the Goods, but no time alledged of the unlading; and per Cur. if it were not unladen with 40 days, it ought to came on the
other part to ≈øhew this, 1 Rolls Abr. Tit. Condition, 442. Leet and Cholwick, Stiles p. 30. id. Ca≈øe.

The Condition was to pay at or before the 29th of September next, at ≈øuch a place; if the Obligor tender the Mony the 28th of September at the place, and the Obligee is not there, its a void Tender, for the Tender is to be the la≈øt day; but if the Obligor meet the Obligee at the place before the day, and then he tenders it, this is ≈øufficient, and Obligee ought to receive it, Cro. El. p. 14. Hawly and Simp≈øon.

A Bill Obligatory to render and pay 1188 Florens, which then amounted to 33 l. 12 s. to he paid id ≈øolutionem Fe≈øti Purification' called Candlema≈øs day next en≈øuing; the Plaintiff in his Declaration avers, that praedictae ≈øolutiones dicti Festi Purification, next after the making of the Bill were according to the u≈øe of Merchants; the 20th day of February; the Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum, and found again≈øt him; in Arre≈øt, re≈øolved, that payment among Merchants is known to be on the 20th of February, and the Judges ought to take notice of it, and the rather, becau≈øe the Defendant by his Plea, confe≈ø≈øeth the Declaration to be true in that Averment, 1 Brownl. Rep. 102. Pear≈øon and Pentes.

The Condition is to pay Anno Dom. 1599. in and upon the 13th of Octob. next after the date hereof at D. where the 13th of Octob. next after the date is long time before 1599. let this ≈øhall be paid in 1599. and not before, for that is fir≈øt expre≈ø≈øed, 1 Rolls Abr. 444. Crook Eliz. p. 420. Hankin≈øon and Kile.

The Condition, if he paid 15 l. at the Fea≈øt of St. Michael next following, and on the Fea≈øt of the Annunciation 15 l. and ≈øo yearly upon the ≈øaid Fea≈øts until H was advanced to a Benefice, that then, &c. The Defendant pleads he was pre≈øented to a Benefice before the fir≈øt Fea≈øt of St. Michael, it is no Plea; for the Advancement di≈øchargeth not the two fir≈øt Summons due at the ≈øaid Fea≈øts: The limitation (until he be advanced) goes only to the other ≈øub≈øequent Payments, Crook Eliz. p. 549. 2 Ander≈ø. 65. Counte≈øs of Warwick ver≈øus the Bi≈øhop of Coventry.

A Condition to deliver 20 Quarters of Corn on the 29th day of February next following, and that Month had but 28 days; per Cur. he is not bound to deliver the Corn till ≈øuch a year comes when February hath 29 days, and that is Leap-year, 1 Leon. 101. Anonymus.

A Condition to pay 20 l. at the Fea≈øt of our Lady, without limiting in certain what Lady-day, whether Conception, Nativity or Annunciation; per Cur. it ≈øhall be intended ≈øuch a Lady-day which ≈øhould next happen and follow the date of the Bond, 3 Leon. p. 7. Anonymus. Quaere.

An Obligation dated 15 May: The Condition was to pay 20 l. the 11th day of May next en≈øuing; this ≈øhall be intented the next 11th day of May, the ≈øame May when the Obligation was made, and not in the next Month of May, 2 Rolls Abr. 255. Crook Jac. 646. Pre≈øcot's Ca≈øe.

A Condition to pay 60 l. on the 25th of June 12 Jac. The Defendent pleads he paid it the 20th of June 12 Jac. The Plaintiff replies, he did not pay it the ≈øaid 20th of June. I≈ø≈øue and Verdict
pro Quer. it is Error; the I≈ø≈øue is taken debors the matter of the Condition, and ≈øo an ill Plea and void I≈ø≈øue, and not aided by the Statute of 32 H. 8. for it may be the Obligation was not forfeited, notwith≈øtanding this Verdict, Crook Jac. 435. Holmes and Brocket.

The Defendant demanded Oyer; which was to pay mony the 31≈øt day of September, where in truth there are not ≈øo many days in September, and he pleads ≈øolvit ad diem upon which they were at I≈ø≈øue; and found for the Plaintiff, and Judgment: For the Condition being impo≈ø≈øible, the Obligation was due pre≈øently; and it was an I≈ø≈øue upon an in≈øufficient Bar, which being found for the Plaintiff, it is helpt by the Statute, as in Nichols's Ca≈øe, in Payment pleaded in Bar upon a ≈øingle Obligation, Jones Rep. p. 140. Jiggen and Purcha≈øs.

The Bond was dated in March, and the Condition was for payment ≈øuper vice≈øimum octavum diem Martii prox. ≈øequentem; per Cur. it ≈øhall be under≈øtood of the currant Month; had it been ≈øequentis perhaps aliter, cited in Modern Rep. p. 112.

One had put him≈øelf an Apprentice to Sell for ≈øeven years, and Sell bound him≈øelf to pay to his Apprentice, his Executors or A≈ø≈øigns 10 l. at the time of the end or determination of his Apprenti≈øhip; the Apprentice ≈øerves ≈øix years and then dyes; per Cur. the Obligation is di≈øcharged. Tho per Cook, if one lea≈øe Land to another for ≈øeven years, if the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould ≈øo long live, and the Le≈ø≈øor obligeth him≈øelf to pay 10 l. at the end of his Term, and he dies within ≈øeven years, the
Mony was pre≈øently due upon his death, 1 Brownl. Rep. fo. 97. Cheney and Sell.

The Condition is that the Obligor before ≈øuch a day ≈øhall make a Lea≈øe to the Obligee for 31 years, if A. B. will a≈ø≈øent to this, and if he will not a≈ø≈øent, then for 21 years; the Obligor mu≈øt make the one Lea≈øe or the other before the day, though A. B. might a≈ø≈øent at any time before the day, Dyer 347. a.

If a Condition be to ≈øtand to the award of J. S. and he awards him to pay 10 l. at ≈øuch a day, this is a good performance if he pay this before the day and the other accept it; for Payment before contains Payment at the day, Berry and Perrin, 1 Rolls Abridg. tit. Condition p. 440. 30 Ed. 3.32. b. So if the Condition be to pay ≈øo much to a Stranger, and he pay it before the day, ibid. So if the Condition be that a Stranger ≈øhall enfeoff a Stranger ≈øuch a day, and he enfeoff him before the day, this is a good performance, ibid.

So if the Condition be to enfeoff a Stranger after the death of J. S. if he enfeoffs him during the Life of J. S. this is a good performance, for that it continues a good Feoffment after his death, 9 H. 7.17, 20.

If the Condition be to make an a≈ø≈øurance within a Month after the date of the Obligation, he is not bound by any reque≈øt to do this at any certain time, but he may perform this at any time within the Month, Perpoint and Thimbleby, 1 Rolls Abr. tit. Condition 441. But if the Condition be to make farther a≈ø≈øurance within a Month upon Reque≈øt of the Obligee, if the Obligee reque≈øt within the Month, and he refu≈øe, though he be ready
afterwards within the Month to do it; yet the Obligation is forfeited, ina≈ømuch as the time of the Month is limited to the Reque≈øt, me≈øme Ca≈øe, ibid.

The Condition of an Obligation is, If the Obligor do at all times hereafter within the ≈øpace of one Month, when he ≈øhall be required, make ≈øuch farther Act and Acts, A≈ø≈øurance and A≈ø≈øurances as the Obligee ≈øhall by his Coun≈øel demand, &c. then, &c. If the Obligee do not demand any farther A≈ø≈øurance within the Month after the making of the Obligation, yet the Obligor is bound to make farther A≈ø≈øurance within a Month after Reque≈øt made after the Month pa≈ø≈øed after the making the Obligation; for that the fir≈øt words, at all times hereafter, are without limit, and the other words, within one Month when he ≈øhall be required, refer to the Reque≈øt; and it is not like the common Covenant to make farther a≈ø≈øurance within ≈øeven years; for U≈øage hath interpreted this that he ≈øhall not be farther troubled after ≈øeven years, H. 1650. Wentworth and Wentworth, 1 Rolls Abr. 441.

The Latitat is ret. die Lunae prox. po≈øt Sanct. Trin. which was the 10th of July, the Sheriff arre≈øts him the 10th of July, and takes Bond the ≈øame date with Condition to appear coram Dom. R. die Lunae prox. po≈øt cra≈øt. Trin. it ≈øeems he ought to appear the ≈øame day and not that day twelve month, 1 Rolls Abr. 444. May and Hooper.

If A. be bound 1 May with a Condition to pay to B. 10 l. at the Fea≈øt of St. Michael, without ≈øaying more, this ≈øhall be intended the Fea≈øt of St. Michael next en≈øuing, 1 Rolls Abridg. 444. Lewknor and Smalwood.

div.head: Payment or Performance where no time is limited: Pre≈øently, or within convenient time.
div.p: IN the Condition of a Bond for payment of Mony no time is limited, it is to be paid pre≈øently, this is, within convenient time: So in other Conditions which concern the doing of tran≈øitory Acts, as delivery of Charters, &c. Aliter of local Acts, Vid. puis, 6 Rep. 30. b. Bothies Ca≈øe, Co. Lit. 208. a. 38 E. 3.12. Crook Eliz. p. 798. No≈øe and Bacon, Popham p. 198. Sir Rob. Brown's Ca≈øe.
If the Condition be to pay a certain Sum to a Stranger without limiting any time, this ought to be within a convenient time, 1 Rolls Abr. tit. Condition fo. 437. the Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter's Ca≈øe.

The Condition was if the Defendant did ≈øell the Tithes in R. that he ≈øhould pay the Plaintiff ≈øuch a Sum of Mony; but if he ≈øold them not, then he ≈øhould deliver an Obligation to the Plaintiff for the payment of an expre≈øs Sum at a certain day: Moved in Arre≈øt, that he had not convenient time, and it appeared not by the Record that he had; but per Cur. there was convenient time between the date of the Bond and bringing the Action, e≈øpecially a ≈øecond thing being to be performed, Stiles p. 11. William≈øon and Henly.
If the Condition be to make a Retraxit of a Suit, he ought to do this within a convenient time. So if it be to acknowledg ≈øatisfaction in ≈øuch a Court, 6 Rep. 30 Bothies Ca≈øe, 1 Rolls Abr. 436.
If the Condition be to perform the award of J. S. who awards the Obligor to pay 10 l. without limiting any time, he ought to pay this within time convenient, 22 E. 4.25.

A Covenant to make farther a≈ø≈øurance at all time and times, and the Covenantee advi≈øeth he ≈øhall levy a Fine, he ≈øhall have convenient time to do it; for the words, at all times, ≈øhall have a rea≈øonable Con≈øtruction, 1 Rols Abridg. 441, Perpoint and Thimbleby.
A Condition to make an Obligation to the Obligee by the advi≈øe of J. S. of 40 l. immediately, yet he ≈øhall have rea≈øonable time to do this, 18 E. 4.21.
Where by the Condition a thing is to be performed upon demand, yet he ≈øhall have rea≈øonable time to perform this after demand, 15 E. 4.30.

div.head: During the Lives of the Parties, not before Reque≈øt.
div.p: WHere by the Condition the Act to be done to the Obligee is of its own nature local, as to make a Feoffment, &c. there the Obligor (no time being limited) hath time during his Life to perform it, if the Obligee doth not ha≈øten the ≈øame by Reque≈øt; for this is collateral and not like to payment of Mony, Crook Eliz. 798. No≈øe and Bacon. Yet when the Obligor may do that that is local in the ab≈øence of the Obligee, as to acknowledge ≈øatisfaction in the Court of Kings Bench, there he mu≈øt do it in time convenient, Co. Lit. 208. a. 6 Rep. 30. b. Bothes Ca≈øe.

The Condition is to do ≈øuch Acts, &c. for the better a≈ø≈øurance, &c. to B. that ≈øhall be devi≈øed by B. or his Coun≈øel, &c. B. devi≈øeth a Relea≈øe. A. not being lettered de≈øires to ≈øhew it to Coun≈øel before he ≈øeal it; he ≈øhall not be allowed rea≈øonable time to ≈øhew it, he having taken it upon him to do it, Co. 2 Rep. Man≈øer's Ca≈øe p. 1. 1 Rolls Abr. 440.
If the Condition be pay without limiting any time, he is not bound to pay before Reque≈øt, 1 Rolls Abr. 438. Qu.

A Condition to make a≈ø≈øurance before the 10th of March, and if the Obligee refu≈øe the a≈ø≈øurance, and ≈øhall make Reque≈øt to have 100 l. in ≈øatisfaction of it, then if upon ≈øuch Reque≈øt within five Months after he pay it, then, &c. he refu≈øed the a≈ø≈øurance, and ten years after he makes Reque≈øt to have the 100 l. Per Cur. it is good, and he may make Reque≈øt during his Life, Crook Eliz. p. 130. Boyton and Andrews, Id. Ca≈øe, 1 Leon. p. 185.
The Condition is to do a thing upon Reque≈øt, the Plaintiff mu≈øt make Reque≈øt to the per≈øon, and not by Proclamation giving notice of the Reque≈øt, 1 Rolls Abr. 443. Gruit and Pinnel.
Reque≈øt to, &c. Bridgm. Rep. 39. Allen and Wedgwood, 1 Rolls Rep. 373. Crook Eliz. p. 62. Gallies Ca≈øe, Keilway 95.

div.head: Place of Payment or Performance: Where a Place is limited.
div.p: A Condition to pay Mony at London, the Action laid in Shrewsbury, 2 Leon. 37. Jay's Ca≈øe.
If the Condition of an Obligation be to appear coram Ju≈øticiariis apud We≈øtm. he ought to appear in B. and not in B. R. Mu≈øgrave and Robin≈øon, 1 Rolls Abr. tit. Condition, 445.
If a place of Payment be limited by the Condition, he is not bound to pay this in any other place, 17 E. 3.16. 1 Rolls Abr. 445.

If a place be limited by the Condition where it ≈øhall be performed, the othere is not bound to receive this in another place. If the Condition be to come to A. at Dale to aid him with his Coun≈øel, it is not performed if he tender his Coun≈øel at the day at another place, 1 Rolls Abridg. p. 446.

In Debt on an Obligation to pay at the Hou≈øe of Y. in Wood≈øtreet magna. The Defendant pleads payment at the Hou≈øe of Y. generally, and the Vi≈øne is from the Pari≈øh of Wood≈øtreet generally. Verdict and Judgment pro Quer. It is no Error, it is only in Fact, and ≈øhould have been pleaded, 1 Keb. 440. A≈øhburnham ver≈øus Braham.

The Condition was, if he paid ≈øuch a Sum of Mony at Newton Petrarch, that then, &c. The Defendant pleads payment at the day at Newton praedict. the Venire Fac. being at Newton only. A Ven. de novo was awarded, Crook Jac. p. 326. Dennis Ca≈øe.
A Condition to pay 10 l. at S. ≈øuch a day, or 10 l. at S. ≈øuch a day, tender at D. the fir≈øt day ≈øaves the Condition, 22 Ed. 4.52. 1 Rolls Abr. 444.
A Condition to pay 10 l. at D. if the Obligee accept this at another place, it's a good performance ≈øans fail, 1 Rolls Abr. 456.11.

div.head: Where no Place is limited.
div.p: IF no place be limited in the Condition for payment of the Mony, he mu≈øt tender the Mony to the per≈øon of the Obligee; but if the Condition be to deliver 20 Quarters of Wheat or 20 Load of Timber, &c. The Obligor before the day mu≈øt go to the Obligee, and know where he will appoint to receive it, and there it mu≈øt be delivered.
If the Condition be to make a Feoffment, it is ≈øufficient to tender it upon the Land, for there the Livery mu≈øt pa≈øs, Co. Lit. 210. b.
If the Obligee be out of England, he is not bound to ≈øeek him, ibid.

If a Man be bound to pay 20 l. at any time during his Life at a place certain, the Obligor cannot tender the Mony at the place when he will, for then the Obligee ≈øhould be bound to a perpetual attendance; but the Obligor mu≈øt give the Obligee notice that at ≈øuch a day he will pay the Mony, and the Obligee mu≈øt attend there to receive it; for if the Obligor then and there tender the Mony, he ≈øhall ≈øave the penalty of the Bond for ever, Co. Lit. 211. a. But if the Obligor at at any time meet the Obligee at the place, he may tender the Mony, ibid.

There is a difference between a place of payment limited in the Obligation, and a place limited in the Condition of the Obligation. For if I am bound to you in 20 l. to be paid at D. if I pay it to you at another place, this ≈øhall not excu≈øe me; but if I am bound in 20 l. on Condition
that I ≈øhall pay it you at D. if I pay this 20 l. at another place, it is good if you receive it, 11 H. 7.17. 9 H. 7.20. b. Lord Cromwels Ca≈øe. If the Mony be paid at any other place and received before the day, it is good, Cook Lit. 211. a.
A. is bound to B. that C. ≈øhall enfeoff D. ≈øuch a day, C. is bound to ≈øeek D. to give him notice and reque≈øt him to be on the Land to receive the Feoffment, ibid.

Debt upon a Bond for payment of Mony, there being no place named in the Obligation where it ≈øhall be paid. The Defendant pleads, the Plaintiff was beyond Sea at the day of payment, and ≈øaith not uncore pri≈øt: Per Cur. this a good cau≈øe of demurrer, Siderfin p. 30. H. 12 & 13 Car. 2. B. R. Hob≈øon and Rudge.

A Condition for a common Chirurgeon to in≈øtruct his Apprentice in his Trade, and to keep him in domo ≈øua propria & ≈øervitio. If he ≈øend him a Voyage to the Ea≈øt Indies to exerci≈øe his Trade, it is a Forfeiture; but he may ≈øend him to any place in England to a Patient. Aliter, if it were a Merchants Apprentice, 1 Rolls Abr. tit. Condition, p. 445. Coventre and Bo≈øwel.
The Le≈ø≈øee is bound by an Obligation to pay the Rent, the Le≈ø≈øee is not bound to ≈øeek the Le≈ø≈øor, to tender it on the Land, Hobart p. 8. Baker and Spain.

In Debt on an Obligation to pay at the Hou≈øe of one Y. in Woodstreet magna. The Defendant pleads payment at the Hou≈øe of Y. generally, and the Vi≈øne is of the Pari≈øh of Wood≈øtreet generally. Verdict pro Quer. and Judgment. It is no
Error, it is only in Fact, and ≈øhould have been pleaded, 1 Keble p. 440. A≈øhburnham ver≈øus Braham.

Debt in an inferior Court, the Condition was for the payment of Mony at a time, but no place was limited in the Condition for the payment thereof. Judgment pro Quer. 'Twas Error, becau≈øe there appears no place of payment: So that by that it cannot appear whether the cau≈øe of Action lyeth within the Juri≈ødiction of the Court where the Action was brought or not; therefore it ≈øhould have been made appear by ≈øome part of the Record, that the Mony was to be paid within the Juri≈ødiction of the Court, which is not here done, and therefore Judgment erroneous, Stiles p. 2. Ma≈øterman's Ca≈øe.

Judgment in the Court at Barn≈øtaple upon an Obligation, and a≈ø≈øigns for Error, that the Condition was to pay Mony at W. which is not within the Juri≈ødiction of the Court. Per Rolls, if it appear by the Declaration that the Mony was to be paid out of the Juri≈ødiction of the Court, the Judgment is not good, and it is not nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øwear this Plea, Stiles p. 225. Dudeney and Collier.

In Debt on a Bill of 40 l. to be paid at H. (which is out of the Juri≈ødiction of the Court of Jernemutha) being in the County of the City of N. which is Error, the Count being upon payment generally, 1 Keb. p. 378. Anni≈øon and Perkin.

A Condition to perform Articles, one whereof was to pay Mony, which the Plaintiff ≈øhould di≈øbur≈øe in compo≈øition of a Fine ≈øet on the Defendant
by the Judges of A≈ø≈øize. The Plaintiff averred he had paid 50 l. ad recept. ≈øuam apud We≈øtm. and ≈øaith not in Com. Midd. The Defendant demurred, the Averment was ill, 2 Keb. 204 An≈øly and An≈ølow.

div.head: Condition to pay Mony upon Marriage.
div.p: THE Condition was to pay 100 l. to the Plaintiff on his Marriage-day. The Defendant pleads, he had no notice given him of his Marriage-day. Ill Plea, for no notice need to be given, 2 Bul≈øtr. 254. Selby and Wilkin≈øon.

A Condition to pay 300 l. in con≈øideration of a Marriage between the Plaintiff and his Daughter; which 300 l. was to be paid within three Months after that he ≈øhall come to the age of 18 years, or within 18 days of the Marriage after notice made, which ≈øhall fir≈øt happen. Per Cur. the notice ≈øhall relate to both, becau≈øe it is uncertain which of them ≈øhall happen fir≈øt, Latch. p. 158. Read and Bullington.

In Debt on a Bond to pay Mony upon Marriage; the Jury may try Wife or not Wife, but not the Legality of Marriage; and it need not be alledged that the party was married at the time of the Bill. The I≈ø≈øue here is not legitimo modo maritatus, as in Dower, which ≈øhall not be tryed by a Jury; but in Debt on Bond it doth not draw the Right of Matrimony in que≈øtion, 1 Keb. 105. Tr. 13 Car. 2. Gla≈øcock and Morgan.

div.head: Conditions to pay Mony concerning Children or Ba≈øtards.
div.p: THE Condition was for the payment of Childrens Portions when they married or came to the age of 21 years. The Defendant pleads that he had paid the ≈øame cum & quam cito they came to their full age generally. It is an ill Plea, he ought to have ≈øhewed the time when they came to age, and when he paid this Mony, that ≈øo upon this I≈ø≈øue might be taken, 2 Bul≈øtr. 267. Haul≈øey and Carpenter.

A Man was bound to pay to the three Daughters of a Stranger 10 l. a piece at 21 years of age. The party being ≈øick makes his Will, and in performance of the Covenant (for which he was bound in an Obligation) devi≈øed to each of the Daughters 10 l. to be paid at 21. One ≈øues for her Legacy, and a Prohibition was granted; for the intent of the Devi≈øe was, he ≈øhould not be twice charged, More n. 368. Margery Davies Ca≈øe.

A Condition for the payment of 120 l. at the full age of J. B. if it be demanded. The Defendant pleads, the Plaintiff did not demand it after the full age of J. B. Judgment for the Plaintiff; for the bringing the Action is a ≈øufficient demand, Crook Jac. p. 242. Dockray and Tanning.

The Condition was to pay 10 s. weekly ≈øecundum ordinem fact. per Ju≈øticiar. &c. for keeping a Ba≈øtard Child. The Defendant ≈øur Oyer pleads nullum talem ordinem fecerunt. Judgment pro Quer. Otherwi≈øe, if it had been ≈øecundum ordinem
faciend. Latch. p. 125. Jermin and Randal, for the one is an E≈øtoppel to the Defendant, the other is Executory, Noy p. 79. vide plus ≈øub Tit. Conditions to ≈øave harmle≈øs.

div.head: A Condition to pay Mony upon proof, or if ≈øuch a thing be proved, then, &c.
div.p: A Condition to pay within three months next after his Arrival from Rome 10 l. the Obligee proving the ≈øame by Te≈øtimonial or Witne≈ø≈øes; the proof might be by Witne≈ø≈øes or Te≈øtimonial under the Seal of ≈øeveral Per≈øons at Rome, Moor n. 307.

The Condition was, If ≈øuch Lands be proved to be parcel of the Mannor of Dale, if then, &c. the Defendant pleads they were not proved to be parcel of the Mannor, and demurs; Per Cur. he ought to have pleaded they were parcel of the Mannor, ≈øo as proof might have been made in this Action, Cro. Eliz. fol. 232. Elve and Sabe, Judgment pro Quer. Vide plus ≈øub Tit. Apprentices Bonds.

div.head: Special Conditions for payment of Mony on Contract, Agreements, Contingency, &c. and pleadings thereon.
div.p:
A Condition to pay 300 l. to the Plaintiff, and to add 3 l. to every Hundred if it were demanded; the Defendant pleads he paid the 300 l. and that he added 3 l. to every hundred, ≈øecundum formam Conditionis praedict. Verdict. pro Quer. but Judgment pro Defendente upon Arre≈øt,
becau≈øe the Plaintiff ought to have alledged a Demand; and this being matter of ≈øub≈øtance, without which the Plaintiff had no cau≈øe of Action, it was not helped by the I≈ø≈øue or Verdict, though the words (≈øecundum formam Conditionis) ≈øeem to imply a Demand, Allen p. 55. Hill ver≈øus Arm≈øtrong.

A Condition, if the Obligor pay to the Obligee 100 l. within one month after notice of his return from Con≈øtantinople into England, that then, &c. the Defendant pleads no notice was given to him of the return, &c. Verdict pro Quer. Error a≈ø≈øigned, becau≈øe it is not averred that the Mony was not paid, and then no cau≈øe of Action; but per Cur. its no Error; for when the Defendant ≈øaid he had no notice, this is a confe≈ø≈øion per nient dedire, that he had not paid it; and I≈ø≈øue being taken upon a collateral Matter, and found for the Plaintiff, he ≈øhall have Judgment, Cro. El. p. 320. Griffin and Spencer.

The Condition was to pay 40 l. per ann. quarterly, ≈øo long as he was to continue Regi≈øter to the Arch-deacon of C. the Defendant ≈øaith, the Office was granted to A. B. and C. for their Lives, and that he enjoyed the Office ≈øo long as they lived, and no longer; and that ≈øo long he paid the ≈øaid 40 l. quarterly; the Plaintiff replies, The Defendant did enjoy the Office longer, and had not paid the Mony; the Defendant demurs: per Cur. the Replication is not double, for the Defendant cannot take I≈ø≈øue upon the non-payment of the Mony, for that would be a departure from his Plea in Bar, Mod. Rep. p. 227. Gaile and Bets.

A Condition, if they or either of them (two Obligors) upon reque≈øt made, ≈øhould pay for ≈øo many Barrels of Beer as ≈øhould be delivered to them, ≈øo much for every Barrel, as ≈øhould be agreed upon between them, &c. the Plaintiff ≈øets forth he had delivered ≈øo many Barrels of Bear, and agreed for 10 s. per Barrel, which Mony he had reque≈øted of one of the Obligors; he may require payment of one or the other, 3 Bul≈øtr. p. 210. Ratcliff and Clerk.

A Condition to pay ≈øo much per dolium; breach is a≈ø≈øigned for the Defendants non-payment of ≈øo many Tuns, and three Hog≈øheads, which per Cur. is ill; the Condition being not to pay ≈øecundum ratam, as in Needlers Ca≈øe, of the Quire of Paper to write at the rate of ≈øo much per Quire for odd Sheets: Per Hales ≈øo much per Tun mu≈øt be intended among≈øt Traders to include pro rata, for over or under mea≈øure; but here the Breach is a≈ø≈øigned in non-payment of the whole, and ≈øaith not nec aliquam partem inde, 3 Keble Hill. 26 Car. 2 B. R. pl. 105. Ree and Barnes.

A Condition to pay all ≈øuch Sums of Mony as my Lord Chancellor ≈øhould Tax for Co≈øts; Sir Robert Rich reports, he thinks, 170 l. to be a fit Sum; the Chancellor ≈øub≈øcribes, Let Co≈øts be taxed according to the Report; its a good Taxation according to the Condition, Harris and Pecks Ca≈øe.

A Condition to pay the Wi≈øe 50 l. per annum (on ≈øeparation) and for non-payment the Action is brought; on Oyer, it was provided the Wife ≈øhould live at ≈øuch a place as A. ≈øhall appoint; Breach a≈ø≈øigned, that ≈øhe did not live ≈øo; the
Plaintiff replies, there was no place appointed; the Defendant demurs; but this being not a Condition precedent, but a Defea≈øance, there mu≈øt be an appointment, 3 Keble 229. Leech and Beer.

A Condition that G. Deputy Po≈øt-Ma≈øter of Oxon, for ≈øix months, ≈øhould pay all ≈øuch Sums as he received while he continued Po≈øt-Ma≈øter; on Oyer the Defendant pleads performance generally; the Plaintiff replies, G. continued two years longer Po≈øt-Ma≈øter, and ≈øuch a day received ≈øo much, and paid not over: Per Cur. no Action lay, the ≈øix months being pa≈øt, and the continuance after mu≈øt be on new agreement, 3 Keb. 45, 59. Lord Arlington ver≈øus Merick.

A Condition to pay ≈øuch Sums of Mony for Tithes which ≈øhould be levied, and upon Oyer of the Condition the Plaintiff demurs, and the que≈øtion was, whether the≈øe words (which ≈øhould be levied) ≈øhall not be con≈øtrued levied, or to be levied; and whether taxed, levied or a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed be not all one; and agreed by the Court that it is ≈øo.

A Condition, if one who was receiver of his Profits ≈øhould truly pay unto him omnia recepta & recipienda in the ≈øaid Office; the Defendant pleads he had paid all which he had received: Per Cur. he mu≈øt give account of both, 1 Bul≈øtr. 174. Hewet and Painter.

A Condition, that the Defendant ≈øhall pay from time to time the moiety of all ≈øuch Mony as he ≈øhall receive as Executor; the Defendant pleads he paid the moiety of all ≈øuch Sums as came to his Hands ante diem exhibitionis Billae: Per Cur. its
a good Plea without ≈øhewing the particular Sums to avoid ≈øtuffing with multiplicity, and this being from time to time, it would be infinite; but if it had been to pay the moiety of ≈øuch Mony as he ≈øhall receive, without ≈øaying (from time to time) he ought to plead ≈øpecially; and another difference is this, Where the thing lies only in the Defendants notice, as to deliver all the Mony in my Pocket, there I mu≈øt plead ≈øpecially; but here others may take notice of it, and the Plaintiff may reply, the Defendant received ≈øuch a Sum, whereof he had not paid the moiety: But the Ca≈øe of H. 7. If a Baker be bound to deliver over ≈øuch Bread as from time to time he ≈øhall receive, that in an Action again≈øt him, he ought to plead how much he had received, was admitted for Law. Mr. Siderfin makes a Quere of this difference; cave ≈øtudens, I conceive in the principal Ca≈øe it is a di≈øtinction without a difference. 2 Keble 220. Siderfin p. 19. Car. 2. B. R. pl. 18. Church ver≈øus Brownwick.

div.head: A Condition to pay Mony on warning.
div.p:
A Condition for payment of 100 l. the 10th day of January next en≈øuing, on three months warning, (being dated 1 July,) the Defendant pleads he had not warning three months before the Action brought; if the warning be intended three months before any 10th day of January, then it mu≈øt be given by the Obligor. Per Twi≈øden, the 10th day of January may be intended next after three months warning, not next
after the Bond. Per Windham, had the Mony been payable the 10th of January next after the Bond, and three months warning by the Obligee, though that day pa≈øs without warning, yet the Mony is not lo≈øt; but three months warning may be given after to the Obligor, and he is bound to pay, the a≈øcertaining the day being for his benefit; payment may be made any January upon three months warning, 1 Keble 380, 415. Law≈øon and Withrington. Cave.

div.head: Condition to pay Mony at ≈øeveral days.
div.p: A Condition to pay Mony at ≈øeveral days; the Defendant pleads particular payments according to the Condition; the Plaintiff replies, He did not pay at ≈øuch a day certain, & hoc paratus e≈øt verificare; ill conclu≈øion, but its not ≈øub≈øtance, and ≈øo mu≈øt be ≈øpecially demurred to; it ought to be & de hoc ponit, &c. but on performance generally pleaded, the Plaintiff may reply with a particular Breach, & hoc paratus, &c. and leave the I≈ø≈øue to the Defendant, 1 Keb. 759, 766. Charlton and Fine.

If a Man be bound in a Bond, or by Contract to another, to pay 100 l. at five ≈øeveral days, he ≈øhall not have Action of Debt before the la≈øt day be pa≈øt, alit' in Recognizance, Covenant and Promi≈øe. C. L.

The Condition was, If the Obligor pay 100 Marks to the Obligee, during the ≈øeven years next en≈øuing, at two Fea≈øts by equal portions, then, &c. the Defendant pleads he had paid 100 Marks during the ≈øaid ≈øeven years, at the ≈øaid Fea≈øts, and
demands Judgment ≈øi Actio; its a good Plea, for want of the word (yearly) the Obligor is bound to pay but 100 Marks. Benlow. n. 18. durus ≈øermo.

A Condition to pay 400 l. half yearly, per Cur. until Judgment, that a Record is made of the Bond; it may be ≈øued on any later Breach, and the Defendant cannot plead any Breach before; and before Plea pleaded, the con≈øtant Cour≈øe of the Court is to accept tender of the Mony and Charges, 2 Keble p. 553, 555. Stern and Vanburge.

Debt for non-performance of Articles, which were to pay ≈øo much in certain, at two days, per equales portiones; the Defendant ≈øaith, He had paid accordingly; the Plaintiff replies, He had not paid accordingly; the Defendant demurs generally: Per Cur. the Replication is a double Plea, for this goes to both days, 1 Rolls Rep. 112. Sanders and Crawley.

div.head: A Condition to pay Mony on a voyage; and Pleading.
div.p:
TO pay Mony on the return of a Ship; the Defendant pleads, the Ship was lo≈øt before the return; the Plaintiff replies, The Ship returned ≈øuch a day, and that the Defendant did not pay Mony, ab≈øque hoc; that the Ship was lo≈øt; the Defendant demurs, its an ill Traver≈øe, the not payment and return being ≈øufficient without it; its ≈øufficient to ≈øay that the Ship returned ≈øuch a day, and the Plaintiff hath not paid, Et hoc paratus,
&c. 2 Keble 668. Wright and Bradcack.

A Condition to proceed in a Voyage and Return, (the dangers of the Sea excepted) that the Defendant pay in 12 Calendar Months, or if the the Ship be lo≈øt before the return or payment, to be void; the Defendant pleads navis ami≈ø≈øa fuit; the Plaintiff demurs, for the meaning of this Bill of Adventure is a lo≈øs by dangers of the Sea. Per Hales, its ≈øufficient for the Defendant to pur≈øue the words of the Bond, and the Plaintiff ≈øhould have replied, the Ship was lo≈øt by the Defendants default, 2 Keble 768. Boddington and Wotton.

div.head: A Condition to pay Mony yearly during Life.
div.p: A Condition to pay yearly 40 l. to S. during his Life at the Fea≈øts of St. Michael and the Annuntiation, or within 30 days after every of the ≈øaid Fea≈øts; S. dies within the 30 days, this ≈øhall di≈øcharge the payment due at the Fea≈øt before his death, Cro El. p. 380. Prices Ca≈øe.

A Condition to pay yearly, and every year, to Thomas and Dorothy his Wife, during their two Lives, then, &c. the Husband dies, the payment cea≈øeth, the Intere≈øt is not in the cesty que vies; the Husband and Wife are Strangers, and the Intere≈øt of the Bond is in the Obligee, Mod. Rep. p. 187. Slater and Carew.
In re≈øpect of the thing it ≈øelf to be done.

div.head: A Condition to perform Covenants generally.
div.p: IF a Man Lea≈øe a Mannor by Indenture, except ≈øuch a parcel of Land, and in the Indenture there are divers Covenants to be performed on the part of the Le≈ø≈øee, and the Le≈ø≈øee binds him≈øelf in an Obligation to perform all Covenants and Agreements contained in one pair of Indentures, and names the ≈øaid Indentures, and after the Le≈ø≈øee enters into the Land excepted; this is no breach of the Condition, for the Land excepted is not lea≈øed, and it is ≈øo as if it had been named, Dame Ru≈ø≈øel and Gulwel, 1 Rolls Abr. Tit. Condition, f. 431.

If one makes a Lea≈øe for years of a Mannor, excepting a Clo≈øe, rendring Rent; and the Le≈ø≈øee is bound to perform all Grants, Covenants and Agreements contenta expre≈ø≈øa aut recitata in the Indenture, if he di≈øturb the Le≈ø≈øor in the occupation of the Clo≈øe excepted, he has forfeited the Obligation; for when he excepts the Clo≈øe, the other is content with this, and that the Le≈ø≈øor ≈øhall occupy this, and then this is the Agreement, and the ≈øaid word contenta expre≈ø≈øa & recitata, every of them go to the exception as well as to the re≈øidue, Plow. fol. 67. in Dive and Manninghams Ca≈øe.

If a Man let for years, rendring Rent payable payable at Michaelmas and Lady-day, on Condition, that if he does not pay at the ≈øaid Fea≈øt, or within 14 days after, then to re-enter; and the
Le≈ø≈øee binds him≈øelf in an Obligation, with Condition, to perform the Covenants and Agreements of the ≈øaid Lea≈øe; the Le≈ø≈øee pays not the Rent at the Fea≈øt, but within the 14. days, yet the Condition is forfeited, for that the Condition in the Lea≈øe is not parcel of the Re≈øervation, 1 Rolls Abr. Tit. Cond. fol. 431. Middleton and Ratcliff.

The Condition of a Bond for performance of Covenants in an Indenture, doth e≈øtop to ≈øay there is no ≈øuch Indenture; but it doth not e≈øtop to ≈øay there are no Covenants, Mod. Rep. 15. Holloways Ca≈øe.

Where an Action of Debt is brought upon a Bond to perform Covenants in a Deed, and the Defendant cannot plead Covenants performed without the Deed, becau≈øe the Plaintiff hath the original Deed, and perhaps the Defendant took not a counter-part of it; the Court u≈øeth to grant Imparlances till the Plaintiff bring in the Deed, and upon Evidence, if it be proved that the other Party hath the Deed, we admit Copies to be given in Evidence; but in Qu. Imp. the Grant of the Advow≈øon mu≈øt be ≈øhewed, Mod. Rep. p. 266.

If I am bound to perform Covenants, and the Covenants are in the affirmative; if the performance of them be by Matter of Fact, I may recite the Condition, and plead generally that I have performed all the Covenants, and ≈øhall not ≈øhew e≈øpecially the performance of them; as if I am bound to enfeoff the Obligee of, &c. and al≈øo that I ≈øhall give to him an Hor≈øe; in Debt brought upon the Obligation, I ≈øhall ≈øhew the Condition, and ≈øhall ≈øay, perimplevi omnes Conventiones, and ≈øhall not ≈øhew the ≈øpecial matter of the performance,
as that I gave him an Hor≈øe at ≈øuch a place, &c. but if the Condition be in the affirmative, and the performance of this may be tryed by Matter of Record; as if I am bound that I ≈øhall be non-≈øuit in ≈øuch an Action, there I ≈øhall ≈øhew the performance of this e≈øpecially; but if the Condition be in the negative; as that I ≈øhall not go to London before ≈øuch a day, I mu≈øt an≈øwer to this in the negative, 13 H. 7.19. b. 10 H. 7.12. b. vide plus.

A Condition to perform all Covenants, compri≈øed in ≈øuch Indenture; the Defendant pleads he had performed all the Covenants without ≈øhewing how; per Cur. as to all the Covenants which are to be performed in the affirmative, the Plea is good; but where the Plaintiff is to be a Party to the performance; as if I am bound to enfeoff you of two Acres in D. which you ≈øhall a≈ø≈øign; here I mu≈øt ≈øhew how; al≈øo where words are in the di≈øjunctive, it ought to be ≈øhewed ≈øpecially; and a Clau≈øe in the negative mu≈øt be an≈øwered in the negative, 16 H. 7.11. a. vide 26 H. 8.5. cont. as to general performance pleaded.

Upon Oyer of the Condition, the Defendant pleads Covenants performed, and doth not ≈øet forth the Indenture, which per Cur. upon Demurrer he ought; and if he have it not, he may move the Court, and have a Copy thereof: Per Twi≈øden it hath been vexata quae≈øtio heretofore who ≈øhould ≈øet it forth, 1 Keble 127. Walker ver≈øus Gib≈øon. 2 Keble 80. Anonymus.

The Court on an Affidavit by the Attorny, that the Bonds are for performance of Covenants, will order the Defendant to deliver a Copy of the
Covenants to the Plaintiff, that he may reply there are none broken, but not el≈øe but by con≈øent, 1 Keble 653. Pa≈øchal and Jekel.

In Action of Debt, the Defendant pleaded it was for performance of Covenants, and that he hath performed all, not ≈øhewing forth the Indenture, to which the Plaintiff demurred; the Court agreed he mu≈øt ≈øet it forth, 1 Keble p. 415. Lewis and Bull.

Det ≈øur Bond, the Defendant pleads the Condition is to perform Covenants contained in a Pair of Indentures, in which are contained divers Covenants, and recites them which he had performed; the Plaintiff demurs, becau≈øe he ≈øaid not when he pleaded the Indenture hic in Curia prolat' and Judgment pro Quer. and per Coke he might take advantage of this upon the general Demurrer without ≈øhewing cau≈øe, for it is matter of ≈øub≈øtance, 1 Rolls Rep. Duport and Wildgoo≈øe, me≈øme Ca≈øe. 2 Bul≈øtr. 259.

If in Debt ≈øur Obligation, with Condition for performance of Covenants in an Indenture, the Defendant pleads performance generally, this is not good unle≈øs he ≈øhew the Deed and plead this; and it is not ≈øufficient to ≈øhew the Deed when the Plaintiff replies and prays Oyer, becau≈øe the Plea of the Defendant ought to be ≈øpecial, if any of the Covenants are in the negative; and it appears not to the Court whether the Covenants are negative or affirmative until the Deed be ≈øhewn; this hath been a controverted Point in our Books; and in ca≈øe the Party who will plead the Deed had not this, he ought to move the Court, and the Court will order he ≈øhall have the Deed, or a Copy of it,
Siderfin 1. p. 50, 97. Lewis ver≈øus Ball, and p. 425. Tap≈øcot and Wooldridge.
If he pleads performance generally, without ≈øhewing the Indenture, I may demur to it, 1 Siderfin p. 425. Tap≈øcots Ca≈øe.

In Debt on Bond for performance, the Defendant cannot now pray Oyer as heretofore, but mu≈øt plead to the Indenture, and produce it to the Court; mi≈øentry of the date of the Deed upon Oyer, may be amended, 1 Keble 104. Anonymus.

The Defendant pleads it was upon Condition to perform Covenants in an Indenture, hic in Curi ‚Ä¢ prolat. and in truth the Deed was not indented; the Plaintiff had Judgment, 5 Rep. 20 b. Stiles Ca≈øe, Cro. El. 472. me≈øme Ca≈øe.

The Defendant demands Oyer of the Condition, & ei legitur, which was to perform Covenants; the Plaintiff demurs generally, becau≈øe the Defendant ≈øaith not profert hic in Cur. the Indenture; for as the Plaintiff profert hic in Cur. the Obligation on which he declares; ≈øo the Defendant ought to poferre in Cur. the Indenture which he pleads, for otherwi≈øe he may recite this in pleading, and the Plaintiff may not have an≈øwer or remedy; this is aided by the Statute 27 Eliz. being matter of form, otherwi≈øe had it been upon ≈øpecial Demurrer; the Entry upon the Roll always ≈øuppo≈øeth this to be brought into Court per the Defendant, and the Court may compe ‚Ä¢ the Plaintiff to give a Copy to the Defendant, if he ≈øwear he never had any part, or that he hath lo≈øt it, 1 Siderfin p. 208. 1 Sanders p. 8. 2 Keble p. 102. Jevans and Harridge.

A Condition to perform Covenants; the Defendant pleads after the making the Bond, and before the Writ, the Indenture was cancelled by the Plaintiff; ill Plea, for the Bond might be forfeited; he ought to have pleaded performance of Covenants till ≈øuch a day, which day the Indenture, was cancelled, 1 Brownl. 78. Anonymus.

The Condition was to perform all Covenants compri≈øed within certain Indentures bearing even date with the Obligation, (and in truth the Obligation and Indenture were both without date,) Per Cur. they ought to have averred a date of the Obligation, and averred al≈øo that the Indenturs bore the ≈øame date with the Obligation, Anonymus, Noy p. 21.

A Condition for performance of Covenants, whereof ≈øome are void by Common Law, yet it ≈øhall ≈øtand good for the re≈øt; otherwi≈øe where part is void by Statute Law, all is void, Hob. p. 14. Sir Daniel Nortons Ca≈øe, Cro. El. p. 529. Lee ver≈ø. Cole≈øhil.
A Condition for performance of Covenants; though the Covenants broken be relea≈øed, yet the Bond remains under Forfeiture, Hob. p. 168.

Where an Act is to be done according to a Covenant, he who pleads the performance ought to plead it ≈øpecially, otherwi≈øe where it is a permittance, then it is as in the negative, in which Ca≈øe permi≈øit is a good Plea, and then it ≈øhall come on the Plaintiffs part to ≈øhew how the Defendant non permi≈øit, ‚Ä¢ Leon. 136. Littleton and Perne.

If the Defendant pleads generally performance of Covenants, where ≈øome in the negative, and ≈øome in the affirmative; and the Plaintiff doth
demur generally upon it, without ≈øhewing cau≈øe of Demurrer, Judgment ≈øhall be given according to the truth of the Ca≈øe, for that default of Pleading is but matter of form, and is aided by the Statute 27 Eliz. except the Plaintiff for cau≈øe ≈øheweth ≈øome are in the negative, and ≈øome in the affirmative; but if any of the Covenants be in the disjunctive, ≈øo as it is in the election of the Covenantor to do the one or other; then it ought to be ≈øpecially pleaded, and the performance of it, for otherwi≈øe the Court cannot know what part hath been performed, 1 Leon. 311. Oglet horp and Hide.

A Condition was for the performance of Covenants within a certain Indenture, whereof ≈øome of the Covenants were in the affirmative and ≈øome in the negative; he pleaded the Indenture and performance of the all Covenants therein generally; and it was thereupon demurred, and without argument adjudged for the Plaintiff, Cro. El. p.
‚Ä¢ 91. Cropwel and Peachy.

By the cour≈øe of the Court upon Bonds of va≈øt Sums to perform Articles, or Covenants, in Debt for non-performance may be common Bail, or according to the value of the Breach a≈ø≈øigned at the di≈øcretion of the Judges, 1 Keble 124. Siderfin 63. Boothbyes Ca≈øe.

A Condition to perform Covenants and Agreements; one was that the Plaintiff had covenanted with the Defendant, that it ≈øhould be lawful for the Defendant to cut down Wood for Fire-boot and Hedge-boot, without making wa≈øte or cutting more than nece≈ø≈øary; the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns a Breach in that Covenant (which is in truth the Plaintiffs Covenant,) exception was, That the Condition ought but to extend unto Covenants to be performed on the part of the Le≈ø≈øee; non allocatur, it is the agreement of the Le≈ø≈øee, though its the Covenant of the Le≈ø≈øor, 1 Leon. 324. Steven≈øons Ca≈øe.

A Condition for performance of Covenants, one is again≈øt the Statute of buying Offices, the other is a good Covenant, and not concerning that, the Obligation is void in all; but for the good Covenant Action of Covenant will lie, Cro. El. 529. Lee and Cole≈øhil, Q.

Debt on Bond to perform Articles; the Plaintiff Covenants to a≈ø≈øign over his Trade to the Defendant, and that he ≈øhould not take away any of his Cu≈øtomers, and in con≈øideration of performance thereof, the Defendant covenants to pay the Plaintiff 60 l. per annum for Life, and pleads, that after the agreement the Plaintiff before any
thing done did work to J. S. a Cu≈øtomer; the Plaintiff demurs, Judgment pro Quer. this is not a Condition precedent, but the≈øe are mutual Covenants, the Plaintiff need not ≈øtay to wait for performance, perhaps then he may ≈øtay as long as he lives; but as on Bonds of Abritrament on breach of either Party hath remedy, 2 Keble 674. Modern Rep. 64. Siderfin 464. Humlock and Blacklow.
In Debt for performance of Covenants, they mu≈øt be ≈øet out in Latin, Allen p. 87.

div.head: Of A≈ø≈øignment of a Breach on Bonds of Covenant.
div.p: IF Breach be a≈ø≈øigned after the Action brought, its ill; the Defendant demands Oyer of the Obligation, and it was for performance of Covenants; the Plaintiff replies, and a≈ø≈øigns a Breach in non-payment of the Rent the 20th day of June, 17 Car. and the Bill was filed Trin. 17 Car. which Term ended the 14th of June, therefore ill, Siderfin 307. Champions Ca≈øe.

Bond of Covenants to perform the Indenture of a demi≈øe; the Plaintiff declares he made the Lea≈øe the 28th of May to the Defendant, and that po≈øtea ≈øcil. 27th of the ≈øame month of May the Defendant broke the Covenant: Demur, becau≈øe the breach is ≈øet forth before the Lea≈øe began, and ≈øo no cau≈øe of Action; but by Bacon, where the po≈øtea & ≈øcil. are repugnant, as here they are, the po≈øtea ≈øhall be good to ≈øignifie the time of the Covenant broken, and the (≈øcil.) ≈øhall be void, Stiles p. 45. Anonymus.

If an Obligation conditioned for payment of Mony become payable, hanging the Action, this had made the Action good; otherwi≈øe where it is conditioned for performance of Covenants, and there is a Breach pendent the Action, Q. Siderfin, in Champions Ca≈øe, p. 308.

The Plaintiff mu≈øt a≈ø≈øign a Breach to intitle him≈øelf, (except in ≈øome Ca≈øes, vide infra,) on a Bond of Covenants, that the Defendant ≈øhould not deliver po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion to any but the Le≈ø≈øor, or ≈øuch Per≈øons as ≈øhould lawfully recover; the Defendant pleaded he did not deliver, but to ≈øuch Per≈øons as lawfully recovered it; the Plaintiff demurs, Judgment pro Quer. Per Twi≈øden, on affirmative Covenants general pleading of performance is ≈øufficient, and ≈øo on negative; for its ≈øufficient for the Defendant to plead an excu≈øe, and the Plaintiff mu≈øt a≈ø≈øign a breach to entitle him≈øelf, 1 Keble 380, 413. Nicholas and Pullen.

One Covenant was, That J. B. her Heirs, &c. ≈øhould perform Covenants in a Deed Poll, whereof one was, That if I. died before the Plaintiff had ≈øatisfaction on Judgment a≈ø≈øigned, then the Admini≈øtrators de bonis non of H. B. ≈øhould farther ≈øecure that A≈ø≈øignment; the Defendant pleaded performance generally; the Plaintiff replies, ≈øuch a day I. died, and ≈øets not forth any Breach, Judgment pro Defendente, 2 Keble 288, 301. Tru≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢
and Mading.

The Plaintiff is not bound to alledge a ≈øpecial Breach, when the Defendants Plea contains ≈øpeciall Matter. A Condition to perform Covenants in an Indenture, one was, That I. the Defendant ≈øhould permit Guy the Plaintiff from time to time
to come and ≈øee if the Hou≈øe lea≈øed by Guy and K. his Wife were in repair; I. pleads in Bar, that I. B. and K. his Wife were Tenants in Tail of the Hou≈øe, and had I≈ø≈øue; that I. B. died, K. married Guy the Plaintiff, and they two make a Lea≈øe to him for 20 years, and that W. the I≈ø≈øue in Tail ≈øuch a day entred, before which entry the Condition was not broken: Guy replies, That William came with him upon the Land to ≈øee if Reparations, &c. and traver≈øes the entry of William, in manner and form prout, and I≈ø≈øue joined upon the Traver≈øe, &c. and found pro Quer. and Judgment; it was a≈ø≈øigned for Error, that there was not any breach of Covenant in I. a≈ø≈øigned, and ≈øo had ≈øhewn no cau≈øe of Action; but per Cur, he need not in this Ca≈øe, for the ≈øpecial Plea of the Defendant had di≈øabled the Plaintiff, that he could not a≈ø≈øign any breach of Covenant, but of nece≈ø≈øity ought to an≈øwer to the ≈øpecial Matter alledged. Its not like the Ca≈øe of Arbitrament, in Debt on Bond to perform Award, the Defendant pleads nul ‚Ä¢ iel Award, then the Plaintiff in his Replication ought to ≈øet forth Award, and a≈ø≈øign his Breach, becau≈øe the Defendants Plea „Äà‚óä„Äâ general; but if in ≈øuch Ca≈øe the Defendant ≈øhould plead a Relea≈øe of all Demands after the Arbitrament, by which he offers a ≈øpecial point in I≈ø≈øue, there it ≈øufficeth if the Plaintiff an≈øwer to the Relea≈øe without a≈ø≈øigning any Breach, Yelv. p. 78. Hob. cont. ‚Ä¢
Brownl. p 89. Jeffry and Guy. 2 Keb. 46, 74.
‚Ä¢ arch and
‚Ä¢ lacka ‚Ä¢ .

The Condition was, That wher ‚Ä¢
Ed. Tailor had bargained, &c. to the Plaintiff a Clo≈øe, &c. and whereas the ≈øaid Ed. T. hath already ‚Ä¢ ort gaged
to J. S. divers Lands in G. whereby the ≈øaid Clo≈øe is either mortgaged, or ≈øuppo≈øed to be mortgaged, &c. if therefore the ≈øaid Clo≈øe of Pa≈øture at the day mentioned in the ≈øaid Indenture of a Mortgage be redeemed and ≈øet free, &c. the Defendant pleads, the Clo≈øe was not mortgaged to J. S. & ≈øic dicit quod clau≈øum praed. &c. fuit redempt. liberat. & exonerat. &c. the Plaintiff replies, That the ≈øaid Clo≈øe was mortgaged to the ≈øaid J. S. and upon this I≈ø≈øue joined, and found pro Quer. and 'twas moved in Arre≈øt of Judgment that the Replication was not good, for he ought to have replied, quod pignoratum fuit to the ≈øaid Smith, and is not redeemed, for it might be redeemed before the day: Per Cur. its a good Replication. 1. The Defendant hath offered a particular point in I≈ø≈øue, that it was not mortgaged, and the Plaintiff an≈øwers it, when he ≈øaith it was mortgaged, and need not alledge that it was not redeemed; for there ≈øhall never be intended any redemption, becau≈øe the Defendant pleads it was not mortgaged, as J. S. is bound to marry the Daughter of J. D. upon Ea≈øter-day next; in Debt on this Obligation, if J. S. pleads in Bar that the Daughter of J. D. died before Ea≈øter-day, its a good Plea, and its a good Replication that the Daughter was living on Ea≈øter-day, without ≈øaying farther, that he had not married her, becau≈øe a ≈øpecial Plea in Bar is always an≈øwered with a ≈øpecial Replication in the Point alledged. 2. Becau≈øe the Mortgage is ≈øuppo≈øed to be made between a Stranger and the Defendant, to who≈øe Acts of Redemption, &c. the Plaintiff is not privy, and cannot have conu≈øance or notice of theire Acts;
its excellent Learning which hath made me more at large recite it, Yelv. M. 44 and 45 Eliz. R. R. fol. 24. Baily and Tailor, Cro. Eliz. p. 899. me≈øme Ca≈øe, the difference is, ≈øuch pleading after Verdict ≈øhould be good, but not if demurred to; as the Condition was, the Defendant ≈øhould render account of all ≈øuch Goods of A. as came to his hands, or pay his part for them. The Defendant pleads, nothing came to his hands. The Plaintiff replies, a ≈øilver Bowl came to hands; Demurrer; Ill Replication, for he ≈øhould have ≈øaid, and had not paid for it, Siderfin 340. 1 Keb. 275. Hayman and Gerrard.

Though in Obligations (put in Suit) for performance of Covenants, the Breach ought to be more preci≈øe and particular than Actions of Covenants, becau≈øe of the Penalty; yet if what is material and the ≈øub≈øtance of the Covenant be alledged it may ≈øuffice, as a Covenant was, that the Defendant (a Bayliff) ≈øhould not let at large any Pri≈øoner, that ≈øhould be arre≈øted, without Licence of the Plaintiff an Under-Gaoler. The Breach was, that the Defendant had let at large at We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øans licence, &c. ≈øuch an one who was arre≈øted, but ≈øhews not the place or time of the Arre≈øt; Per Cur. he need not, the E≈øcape being the material part of the Covenant, Siderfin H. 12 Car. 2. f. 30. Jenkins and Hancocks.

Debt by a Brewer on a Bond to perform Articles again≈øt his Clark; one was, that the Defendant ≈øhould deliver ≈øuch Ale and Beer weekly as ≈øhould be delivered unto him to ≈øuch Cu≈øtomers as he had in his Charge, and to receive the Monies due for the ≈øame, and ≈øhould accompt with the Plaintiff
every Saturday weekly for ≈øuch Monies he ≈øhould receive; for Breach the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns that the Defendant did not account with him for ≈øuch Monies as he had received on Saturday the 25th &c. Verdict pro Quer. Judgment was arre≈øted; for the Breach was uncertainly alledged, becau≈øe the Plaintiff doth not ≈øhew the Defendant had any Cu≈øtomers in his charge, or who they were, or that he had delivered Ale or Beer to them, or received any Mony of them, Stiles p. 473. Arnold and Floid.

A Covenant that he and his Executors and A≈ø≈øigns would repair a Mill, and alledgeth that the Mill was defective in Reparations, and the Defendant, his Executors and A≈ø≈øigns did not repair it‚ñ™ Def. demurs, becau≈øe he did not alledge that he not his Executors or A≈ø≈øigns did not repair it; for if any of them did repair it, the Action lies not; and per Cur. it is naught: But upon motion of the Court the Defendant waved his Demurrer, and the Plaintiff amended, Crook Eliz. p. 348. Cole and How.
If the breach of the Condition of an Obligation be ill a≈ø≈øigned, the Verdict ≈øhall not aid this Default, Sanders 2 part 179. Hele and Wotton, Kerby and Han≈øaker there cited.

Though the Action be well brought upon the Obligation, yet when it appears the Condition was for performance of Covenants, there can be no cau≈øe of Action without ≈øome Covenant broken, and ≈øo ≈øhall not have Judgment though he hath a Verdict, Hob. 14. in Sir Daniel Norton's Ca≈øe.

div.head: Di≈øability, wherein the Obligor hath di≈øabled him≈øelf to perform the Condition.
div.p: IF a day be limited to perform a Condition if the Obligor once di≈øable him≈øelf to perform this, although he be enabled afterwards before the day, yet the Condition is broken; as if the Condition be to enfeoff me before Mich ‚Ä¢ mas, if before the Fea≈øt he enfeoff another, yet the Condition is broken, 21 E. 4.55.

The Condition is, if he permit and ≈øuffer all his Lands, &c. to de≈øcend, remain or revert to ≈øuch an one his Son immediately after his decea≈øe without any Act, &c. The Obligor ‚Ä¢ ells parcel of the ≈øame Lands, though he purcha≈øe them again, yet the Obligation is forfeited, Benlow. n. 34. p. 9.

Sir A. Main by an Indenture demi≈øeth Lands to Scot for 21 years, and covenants at any time during the Life of Scot upon Surrender of his Lea≈øe to make a new Lea≈øe, &c. and an Obligation to reform the Covenants. Sir A. Main pleads in Debt upon this Obligation, that Scot did not ≈øurrender. Scot replies, that after the ≈øaid Demi≈øe, Sir A. M. had accepted a Fine. ≈øur omi≈øance de droit come ceo, and by the ≈øame Fine grant and renders the Land to the Coni≈øee par 80 ans Defendant demurs: Per Cur. 1. Sir A. M. by the Fine levied had di≈øabled him≈øelf either to take a Surrender, or to make a new Lea≈øe, and ≈øo hath broken his Covenant. 2. Though the fir≈øt Act was to be done by Scot (viz.) the Surrender, and Scot may ≈øurrender (if the term for 80 years be the
Intere≈øt of a future term) yet Scot ≈øhall have his Action without making any Surrender, for after Surrender Sir A. M. cannot make a new Lea≈øe, which is the Effect of the Surrender, he hath di≈øabled him≈øelf, 5 Rep. 20. b. Sir Anthony Mains Ca≈øe, Poph. 109. Benl. n. 121, 125.

So if he di≈øable him≈øelf to perform it in the ≈øame plight, as Feoffee on Condition to re-enfeoff, grants a Rent-Charge, marries a Wife, &c. this is a forfeiture of the Condition, 44 E. 3.9. b. Coke on Litt.
But if the Feoffee on a Condition to re-eneoff a Stranger, and after another recovers the Land again≈øt him by default, yet until Execution ≈øued the Condition is not broken, 44 E. 3.9. b.

One promi≈øeth to perform an Award, which is that he ≈øhall after deliver an Obligation to another in which he is bound to him, without limiting any time when this ≈øhall be performed. If he bring Debt on the Bond, and recover, and after deliver the Obligation, yet this is not any performance of the Condition; for he ought to deliver this as it was at the time of the Award made, Tr. 15 Jac. B. R. 1 Rolls Abridg. 447. Nichl ‚Ä¢
and Thomas.
If no time is limited, if the Obligor be once di≈øabled, he is perpetually di≈øabled, 21 E. 4.54. b. Vid. Ca≈øes del Di≈øability, 1 Rolls Abr. 447, 448.

div.head: Conditions to perform particular Covenants. To make A≈ø≈øurance.
div.p: TO make ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurance as Coun≈øel ≈øhall advi≈øe.

A Condition to make to the Obligee or his A≈ø≈øigns ≈øo good a Lea≈øe as Coun≈øel ≈øhall advi≈øe, and the Obligee appoints him to make a Lea≈øe to J. S. he mu≈øt do it; for it is not, as ≈øhall be advi≈øed by Coun≈øel. Per Coke, if the words were, he ≈øhall make as good a Lea≈øe as Coun≈øel ≈øhall devi≈øe, he ought to have brought a Lea≈øe drawn by the advi≈øe of Coun≈øel, 1 Rolls Abr. 424. 1 Rols Rep. 373. Allen and Wedgwood.

To make ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurance, &c. as the Plaintiffs Coun≈øel ≈øhall devi≈øe; it is not ≈øufficient to plead, he made ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurance, but that the Plaintiffs Coun≈øel devi≈øed ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurance which he had made, Crook Eliz. 393. in Hutchin≈øon's Ca≈øe.

One covenants to make ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurance, &c. as the Plaintiffs Coun≈øel ≈øhall advi≈øe, and he pleads performance of Covenants; he cannot afterwards ≈øay, Con≈øilium non dedit advi≈øantentum, in Specot and Sheer's Ca≈øe, Crook Eliz. 828.

The Defendant covenants to a≈ø≈øure ≈øuch Lands by ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurance, as by the Coun≈øel of the Plaintiff ≈øhall be devi≈øed; the Breach a≈ø≈øigned in this, the Plaintiff cau≈øed ≈øuch an A≈ø≈øurance to be drawn and ingro≈ø≈øed, and put Wax to it, and required the Defendant to execute it, and he refu≈øed. The Defendant demurs; per Cur. it is no Breach, becau≈øe
the Plaintiff him≈øelf devi≈øed it, Crook Eliz. p. 297. More ver≈øus Ro≈øwel.

On Covenant that before ≈øuch a day he would make ≈øufficient E≈øtate of Lands to ≈øuch value to the Plaintiff for term of his Life, as by the Plaintiffs Coun≈øel ≈øhould be advi≈øed. The Defendant pleads he made E≈øtate in Lands of ≈øuch a va ‚Ä¢ , &c. he mu≈øt ≈øhew what E≈øtate was advi≈øed, and what Land, that ≈øo there may be an I≈ø≈øue, 28 H. 8.1. b.

A Condition to make ≈øuch an E≈øtate to the Plaintiff as his Coun≈øel ≈øhall advi≈øe, and ≈øaith Co ‚Ä¢
c ‚Ä¢ lium non dedit advi≈øamentum. It was a Qua ‚Ä¢
whether he ought not to ≈øay, concilium null ‚Ä¢ dedit advi≈øumentum: But it is now ≈øetled, a good Plea, 11 H. 7.23. a. 6 H. 7.4. and need not ‚Ä¢
ledge what per≈øons were of his Coun≈øel, and that they gave no advi≈øe, for the Plea is in the negative; but if he plead, his Coun≈øel gave to him ≈øuch advice, he ought to plead what per≈øons were of his Coun≈øel. Then the Replication was, that J. W. was of the Plaintiffs Coun≈øel and no more and he made ≈øuch advice, &c. which advi≈øement the Plaintiff notified to the Defendant: I≈ø≈øue on the Advice, 6 H. 7.4.

The Defendant by prote≈øtation ≈øaith, that the Plaintiffs Coun≈øel made not any devi≈øe, and pro placito, that he was not required. The Plaintiff ≈øaith, J. S. his Coun≈øel devi≈øed a Relea≈øe, and that he required the Defendant to ≈øeal it and he refu≈øed. The Defendant rejoyns he did not refu≈øe, it is a departure, and the I≈ø≈øue is a Jeofall, 28 H.
‚Ä¢
Dyer 31. b.

The Condition is to make ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance of this Mannor of D. as the Coun≈øel of the other ≈øhall advi≈øe, and the Coun≈øel devi≈øeth that he ≈øhall be bound in a certain Obligation that the other ≈øhall enjoy the Mannor peaceably. He is not bound to perform this, for this is not any a≈ø≈øurance within the intent of the Covenant, 1 Rolls Abridg. p. 423. part 1.

But if a Man be bound to do ≈øuch Acts for the a≈ø≈øurance of the Mannor of D. as the Coun≈øel of the other ≈øhall devi≈øe; and the Coun≈øel advi≈øeth that he ≈øhall make an Obligation or Statute that the other ≈øhall enjoy this, he ought to perform this, 1 Rolls Abr. 431. per Poph.

To make ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurances of, &c. as Coun≈øel of, &c. ≈øhall devi≈øe, and the Defendant by advice of Coun≈øel demanded a Relea≈øe with Warranty. Per Cur. this is not any a≈ø≈øurance, but a means to recover in value, 2 Leon. p. 130. Wy ‚Ä¢
and Throgmorton.

If a Man covenant to make ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance as the Coun≈øel of the Covenatee ≈øhall devi≈øe of an Annuity of 30 l. and of 300 l. in Mony. If the Coun≈øel devi≈øe he ≈øhall make an Obligation to pay the Annuity, and the 300 l. at certain days, he is not bound to perform it, the Obligation being no a≈ø≈øurance of the Annuity, 1 Rolls Rep. 423.

If A. Covenant to make ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance for the payment of 100 l. to R. as his Coun≈øel ≈øhall devi≈øe, and his Coun≈øel devi≈øeth that A. ≈øhall make an Obligation of 1000 l. for the payment of an 100 l. he ought to perform this: Otherwi≈øe, if it had been to make ≈øuch rea≈øon his a≈ø≈øurance as
the Coun≈øel of the Covenantee ≈øhall devi≈øe, 1 Roll ‚Ä¢ Abr. p. 423.

A Conclu≈øion to ≈øeal ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance of Copyhold as ≈øhould be devi≈øed. The Plaintiff devi≈øed that the Defendant ≈øhould ≈øeal a Letter of Attorny made to one to ≈øurrender the Copyhold for him, and al≈øo ≈øeal a Bond for quiet enjoyment. The Defendant may refu≈øe, for he is not bound to ≈øeal the Obligation; and after Verdict, Judgment was arre≈øted, 1 Brownl. p. 93. Stamford and Cookes.

A. covenants with B. to make ≈øuch rea≈øonable a≈ø≈øurance to B. in Fee of ≈øuch Land, re≈øerving to A. and his Heirs 20 s. Rent per annum, as the Coun≈øel of B. ≈øhall advi≈øe, and after B. tenders to A. a Deed poll by which A. ≈øhall enfeoff B. of Land in Fee re≈øerving the ≈øaid Rent to A. in Fee; this is not any ≈øuch rea≈øonable a≈ø≈øurance to bind A. to ≈øeal it, for this is a Rent Seck; and the Deed belongs to the Feoffee, and then A. without the Deed may not have any Remedy for the Rent, 1 Rolls Abr. 423. Guppage and A≈øca ‚Ä¢ . It ought to have been a Feoffment by Indenture rendring Rent, Id. ibid. Sect. 7.

If the Condition be to make ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance in Law of certain Lands to the Obligee as by the Coun≈øel of the Obligee upon Reque≈øt ≈øhall be advi≈øed, and after J. S. was of the Coun≈øel of the Obligee, and gives his advice to the Obligee that the Obligor ≈øhall make a certain a≈ø≈øurance, and the Obligee gives notice to the Obligor of the ≈øaid advice, and requires him to perform it, he ought to perform it; for its more convenient that the Coun≈øel ≈øhould give the advice to the Obligee,
than to the Obligor, for that the Obligor knows not whether he be his Coun≈øel in this matter, 5 Rep. Higgenbotham's Ca≈øe.
A Covenant is to make a Lea≈øe on ≈øuch Covenants as the Plaintiff or his Coun≈øel ≈øhall advi≈øe; the Plaintiff mu≈øt tender this Lea≈øe, 3 Keble 183. Twiford and Buckly.

If the Condition be to a≈ø≈øure certain Lands to ≈øuch a per≈øon which the Obligee ≈øhall name, and after he a≈ø≈øures this to the Obligee him≈øelf, it is a good performance, though it be not alledged that the Obligee named him≈øelf, for this acceptance is a nomination of him≈øelf, 1 Rolls Abridg. p. 424. Hu≈øego and Wild.

div.head: At who≈øe Co≈øts.
div.p: IF the a≈ø≈øurances are to be made at the co≈øts of him to whom they ought to be made, he may require the a≈ø≈øurance to be made by parcels. Aliter, when the Covenantor is to be at the charges; yet there if the party require an a≈ø≈øurance of parcel, the Covenantor mu≈øt do it; but then he is di≈øcharged from making any a≈ø≈øurance of that which remains, Crook Eliz. p. 681. Wa≈øhington's Ca≈øe.

A Condition to make a ≈øufficient Lea≈øe to the Obligee before ≈øuch a day, the ≈øame to be made at the co≈øts of the Obligee: It is a good Plea, that the Plaintiff did not tender the Co≈øts to him, and if then that he was ready, More n. 72.

That the Covenantor at the Co≈øts of the Covenantee would a≈ø≈øure ≈øuch Lands before ≈øuch a day; the Covenantor is to make the a≈ø≈øurance what he plea≈øeth, and ought to give notice what
a≈ø≈øurance he will make, and his readine≈øs, that the other may know what co≈øts he is to tender, Crook Eliz. f. 517. Halling and Connard.
Who to do the fir≈øt Act, as Notice, Reque≈øt, Tender, Vid. infra.

De≈øea≈øance of a Statute, that if E. M. and his Wife before ≈øuch a day ≈øhould make ≈øuch good a≈ø≈øurance of an Hou≈øe to W. with ≈øuch Covenants as he ≈øhould accept and ≈øignifie under his hand to be rea≈øonable, or ≈øhould pay to him ≈øuch a day 350 l. then the Statute ≈øhould be void. E. M. in Audita Querela furmi≈øeth that he and his Wife were always ready to have made the a≈ø≈øurance, and that the Coni≈øee had not ≈øignified what a≈ø≈øurance he would accept, nor required any, and yet he had ≈øued Execution: Demurrer; adjudged for the Defendant. For he is not bound to devi≈øe any a≈ø≈øurance, but it is at his Election to accept the E≈øtate tendred, or the Mony; and there cannot be an acceptance but where there is a tender on the other part. Therefore the Coni≈øor ought to have devi≈øed the E≈øtate, and procured the Coni≈øee to accept thereof, otherwi≈øe he ought to pay the Mony, Crook Eliz. p. 718. Mills and Wood.
A Covenant to make a Lea≈øe on ≈øuch Covenants as the Plaintiff or his Coun≈øel ≈øhall advi≈øe; the Plaintiff mu≈øt tender the Lea≈øe, 3 Keble 183. Twiford and Buckly.

The Covenant is to make a Lea≈øe for three Lives before Michaelmas; the Defendant pleads, that none of the Lives were named by the Plaintiff. The Plaintiff demurs: Judgment was for the Defendant; the Plaintiff mu≈øt name them, 3 Keble 183, 203. Twiford and Buckly.

The Defendant pleads the Condition was, if the Defendant make an E≈øtate to the Plaintiff of certain Land before ≈øuch a day in Fee by Feoffment, Fine or otherwi≈øe, as his Coun≈øel learned in the Law ≈øhall advi≈øe. The Plea was, Concilium non dedit advi≈øamentum. The Defendant is not bound to reque≈øt his Coun≈øel to make advice, and the advi≈øement doth not come on the part of the Plaintiff, but on the part of the Defendant. This is not like the Ca≈øe of Obligors being bound to pay to the Obligee 10 l. or enfeoff him of the Mannor of S. he ought to make tender of the Monies, and in the other Ca≈øe he ough ‚Ä¢ to tender that he will make a Feoffment, becau≈øe all comes from the Defendant, 6 H. 7.4. as in this Ca≈øe. The Plaintiff replies, J. S. was of his Coun≈øel and no more, and he made ≈øuch advice, which advi≈øement the Plaintiff notified to the Defendant, ≈øo it is good, ibid.

If I am bound to make you ≈øuch an a≈ø≈øurance as J. S. ≈øhall devi≈øe, I am bound at my peril to procure notice; but if I am bounden to make ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance, as your Coun≈øel ≈øhall advi≈øe, there notice ought to be given to me, 1 Leon. p. 105. Ca≈øe 141. in Atkin≈øons Ca≈øe.

A Condition to perform Covenants, Breach a≈ø≈øigned, whereas the Covenantor covenanted with the Covenantee, that he at the co≈øts of the Covenantee would a≈ø≈øure ≈øuch Lands unto him before ≈øuch a day, that the day was pa≈øt, and no a≈ø≈øurance tendred by the Covenantor, not co≈øts by the Covenantee. Per Cur. the Covenantor is to make the a≈ø≈øurance, and to give notice what a≈ø≈øurance he will make, and his readine≈øs that the other may
know what Co≈øts to tender, Crook Eliz. 517. Hallings and Connard.
