The Covenantor ought to do the fir≈øt act (viz.) notifie the Covenantee what manner of E≈øtate he will make, ≈øo that the Covenantee may know what Sum of Mony to tender; and it is all one whether the Covenant be general or particular, as to make a Feoffment, &c. and ≈øo if nothing were done before the day, the Obligation is forfeited, 5 Rep. me≈øme Ca≈øe, 22. b. The Obligor having election what manner of a≈ø≈øurance he will make, ought fir≈øt to give notice to the Obligee, that he will make ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance, More n. 595. me≈øme Ca≈øe.

W. covenants for him≈øelf, his Heirs, Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns within ≈øeven years upon Reque≈øt to convey to the Plaintiff a Copyhold E≈øtate for life; W. dies, a Reque≈øt mu≈øt be made to his Executors; though W. was ≈øei≈øed in Fee, the Executors are bound to ≈øee it done, 2 Bul≈øtr. 158. Thur≈ødens Ca≈øe.

A Condition to perform Articles, one was, the Defendant covenanted before ≈øuch a Fea≈øt to make to the Plaintiff and his Wife a Demi≈øe of, &c. Hebendum immediately after the death of E. F. for 30 years; if E. W. to this a≈ø≈øent then Habend. after the death of E. F. for 21 years. The Defendant pleads, E. W. denied his a≈ø≈øent, and farther that the Plaintiff did not require the Defendant to make him the Lea≈øe for 21 years. Demurrer, and Judgment pro Quer. For the Plaintiff need not make Reque≈øt, but the Defendant at his peril ought to have made the Lea≈øe for 21 years before the Fea≈øt, 1 Ander≈ø. n. 124. f. 49. Henry Cage ver≈øus Tho. Furtho.

The Condition is, if the Obligor make all rea≈øonable Acts, &c. which ≈øhall be for a≈ø≈øurance, &c. to be required by the Obligee before ≈øuch a day, &c. a general Reque≈øt is ≈øufficient. Aliter, if the a≈ø≈øurance were to be advi≈øed by the Obligee or his Coun≈øel, there he mu≈øt ≈øhew he had required ≈øuch a particular a≈ø≈øurance, as Fine, &c. and as to this the Ca≈øe was thus; The Condition was, if the Defendant before M. do make, acknowledg and ≈øuffer, &c. all and every ≈øuch rea≈øonable Acts and things what≈øoever they be, for the good, and lawful a≈ø≈øuring and ≈øure making of the Mannor of D. to J. S. and his Heirs, that then, &c. The Defendant pleads, that before M. the Plaintiff rationabiliter non requi≈øivit le def. ad faciend. &c. aliqua rationabilia actum & acta, quae forent pro bona & legitima a≈ø≈øurantia del mannor de D. &c. The Plaintiff replies, that ≈øuch a day before M. he reque≈øted the Defendant quod ip≈øe conveiret & a≈ø≈øuraret manerium de D. al J. S. &c. ≈øecundum tenorem conditionis. And I≈ø≈øue found pro Quer. Moved in arre≈øt of Judgment, that there was no ≈øufficient Breach, for that the Plaintiff ought to have required an a≈ø≈øurance in certain (viz.) Fine or Feoffment; but per Cur. the Condition is broken; for by the Condition the Defendant is to do all and every act what≈øoever, &c. ≈øo that if the Plaintiff reque≈øt a Fine, Recovery, Feoffment, Bargain and Sale, the Defendant ought to do all; but not to make any Obligation or Recogni≈øance for the enjoying the Mannor, for that is but collateral Security and not any A≈ø≈øurance. Then when the Plaintiff reque≈øts the Defendant to convey the Mannor in the generality;
the Defendant ought at his peril to do this by ≈øome kind of A≈ø≈øurance, and if upon this Reque≈øt the Defendant makes a Feoffment of the Mannor, yet if after this the Plaintiff reque≈øt a Fine, he ought to acknowledge a Fine al≈øo, and ≈øo upon every ≈øeveral Reque≈øt, Yelv. p. 44. 1 Brownl. p. 84. More n. 889. Pud≈øey and New≈øam.

The Condition was to make an E≈øtate of Inheritance to the Obligee at ≈øuch a day and place. The Defendant pleads he was ready at the day and place to make it, &c. The Plaintiff demurs: Per Cur. ill Plea, he ought to have ≈øhewed that he gave notice what E≈øtate of Inheritance he would make him, Stiles p. 61. Allen p. 24. Brook and Brook, 5 Rep. 22.
If a Man be bound to make a Conveyance of certain Lands; if a Warranty or Covenant be put into the Deed, he is not bound to ≈øeal it, 1 Rolls Abr. p. 424. ≈øect. 13.

The Condition is to make ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurance to the Obligee, as the Obligee ≈øhall devi≈øe, and after the Obligee devi≈øeth an Indenture, and tenders this to him, and he requires time to ≈øhew it to his Coun≈øel, he mu≈øt ≈øeal it pre≈øently, for the Covenant is peremptory, 1 Ander≈ø. p. 122. Ca≈øe 117. Andrews and Eddon, 1 Rolls Abr. 424. Wotton and Crook, 2 Rep. Man≈øers Ca≈øe.

The Condition is, that he ≈øhall make a good, ab≈øolute, perfect A≈ø≈øurance in Fee of Copyhold Lands, and after he renders this upon Condition of payment of Mony; it is not any performance, for the A≈ø≈øurance ought to be ab≈øolute; ≈øo if it were to make farther A≈ø≈øurance, if he make A≈ø≈øurance
on Condition, it is not a performance, 1 Rolls Abr. 425. Risbon and Gayre.

It mu≈øt not only be an ab≈øolute, but an effectual Conveyance. If a Man be bound to ≈øurrender a Copyhold to the u≈øe of A. and his Heirs on con≈øideration of Mony; if he ≈øurrender into the Tenants hands, he mu≈øt get it pre≈øented, for it mu≈øt be an effectual Surrender; as if a Man be bound to make a Feoffment to me upon Reque≈øt if I reque≈øt him him to make a Deed of Feoffment with Letter of Attorny to B. to make Livery to me, and he doth ≈øo, this is a good inception; yet if Livery be not made, it is a Forfeiture of the Condition, 1 Rolls Abridg. p. 425. Shan and Belby.

A Condition to make a≈ø≈øurance of Lands to the Obligee and his Heirs, and the Obligee dies, yet he mu≈øt make a≈ø≈øurance to the Heir, for the copulative ≈øhall be taken as a disjunctive, 1 Rolls Abr. p. 450. Horn and May. Dubitat. in Jones p. 181. Eaton and Laughter. For it was the intent the Heir ≈øhould take by de≈øcent and not by purcha≈øe.
A Condition to enfeoff two before ≈øuch a day, and one dies before the day, yet he ought to enfeoff the other, 1 Rolls Abr. 451. Horn and May. 5 Rep. 22. a. Benl. n. 31. contra.

A Condition to give and grant to him, his Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns. The Defendant pleads he hath been ready to give and grant; ill Plea, for he mu≈øt plead that he did it. Aliter, if the words had been as Coun≈øel ≈øhould advi≈øe, 1 Brownl. Kep. 75. Chapman and Pe≈øcod.

Condition to enfeoff Lands of ≈øuch an yearly value. The Defendant pleads he enfeoft him of
the Mannor of D. in Com. W. and of the Mannor of S. in the County of S. Cave Replication, for it cannot be tryed, 11 H. 7.14.

One is obliged to a≈ø≈øure 20 Acres of Land, the Acres ≈øhall be accounted according to the E≈øtimation of the Country where the Lands lie, and not according to the mea≈øure limited in the Statute, Cro. Eliz. p. 665. Some and Taylor.

One by Indenture bargains and ≈øells to the Obligee all his Lands in D. and covenants that he will make farther a≈ø≈øurance of all his Lands; the Breach a≈ø≈øigned was, becau≈øe he did not make farther a≈ø≈øurance of tho≈øe Lands; and it appears by the pleading, that the Bargainor had enfeof ‚Ä¢ the Bargainee before all his Lands there; ≈øo as he had not any Lands at the time of the Bargain and Sale; and if he then had not, then the Breach is not well a≈ø≈øigned, and ≈øo held tota Curia. But if one enfeoffs another of his Lands, and afterwards bargains and ≈øells them by name, and covenants to make a≈ø≈øurance, he is bound to make a≈ø≈øurance accordingly, Crook Eliz. p. 833. La ‚Ä¢
and Hodges.

The Condition was, whereas the Defendant had granted an Annuity to the Plaintiff, that the Defendant ≈øhould make farther a≈ø≈øurance to the Plaintiff for the enjoying thereof within one Month when he ≈øhould be thereunto required; the Month ≈øhall begin from the time of the Reque≈øt, Stile ‚Ä¢ p. 242. Wentworth's Ca≈øe.

A Man by Deed, indented, bargained and ≈øold Lands to another in Fee, and covenanted by the ≈øame Deed to make him a good and ≈øufficient E≈øtate in the ≈øaid Lands before Christmas next;
and afterwards before Chri≈øtmas the Bargaino ‚Ä¢ acknowledged the Deed, and the ≈øame is enrolled; per tot. Cur. by the Act the Covenant was not performed, for he ought have levied a Fine, or made a Feoffment, &c. 3. Leon. p. 1. Anonymus.

div.head: Condition of Covenant for quiet Enjoyment.
div.p: D. was bound to H. on Condition that H. and his Heirs might enjoy certain Copyhold Lands ≈øurrendred to him. The Defendant pleads the Surrender, and that the Plaintiff entred and might have enjoyed the Lands. The Plaintiff replies, that after his Entry one G. entred upon him and ou≈øted him. Per Cur. Replication ill, becau≈øe he did not ≈øhew he was evicted out of the Land by lawful Title, for el≈øe he had his Remedy again≈øt the wrong doer, Vaugh. p. 121, 122. Hammonds Ca≈øe.

The Defendant lea≈øed to the Plaintiff an Hou≈øe by the words of Demi≈øe and Grant, which words import a Covenant in Law; and the Le≈ø≈øor covenanteth that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall enjoy the Hou≈øe during the term without Eviction by the Le≈ø≈øor or any claiming under him (which expre≈øs Covenant was narrower than the other) and gave Bond to perform Covenants. The Plaintiff grants his term over to a Stranger. The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigned for Breach, that one S. entred upon the A≈ø≈øignee, and upon Ejectment recovered again≈øt the A≈ø≈øignee. Debt was brought upon this Bond; per Cur. by this Covenant in Law the A≈ø≈øignee ≈øhall have a Writ of Covenant, and for this breaking the Covenant in Law the Obligation was forfeited;
but becau≈øe the Plaintiff did not ≈øhew that S. had an ancient Title, (for otherwi≈øe the Covenant in Law was not broken,) therefore Judgment again≈øt the Plaintiff, 4 Co. Rep. 80. b. Nokes Ca≈øe, Cro. El. p. 674. id. Ca≈øe.

If I. covenanteth with B. to enter into a Bond to him for enjoyment of ≈øuch Lands, and do not expre≈øs what Sum, he ≈øhall be bound in ≈øuch a Sum as amounteth to the value of the Land, 5 Rep. 78. a. in Samons Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads performance of Covenants; the Plaintiff alledgeth a Breach upon this Covenant, that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould enjoy the Land without any lawful interruption or di≈øturbance of the Le≈ø≈øor or his Executors, and ≈øhews that the Executors entred upon him, and ou≈øted him, and ≈øhews not any interruption for a ju≈øt cau≈øe, and adjudged good, 1 Brownl. 80. Ratcliffs Ca≈øe.

Debt on Bond to perform Covenants; the Covenant was for quiet enjoyment, without let, trouble or interruption, &c. the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigned his Breach, that he forbad his Tenant to pay his Rent; Per Cur. its no Breach unle≈øs there were ≈øome other Act, 1 Brownl. p. 81 Witchcot and Live≈øeys Ca≈øe.
Vide Moor n. 156. Broughton and Conrey, Where the Defendant is not bound to warrant peaceable po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion to the Vendee, but only for Acts by him≈øelf done or to be done.

The Condition was, If the Defendant warrant and defend an Ox-Gang of Land to the Plaintiff again≈øt J. S. and all others, that then, &c. Re≈øolved that the word defend ≈øhall be taken as a Defence again≈øt lawful Titles, and not again≈øt
Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes: And per Ander≈øon, one Covenants to make a Lea≈øe of all his Lands in D. and in D. he hath as well Copyhold as Freehold Lands, he is not by this Covenant to make a Lea≈øe of his Copyhold Land, for that he cannot do ≈øans Licence, Moor n. 294. Crocock and White.

An Action is brought again≈øt the Heir of Edmund A. the Condition, Whereas the ≈øaid Ed. A. ≈øuch a day hath granted and given to the Plaintiff the Pre≈øentation to the Church of D. if therefore the ≈øaid Ed. A. from time to time ≈øhall make good the ≈øaid Grant from all Incumbrances made or to be made by him and his Heirs, that then, &c. the Grantor died, the Church became void, the Heir of the Grantor pre≈øented, this tortious Pre≈øentation is no Breach, but this extends only to lawful di≈øturbance by the Heir; for it appears by the pleading the Heir had no right to pre≈øent, his Father having granted that before. Per Hobert the words ≈øhall be con≈øtrued as if it had been ≈øaid that he ≈øhall enjoy the ≈øame from any Act or Acts made by him or his Heirs; and in this Ca≈øe there ought to be a lawful Eviction to make a breach of the Condition; but otherwi≈øe, if the Condition had been that he ≈øhall peaceably enjoy from any Act or Acts made by him or his Heirs, for in this Ca≈øe a tortious di≈øturbance would have been a Breach of the Condition, Winch p. 25. Dr. Hunt ver≈øus Allen.

The Condition was, That he ≈øhould enjoy ≈øuch Lands ≈øans Eviction; the Breach was a≈ø≈øigned in the Recovery by Verdict in Ejectione Firmae, upon a Lea≈øe made by one E≈ø≈øex, and doth not ≈øhew what Title E≈ø≈øex had to make the Lea≈øe,
but avers that E≈ø≈øex had good Title, and it might be he had Title derived from the Plaintiff him≈øelf after the Obligation made, and therefore he ought to ≈øhew that he had good and eigne Title before the Lea≈øe made and in the Exchequer-Chamber the Replication held ill, Cro. Jac. p. 315. Kirby ver≈øus Han≈øaker, 2 Sanders, Hele and Wotton, though this was after a Verdict, 2 Sanders 177, 178. Id.

The Condition was, If the Obligee peaceably enjoy an Acre of Copyhold Land according to the Cu≈øtom of the Mannor; the Defendant pleads by Cu≈øtom of the Mannor the Obligee ought to pay to the Lord a Rent, and for non-payment the Lord to re-enter, and that the Obligee did not pay it, and the Lord entred, and demanded, Judgment ≈øi Actio, bon Plea, Benl. p. 32.

The Condition was to enjoy peaceably again≈øt M. Breach a≈ø≈øigned that M. had entred and cut down five Elms; upon Evidence it was A. Servant of M. by commandment and in the pre≈øence of his Ma≈øter, had entred and cut, and good, 1 Leon. 157. Seaman and Browning.

Debt on Obligation for performance of Covenants; Breach a≈ø≈øigned was, the Defendant Le≈ø≈øor covenanted, that it ≈øhould be lawful for the Plaintiff, being Le≈ø≈øee, quietly to enjoy the Land, and that the Le≈ø≈øor him≈øelf ou≈øted him; this illegal ou≈øter was a Breach of the Covenant, Cro. El. 543. Corus Ca≈øe.

The Condition is, If ≈øuch Lands be di≈øcharged of all Incumbrances made by him, except the E≈øtate and Title of Jointure of his Wife Elizabeth, that then the Breach is a≈ø≈øigned, that the Defendant
before the Obligation made, had ≈øurrendred the≈øe Lands to the u≈øe of Elizabeth his Wife; its no Breach, vide Cro. El. p. 761. Woodward ver≈ø. Dannock.

In Debt on Bond again≈øt Baron and Feme being made in her Widowhood, with Condition that ≈øhe, her Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns keep Contracts and Covenants made between former Husband and his Le≈ø≈øee, the Plaintiff; and there was an Agreement that the Plaintiff ≈øhould enjoy a Warren of the Demi≈øe of the former Husband, and that he entred till put out by the Defendant; I≈ø≈øue on the Agreement, found pro Quer. Jones moved, there was no E≈øtate alledged in the former Husband in jure Uxoris, whereby though the ≈øecond Husband be a≈ø≈øigned in Law, yet he enters of his own wrong, and not as claiming under her; but per Windham, its not requi≈øite that the Husband be A≈ø≈øignee of the E≈øtate, but her A≈ø≈øignee of Contract, 1 Keble 348, 512. Hall ver≈øus Cre≈øwel and his Wife; Judgment pro Quer.

A Covenant to ≈øave harmle≈øs from lawful Eviction; the Defendant pleads performance; the Plaintiff replies, That J. S. took out a Writ of Hab. fac. po≈ø≈ø. in B. I. debito modo exeunt' and by vertue thereof entred and expelled him; per Cur. debito modo is not ≈øufficient without ≈øhewing particulars; he ought at lea≈øt to recite the Term of the Judgment, but not the Title of him that evicted, 1 Keble 379. Nicholas and Pull ‚Ä¢ n.

The Condition was, That the Obligor ≈øhould not enter nor claim a certain Hou≈øe; the Defendant ≈øaid, he did not enter nor claim; the Plaintiff replies, he claimed; no Plea; he ≈øhould ≈øay he
came to the Land; and claimed the Land, and entred into the Land, and nothing ≈øhall be traver≈øed but the Claim, 4 H. 7.13. not the Entry.

A Condition to di≈øcharge a Me≈øuage of all Incumbrances; there one may plead generally that he did di≈øcharge it of all Incumbrances; but if it be to di≈øcharge it of ≈øuch a Lea≈øe, he mu≈øt ≈øhew how, 1 Brownl. 63.

The Condition was, That he ≈øhall ≈øuffer his Le≈ø≈øee for years to enjoy, &c. and that without the trouble of him or any other Per≈øon; a Stranger enters per eigne Title, the Condition is not broken, for this word ≈øuffer is a pa≈ø≈øive, and all the re≈øt is to be referred to this; but if any procurement or occa≈øion of di≈øturbance be by the Le≈ø≈øor, his Executors or A≈ø≈øigns, then he forfeits the Obligation, 2 Ed. 4.2. b. 1 Rolls Abr. 425. Q. 1.

A Man is bound to warrant Lands by Obligation, in Action de Det port, pacifice gavi≈øus e≈øt is no Plea, for its but an Argument that he had warranted, and its but a fallible Argument, for the Party may enjoy peaceably without having Warranty, Dyer 42. b. 43. a. 2 Co. fol. 3.

A Condition peaceably to enjoy from the 1≈øt of Febr. u≈ø
que Michaelmas-day Tithes, paying half yearly during the Term, and on default of payment, the Defendant (Le≈ø≈øor) to be free from all Obligation to the Plaintiff; he replies, he a≈ø≈øigned a Breach in non-payment of Rent at Michaelmas, which is after the Term ended, and ≈øo the Defendant demurs; Al≈øo the ≈øub≈øtance of the Suit is quiet Enjoyment, and therefore ought not to
be taken by prote≈øtation; ≈øed per Cur. enjoyment need not be an≈øwered where its defea≈øanced by payment of the Rent, yet Judgment pro Def. 3 Keb. 594. Biggin and Bridge.

A Condition that he ≈øhall ≈øuffer his Le≈ø≈øee for years to enjoy his Lands during the Term, and that without trouble of him or any other Per≈øon; a Stranger enters per eigne Title; per Cur. the Condition is not broken, for that this word ≈øuffer is a pa≈ø≈øive, and all the re≈øidue is to be referred to this; but if any procurement or occa≈øion of di≈øturbance by the Le≈ø≈øor, his Executors or A≈ø≈øigns, then he hath forfeited the Obligation; a Man is bound to permit Land to de≈øcend to his Son, he need not aver that this had de≈øcended to him, 1 Rolls Abr. p. 425. Q. 1.

A Condition to perform Covenants in a Lea≈øe, one was, That he ≈øhould enjoy ≈øuch Lands let to him quietly, without interruption; and the Plaintiff in his Replication ≈øheweth in facto, that the Defendant the 20th of March, 30 Eliz. had di≈øturbed him, and in that a≈ø≈øigned the Breach; the Defendant by Rejoynder ≈øheweth, that in the Indenture there was a Provi≈øo, that if he paid 10 l. the 31 of March, 30 Eliz. that the Indenture and all therein contained ≈øhould be void, and alledged he paid 10 l. at the day (but this was after the di≈øturbance ≈øuppo≈øed) and the Plaintiff demurs: Judgment pro Quer. for by the Covenant broken before the Condition performed, the Obligation was forfeited; and its not material that the Covenants became void before the Action brought; but by Wray, if the Provi≈øo had been, that upon the payment of the 10 l. as well the
Obligation as the Indenture ≈øhould be void,
‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ . for then the Bond was void before the Action brought; ≈øo where a Par≈øon made a Lea≈øe for years, in which were divers Covenants, and after he became non re≈øident, by which the Indenture became void, yet he may maintain an Action of Covenant for a Covenant broken before his non Re≈øidency, Cro. Eliz. p. 244. Hill and Pilkington, Dyer 57. Bylones Ca≈øe.

The Condition was, If the Obligee, his Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns ≈øhall and may lawfully hold and enjoy a Me≈øuage, &c. without the let, &c. of the Obligor or his Heirs, or of every other Per≈øon, di≈øcharged, or upon rea≈øonable reque≈øt ≈øaved harmle≈øs by the ≈øaid Obligor from all former Gifts, &c. the Defendant pleads no reque≈øt was made to ≈øave him harmle≈øs; Judgment pro Quer. becau≈øe the Defendant hath not an≈øwered to all the the Conditions, (viz.) to enjoying of the Land; and there were two Conditions, (viz.) the enjoying and ≈øaving harmle≈øs, Moor n. 756. Cre≈øwell and Holmes.

Debt to perform Covenants in a Lea≈øe, one was for quiet enjoyment again≈øt all claiming Title; the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns for Breach, that a Stranger entred, but ≈øaith not habens titulum. Hales, habens titulum at that time would have done; Dyers Ca≈øe is, another entred claiming an Intere≈øt, but that is not enough, for he may claim under the Le≈ø≈øee him≈øelf: If the Covenant had been to ≈øave him harmle≈øs again≈øt all lawful and unlawful Titles, yet it mu≈øt appear that he that entred, did not claim under the Le≈ø≈øee him≈øelf, Mod. Rep.
101. 3 Keble 246. Norman and Fo≈øter, Hob. 34. Ti≈ødale and E≈ø≈øex, Moor 861.

The Condition was, if neither J. S. nor J. B. nor J. G. did not di≈øturb the Plaintiff in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of ≈øuch Lands by indirect means, but by due cour≈øe of Law. The Defendant pleads that neither J. S. nor J. B. nor J. G. did di≈øturb the Plaintiff by any indirect means, but by due cour≈øe of Law; Q. if Plea good, 2 Leon. 197. Dighton and Clark.

K. was ≈øeized, and lea≈øed for years to J. H. Husband of I≈øabel; and J. H. being ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, by his Will devi≈øed, that the ≈øaid I≈øabel ≈øhould have the u≈øe and occupation of the ≈øaid Lands for all the years of the ≈øaid Term as ≈øhe ≈øhould live, and remain ≈øole; and if ≈øhe died or married, that then his Son ≈øhould have the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid Term not expired: J. H. died, I≈øabel entred, to whom the ≈øaid Kidwilly conveyed by Feoffment the ≈øaid Lands in Fee, and covenanted that the ≈øaid Lands from thence ≈øhould be clearly exonerated de omnibus prioribus barganiis titulis juribus & omnibus aliis oneribus quibu≈øcun
que I≈øabel married and the Son entred: Per Cur. this po≈ø≈øibility which was in the Son at the time of the Feoffment, though it was not actual, yet the Land was not di≈øcharged of all former Rights, Titles and Charges; by the Marriage of the ≈øaid I≈øabel, its become an actual Charge, and the Term is not extinct by the acceptance of the Feoffment, 1 Leon. p. 92. n. 120. Hamington and Rydear. I am bound in a Statute, and afterwards ≈øell my Land with Covenant prout ≈øupra, here the Land is not charged; but if the Condition in the Defea≈øance
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
be broken, ≈øo as the Conu≈øee extends, now the Covenant is broken, 1 Leon. p. 93. ibid.

On Covenant to enjoy ab≈ø
que legali molestatione of the Defendant; the Defendant pleads performance; the Plaintiff replies, by entry of the Defendant Le≈ø≈øor, which is intended tortious, and and ≈øo no breach, for which cau≈øe the Defendant demurs: Per Moreton, Entry and lawful Entry are all one as to the Le≈ø≈øor; and Rainsford conceived a general Entry no Breach, the general Covenant being re≈øtrained by ≈øpecial Covenant again≈øt any lawful let, 2 Keb. 717. Lee and Dalfton.

Debt on Bond to perform Covenants, one of which was, That the Plaintiff ≈øhould not be interrupted in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of certain Lands by any Per≈øon that had lawful Title, and particularly that he ≈øhould not be interrupted by one Thomas Antony by vertue of any ≈øuch Title; the Defendant pleads performance; the Plaintiff replies 1 No. 20 Car. The Defendant made the Lea≈øe to the Plaintiff, and 3 No. he entred, and that 17 Aug. 20 Car. before the Defendant made a Lea≈øe to Antony for years yet to come, who 20 Aug. 20 Car. entred; the Defendant pleads the Lea≈øe to Antony was on Condition of re-entry for non-payment of Rent, and that before the Lea≈øe made to the Plaintiff the Rent was behind, & legit ‚Ä¢ demandat, ≈øecundum formam Indenturae, and he re-entred, and made the Lea≈øe to the Plaintiff; upon general Demurrer per Cur. the Demand was not ≈øufficiently alledged, for he ought to ≈øet forth when and where it was made, that the Court might know if it were legal; but for a ‚Ä¢ w in the Plaintiffs Replication, becau≈øe he alledged
his Entry after the Lea≈øe made to Antony, ≈øo that it appears not he was interrupted by him; the Opinion of the Court was again≈øt the Plaintiff, Allen p, 19. Colman and Painter.

Debt on Bond conditioned, that if the Obligee, his Executors and A≈ø≈øigns from the time of the Obligation may enjoy ≈øuch Land, &c. The Defendant pleads, that po≈øt obligationem until the day of the Bill the Plaintiff had enjoyed that Land; Plaintiff demurs. 1. Becau≈øe the Defendant doth not ≈øay a die confectionis ≈øcripti obligatorii & ≈øemper post; non allocatur, a Bar is good to common intent, and it ≈øhall be taken he always enjoyed it, unle≈øs the contrary be ≈øhewn, which mu≈øt come on the Plaintiffs part. 2. Becau≈øe he does not plead the Plaintiff and his A≈ø≈øigns enjoyed it; non allocatur, for it ≈øhall not be intended the Plaintiff made an A≈ø≈øignment, unle≈øs he him≈øelf had ≈øhewn it; Judgment pro Def. but it was moved to have the Plaintiff di≈øcontinue his Suit, for otherwi≈øe he ≈øhould be barred of his Debt, whereas he had good cau≈øe of Action, and the Court adjourned it till next Term, that in the interim he might di≈øcontinue, Cro. Car. 195. Harlow and Wright.

The Plaintiff by Deed indented, lea≈øed to the Defendant a Farm called D. except one Clo≈øe by Name; Le≈ø≈øee Defendant was bound in a Bond to perform all the Covenants and Agreements in the ≈øaid Indenture, and pleaded he had performed all the Covenants; the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns for breach, that the Defendant entred into the Clo≈øe excepted; the Defendant demurs: Per Cur. the Obligation is not forfeited by this di≈øturbance; this Exception is not ≈øuch an Agreement as is within the intent
of the Condition, its an Agreement, that the Land excepted ≈øhall not pa≈øs by the Demi≈øe, but no Agreement that he ≈øhall occupy; but ≈øometimes an Exception is an Agreement that ≈øhall charge the Le≈ø≈øee, but this when he agrees on his part, that the Le≈ø≈øor ≈øhall have a thing dehors, which he had not before; as except a Way or Common, or any other Profit, a Prender, that is Agreement of the Le≈ø≈øee that he ≈øhall have the Profit, and if he bound to perform all Covenants and Agreements, if he di≈øturb him in this, he ≈øhall forfeit the Obligation, Cro. Eliz. p. 657. Lady Ru≈ø≈øel ver≈øus Gullwell, Moor n. 713. id. Ca≈øe.

In a Lea≈øe for years, the Defendant Covenants that the Plaintiff ≈øhould enjoy it during the Term; on Demurrer the Ca≈øe was, Tenant pur vie levies a Fine to him in Rever≈øion, come ceo, &c. the u≈øes were to the Conu≈øee and his Heirs, on condition to pay to the Tenant pur vic 4 l. per ann. during his life, and upon default that it ≈øhould be to the u≈øe of the Conu≈øor for his life; the Conu≈øee made a Feoffment to the Defendant, who lea≈øed to the Plaintiff; the 4 l. was not paid nor demanded; the Tenant pur vie enters on the Plaintiff; this is a breach of the Condition without any demand of the Rent, for its a Sum in gro≈øs, and not i≈ø≈øuing out of the Land; the Covenant is, that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall ab≈øolutely enjoy it; and this Condition is properly to be performed by him who hath the Freehold, and it was held that this Feoffment had not de≈øtroyed the future u≈øe, which is to ari≈øe for non-performance of the Condition, Cro. El. 688. Smith and Warren.

Two make a Lea≈øe for years by Indenture, and covenants that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould not be di≈øturbed, nor any incumbrance made by them; one of the Le≈ø≈øors makes a Lea≈øe to a Stranger who di≈øturbs, on Bond to perform Covenants, its a breach of the Condition, for (them) ≈øhall not be taken jointly, Lach. p. 161. Merritons Ca≈øe.

Condition of the Obligation was, That the Plaintiff ≈øhould have, hold and enjoy Lands acquitted from all Charges and Incumbrances, and for breach the Plaintiff ≈øhew there was a Rent-charge granted by the Predece≈ø≈øor, under whom the Defendant claimed, which is yet undi≈øcharged; the Defendant demurred, becau≈øe the acquittal goes to the having and holding the Land, and its not ≈øhewed that the Plaintiff was ever in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, nor that he was charged or endamaged, to which Twi≈øden and Keeling agreed; but by Windham the Defendant ought to ≈øhew how he had di≈øcharged and acquitted from the very Rent, and not to let it perpetually hang over him; but by all the Court, if the Acquittal refer to the Land it ≈øelf, or to the Per≈øon, the Defendant mu≈øt ≈øhew how, 1 Keb. fol. 927. King and Standi≈øh.

A Covenant, that the Indenture of a Lea≈øe at time of the A≈ø≈øignment is a good, true and indefea≈øible Lea≈øe, and that the Plaintiff ≈øhall enjoy, &c. without the let or interruption of the Defendant, or of any claiming by, from or under him, and ≈øhews for breach, that before he that made the Lea≈øe had any thing, one J. S. was ≈øeized in Fee, and that he which made the Lea≈øe entred upon him, and di≈ø≈øei≈øed, and lea≈øed prout, and that J. S. re-entred upon him, upon which
Replication the Defendant demurs, & per Cur. the word indefea≈øible Lea≈øe ≈øhall be con≈øtrued as a di≈øtinct Sentence from the la≈øt words, that he ≈øhall enjoy it without the interruption of the Defendant, Siderfin p. 328. Gainsford and Griffith, 1 Sanders p. 51.

John≈øon and Vavi≈øor Joyntenants of a Mill by Lea≈øe for years. Vavi≈øor a≈ø≈øigns all his Intere≈øt in the Mill to another without John≈øons a≈ø≈øent or privity, and dies. John≈øon after recited this Indenture by Lea≈øe, and that all came to him by Survivor≈øhip, grants the ≈øaid Mill and all his E≈øtate, Title and Intere≈øt to Procter, and covenants that he ≈øhall quietly enjoy it notwith≈øtanding any Act done by him, and Bond of Covenants, Act. de Det ≈øur Bond. John≈øon pleads, that the Plaintiff had enjoyed this notwith≈øtanding any Act done by him. Procter replied, that Vavi≈øor Joyntenant with John≈øon a≈ø≈øigned his E≈øtate to J. D. who entred and expelled him. The Defendant demurs; adjudged again≈øt the Defendant, for the Grant was never good, for he had no power to grant one Moiety, and yet he had expre≈øly granted the Mill to Procter. And the Condition of the Obligation being to perform all Grants, the Grant being defective at the fir≈øt as to a Moiety which is the Sub≈øtance of the Agreement of all the Parties, this is not qualified by the Covenant en≈øuing, and it is not like to Nokes Ca≈øs, 4 Rep. for there the Grant was good for the whole, and becomes ill by Eviction afterwards, and therefore the Covenant en≈øuing qualified the general Covenant. Yelv. p. 175. John≈øon and Procter, Lit. 206. 1 Bul≈øtr. 3, 4.

A Covenant that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall enjoy again≈øt the Le≈ø≈øor and all claiming under him. The Defendant exhibited a Bill whereby the Le≈ø≈øor appeared to be in Tru≈øt, and adjudged this was, no Breach, Selby and Chute cited 2 Keb. 288. 1 Brownl. p. 23.
The Covenant was, if the Defendant ≈øued or troubled, charged or vexed the Plaintiff: Per Cur. a Suit in Chancery is within the Condition, 2 Keb. 288. A≈øhton and Martin.

A Condition to ≈øurrender a Copyhold, and that the Plaintiff ≈øhall enjoy this without the let of any claiming under the Defendant and of one Lancelot Simons. The Defendant pleaded Surrender, and that the Plaintiff had quietly enjoyed this. The Plaintiff replies that one Jane Simons claiming under Lanceolet ou≈øts him. Demurrer, and Judgment pro Quer. The Ca≈øe was; this Copyhold was granted to Patience Hu≈ø≈øy for Life, the Remainder to Lanceolet S. in Fee; and that after and before the Obligation Lancelot ≈øurrenders his Remainder to the u≈øe of Patience for Life, and after to the u≈øe of Lancelot and Jane for their Lives, and after to Lancelot's Heirs: Lancelot and Patience dye, and after the Obligation Jane enters. The cau≈øe of Demurrer was that Jane took nothing by the Surrender, for the Surrender to P. H. pur vie was void, ≈øhe having an E≈øtate pur vie before, and con≈øequently the Remainders by notice upon this void E≈øtate are void al≈øo. Dut per Cur. the E≈øtate limited to Jane S. ≈øhall be by way of pre≈øent E≈øtate and mediate Settlement, and not by way of Remainder, 1 Sanders p. 150. Wade and Balch, 2 Keb. 341. Id. Ca≈øe, Siderfin p. 360.

The Condition was, whereas J. F. claimed to have Lea≈øe for years of the M. of D. made to him by W. If the ≈øaid Defendant keep without damage the Plaintiff from all Claim and Intere≈øt to be challenged by J. F. de tempore in tempus during the years, &c. The Defendant pleaded after making the Obligation until the Action brought, The Plaintiff was not damnified ratione dimi≈ø≈øionis. Plea good, for if he were not damnified ratione dimi≈ø≈øionis, then he was not damnified by rea≈øon of any Claim or Intere≈øt, 3 Leon. 118. Brainthwait's Ca≈øe.
To enjoy ab≈øque legali impedimento of J. S. the Breach is, that J. S. habens jus entred, it is a ≈øufficient Breach, 2 Keble 878. Procter and Newton.

div.head: On Covenant to acknowledg a Fine.
div.p: A Covenant that the Vendor ≈øhould make farther A≈ø≈øurance at the Co≈øts and Charges of the Purcha≈øor. It was alledged for Breach that a Note of a Fine was devi≈øed and ingro≈ø≈øed in Parchment, and delivered to the Vendee to acknowledg the Fine at the A≈ø≈øizes, which he refu≈øed to do; and the Plaintiffs Breach was demurred upon, becau≈øe he did not offer Co≈øts to the Vendee, and per Cur. its ill, 1 Brownl. Rep. p. 70. Pre≈øton and Daw≈øon.

On a Covenant for farther A≈ø≈øurance; the Breach is, Advice and Reque≈øt of a Fine by ≈øuch a Coun≈øel, and ≈øhews Dedimus Pote≈øtatem to A. and to revive the Conu≈øance, and the Obligor being reque≈øted, refu≈øeth; though he ≈øhew not any
Writ of Covenant was depending, or that the Writ was delivered to the Commi≈ø≈øioners, and though the Fine was with Warranty, yet becau≈øe the Covenant is not to levy a Fine, but to do ≈øuch Acts as ≈øhall be required. Judgment pro Quer. Latch p. 186. Tindal's Ca≈øe.
If one do covenant generally to levy a Fine of Lands, he is not bound thereby to go before Commi≈ø≈øioners by Dedimus, Stiles Pract. Reg. 75.

I am obliged that J. S. who is a Stranger ≈øhall levy a Fine to the Obligee, the Obligee is bound to ≈øue out a Writ of Covenant: Aliter, if I am obliged to you that J. S. ≈øhall levy a Fine to J. N. Winch p. 30. Hill and Waldron.
The Condition was, the Obligor ≈øhall levy a Fine to the Obligee, the Obligee ought to do the fir≈øt Act (viz.) to ≈øue a Writ of Covenant, 5 Rep. Palmer's Ca≈øe.

The Condition was, J. S. ≈øhall levy a Fine to the Obligee before ≈øuch a day. The Defendant pleads, the Obligee had not ≈øued forth a Writ of Covenant. The Plaintiff replies, that before the Obligation made J. S. had made a Feoffment to J. D. of the Land, and the Feoffee was in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion at that time. Here the Obligee need not ≈øue a Writ of Covenant, for by the Feoffment J. S. had di≈øabled him≈øelf at the time of the Obligation, Sed Quaere, Winch. p. 30. Eill and Waldron.

A Condition to levy a Fine at the Co≈øts of the Obligor, &c. The Defendant pleads, no Fine was levied by, &c. according to the Condition. The Plaintiff demurs, becau≈øe it is not averred the Defendant brought any Writ of Covenant. Sed
non allocatur. Per Cur. the Law is now changed, and the Fine levied before any Writ entred, and therefore mu≈øt be done by the (Plaintiff) without any Writ, 1 Keb. 816. Culpepper ver≈øus Au≈øtin.

A Condition, that Baron and Feme being Le≈ø≈øees for Life ≈øhould levy a Fine to a Stranger at the Co≈øts of the Stranger; and al≈øo that they ≈øhould levy a Fine of other Lands to a Stranger at their Charge. The Obligor ≈øaith, the Baron and Feme did offer to levy the Fine if the Stranger would bear the Charges. The Plaintiff demurs, and pro Quer. becau≈øe the levying the ≈øecond Fine had not reference to the other, for (and al≈øo) make them two di≈øtinct Sentences, 1 Brownl. 94. Hollingworth and Huntly.

A Condition that he and his Wife would levy a Fine upon rea≈øonable Reque≈øt of the Obligee; he made the Reque≈øt the Wife being very ≈øick, ≈øo as ≈øhe could not travel: Re≈øolved, her Sickne≈øs ≈øaved the Obligation from the Forfeiture, More n. 256.

A Condition that ≈øuch a Woman ≈øhould make ≈øuch farther rea≈øonable a≈ø≈øurance to J. D. as J. D. ≈øhould devi≈øe: J. D. devi≈øed a Fine and required her to come before the Judge of A≈ø≈øize to acknowledg; ≈øhe came, and the Judg refu≈øed her as non compos mentis: Per Cur. the Condition was not broken, becau≈øe it is to make a rea≈øonable a≈ø≈øurance: Aliter, if the words had been ≈øpecial to acknowledge a Fine, 1 Leon. p. 304. Pet and Cally.

If a Man be bound to another to make ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance of Lands as the Obligee ≈øhall devi≈øe, it is not ≈øufficient for him to devi≈øe a Fine, and to take out a Dedimus, &c. upon it, and require his
Coni≈øance in that, for this is but a ≈øpecial way of taking the Coni≈øance. But if there were a Provi≈øo that he ≈øhould not go above five miles from his Hou≈øe, then if his Hou≈øe be above five miles from We≈øtmin≈øter he is bound to make his Coni≈øance on the Dedimus, this hath been the difference, Allen p. 69.

One covenants for farther a≈ø≈øurance to levy a Fine of all his Lands in D. which was four Hou≈øes, and tenders a Fine. The Defendant pleads at the time of the Covenant he was only ≈øei≈øed of two Hou≈øes, and that the other two de≈øcended to him afterwards, and good. A Covenant to levy a Fine of two Acres, and the Fine is of four Acres by the name of two Acres comprehended in the Indenture, it is not good, 1 Rolls Rep. 103, 117. Wil≈øon and Wel≈øh, 2 Bul≈øtr. p. 317. 1 Rolls Abr. 425.

A Covenant to make farther A≈ø≈øurance and to do any Act or Acts, &c. and ≈øhews he demanded of him, and tendred a Note of a Fine, comprehending that he would levy a Fine of three Me≈ø≈øuages, &c. and that he required him to acknowledg it before a Judge of A≈ø≈øize. The Defendant pleads in the Note were more compri≈øed than he intended to a≈ø≈øure, it is no Plea, Cro. Jac. 251. Bonlay and Curtes. If one be bound to levy a Fine to another, he is not bound to ≈øue forth the Writ of Covenant, but he who is to have advantage of the Fine is to do it; and in the Ca≈øe afore≈øaid, he ought to levy a Fine upon this Note, notwith≈øtanding there was no Writ of Covenant then hanging; and in the ≈øaid Ca≈øe though the
Note contained more Acres than the two Yard-Lands, this is good, 1 Bul≈øtr. 90. Id. Ca≈øe.

For performance of Covenants; one was to marry S. the Daughter, another, that Sir E. S. and his Wife ≈øhould levy a Fine of ≈øuch Lands to the Defendant and to the Plaintiffs Daughter S. and to the Heirs of their Bodies. 3. That the Inheritance of the Premi≈øes ≈øhould remain in the ≈øaid Sir E S. or him≈øelf until the Fine levied. 4. Whereas he had granted a Lea≈øe for years to S. the Plaintiffs Daughter, that he bad not made any former Grant, nor would afterwards make any Grant thereof without the Plaintiffs a≈ø≈øent. The Defendant quoad the la≈øt Covenant in the negative pleads, that he had not made any former Grant of the Lea≈øe, nor had made any Grant after the Obligation without the Plaintiffs a≈ø≈øent. Et quoad alias omnes Conventiones, that he had performed them. The Plaintiff demurs. 1. Becau≈øe the Covenant to levy a Fine, &c. is an Act to be performed by a Stranger, and it is an Act to be performed on Record, in both which Ca≈øes he ought to plead and ≈øhew how he performed it; and it is not ≈øufficient to plead general performance, for Acts of Record ought to be ≈øhewn ≈øpecially, and the An≈øwer to them is nul tiel record, and no other I≈ø≈øue can be taken. 2. Becau≈øe the Covenant being in the disjunctive, he ought to ≈øhew ≈øpecially which of them, and not generally. 3. He pleads he did not grant without the Plaintiffs a≈ø≈øent, which is a negative pregnant, and ≈øo not good, and all allowed per Cur. and again≈øt the Plaintiff, Crook Jac. 559. Lee and Luthiel.

div.head: On Covenant to pay Rent.
div.p: ON Condition performed pleaded, the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns the Breach for Non-payment of Rent and pleads in this manner; that in December he demi≈øed to the Defendant one Wine-Cellar for one year, and if the Defendant would hold the Wine-Cellar for three years paying 40 l. yearly during the ≈øaid term, and alledges Non-payment of the Rent for one Quarter of the fir≈øt Year: Per Cur. the Re≈øervation had reference as well to the fir≈øt year as to the two years following, 1 Brownl. 61. Young and Melton.

Debt on Bond to perform all Covenants, Payments and Agreements contained in a pair of Indentures. The Defendant pleads the Indenture and performance. The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns the Breach that the Defendant had not paid half a years Rent. The Defendant replies, the Plaintiff had entred into part of the Premi≈øes the day before the day of Payment, and ≈øo at I≈ø≈øue. Exception was taken, becau≈øe the Plaintiff had alledged no demand to be made, and the Court held, that was implyed by the I≈ø≈øue, and that it was not nece≈ø≈øary in this Ca≈øe, the I≈ø≈øue ari≈øing on a collateral point, which admitted the Rent not paid, 1 Brownl. p. 76. Baker and Pain, Hob. p. 8. Crook Eliz. p. 332. Dr. Aidir ver≈øus Wood.

Debt on an Obligation to perform Covenants of a Lea≈øe: The Defendant pleaded he had performed. The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns a Breach, and the Defendant demurs. Upon Demurrer the Ca≈øe was; A Lea≈øe was made for one year, the Le≈ø≈øee
covenants for him and his A≈ø≈øigns to pay the Rent ≈øo long as he and they ≈øhall have the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the thing let. The Le≈ø≈øee a≈ø≈øigns over his Term, the Term expires, and for Rent behind by the A≈ø≈øignee after the Expiration of the Term, the Le≈ø≈øor brings the Action: Per Cur. though here be not an A≈ø≈øignee ≈øtrictly according to the Rules of Law, yet he ≈øhall be accounted ≈øuch an A≈ø≈øignee as is to perform the Covenants made between the Parties, Stiles p. 407. Bromfield and Sir John William≈øon.

Debt lies for a Rent re≈øerved on a Lea≈øe for years without demand, and if the Le≈ø≈øee be bound to pay the Rent at the day, he ought to tender it at the day before demand; otherwi≈øe it is where the Le≈ø≈øee is bound to perform Covenants, 1 Rolls Rep. 216. Mo≈øes Den's Ca≈øe.

If a Man be bound to pay Rent, which is re≈øerved upon a Lea≈øe made to him, he ought to pay it at his peril; but if it be to pay it according to the Lea≈øe, there he ≈øaid it is not payable but upon the Bond; and if the Land be evicted in the interim before the day of Payment, the Obligor ≈øhall help him≈øelf by pleading it upon ≈øuch an Obligation. But if the Condition is to perform Articles. The Defendant cannot ≈øay there are no ≈øuch Articles. So bound to pay 10 l. per annum Rent re≈øerved upon a Lea≈øe of Lands in D. the Defendant ≈øhall not plead, the Plaintiff had not any E≈øtate in the Lands, Quaere de hoc, Popham 114. Stroud and Willis.

The Condition was, if the Obligor ≈øhall pay the Rent of, &c. according to the intent of certain Articles, &c. that then, &c. The Defendant
pleads, the Articles did contain that the Obligor demi≈øit, &c. to the Defendant omnia talia domus, &c. in Y. in quibus the Obligee had an E≈øtate pur vie per Copy, habend. pur 21 a ‚Ä¢ s rendant rent. Per Cur. no Rent is to be paid, for the Lea≈øe did never begin: But per Popham, the Obligor is to pay the Rent, though nothing be demi≈øed to him, for by the Bond he hath made it a Sum in gro≈øs, Fenner contra, More n. 521. Stroud and Willis.

A Condition to perform Covenants in a Lea≈øe. The Le≈ø≈øee doth not pay the Rent at the day, and the Plaintiff without making any Reque≈øt, ≈øues the Bond; upon this matter pleaded in Bar, the Plaintiff replied, that he was not demanded. Demurrer: If the Bond be for Rent preci≈øely, there the Le≈ø≈øee ought to ≈øeek the Le≈ø≈øor, and tender on the Land will not excu≈øe him; but an Obligation to perform Covenants doth not alter the nature of the Rent, 2 Brownl. Rep. 176. Manly and Jennings, Quaere in Hobart p. 8. Baker and Pain.

Debt on Bond, the Condition to perform Covenants. Performance pleaded. Non-payment of Rent a≈ø≈øigned in the Replication. The Defendant rejoyns, the Plaintiff entred before the Rent-day: Per Cur. it is a departure, 1 Keb. 115, 178, 185. Granger ver≈øus Lemborough. This point in Hobart p. 8. Baker and Pain's Ca≈øe, was not ≈øtirred there.

The Condition was to pay quarterly an Annuity ≈øo long as the Defendant continues the occupation of the Land. Defendant pleads payment till the 24th of June before which day the Plaintiff
entred and brought Ejectment in Trin. and had Judgment in Michalmas Term. The Plaintiff demurred, becau≈øe he ≈øaith not expulit or amovit; nor that the Plaintiff continued in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, as it ought to be, being pleaded by way of Su≈øpen≈øion; but by way of Eviction it were well enough, which the Court agreed in ca≈øe it were payable as a Rent. But per Cur. the Entry ≈øhall be intended continuing, and there ≈øhall be no apportionment on a Bond as it might upon a Lea≈øe, 3 Keb. 453, 515. Arnold and Foot.

The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns a Breach for Non-payment of Rent, but ≈øhews no demand at the day. The Defendant demurs, and adjudged for the Plaintiff. For when the Defendant pleads performance of all the Payments, Covenants and Agreements, it ≈øhall be intended he had really performed them, and ≈øo had paid all the Rents; and when the Plaintiff replies he had not paid ≈øuch a Rerit, he need not alledge a demand; for the Defendant may not ≈øay it was not demanded, for that would be a departure; yet the Obligation being general for performance of Covenants, doth not alter the nature of the Rent, but that it ought to be demanded, Crook Car. 76. Chapman and Chapman.

But becau≈øe the Defendant pleaded generally quod perimplevit omnes conventiones, &c. which implies a Payment of the Rent, and the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns for Breach that it was in arrear ≈øuch a day. The Defendant demurs, and ≈øo confe≈ø≈øeth it was not paid. The Plea was ill, though in ≈øuch Ca≈øe the Obligation is not really forfeited unle≈øs there be a demand of the Rent, Crook Eliz. p. 828. Specot and Sheeres.

A Condition to perform Covenants in an Indenture, whereby he lets Land, rendant 10 l. per annum, or within ≈øix days after the Fea≈øt. The Defendant pleads performance. The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns a Breach, that he ≈øuch a day being the ≈øixth day after the Fea≈øt before Sun-≈øet demanded 3 l. Rent then due, and that neither the Defendant nor any for him was ready to pay it; for which, &c. Per Cur. 1. He need not ≈øhew the certain time when he came, nor how long he remained there. 2. Whereas it was objected this demand was not good, becau≈øe he demanded it as a Rent then due; for he ought to have demanded it as a Rent due the la≈øt Fea≈øt: But per Cur. it is not due to be demanded till the ≈øixth day, though the Tenant, if he will, may pay it before. 3. The Condition being for performance of Covenants, Payments and Agreements, the Non-payment of Rent upon demand on the la≈øt day, was a Breach of the Bond; Crook Jac. 499. Thomp≈øon and Field.

Debt on an Obligation conditioned to perform Covenants and to pay Rent: The Defendant on Oyer pleads performance, to which the Plaintiff demurs, as being no ≈øpecial An≈øwer to the Rent; which per Cur. is ill. Judgment pro Quer. 3 Keb. 60. Betent and Frim.

Per Hales, If the Le≈ø≈øee covenants to perform Articles in an Indenture, it is ≈øufficient to ≈øay the Rent was demanded; but if there be an expre≈øs Covenant to pay the Rent, there needs no demand, 3 Keb. 299. in Drew and Baylies Ca≈øe.

A Condition to perform Covenants in a Lea≈øe. The Defendant pleads Conditions performed. The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns a Breach for Non-payment of Rent.
The Defendant pleads to this a Relea≈øe of all Demands. Per Cur. this Rent is not relea≈øed by all Demands, Siderfin p. 141. Hen and Han≈øon.

In Debt on a Bond, the Condition to perform Covenants of payment of Rent and another particular. The Defendant pleads Covenants performed generally. Plaintiff demurs, becau≈øe he ≈øhould have pleaded to each particular performance or other particular Plea, and ≈øo whereever particulars are ≈øpecified; but when it is to perform Covenants in an Indenture, performance according to the Indenture is ≈øufficient, 2 Keb. 362. Brown and Talderly.

On performance pleaded the party cannot after plead Rent was not demanded; Aliter on a particular Covenant to pay Rent, for perimplevit implies actual performance, not by way of excu≈øe, 2 Keb. 848. Forth and Lewin.

The Le≈ø≈øee covenants to pay his Rent to the Le≈ø≈øor, and he pays it before the day, the ≈øame is not any performance of the Covenant: Aliter, of a Sum in gro≈øs, 1 Leon. p. 136. in Littleton and Pernes Ca≈øe.

The Condition was, that the Defendant ≈øhould pay to the Plaintiff 10 l. which is for Rent of certain Lands. The Defendant alledged the Plaintiff had entred upon the Land and ≈øo a ≈øu≈øpen≈øion. The Plaintiff demurred, and adjudged for him; for this being but a recital that it was for Rent is not material; it ≈øeems the ≈øame though he had applied it by pleading to the Lea≈øe, Heb. p. 130. St. John and Diggs.

div.head: On Covenants in a void Lea≈øe.
div.p: THE Covenants depend upon the Lea≈øe, and the Bond upon the Covenants. If a Lea≈øe be made and after ≈øurrendred, all the Covenants and Bonds for the performance of them are void al≈øo, in Sapeans and Skurro's Ca≈øe, Yelv. p. 19. Quaere.

A Grant or A≈ø≈øignment of ≈øo much of a Term as ≈øhall be unexpired at his death, and a Covenant that the Grantee ≈øhall quietly enjoy & the Grantor dies; in Bond for performance the Action of Debt is brought again≈øt the Executor, though the A≈ø≈øignment be void; but this is a Covenant by it ≈øelf, and the Breach was that the Executor entred on the Grantee. Per Windham, the difference is where a Deed is void in the Fabrick, there the Covenants on it are void; as when a Freehold is to commence in future, and where there is only want of Intere≈øt in the party Grantor, which the Court agreed. 2. The Condition was to keep and perform all Covenants generally, which being void, the Bond is ≈øingle; if there had been no Indenture the Bond had been good ≈øingle, 1 Keb. 130. Cavenhur≈øts Ca≈øe.

A Par≈øon made a Lea≈øe for years and became bound to the Le≈ø≈øe to perform the Covenants in the Lea≈øe. The Defendant pleads, the Lea≈øe is void by the Statute of 14 Eliz. becau≈øe he was ab≈øent from his benefice above the ≈øpace of 80 days. Per Cur. the Plea is good as to that Point, 3 Leon. p. 102. Cox's Ca≈øe.

One that is mere Laicus being in≈øtituted and inducted made a Lea≈øe for years of the Rectory, which was confirmed by the Patron and Ordinary. In Debt for performance of Covenants, Per Cur. this Lea≈øe ≈øhall bind the Succe≈ø≈øor Incumbent, Crook Eliz. Costard and Windet.
To perform Covenants in a Lea≈øe again≈øt Stat. 32 H. 8. Lea≈øes made to Alien Artificers, void, Siderfin p. 357. Freeman and King, 1 Sanders Javans and Harweck, Siderfin p. 309.
An Obligation to perform Covenants of an Obligation void by the Statute of 14 El. c. 11. 1 L ‚Ä¢ . p. 100. St. John and Petits Ca≈øe.
If the Indenture of Covenants be made void, as by Relea≈øe, &c. the Bond is void, 2 Keble 116.

div.head: On Covenants in a Mortgage.
div.p: A Grant, Bargain and Sale of certain Lands with a Provi≈øo that if the Defendant did not pay 40 l. ≈øuch a day, then it ≈øhould be void. The Condition was to perform all Covenants, Clau≈øes, Payments and Agreements contained in the Deed: This doth not extend but to compul≈øory Payments, and not to the voluntary Sum in the Provi≈øo; for if he choo≈øe not to pay, he may forfeit the Land to the Plaintiff, Yelv. p. 206. Bri≈øtow ver≈øus Knipe, 1 Bul≈øtr. 156. Id. Cro. Jac. 281. Id. Ca≈øe.

Debt on an Obligation to perform all Conditions, Covenants, Payments in the Indenture. The Defendant pleads, one Condition was of a Lea≈øe to pay on a Mortgage, or to be void, and that he
was not bound to perform it. The Plaintiff demurs, (Vid. 3 Keb. p. 387.) adjudged for the Defendant, becau≈øe the Land was to be lo≈øt for Non-payment, 394. Per Hales, the word Conditions would be idle, if this were not effectual; aliter, if the word Conditions was not in, and then it would be at the Mortgagors Election to pay or forfeit: But here perhaps the Le≈ø≈øor had no Title, and ≈øo it is requi≈øite the Mortgagee ≈øhould have his Mony, 437. Per Cur. were it a Condition in the Indenture ≈øpecially recited in the Bond, though thereby the Mortgage was forfeited, the Bond is ≈øo too upon Non-performance; but being general to perform all Covenants and Conditions, it binds only to ≈øuch as are compul≈øory, 3 Keb. 454, 460. Toomes and Chandler.

div.head: On Covenant for Reparations.
div.p:
THE Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns the Breach in one Covenant, whereas the Plaintiff had lea≈øed Hou≈øes, &c. the Defendant did covenant to repair all the ≈øaid Hou≈øes alia quam quae appunctuat. for ‚Ä¢ t divelli pro Qu ‚Ä¢ r. and ≈øhewed that the Defendant had not repaired the Me≈ø≈øuages to him demi≈øed, and averred that the Hou≈øe in which the Breach of Covenant is a≈ø≈øigned non fuit appunctuat. divelli: Per Cur. this Averment was ≈øuperfluous; for if the Hou≈øe in not repairing of which the Breach is a≈ø≈øigned was appointed to be pulled down, the ≈øame ≈øhall come in on the Defendants part to who≈øe benefit it trencheth, for ≈øuch appointment doth di≈øcharge the Covenant as to that, 1 Leon. fo. 17. Sir John Smith's Ca≈øe.
The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigned a Breach in Non-reparation. The Defendant pleads the Plaintiff had acqui ‚Ä¢ d and di≈øcharged him of all Reparations. The Plaintiff demured: Per Cur. this is an acquittance and di≈øcharge of the Reparations for the time pa≈øt as well as the time to come, and amounts to as much as if he had relea≈øed that Covenant; but the Covenant being broken, that di≈øcharge ≈øhall not take away the Action on the Obligation, which was once forfeited, 3 Leon. p. 69. Anonymus.

A Condition to perform Covenants in a Lea≈øe, which recites a Lea≈øe of a Brew-hou≈øe and a Mill in occupation of F. with Covenant to repair all the Premi≈øes. The Defendant pleads general performance as to the Brewhou≈øe, and as to the Mill the Tenant did not attorn. The Plaintiff demurred; per Cur. this is no excu≈øe, though there be no Remedy for the Rent till Attornment, yet it was the Defendants fault he did not take a Covenant that the Under tenant ≈øhould attorn, 1
‚Ä¢ eb. 879. Lewin and Forth.

A Bond conditioned to deliver up an Hou≈øe repaired at the end of the Term. The Defendant pleads, the Plaintiff agreed he ≈øhould hold it for a longer time; it is a good Plea, though a Covenant is not di≈øcharged without a Deed, w ‚Ä¢ it is to do any collateral Act, 2. Keb. 99. M ‚Ä¢
and Rainsborough.

A Condition to repair and ≈øu≈øtain two M ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢
ages at all times. The Defendant pleads, he had performed the Condition in all, except as to one Kitchen, which at the time of the Demi≈øe was ≈øo ruinous that he could not repair it, but he pulled it down and rebuilt another, &c. this had been
a good Plea in Action of Wa≈øt, not here where he hath by his own Act tyed him≈øelf to a di≈øadvantage, 2 Leon. 189. Wood and Avery.

div.head: Pleadings on Bonds of Covenants. Variance.
div.p: DEbt on Bond of Covenants: After Verdict it was moved in Arre≈øt of Judgment, that the Defendants Plea was, that praedictus Ed. did covenant that R. was ≈øei≈øed, whereas the Defendants name was Robert that did covenant; this mi≈ørecital is not material, becau≈øe here is a good affirmative, and the Bond, if this be mi≈ørecited, is ≈øingle. Contra, if it had been an Action of Covenant; or when the Indenture by prayer of the Defendant is entred in hae ‚Ä¢ verba, 1 Keb. 126. Siderfin p. 49. Pegg and Wa ‚Ä¢ ere.
Variance between the Indenture and the Declaration ≈øhall not ≈øtay Judgment after a Verdict, Siderfin p. 49. Pegg and Waters.

The Covenant was, that he will a≈ø≈øure, convey and a≈ø≈øign a Lea≈øe. The Defendant pleads performance. The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigned the Breach, quod non a≈ø≈øuravit, conveiavit & tran≈øpo≈øuit, Anglice ≈øet over; and the Defendant pleaded quod a≈ø≈øuravit, conveiavit & a≈ø≈øign ‚Ä¢ t Anglice ≈øet over, and the word tran≈øpo≈øuit is not in the Covenant nor in the pleading of the performance thereof: It is I≈ø≈øue misjoyned, 2 Leon. p. 116. n. 155. Gray ‚Ä¢
and Con≈øtable.

In a Debt on a Bond of performance; J. and A. were named in the Bond, but the Indentures,
as pleaded, were only betwixt J. of the one part and the Defendant of the other; but were re vera betwixt J. and A. on the one part and the Defendant on the other. Per Cur. it is a variance, and Judgment pro. Quer. 1 Keb. 127, 167. Pavie and Hall.
Where Covenants are ≈øpecial, they mu≈øt be ≈øpecially an≈øwered unto and particularly, 2 Keb. 54. Herrick and Sander≈øon.
Again≈øt a negative or disjunctive Condition, the Defendant mu≈øt plead ≈øpecially.

Debt on a Bond for performance of Covenants; the Defendant ≈øets forth the Covenants by a Te≈øtatum exi≈øtit, its ill; this in a Plea in Bar, or Debt on the Indenture, is naught, aliter in Covenant, 2 Keble 54, 79. An≈ølows Ca≈øe.

Debt on Obligation, conditioned for performance of Covenants in quadam Indentura, bie in Curia prolat', and in truth the Deed was not indented, adjudged pro Quer. Cro. El. 472. Frampton and Stiles, 5 Rep. 20. b.

In Barnstaple. Debt on Obligation to perform Articles; the Defendant pleads performance; this Bar is ill, not ≈øetting forth the Indenture (below.) The Plaintiff alledges non-payment to J. S. ≈øecundum formam Articulorum: Per Cur. the general Replication is well enough, without ≈øetting forth the Indenture; but the Plaintiff by alledging the Breach hath waved the ill Bar, 3 Keb. 605. L ‚Ä¢
and Pig≈øly.

In Debt on Bond conditioned for performance of Covenants in an Indenture; the Defendant pleads peformance generally; this is not good unle≈øs he ≈øhew the Deed, and plead this: And it
is not ≈øufficient to ≈øhew the Deed, when the Plaintiff replies, and prays Oyer, becau≈øe the Plea of the Defendant ought to be ≈øpecial, if any of the Covenants are in the negative; and it doth not appear to the Court whether the Covenants are negative or affirmative, until the Deed be ≈øhewed; if the Party who will plead the Deed, had it not, he ought to move the Court for to have the Deed or a Copy, Siderfin p. 50, 97. Lewes and Ball.

The Defendant pleads there are no Covenants; Per Cur. this being general of all, is well; cont. if it were to perform any certain Covenant, but the Party is e≈øtopt to ≈øay there is no Indenture, 1 Keble 381. Brazier and Acton. Mod. Rep. in Holloways Ca≈øe; yet 2 Keble 564. Smith and Yeo
‚Ä¢ ans, cont. but that was becau≈øe of the ≈øhifting way of pleading.

The Condition was, Whereas J. S. claimed to have a Lea≈øe for years of D. granted to him by W. if the ≈øaid Defendant keep without damage the Plaintiff from all claims, &c. the Defendant pleads the ≈øaid J. S. had not any ≈øuch Lea≈øe; per Cur. he is e≈øtopt to ≈øay ≈øo by the recital.

A Condition to perform Covenants, The Defendant pleads the Indenture of W. S. and A. his Wife, whereas in truth his Wife never ≈øealed it; the Plaintiff replies, The Indenture ≈øhewn by the Defendant non fuit. fait, inter W. S. and Ann his Wife of the one part, and the Plaintiff on the other; and I≈ø≈øue; the Jury found, the Husband only ≈øealed; Per Cur. this Verdict is found again≈øt the Defendant, the Plaintiff is not
e≈øtopt to ≈øay that the Deed ≈øhewn, is not the Deed of the Baron and Feme; but he is e≈øtopt by the Condition to ≈øay that there is not any ≈øuch indenture, Cro. Eliz. p. 796. Ship and Steed.
Relea≈øe Pleaded.

If before the breach of any of the Covenants, the Obligee relea≈øeth the Covenants, and afterwards one of the Covenants is broken, the Obligation is not forfeited; for there is not now any Covenant which may be broken, and ≈øo the Obligation is di≈øcharged; but if the Relea≈øe had been made after the Covenant broken, aliter, 3 Leon. 69.
What is confe≈ø≈øed by pleading Conditions performed.

Obligation to perform Covenants; the Covenant was, If the Plaintiff pay the Defendant 100 l. at Michaelmas, that the Defendant would pay him yearly after 10 l. for his life, and averred he did not pay him 10 l. yearly, but did not mention the payment of 100 l. by him, which was a≈ø≈øigned for Error; Per Cur. its no Error, becau≈øe the Defendant by pleading Conditions performed, had confe≈ø≈øed the payment of the 100 l. to him by the Plaintiff, Moor n. 474. Goodwin and I≈øham.

If the ≈øub≈øtance be an≈øwered, though not the very words, its good; as the Condition was, if he perform all the Covenants, Conditions, Agreements and Articles, and when the Defendent cited them in his Plea, which are all the Covenants, Conditions, Agreements, and leaves out (Articles) and ≈øo hath not pleaded performance of the Condition; but per Cur. Agreements is all
one with Articles, and if many words contain one thing in ≈øignification, if he an≈øwer to them in ≈øub≈øtance, its good; and the Condition was, If the Defendant and T. and their A≈ø≈øigns perform, &c. and he pleads he and T. had performed, but ≈øaith not, he and T. and their A≈ø≈øignes had performed, &c. and it may be they had a≈ø≈øigned it over; but per Cur. it appeareth not there is any A≈ø≈øignee, and it ≈øhall not be intended, except it be ≈øpecially ≈øhewn, and a Bar it good to common intent, Cro. Eliz. p. 255. Eniot and Cole.

Where an Act is to be done according to a Covenant, he who pleads the performance of it, ought to plead it ≈øpecilly; but where no Act is to be done, but only a permittance, permifit is a good Plea; one Covenant was, That the Plaintiff to ≈øuch of the ≈øaid Lands as by the Cu≈øtom of the Country tunc jacebant fri≈øca ≈øhould have free ingre≈øs, &c. at his plea≈øure, the Defendant pleads, quod permifit D. querentem habero intrationem & exitum, &c. in tales t ‚Ä¢ rt ‚Ä¢ quales tunc jacobant fri≈øca ≈øecundum con ‚Ä¢ uetudinem p ‚Ä¢ triae, he need not ≈øhew in certain what Lands did lie fre≈øh, and it ≈øhall come on the Plaintiffs part to ≈øhew in what Lands the Defendant non permifit, 1 Leon. p. 136. Littleton and Perne.

The Defendant is not bound to plead performance of any more than his own Grants and Covenants, vid. Dyer 26 H,
‚Ä¢ .27. b.

One Covenants with J. S. that he ≈øhall enjoy the Land; and farther, that A. a Farmer of the Tithes ≈øhall pay 8 l. per annum, and is bound to performance; in Debt on Bond, its good to plead performance of the Covenants, ex parte ≈øua perimplend.
for this implies the Farmer had paid the 8 l. and expre≈øs mention of that needs not be, Dyer 23 El. 372, 373.

In Debt for non-performance of Covenants, the Plaintiff ought to ≈øhew how the Covenants are broken; and if it be in non-payment of Rent, he ought to ≈øhew in certain, what day the Rent was arrear, 9 H. 6.18.

Debt to perform Covenants; one was, to many the Plaintiffs Daughter before ≈øuch a day. 2. That Sir E. S. and his Wife ≈øhould levy a Fine of ≈øuch Lands, &c. 3. Whereas he granted a Lea≈øe of, &c. to S. that he had not made any former Grant, nor would afterwards make any Grant thereof, without the Plaintiffs a≈ø≈øent; the Defendant quoad the la≈øt Covenant in the negative pleaded, that he had not made any former Grant of the Lea≈øe, nor had made any Grant after the Obligation, without the Plaintiffs a≈ø≈øent. Et quoad omnes alias conventiones, that he had performed them; the Plaintiff demurs. 1. Becau≈øe the Covenant to levy a Fine is an Act to be performed by a Stranger, and to be performed on Record; and its not ≈øufficient to plead general performance. 2. Becau≈øe the Covenant being in the disjunctive, he ought to ≈øhew ≈øpecially which of them, and not generally. 3. He pleaded, he did not grant without the Plaintiffs a≈ø≈øent, which is negativa prognans; Per Cur. for the≈øe Cau≈øes the Plea not good, Cro. Jac. 560. Lee and Luithil.

div.head: I≈ø≈øue, Trial.
div.p: COvenants in a Lea≈øe of an Hou≈øe; the Defendant pleads he was an Alien, born at Paris in France, and an Artificer; and ≈øo by 32 H. 8.16. the Lea≈øe void; the Plaintiff replies, The Defendant was not an Alien and Artificer; the Defendant demurs: Per Cur. Alien and Artificer are but the ≈øame Per≈øon, and but one Breach. 2. This I≈ø≈øue cannot be tried, becau≈øe the Replication ≈øhould have been, that he was a Denizen born at I≈ølington in England, and that he is no Alien generally, 2 Keble 315. Freeman and King 98.

On performance generally pleaded, the Plaintiff may reply with particular Breach, & hoc paratus, &c. and leave the I≈ø≈øue to the Defendant; contra on Condition to pay Mony at ≈øeveral days; the Defendant pleads particular payment; the Plaintiff replies, he did not pay ≈øuch a day certain, & hoc paratus, &c. its ill, 1 Keble 759. Charleton and Fine.

The Defendant pleads Covenants performed; the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns a Breach in not delivering up an Hou≈øe; the Defendant rejoins, before the end of the Term the Plaintiff gave him leave to continue it longer: Per Cur. its a departure, the parol Agreement was pleaded in Bar, 1 Keb. 678. Brooks and Lake.

The Defendant pleads the Obligation was for performance of Covenants, and ≈øhews what, and alledgeth farther, that in the ≈øaid Indenture is a Provi≈øo, ≈øi aliqua lis vel controver≈øia oriatur impo≈øterum
by rea≈øon of any clau≈øe, that then before any Suit thereon, the Parties ≈øhould choo≈øe four indifferent Per≈øons for the ending thereof, which being done, the Obligation to be void; and in facto ≈øaith, that Controver≈øy did ari≈øe; the Plaintiff demurs; per Cur. becau≈øe the Defendant hath not ≈øhewed what ≈øtrife, and what clau≈øe, the Bar is not good, for it extends not to every Covenant, only where ≈øtrife ari≈øeth, 1 Leon. 37. Parmort and Griffin.

A Condition for performance, and ≈øets forth the Covenant, and ≈øhewed farther, that the Plaintiff after ≈øealing procured J. S. to ra≈øe the Indenture, and ≈øhews wherein, and ≈øo the Indenture became void: Per Cur. its again≈øt the Defendant, the Ra≈øure not being in a place material, an the Ra≈øure trencheth to the advantage of him≈øelf who pleads it; and if the Indenture had become void by the Ra≈øure, the Bond had been ≈øingle, 1 Leon. p. 282. The Lord Darcy and Sharps Ca≈øe.

A Condition to perform Covenants; one was, To give an account ju≈øt and true (being a Brewers Clark,) the Defendant pleads performance; the Plaintiff replies, by receipt of 30 l. The Defendant rejoins, that it was ≈øtollen out of the Plaintiffs Counting-hou≈øe; the Plaintiff demurred; the Robbery is a good ‚Ä¢ ar; but the Plaintiff per Cur. di≈øcontinued, becau≈øe a Rule for Trial of the Robbery was di≈øobeyed, 2 Keble 761, 779, 830. Vere and Smith.

A Condition to perform Covenants; one was not to take a new Lea≈øe without a≈ø≈øent of the Plaintiff; the Defendant pleads he took no new Lea≈øe
contra f ‚Ä¢ Indentur. The Plaintiff replies, he did take a new Lea≈øe, but ≈øaith not without a≈ø≈øent of the Plaintiff; the Defendant demurs; per Cur. the Replication is good; for the Plaintiff is mi≈øled by the Defendant, and the I≈ø≈øue is good enough, 3 Keble 524. Perry and W ‚Ä¢ itby.

A Condition to perform things for which he was bound in a Recognizance; the Defendant pleads ≈øpecially, that he acknowledged a thing in nature of a Recognizance, but upon ≈øpecial matter it appeared to the Court it was not any Recogni
‚Ä¢ ance; male, for it amounts to the general I≈ø≈øue, 1 Rolls Rep. 83. Fletcher and Farrer.

A Condition to pay unto the Plaintiff all ≈øuch Legacies which he had given to him when he ≈øhould come of his full Age, &c. The Defendant pleads he paid omnia talia Legata qualia ad tale tempus generally, without ≈øhewing the particulars, and time when, and ≈øo the Plea not good, 1 Bul≈øt. p. 43. Stone and Bli≈øs.

div.head: To do or permit other Acts; to ≈øave harmle≈øs.
div.p:
A Condition for ≈øaving the Plaintiff harmle≈øs from all Legacies; and ≈øhews for Breach, there was a Suit commenced again≈øt him in Chancery for a Legacy; Per Cur. this Declaration is not good, becau≈øe he doth not ≈øhew ≈øuch a Legacy was devi≈øed, or that he was chargable with it. 2. Becau≈øe he doth not ≈øhew any place where Chancery was; in all Ca≈øes where a Man pleads any thing out of Chancery, or any thing to be done in Chancery, he ought in pleading to ≈øhew the ≈øame certainly, and to ≈øay in Ca ‚Ä¢ . apud We≈øten.
otherwi≈øe upon I≈ø≈øue no Venue can ari≈øe, 2. Bul ‚Ä¢ . 19. Dowty and Fawn. Yelv. 226. id. Ca ‚Ä¢ .
‚Ä¢
Brownl. 117. id. Ca≈øe. vid. 1 Rolls Abr. 430.

A Condition, if he ≈øave harmle≈øs and indempnifie the Plaintiff and his Lands in Sale from an annual Rent of ≈øuch a Lea≈øe during the ≈øaid Term, the Defendant pleads quod a tempore confection. ≈øcript. obligation. hucu≈ø
que exoneravit & indempnem con≈øervavit the Plaintiff and all his ≈øaid Lands from the ≈øaid Rent, Et hoc, &c. Plaintiff demurs, he ought to ≈øhew quomodo exoneravit, it being a Plea in the affirmative; had he pleaded non dampnificavit, it had been good, Cro. Jac. 634. Hor≈øeman and Obbins, Winch.
To ≈øave harmle≈øs from Incumbrances, vide antea.

A Condition to ≈øave harmle≈øs from ≈øuch a Bayl in ≈øuch an Action; the Defendant pleads quod libere & ab≈øolute exoneravit; &c. and ≈øhews not how he had di≈øcharged him, and therefore ill; aliter if he had pleaded non dampnificatus, Cro. Jac. p. 363. Codner and Dalby. 2 Bul≈øt. 270.

A Condition to ≈øave the Plaintiff harmle≈øs again≈øt J. Roberts of one Obligation; the Defendant pleads non dampnificatus; the Plaintiff replies, that J. R. had ≈øued him to the Exigent, and then he appeared, and R. had Judgment again≈øt him, & i≈ø≈øint dampnificat. the Defendant rejoins, that he had retained Attorn. pro Plaintiff, and the Plaintiff was at no Expences, nor was arre≈øted, nor Lands or Goods ≈øei≈øed, and that after Judgment he was not dampnified; the Plaintiff demurs; Cur. pro Quer. for immediately upon the Judgment given he was dampnified, for all
are liable to execution; and if the Defendant after Judgment had paid the Debt, it would not ≈øerve, for he was dampnified before, Cro. El. p. 264. Bu≈øh and Ridgely

Act. port by High-Sheriff ver≈øus Under-Sheriff; The Defendant pleaded he ≈øaved him harmle≈øs; the Plaintiff demurs; male Ple ‚Ä¢ , for he may ≈øave him harmle≈øs in many things, and yet the Plaintiff may be dampnified in ≈øome other; he ought to have pleaded non dampnificatus, Stiles p. 23. Car. 1. fol. 16. Wroth and El≈øey, that he ≈øaved harmle≈øs, and ≈øhews not how, Cro. Jac. 165. Alingtons Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads non dampnificatus; the Plaintiff replies, and ≈øhews a Breach on the Defendants part, wherein he was dampnified; the Defendant demurs, becau≈øe the Breach was a≈ø≈øigned to be at We≈øtmin≈øter, and doth not ≈øhew in what County We≈øtmin≈øter is, and good, Stil ‚Ä¢ p. 142. M. 24 Car. B. R. Nel≈øon ver≈øus Tomp≈øon.

A Bailiff conditions to ≈øave the Under-Sheriff harmle≈øs in executing Proce≈øs, &c. and a≈ø≈øigns a Breach that, the Bailiff had not executed his Warrant upon Proce≈øs directed out of the Exchequer, to levy I≈ø≈øues on Lands in the Mannor of A. but he doth alledge that the Mannor is within the Hundred where he is Bailiff, quod aportuit, and a good exception; for a Bailiff cannot execute a Precept out of his Hundred, Stil ‚Ä¢ s p. 18. Pa≈øch. 13. Car. 2. Stoughton and Day. Allen p. 10. id. Ca≈øe.
The Condition of a Bond to ≈øave the Obligee harmle≈øs concerning his buying of certain Goods at ≈øuch a price, extends not to the Price but to the Title, Allen p. 95.

A Condition to ≈øave the Plaintiff and Inhabitants of N. harmle≈øs from all Charges that may happen by placing A. in a Cottage; the Defendant pleads non dampnificatus; the Plaintiff replies, they were forced to provide Nece≈ø≈øaries by rea≈øon of a Rate ≈øet on the Inhabitants by Ju≈øtices and Over≈øeers, good, without ≈øhewing any particular Inhabitant was charged; the po≈ø≈øibility that they may be charged by the Rule, is a ≈øufficient dampnification, 1 Keble 392. Tavernor and Quatorman.

A Condition to ≈øave harmle≈øs from all Damage that may happen by non-payment of Legends, being Executor of J. S. the Plaintiff alledgeth damage in Suit by Legatee in Chancery; the Defendant demurs; Judgment pro Quer. 1 Keb. Hill. 14, 15 Car. 2. p. 464. Gibs and Tailor.

A Condition to ≈øave harmle≈øs of being Bail for an appearance; the Defendant pleads non damnificat. on Oyer; the Plaintiff replies, the Defendant did not appear, per quod the Sheriff did pro≈øecute him per dubitum logis cur≈øum; here being a Suit alledged is a ≈øufficient Breach, per Twi≈øden, Q. 2 Keble fol. 625. Pa≈ø. 22 Car. 2. Baker and Porter.

A Condition was to ≈øave the Plaintiff harmle≈øs from all Actions and Damages that might ari≈øe upon the relea≈øe of the Defendant out of Execution (being then in execution at the Plaintiffs Suit) from all Per≈øons that might trouble him concerning
the ≈øaid Relea≈øe: the Ca≈øe was, The Plaintiff ≈øued N. in the Court at Y. for 100 l. the Defendant and one H. became Bail; the Plaintiff had Judgment again≈øt N. and al≈øo the Bail; the Defendant was thereupon taken in Execution; but before the Defendant was taken in Execution. H. the other Bail gave him Security for the Mony, and in con≈øideration thereof, the Plaintiff promi≈øed H. that he might take out Execution again≈øt the other Defendant, and that he would not relea≈øe him without the con≈øent of H. whereupon H. procured him to be taken in Execution, and he then moved the Plaintiff to di≈øcharge him, who acquainted him with the promi≈øe made to H. at ≈øupra, thereupon the Defendant made him this Bond, and conditioned prout, ≈øo he di≈øcharged him, and H. brought an Action upon the Promi≈øe and recovered 150 l. damage; and ≈øo damnificat. the Defendant demurred; Judgment pro Quer. this is a Breach, for by the word (damages) is not only intended damages which ari≈øe directly by the Relea≈øe, but to any other collateral Act dehors, as is this promi≈øe, Hob. p. 269. Wilden and Wilkin≈øon. 1 Rolls Abr. 431. id. Ca≈øe. vid. 1 Rolls Abr. 422. id. Ca≈øe.

Condition is to perform an Award, which was, That the Obligee ≈øtaret acquietatus de qualibet materia contained in a Bill in Chancery, which the Obligor had depending again≈øt him, and that the ≈øaid Suit ≈øhall cea≈øe; and after the Obligor exhibits a new Bill in Chancery again≈øt the Obligee for the ≈øame matter, and in the end of the Bill prays Proce≈øs, but never takes out Proce≈øs thereon again≈øt him; this is not any ≈øuch mole≈øtation
as ≈øhall be a forfeiture of the Condition, for he is not at any damage by this, P. 12 Jac. 1 Rolls Abr. 432. Freeman and She ‚Ä¢ n.

A. and B. are bound in an Obligation to perform certain Covenants contained in an Indenture; and one is to pay Mony; and C. covenants with A. and B. to ≈øave them harmle≈øs of all things contained in the ≈øame Indenture; and after the Mony is not paid according to the Indenture, by which the Obligation is forfeited, yet C. is not bound to ≈øave them harmle≈øs of the Obligation, for this is a collateral thing to the Indenture, M. 5 Jac. 1 Rolls Abr. 432. Scot and Pope ver≈øus Griffin.

A Condition recites, That the Plaintiff at the reque≈øt of the Te≈øtator was bound in 2000 l. to the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Exci≈øe; and if the Te≈øtator acquit and di≈øcharge, or ≈øufficiently ≈øave harmle≈øs from all Suits, Troubles, &c. concerning the ≈øaid Bond, then, &c. the Defendant ≈øaith there were no Suits; the Plaintiff replies, there was a So. Fac. out of the Exchequer, and he was forced to retain an Attorny, and give him 3 s. 4 d. the Defendant demurs, becau≈øe no notice of the Suit is given to the Defendant: per Cur. there needs no notice, 2 Keb. 529, 609, 642. King and Atkins, Cro. El. 613. Fox and Wright.

The Defendant is Security to the Plaintiff for payment of Mony as ≈øeparate Maintenance to William≈øons Wife; the Breach a≈ø≈øigned, is that William≈øon brought an Action ≈øur Ca≈øe again≈øt the Plaintiff, on his promi≈øe to pay ≈øo much, if the Defendant now, who was then Plaintiff, would remit the re≈øt: Its a Cheat, and the Defendant i ‚Ä¢
not bound to ≈øecure the Plaintiff, 2 Keble p. 106. Campian ver≈øus Skipwith.
Counter-bond writ in a Book and good, Cro. El. p. 613. Fox and Wright.
If the Condition be to ≈øave harmle≈øs from ≈øuch a thing, this doth not extend to Actions in which he might have lawful defence without the Obligor, 2 H. 4.9.

A Condition to ≈øave harmle≈øs from J. S. if J. S. after ≈øaith to him, that if he will go to his Hou≈øe he will beat him, by which menace he dares not go to his Hou≈øe about his Bu≈øine≈øs, the Obligation is forfeited, 18 Ed. 4.28.

To plead he had ≈øaved the Plaintiff harmle≈øs, and not to ≈øhew how, is ill, Stiles p. 219. Shertliff ver≈ø. Timberly. Allen 72. Ellis and Box. If it be that from time to time he hath ≈øaved him harmle≈øs, its well enough, Stiles p. 353. M. 1652. Bond and Martin. But in Condition to ≈øave harmle≈øs from E≈øcapes; the Defendant pleads he had ≈øaved harmle≈øs, but ≈øaith not how; and the Plaintiff demurs generally; Per Cur. its ill on ≈øpecial demurrer, but aided by general demurrer, 2 Keble 629. Hen≈øhaw and Warren. 3 Keble 198. Fletcher and White.
To di≈øcharge and ≈øave harmle≈øs. Qu. if any difference on Man≈øers Ca≈øe, 1 Keble 379. Morgan and Thomas.
In ≈øuch Ca≈øes the Plaintiff ought to plead non damnificat. for that he hath ≈øaved him harmle≈øs, doth imply he was damnified, Ibid.

A Condition was to ≈øave the Obligee harmle≈øs of a Nomine poenae again≈øt M. To plead he had ≈øaved him harmle≈øs, and not to ≈øhew how, is not
good; had he pleaded non damnificatus in the negative, it had been good, Winch. p. 9.

A Condition to keep a Pari≈øh harmle≈øs from a B ‚Ä¢ ≈øtard Child; the Defendant pleads he had ≈øaved the Pari≈øh harmle≈øs, but ≈øhews not how; the Plaintiff replied, That the Pari≈øh was warned before the Ju≈øtices of the Peace at the Se≈ø≈øions, and was there ordered by Record to pay ≈øo much for the keeping of the Child; the Defendant pleads, nul tiel Record; the Plaintiff demure 1. The Plea of nul tiel Record is a good Plea, becau≈øe an Order of Se≈ø≈øions of Peace is a Record. 2. Judgment pro Quer. becau≈øe the Defendants Bar is ill, in that he hath pleaded in the affirmative, and ≈øhews not how. Non damnificatus had been good; and it is not helped by demurrer, it being matter of ≈øub≈øtance, March. 121. n. 200. Anonymus.

A Condition to ≈øave harmle≈øs from all Obligations which he had entred into for him; the Defendant pleads, quod exoneravit & indemp ‚Ä¢ em con≈øervavit from all the Obligations, and ≈øhewn not from what, and yet good, becau≈øe there might be many, and ≈øo to avoid perplexity of pleading; and becau≈øe he pleaded not qu ‚Ä¢ modo exoneravit, but generally, the Plea was ill, Cro. El. p. 916. Braban and Bacon.

A Condition to ≈øave the Pari≈øh harmle≈øs of a Ba≈øtard Child, (vide the Form,) the Defendant pleads, non damnificatus; the Plaintiff replies, That the Defendant nor any other, for the ≈øpace of a month, provided, for the Child, wherefore the Pari≈øh, paid 40 s. for its Maintenance; the Defendant rejoins, he offered to maintain the Child at
his own Charge, and the Pari≈øh refu≈øed to permit him, Et hoc paratus, &c. this rejoinder is ill, becau≈øe it is a departure, „Äà‚óä„Äâ he ought to have pleaded this fir≈øt in his Plea, 2 Sander ‚Ä¶
„Äà‚óä„Äâ . Siderfin p. 444. 2 Keble 219. Mod. Rep. 45. Richards and Hodges.

div.head: Counter-Bonds, Sureties.
div.p: IF the Condition be to di≈øcharge another again≈øt J. S. of an Obligation wherein he is bound, he ought to di≈øcharge him of the Obligation by Relea≈øe, or otherwi≈øe, and it is not ≈øufficient to ≈øave him harmle≈øs, 22 Ed. 4.40. b.

The Defendant pleads non damnificatus‚ñ™ the Plaintiff replies, the Mony was not paid at the da ‚Ä¢ , per quod the Plaintiff became on ‚Ä¢ rabilis, and d ‚Ä¶ ≈øt not go about his Affairs; the Defendant, rejoins, that the Mony was tendered and refu≈øed, ab≈ø
que hoc, that the Plaintiff was chargeable; the Plaintiff demurs, here need not be alledged any ≈øpecial damage; but the ≈øaying he could not attend his Bu≈øine≈øs is ≈øufficient; Judgment pro Qu ‚Ä¢ r. 3 Keble p. 336. T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . 26 Car. 2 B. R. Young and White.
