A Condition to acquit, di≈øcharge, or otherwi≈øe ≈øave harmle≈øs of 12 Bonds entred into by the Plaintiff with the Defendant; and of all Suits and Troubles which may happen thereupon; after Oyer the Defendant pleads performance, the Plaintiff replied, he was ≈øued, and forced to retain an Attorny, and that the Defendant licet ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pius requi≈øitus had not acquitted him; the Defendant demurs, becau≈øe the Plaintiff had not alledged p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ticular
notice to him of the Suit: Per Cur. he is not bound to give ≈øpecial notice, Siderfin p. 442. H. 21 Car. 2. King and Atkins.
An Obligation made by J. S. & ad majorem rei ≈øecuritatem inveni J. D. fideju≈ø≈øorem, and J. D. put his Seal to it; this was his Deed, Cro. P. 29. Eliz. B. R. Skidmore ver≈øus Van Stevan.

One is bound with another as his Surety, jointly and ≈øeverally, they are both principals, and neither Pledge nor Fideju≈ø≈øor for the other; and one cannot have the Writ de plegiis atquietandis again≈øt the other; for this lies not but where one is named expre≈øly as Surety in the Bond, Hob. 53. in Fo≈øter and Jack≈øons Ca≈øe, Dyer 370.

B. was bound with K. for the payment of 200 l. to A. B. The Condition was, If K. ≈øhall ≈øave harmle≈øs B. of all Suits, Quarrels and Demands, touching and concerning the ≈øaid Bond of 200 l. then, &c. B. came to the place of payment at the day, and perceiving no Per≈øon there pre≈øent to pay the 100 l. for K. he to ≈øave the penalty of his Bond, paid the 100 l. to A. B. and ≈øo brought this Action upon the Counter-bond, and upon non damnificatus pleaded, the Plaintiff replied, and ≈øhewed all the ≈øpecial matter; the Defendant demurred; adjudged pro Quer. for it was harm to him, and its not needful for the Plaintiff to be arre≈øted or ≈øued. And this Plea of non damnificatus implied, that the Defendant had ≈øaved him harmle≈øs as by Relea≈øe, payment, or otherwi≈øe. Terror of Suit ≈øo that he dares not go about his Bu≈øine≈øs, is damnification, though he be not arre≈øted by Proce≈øs, 5 Rep. 24. Broughtons
Ca≈øe. Capia ‚Ä¢
i≈ø≈øued out again≈øt a Surety, is a damnification, 2 Bulst. 105. Reve ver≈øus Harris.

The Cu≈øtom of London is, if many are bound as Sureties, if the principal fall of payment, and one of the Sureties be ≈øued upon the Obligation, he may have a Writ de Contributione facienda again≈øt the other Sureties, ≈øuch a Writ was brought in London, and removed in B. R. but it was remanded, Moor n. 266 2 Leon. p. 166, 67. Offly and John≈øon, The Book of Entries, 160.
One Surety may pay the Mony and have the Bond decreed to him in Chancery to make his advantage, Latch 170. Daw≈øon's Ca≈øe.

The Surety cannot plead that the principal was kept in Dure≈ø≈øe, till he and the Defendant entred into the Bond, though the principal might plead it; for none ≈øhall avoid his own bond for the impri≈øonment or danger of any other than him≈øelf only, Crook M. 5 Jac. fo. 187. Hu≈øcomb and Standing, 1 Brownl. p. 64. Martel and Cobb ‚Ä¢

The Defendant in a Counterbond pleads, that the Bond to J.S. (wherein the Plaintiff was bound with him as Surety) was upon u≈øurious Contract, and pleads the Statute & i≈ø≈øl ‚Ä¢ non damnificatu ‚Ä¢ , no Plea; for he ought to ≈øave his Surety harmle≈øs, and it ≈øhall not be intended that the Surety knew of the u≈øurious Contract, Crook Eliz. p. 588. Robin≈øon and May p. 643. Boulton and Downham, Noy p. 73. 3. Leon. 63. Potkin's Ca≈øe, 2 Leon. 166. Ba≈ø≈øet and P ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ . The Stature ≈øaith, All Bonds and collateral A≈ø≈øurancos made for the Payment of Mony lent upon U≈øury, ≈øhall be interly void. Counter-Bond here was not for the payment
of the Mony lent, but for the Indemnity of the Surety.

A Condition to ≈øave harmle≈øs in a Counter-Bond. The Defendant paid not the Mony at the day, this is a pre≈øent Forfeiture of the Counter-Bond, for he hath put the Plaintiff in danger of being arre≈øted, and it is a pre≈øent damage, 3 Bul≈øtr. p. 233. Abhors and John≈øon, 10 E. 4.27, 28.

The Defendant pleads, he had ≈øaved the Plaintiff harmle≈øs. The Plaintiff replied that the Mony was not paid, and Proce≈øs went out again≈øt him. The Plaintiff rejoyns, he had not any notice of the Damnification. No good Rejoynder. 1. The Defendant him≈øelf ought to take notice of the Act of a Stranger. 2. It is a departure from the Bar, 1. Sanders 117. Cutler and Southern, Vid. the Pleadings.

If a Man be bound to pre≈øerve his Surety ≈øans damage of an Obligation, if he ≈øuffer the Obligation to be forfeited, yet this is not any Damnification, and by this the Counter-Bond is not forfeited, cited in Freeman and Sheens Ca≈øe. 1 Rolls Rep. p. 7. Qu. de ceo.

The Defendant pleads, that J. S. (the Creditor) ≈øued the Plaintiff on the Bond, and had Judgment; but before Execution he delivered the Mony to the Plaintiff to ≈øatisfie it; no Plea; for by the Judgment the party is damnified, and the Co≈øts are not paid, Crook Eliz. p. 396. Bothwright and Harvy, 1 Rolls Abr. 432. Id. Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads, that at the day of payment he was going ad ≈øolvend. and that the Plaintiff by Covin betwixt him and another Stranger cau≈øed the Defendant to be impri≈øoned until after
Sun-≈øet, it is an ill Surmi≈øe and no Ba ‚Ä¢ , Crook Eliz. 6 2. Morris and Lutter ‚Ä¢ .

The Plaintiff declares, that at the Reque≈øt of the Defendant he became bound with a third per≈øon to pay Mony to J.S. at a day; and the Defendant became bound to the Plaintiff with Condition that if the Defendant did pay the Mony to J. S. at the day for which the Plaintiff was bound, and in the mean time ≈øhould ≈øave him harmle≈øs, then, &c. The Defendant pleads, be cau≈øed the party with whom the Plaintiff was bound to ≈øubmit him≈øelf to pri≈øon, and that the Plaintiff was not damnifieth. The Plaintiff denies not the Bar, but ≈øays that a Latitat was ≈øued out again≈øt him, and ≈øo feared. The Defendant demurs; the Plea is ill, and the other hath alledged an ill Breach, he ≈øaith not he took a Lat. prout patet per Record the words (in the mean time) refer to the la≈øt words of the Condition. Judgment pro Def. Stiles p. 356. Young and Petit.
Mony prayed out of the Coroners hands by one who had paid the Debt as Surety, 2 Keb. 400. Fo≈øter and Clo≈øon.

A Condition, whereas the Plaintiff was obliged in ≈øuch Obligations for the Defendant; that if „Äà‚óä„Äâ were charged or mole≈øted in his Body or Goods for tho≈øe Obligations, he would within a Month ≈øatisfie him for it. The Defendant ≈øaith, he hath paid him ≈øuch a Sum for all his Charges within a Month, no Plea‚ñ™ for he ought to ≈øhew how the Plaintiff was mole≈øted, and then he had ≈øatisfied ≈øo much, or that was not mole≈øted, Crook Eliz. p. 393. Hutchin≈øon and Le ‚Ä¢ ≈øon.

The Condition is if R. C. acquit R. F. and J. B. of ≈øuch Sureties they have made to N. that then, &c. pleaded that R. F. and J. B. were bound to N. in 15 l. and R. C. did procure Acquittances of N. to R. F. and J. B. for the ≈øame: See the form of pleading: Quaere if good Plea, 1 H. 7.30. a.

The Condition was to ≈øecure him harmle≈øs again≈øt J. S. in an Action for 53 l. for which he was Bail for him. The Defendant pleads he had paid to J. S. 20 l. in ≈øatisfaction of the 53 l. and ≈øo kept him harmle≈øs; but for that the Plaintiff might be damnified before the payment, to which he doth not an≈øwer, the Plea is ill, Crook Eliz. p. 136. Davies and Thomas.

In Debt on a Counter-bond for Security of Bail given for appearance of the Defendant. The Defendant pleads non damnificatus. The Plaintiff replied Non comparuit. The Defendant rejoyns, that the fir≈øt Bond given was void per 23 H. 6. and that there was no Latitat i≈ø≈øued forth; per Cur. this is a departure. But notwith≈øtanding the Bond the party is not e≈øtopt to ≈øay there was no Latitat; but the Non-appearance is a damnification, be the Bond void or not, 1 Keb. 59, 98. Cook and Morgan.

div.head: Condition to permit.
div.p:
WHere no Act is to be done, but only a Permittance, he need not plead it ≈øpecially; and non permifit or permi≈øit is a good Plea. A Covenant, that the Plaintiff to ≈øuch of the ≈øaid Lands, as by the Cu≈øtom of the Country tunc jacebant fri≈øca, ≈øhould have free ingre≈øs, &c.
The Defendant pleads, quod per ‚Ä¢ ni≈øit Querentem intrare, &c. in tales terras quales tunc jacebant fri≈øco ≈øecundum con≈øuetud, patriae; he need not ≈øhew what Lands did he fre≈øh, 1 Leon. p. 136. Littleton and Perne.

L. covenants with S. that he would ≈øuffer him and his A≈ø≈øigns to have free ingre≈øs, &c. into his Hou≈øe and Shop without let or interruption of the ≈øaid L. and that S. appunctuavit one T. ut ≈øervientem ≈øuum in Me≈ø≈øuag. &c. intrare in u≈øum de S. ≈øuper quo praedict. T. intravit, & praedictas L. expulit. Moved in Arre≈øt. 1. It is alledged L. expels the Servant, and this was the expul≈øion of the Ma≈øter. 2. Appunctuavit intrare, and doth not ≈øay what time, for perhaps his Licence to enter might be determined. 3. It is not ≈øaid at what time he entred, but ≈øuper quo intravit; all the≈øe Exceptions were over-ruled, 2 Rolls Rep. 78. Snelling and Lowe.

The Condition was, if A. (a Stranger) would render him≈øelf to an Arre≈øt in ≈øuch a place. The Defendant pleads A. was a Servant to a Parliament-Man and pleads Priviledge. The Plaintiff demurs, Pro Quer. for A. might render him≈øelf, and let it be at their peril, if they will arre≈øt him, 1 Brownl. Rep. 91. Jack≈øon and Kirton.

A Condition to perform all Covenants in a Lea≈øe made by her Husband of a Warren; one whereof was to do no Act to di≈øturb the Le≈ø≈øee; ≈øhe after marries another Husband, who entred on the Plaintiff and cut his Nets, no Title being ≈øhewed by which he entred; The Plaintiff demurred, and Judgment pro Quer. It is not requi≈øite that the Husband be A≈ø≈øignce of the E≈øtate,
but her A≈ø≈øignce of Contract, which ≈øhe might have avoided, the Husband acts in her Right, 1 Keb. 348, 512. Hall ver≈øus Cre≈øwel & Uxor.

One is bound to permit his Tenants to u≈øe the Common, and that he ≈øhall not alter the Cour≈øe of the Common, quod permi≈øit, and that he ≈øhall not alter, &c. is a good Plea generally, 11 Eliz. Dyer 279.

div.head: Condition to ≈øurrender Copyhold Lands.
div.p: THE Condition was, that the Obligor ≈øhould ≈øurrender his Copyhold Land to the u≈øe of the Obligee; he pleaded, he had ≈øurrendred it; ill Plea, becau≈øe he had not ≈øhewed when the Court of the Lord was holden, Winch p. 11. Llewellins Ca≈øe.

The Condition reciting whereas ≈øuch Copyhold Lands were to be ≈øurrendred by A. S. at her full age, to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Hammond and Guy and their Heirs, and that Gay ≈øhould pay to Hammond 33 l. at ≈øuch a day, and if he failed it ≈øhould be to the u≈øe of Hammond and his Heirs. It was conditioned, that if the Obligor procured the ≈øaid A. S. at her full age to ≈øurrender to the u≈øe of Hammond and his Heirs, and if Hammond and his Heirs might have and enjoy the ≈øaid Lands to him and his Heirs, then the Obligation, &c. The Defendant pleads Gay paid not the 33 l. and that A. S. came of full age ≈øuch a day, and afterwards at ≈øuch a Court in full Court did ≈øurrender, relea≈øe and quit claim to the Plaintiff, being in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, all her E≈øtate, Right and Intere≈øt in the ≈øame Tenements, and that the Plaintiff always after might
have enjoyed the ≈øame Tenements. The Plaintiff replies, quod bene & verans e≈øt, that the ≈øaid A. S. did ≈øurrender prout, &c. but that afterwards (≈øuch a day) the ≈øaid Gay entred and expelled him; The Defendant demurs, per Cur. the Replication is not good, becau≈øe he hath not ≈øhewed he was evicted by lawful Title, for otherwi≈øe this Bond doth not extend to it; and per Cur. the Bar (that ≈øhall be ≈øurrendred and relea≈øed in Court) is good and certain enough according to common intendment. And although it be not ≈øaid ≈øhe ≈øurrendred to the u≈øe of the Plaintiff, yet it being alledged it was ≈øurrendred in Court and accepted by the Plaintiff and confe≈ø≈øed by the Replication, it is good, Crook Car. fir≈øt Ca≈øe, Hammond and Dod.

The Condition, whereas F. held Copyhold Land of Sir J. K. if he within ≈øix Months after the death of F. granted the Land to the Plaintiff and two others whom the Plaintiff ≈øhould name, for three Lives according to the Cu≈øtom of the Mannor, that then, &c. The Defendant pleaded, the Plaintiff nominated no Lives. The Plaintiff replies, Sir J. K. within the ≈øixth Months granted it to J. S. and two others for their Lives, who are yet alive, the Defendant pleads non con ‚Ä¢ o≈ø≈øit, and found again≈øt him. It is not Error, that the Plaintiff in his Replication ≈øhows not that the lands are Copyhold, for the Condition reciting it is Copyhold Land, he is e≈øtopt, Crook Ja ‚Ä¢ . p. 275. Sir J. Kernes Ca≈øe.

div.head: To ≈øatisfie Imbeziled Goods.
div.p: ONe was bound to ≈øatisfie for Goods he had imbeziled; he pleads that upon ≈øuit for tho≈øe Goods, he was taken in Execution for the damage. No Plea 33 H. b 47. Hillaries Ca≈øe, Hob. p. 59.

The Condition, if A. turned over Apprentice ≈øhould wa≈øte the Goods of his Ma≈øter, to pay what the Ma≈øter was damnified; no damage pleaded. Plaintiff ≈øets forth goods wa≈øted, but its forth no notice given to the Defendant; no notice is nece≈ø≈øary; when any one undertakes for a third per≈øon, he mu≈øt an≈øwer for him at his peril, becau≈øe the imde≈øilment is not in the Coni≈øance of the Plaintiff, and the particulars of the Goods wa≈øted need not be ≈øet forth. 1 Keb. 467.471. French and Beirce.

div.head: To enjoy Office.
div.p:
A Condition, Whereas the Plaintiff and Defendant be now jointly ≈øei≈øed of the Office of the Regi≈øtry of the Court of Admiralty: if the Defendant ≈øhall permit the Plaintiff to u≈øe the ≈øaid Office, and take the profits of it to his own u≈øe during his Life, without let or interruption done by him, then, &c. the Defendant pleads, That the Cu≈øtom of the Realm of England is, that the Lord Admiral might grant the ≈øaid Office during his own Life; and the Lord Clynton did grant it to the Plaintiff and Defendant, and dyed: and the Lord Howard granted to Wade, who ou≈øted
him; before which time the Defendant ≈øuffered the Plaintiff to enjoy the ≈øaid Office, and to take the Profits; the Plaintiff demurs; male plea, for if it be the cu≈øtom of England, then its common Law, and this cannot be tryed, for no Venue can be from the Realm of England; al≈øo he doth not an≈øwer to any time after the grant of Admiral Howard; for though Wade might lawfully put him out, yet the Defendant could not, 2 Leon. 114. Parker and Harrold.

Condition, if the Plaintiff had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and enjoyed the Office of Ecadle≈øhip, &c. that then, &c. Defendant pleads, quod habuit gavi≈øus fuit & occup ‚Ä¢ vit, &c. Jury find the Plaintiff did exerci≈øe and occupy that Office, but whether that ≈øhall be ≈øaid having and enjoying, they doubted. Per Cur. diver≈øity between an Office in verity and an Office in reputation; for of Office in reputation there can be no other po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion but by occupation, for it is no Office in Intere≈øt, as Office of Mar≈øhal, of Ju≈øtice of A≈ø≈øize, Cro. Eliz. p. 382. Dudly and King ‚Ä¢ n.

div.head: To procure an Office, Place, Benefice.
div.p:
THe Condition was, if S. procure a Grant of the next Avoydance of the Arch-Deaconry of Staff. to be made to the ≈øaid Bingham, ≈øo that the ≈øaid Bingham to ≈øuch next Avoydance may pre≈øent, that then, &c. the Ca≈øe was, by the means of S. the Grant of the ≈øaid next Avoydance was made to Bingham, but before the next Avoydance, the pre≈øent Arch-Deacon was made Bi≈øhop, ≈øo as the Pre≈øentment to the n ‚Ä¢ t Avoydance appertained to the ‚Ä¢ en; Per Cur. the Condition was not performed
and that by rea≈øon of the≈øe words (≈øo that Bingham may pre≈øented) 3 L ‚Ä¢ on. 151. Bingham and Squire.

Condition, if the Defendant do not lawfully procure Market to be granted within ≈øix Months of a return of an ad quod damnum to be ≈øued out for that purpo≈øe, that them if the Obligor pay 20 l. to the Obligee, then, &c. it was returned to be ad damnum, and ≈øo no Market procured‚ñ™ Obligee ≈øhall recover the 20 l. Rationem, vide 2. Rolls Rep. 467. J ‚Ä¶
and March.

div.head:
Conditions concerning Writings
to procure
to deliver.
to execute
to make.
div.p:
IF a Man bind him≈øelf to procure a Stranger to make a Relea≈øe of all his Right and Title to Land, the Obligor mu≈øt procure him to make ≈øuch a Relea≈øe de facto, though he had no right. 1 S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ders 216. Doughty and Neal. Vide there the Form of the Condition and the Pleadings.

A Condition if J. S. make Obligation to the Plaintiff before Michaelmas, that then, &c. the Defendant pleads J. S. made the Obligation, and ≈øealed it and delivered it to another as his Deed, to the U≈øe of the Plaintiff, Per Cur. its no performance, for perhaps the other will not deliver it to the Plaintiff, Cro. Eliz. p. 143. Bea≈øe and Draycot.

Condition to pay 100 l. to the Plaintiff when he ≈øhall take a ≈øufficient di≈øcharge from A. and B. for the payment of Legacies: an Acquittance from
one by the others con≈øent is no ≈øufficient di≈øcharge, 1 Keb. 739. Forquer and Fra ‚Ä¢ .

Condition that the Daughters when they come to full Age ≈øhall give Relea≈øes, it ≈øhall be taken di
‚Ä¢ 2 Keb. 591.
‚Ä¢ o≈øviles Ca≈øe.

Condition to give ≈øuch a Relea≈øe and Di≈øcharge from and again≈øt him and his Heirs, for receipt of a hundred Marks, as by the Judge of the Prerogative Court of Canterbury ≈øhall be thought meet: the Defendant pleads the Judge did not appoint any relea≈øe or di≈øcharge, &c. no Plea, for it ≈øhould be alledged he cau≈øed a Relea≈øe to be drawn, and tendered to the Judge to be allowed of, for it is on his part in di≈øcharge of his Obligation, to draw ≈øuch a Relea≈øe as the Judge ≈øhall allow: Cro. Eliz. p. 716. Lamb and Brownwent, 5 Rep. 23. b. The Judge is a ≈øtranger to the Condition, and he hath taken it upon him to do it at his peril; he ought to procure the Judge to direct it: Lambs Ca≈øe.

A Condition, if Obligor deliver to the Plaintiff an Obligation in which he was bound to the Defendant before ≈øuch a day; that then, &c. the Defendant ≈øueth the Plaintiff upon the Obligation and recovereth, and afterwards and before the day he delivers it to him; this is no performance; though the words were performed, yet the intent was not; for the intent was, he ≈øhould have the Obligation for his di≈øcharge, which is not by the delivery, for tranfit in rem, judicatam, and he may have the benefit of the judgment, Cro. Elz. p. 7. Teales Ca≈øe.

If a man not Lettered be bound to make a Deed, he is not bound to ≈øeal and deliver any
Writing which ≈øhall be tendred to him, unle≈øs there be ≈øome body pre≈øent that may read this to him, or expound it if he reque≈øt it, 2 Rep. 3. Man≈øers Ca≈øe.

The Condition was, to ≈øeal and execute a Relea≈øe to the Plaintiff. The Defendant demurs, becau≈øe the Plaintiff in his Declaration did not alledge a Tender, the Condition not being to make, but to ≈øeal and execute. Per Cur. he is bound to do it without a tender, Mod. Rep. 104. Baker and Bul≈øtrode.
Condition was, That the Obligor ≈øhall deliver all Writings concerning ≈øuch Land; its a good Plea to ≈øay generally; that he had delivered all the Writings, 28 H. 8. Dyer 28. 4 H. 7.12.

Condition to enfeoff the Obligor of certain Lands, at ≈øuch a day and place. Pleaded that the Defendant was pre≈øent there all the day to enfeoff the Plaintiff, and that the Plaintiff came not there to accept of this: Plaintiff replies, he was there pre≈øent all the day to accept the enfeoffment, without that that the Defendant was there: its a good Replication, Doct. pl. 323. 22. Ed. 4.43.

div.head: Condition to deliver Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.
div.p:
COndition if R. H. upon reque≈øt by the Plaintiff his Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns ≈øhould deliver the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of ≈øuch a Farm to the Plaintiff, his Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns, &c. The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns the Rever≈øion by Deed to Richard and Henry P. in Fee. At the day H. P. alone came and demanded the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, without notice given of ‚Ä¢ s coming, &c.
Per Cur. 1 The de ‚Ä¢ of H. P. is the demand of both, and the delivery of the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion to one had been delivery to both. 2 The two Barga ‚Ä¢ es need not give notice to the Defendant that they had the Rever≈øion by Bargain and Sale; for being the condition of a Bond, it is at his Peril to take notice, being obliged to deliver it to him or his A≈ø≈øigns, Cro. Jac. p. 475. Hingen and Pain. Bridgman Rep. 128.

The Condition was, that the Defendant ≈øhould not deliver Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion to any but the Le≈ø≈øor, or ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhould lawfully recover. The Defendant pleads he did not deliver but to ≈øuch per≈øons as lawfully recovered it: Good Plea, he need not ≈øhew he delivered to J. S. by lawful Title, 1 Keb. 380, 413. Nicholas and Pullen.

div.head: Conditions concerning Wives.
div.p: COndition not to ≈øell the Apparel of his Wife; its a good condition.
If a man bind him≈øelf to a ≈øtranger to pay 20 l. per Annum to his Wife, this is good, 1 Rol. Rep. 334. Smith and Wat≈øon.

The Condition was to permit his Wife to make a Will, and di≈øpo≈øe ≈øuch Legacies; the Defendant pleads ≈øhe made no Will; it was found ≈øhe made a Will, but that ≈øhe was Covert, &c. Per Cur. This is a good Will, within the intent of the Condition, and it is but her appointment, which the Husband by his Obligation is bound to perform, Cro. Car. 219. Marriot and Kin ‚Ä¢ an.

The Condition was to permit his Wife to make a Will, and to di≈øpo≈øe of one hundred pounds
of her Husbands Goods, „Äà‚óä„Äâ paid within one year after her decea≈øe. The Defendant pleads ‚Ä¢ e permitted his Wife to make a Will: the Plaintiff demurs. Per Cur. he ought to have pleaded, that he had paid accordingly, otherwi≈øe he doth but an≈øwer to one part of the Condition. Cro. Car. 597. Sherman and Lally.

The Condition was, if he ≈øhould ≈øurvive A. S. his Wife, that if within three Months after her decea≈øe there were paid to the Obligee 300 l. to and for ≈øuch u≈øes and purpo≈øes as the ≈øaid A. S. by any Writing under her Hand and Seal ≈øub≈øcribed, &c. ≈øhould nominate and appoint, that then, &c. The Defendant pleads ≈øhe did not limit, &c. any u≈øe for the imployment of that mony. The Plaintiff replies, ≈øhe by her Will in Writing, &c. did appoint ≈øuch Sums to be paid. The Defendant demurs, becau≈øe ≈øhe ought to have made a Deed in Writing, and not a Will. But Per Cur. this Declaration was good; and though the pleading was, that A. S. Voluit & devi≈øavit, and not that it was appointed by her; yet Per Cur. well enough; for it is not properly a Will that is made by a feme Covert, but a Writing in nature of a Will. Cro. Car. 376. Tille and Petre.
Authority was given to the Wife to ‚Ä¢ l≈øo 300 l. and ≈øhe di≈øpo≈øeth 200 l. by fifties, and well.

Condition to make a Will in the pre≈øence of her Husband, or if he refu≈øes it, ≈øuch per≈øon as her Hu≈øband ≈øhould appoint. Qu. If refu≈øal ought to be alledged, or notice to the Husband, 1 Keb. 347. Harris ver≈øus Beffie.

To procure a Marriage between the Plaintiff and B. P. ≈øuch a day, or before. The Defendant pleads
the Plaintiff before that day called B. P. Whore, and u≈øed other ba≈øe Language, by rea≈øon whereof the Defendant could not procure the Marriage; no Plea, for he hath not ≈øhewed his endeavour to procure the ≈øaid Marriage; and notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch words they might have inter-married, Cro. El. p. 694. Blandford and Andrews.

A Condition to pay ≈øuch a Sum as E. B. ≈øhould appoint after Marriage with the Defendant by her la≈øt Will, or other Writing ≈øigned in tiel form; the Defendant ≈øaith ≈øhe made no Will, nor any other Writing, &c. the Plaintiff ≈øets an appointment in Writing forth; the Defendant ≈øaith it was after revoked; this is no departure, becau≈øe its a fortification of the Bar, and could not be fore≈øeen, and its revocable, contrary to Hobert, Ormonds Ca≈øe, 1 Keble p. 821. Shepard and Spencer.

A Condition not to meddle with the Goods of the Feme, which were her fir≈øt Husbands, but that ≈øhe and her Children might enjoy them ≈øans di≈øturbance, claim or interruption of the Defendant; Breach a≈ø≈øigned, that the Defendant took and detained the Goods of the fir≈øt Husband; and I≈ø≈øue pro Quer. and the Breach well a≈ø≈øigned Cro. Car. p. 204. Crawle and Daw≈øon.
A Condition to pay ≈øo much yearly to his Wife; it good, as well as to give her a Gown, 27 H. 8.27.

div.head: Condition to accept a Lea≈øe.
div.p: A Condition, If the Obligor accepted a Lea≈øe by Indenture of ≈øuch Lands upon the Plaintiffs reque≈øt, and ≈øealed a Counter-part thereof, then, &c. The Defendant pleads, the Plaintiff did not reque≈øt him to accept a Lea≈øe; the Plaintiff replies, he had cau≈øed an Indenture to be drawn, and ingro≈øt according to the ≈øaid Condition, and a Label affixed cum ≈øera appen≈øa, and required and offered it to the Defendant to accept thereof, and he refu≈øed; I≈ø≈øue upon the reque≈øt found pro Quer. Error. 1. Sera is not Wax, ≈øed non allocatur. 2. Becau≈øe he avers not the Lands mentioned in the Indenture, are the ≈øame in the Condition; but becau≈øe he pleads non requi≈øivit, and he replied it was ≈øecundum formam Conditionis, it ≈øhall be intended the ≈øame Lands; and if they were other Lands, the Defendant ought to ≈øhew it, Cro. Car. 560. Lee ver≈øus Ru≈ø≈øel.

div.head: Condition to appear at a Place.
div.p: THE Condition was, That S. and his Wife ≈øhould appear at the Mar≈øhals Court: S. appears and pleads, that at the time of the Obligation he was ≈øolus & innuptus; Judgment pro Quer. ≈øur demurer, Stiles p. 17. Pain and Skelton.
To appear within eight days after warning‚ñ™ warning ought to be ≈øhewn to be given of the Action brought, Cro. Jac. 46. Yelv. p. 52. Hargrave and Rogers.

In Debt on an Obligation to appear at a certain day; Impri≈øonment is no Plea, 2 Rolls Rep. 136. Anonymus. In a Recognizance to appear, &c. Impri≈øonment by Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Ad ‚Ä¢
ralty is an excu≈øe, Moor n. 251. Lacies Ca≈øe.

A Condition to come to the Kings Head, &c. on the 12th of October, and there elect two Arbitrators, who with two others to be elected by the Plaintiff, ≈øhould arbitrate of all Sums, &c. the Defendant pleads, on the 12th of October he came to the Kings Head, &c. and there elected two Arbitrators, but the Plaintiff was not there; Plea not good, becau≈øe he ≈øhewed not at what hour of the day he came, nor how long time he continued there; for he ought to be there ≈øo long time before the la≈øt in≈øtant, as the Arbitrament may be made; neither doth he ≈øhew that his two Arbitrators were there pre≈øent, Cro. Eliz. 549. Edmonds ver≈øus Marks.

The Under-Sheriff took a Man by Attachment out of Chancery, who took Bond of him to appear at the day contained in the Attachment: Per Cur. the Bond is void, for that the Defendant was not bailable upon the Attachment, 3 Leon. 208. Bland and Riccards.

Debt upon an Obligation taken in the Kings Name, in the Court of Reque≈øts, with a Condition to appear before the Ma≈øter, &c. the declaration is general, that the Defendant ≈øuch a year and day by his Obligation did acknowledge him≈øelf to be bound to the King in 60 l. to be paid, &c. and naught, becau≈øe it did not appear to be taken in a Court of Record, 1 Brownl. p. 68. Rex ver≈øus Ca≈øtle.

div.head: Not to alien.
div.p: A Condition to perform Covenants; one was, That the Le≈ø≈øee, his Executors or A≈ø≈øigns, nor any other who ≈øhall come to have the E≈øtate or Intere≈øt in the Term, ≈øhall not alien their E≈øtate ≈øans licence of the Le≈ø≈øor, but only to his Wife or Children; the Le≈ø≈øee devi≈øeth it to his Wife; ≈øhe alieus the Covenant is broken, it extends to the Le≈ø≈øee and his A≈ø≈øigns, and ≈øhe is A≈ø≈øignee expre≈øs‚ñ™ ≈øo although there was once an Alienation by Licence, yet that A≈ø≈øignee cannot alien ≈øans Licence. Where a Condition is in a Lea≈øe that neither he nor his A≈ø≈øigns ≈øhould alien without Licence; the Le≈ø≈øee died Inte≈øtate, the Admini≈øtrator was bound by this Condition, Cro. El. 757. Thornil and Adams ver≈øus King & ≈øa Feme.

A Condition not to alien without the con≈øent of the Le≈ø≈øor; the Le≈ø≈øee makes his Executor, and devi≈øeth this to him; the Executor enters generally, the Te≈øtator not being indebted to any; this is a Forfeiture, 1. Rolls Abr. 429. Damp ‚Ä¢
and Symons.

div.head: Not to continue a Suit.
div.p: A Condition that he ≈øhall not continue ≈øuch a Suit. If he continue it by an Attorny, its a Breach; alit. if the Attorny enters the Continuance without his privity, Cro. Jac. 525. Gray and Gray.

div.head: To convey Land upon Marriage.
div.p:
THE Condition was, That after Marriage of the Plaintiff, and having a Son by his Wife, that if he conveyed Lands to the „Äà‚óä„Äâ of ‚Ä¢
l. per a ‚Ä¢ n. in Tail to the Son, to enjoy after the death of the Obligor, that then, &c. the defendant ≈øhews the day of the Ma ‚Ä¢ , and the having of a Son, and that he made „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to a Stranger, to the u≈øe of him≈øelf „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ after to the u≈øe of the Son in Tail; the Plaintiff replies, quod non feoffavit; the Bar is ill, for the Infant was not made party to the Conveyance, nor had any Deed to prove his E≈øtate; but the Plaintiff by the Replication hath admitted the ‚Ä¢ ar to be good; and he may traver≈øe the Feoffment or the U≈øes, Cro. Eliz. p. 825. Statfield and Somer≈øet.

A Condition, if the Obligor pay 200 l. by the fir≈øt of December 1634. that then the Surrenderce ≈øhould reconvey on reque≈øt; the Plaintiff alledgeth a Reque≈øt in 1644. the Defendant demurs: Per Cur. the Surrender being ab≈øolute, and in tru≈øt only for payment, there being no payment at the day, this Mortgage is irremediable; Judgment pro Defendente, 3 Keb. 786. Hancocks Ca≈øe.

div.head: To perform a Promi≈øe.
div.p:
A Condition to perform ≈øuch a Promi≈øe made by the Obligor to the Obligee, but it not appearing when the breach of Promi≈øe was
made, it was Error, Stiles 17. Sander≈øon and Martin.

div.head: Condition to do things belonging to a Trade.
div.p: A Condition to make all ≈øuch Linnen as he ≈øhould want during his living ≈øingle; the Semp≈øtre≈øs is not bound to find Linen; nor a Tailor Materials; the Intent may guide the Contracts; contra of a Shoe-maker, Gold-≈ømith, &c. 1 Keble 466. Oates ver≈øus Thornel.

div.head: Condition to deliver Goods, or pay Value.
div.p: A Condition to deliver all the Tackle of a Ship mentioned in an Inventory, under the Hands of four Men, or in default thereof to pay ≈øo much Mony to the Plaintiff before ≈øuch a Fea≈øt as the four Men ≈øhould value the Tackle at; the Defendant ≈øaid they did not value the Tackle; no Plea, for he had election to do two things; and if he cannot do the one, he is to do the other; and it is at his peril to procure the Men to value the Tackle, Moor n. 844. More and Morecomb.

A Condition at the end of the Term of a Lea≈øe of Lands and Goods, to deliver the ≈øaid Goods to T. or make him ≈øuch ≈øatisfaction for them as ≈øhall be by two indifferent Per≈øons to be elected for review of them, thought fit; the Defendant pleads, two Per≈øons were not elected; the Plaintiff replies, two were elected; the Defendant rejoins, that they were not cho≈øen by con≈øent of
both, for the Defendant con≈øe ‚Ä¢ no ‚Ä¢ to the election: Per Cur. the election by the Plaintiff is ≈øufficient; for the word (indifferent) ≈øhall be referred to the Parties elected, and not to the election of the Parties; aliter, if it had been by two Per≈øons indifferently to be cho≈øen, 2 Rolls Rep. 86. Talbot and Ben≈øon. 5 Rep. Hungates Ca≈øe.

div.head: Condition to reap and carry Corn, &c. over the u≈øual Way.
div.p:
A Condition to permit and ≈øuffer J. S. quietly to reap and carry, &c. without any di≈øturbance or interruption of him; the Defendant pleads permi≈øit; the Plaintiff replies, there were ≈øome Acres ≈øowen with Rye, and ≈øhews the certainty; and coming to reap he prohibited him, ≈øaying the≈øe words, Moneo & prohibeo te quod ne
que metes ibid. ne
que abcarriabis, &c. this di≈øturbance is a Breach, 1 Ander≈øon n. 188. fol. 137. Bur and Higs.

div.head: Condition to give an Account.
div.p: A Condition to give account of all Monies gathered by vertue of a Brie ‚Ä¢ &c. the Defendant pleads, he gave account of all ≈øuch Monies; ill Plea; he ought to ≈øpecifie what he had received, or el≈øe to ≈øay he had received nothing, 1 Keb. 760. Woodcot ver≈øus Cole.

A Condition to give a ju≈øt and true account, (being a B ‚Ä¢ s Clark;) the Defendant pleads performance, the Plaintiff replies, by receipt of 30 l. the Defendant rejoins, it was ≈øtollen out of the Plaintiffs Count hou≈øe; the Plaintiff demurs; the Robbery is a good Bar, 2 Keble 761, 779, 830. Vere and Smith.

A Condition was, to render a full account to the Plaintiff of all ≈øuch Sums of Mony and Goods which were due and owing to W. N. at the time of his death, which ≈øhall any ways come to the hands of the Defendant, and ≈øhall upon ≈øuch account, within the ≈øpace of one Week, when required, make an equal dividend of all ≈øuch Sums of Mony and Goods, and pay the Plaintiff his proportion of the ≈øame; the Defendant pleads no Goods or Sums of Mony came to his hands. Et hoc paratus, &c. the Plaintiff replies, a Silver Bowl belonging to the ≈øaid W. N. at his death came to the Defendants hands ≈øuch a day and place. Et hoc paratus e≈øt verificare; the Defendant demurs: Per Cur. the Replication is ill, for the Plaintiff hath not ≈øhewed a Breach; for he
ought to ≈øha ‚Ä¢ e the Defendant had „Äà‚óä„Äâ made a dividend, or paid the proportion 1 Sander ‚Ä¢
100. Heyma ‚Ä¢
and Gerrard.

div.head: Conditions concerning Wills and Legaci ‚Ä¢ .
div.p: A Condition to ≈øuffer his Wife to make her Will, vide antea.

A Condition to ob≈øerve, perform, fullfil and keep the Will of M. D. in all Points and Articles, according to the true intent and meaning thereof, that then, &c. and D. M. by his Will bequeathed to the Poor of ≈øuch a Town 10 l. and to J. S. 3 l. The Defendant pleads he had paid the 10 l. to the Poor, and as to the 33 l. he is, and always was ready to pay the ≈øame to the ≈øaid J. S. if he had demanded it; a good Plea; for this Obligation (the Condition of which being general to perform the Will) hath not altered the nature of the payment of the Legacy; but the ≈øame remains payable in ≈øuch manner as before upon reque≈øt, 1 Leon. p. 17. Fringe and Lewis.

A Condition to find J. S. till he come to the Age of 21 years, ≈øufficient Meat, Drink and Apparel; he pleads, he had found ≈øufficient Meat, Drink and Apparel all the time at W. its good‚ñ™ though he alledge it generally; and I≈ø≈øue was taken upon the Apparel; for he dur≈øt not take I≈ø≈øue upon all the things for the doublene≈øs, 12 H. 7.14.
A Condition to have free ingre≈øs, egre≈øs and regre≈øs; he pleads, he had ingre≈øs, ‚Ä¢ egre≈øs and regre≈øs, and ≈øaith not (frank) male Bar, Latch. 47. Clim≈øon and Pool.

A Condition to have all the Debts, and that the Defendant ≈øhould not relea≈øe any in a certain Schedule mentioned; the Defendant pleads performance generally, but doth not ≈øet forth the Schedule; he ≈øhould have ≈øhewed what were the Debts mentioned, and then have averred performance de omnibus & ≈øingulis, & quod non relax ‚Ä¢
vit. Qu. 1 Keble 680. Barcroft and Doughty.

A Condition, If the Defendant ≈øhould make compo≈øition with one E. for Lands, &c. then he ≈øhould pay the Plaintiff 30 l. The Defendant pleads, he made no compo≈øition; the Plaintiff replies, that the ≈øaid E. did grant unto the Defendant a Rent-charge of 5 Marks in Fee, in ≈øatisfaction of his Title, &c. which the Defendant did accept, &c. and ≈øo he made compo≈øition; the Defendant prote≈øtando E. non conce≈ø≈øit, &c. pro placito, &c. that the Defendant did not accept it in ≈øatisfaction, &c. a good Plea; its no compo≈øition without con≈øent, which depends upon the acceptance, Hob. p. 178. Earle and Tuck.

A. bound to ≈øtand to, and ob≈øerve ≈øuch order and decree as the Kings Coun≈øel of the Court of Reque≈øts ≈øhould make, and that the Defendant did not ob≈øerve it; the Defendant pleads, that the King and his Councel did not make the Decree; no Plea, Mar≈øh Rep. 78. Smith≈øon and Simp≈øon.

div.head: Expo≈øitions and Constructions of a Condition.
div.p:
I ≈øhall now ≈øhew how Conditions are to be expounded and con≈øtrued by ≈øome ≈øpecial Rules and Ca≈øes, and what ≈øhall be intended a
good performance, Et vide ≈øupra ≈øpar≈øim ≈øub multis titulis.
Sometimes Conditions mu≈øt be performed according to the very Words and Circum≈øtances.

A Condition to ≈øtand to the Award of J. S. ≈øo as the ≈øaid Award be made in Writing indented under his Hand and Seal; the Award ≈øhall not bind if it be not indented, though it be under Hand and Seal, 1 Rolls Abr. 409. Holmes and Ho ‚Ä¢ .
Vid, infra plus tit. Pleadings, Where a Man is to plead according to the expre≈øs Words of the Condition.
If the Condition be performed in ≈øub≈øtance it is good, though it differ in words.
Where one is bound to deliver the Te≈øtament of the Te≈øtator, if he pleads he hath delivered Literas Te≈øtamentarias, it is good, 7 E. 4.3.

When the Condition is to make a Feoffment, Lea≈øe and Relea≈øe is a good performance, 17 E.
‚Ä¢ .3. Though this be a collateral Condition, yet it is well performed, for it amount in Law to a Feoffement, Co. Lit. 207. a.

If the Covenant be to grant the Rever≈øion of the Tenant for Life or Years, and he enters upon the Le≈ø≈øee and makes a Feoffment, and the Le≈ø≈øee re-enters; the Condition is performed, for the Effect is performed, 1 Rolls Abr. 426.

The Condition is to give Licence to the Obligee to carry Trees, &c. and he gives him Licence, the Condition is performed, though a Stranger, who has Right, di≈øturbs him, for this extends but to the per≈øon of the Obligor by the≈øe words, 18 E. 4. 20. b. Aliter, if the words had been, he ≈øhall have Licence.

But it mu≈øt be performed in ≈øub≈øtance exactly and not in ≈øhew; for the performance of a Condition ought to be true, full and effectual according to Goodal's Ca≈øe, 10 Rep. And not illu≈øory, Lit. Rep. 130. Brockhams Ca≈øe.

A Condition is to retract ≈øuch a Suit, a Di≈øcontinuance of this is no performance, becau≈øe it differs in ≈øub≈øtance; for a Retraxit is a Bar in another Action, and ≈øo is not a Di≈øcontinuance, 20 E. 4.8. Aliter in Ca≈øe of an Award, as if it be awarded he ≈øhall withdraw his Suit; Di≈øcontinuance is a good performance of the Award, for the intent of the Arbitrator was not that he ≈øhould make a legal Retraxit, but pro≈øecute the Suit no farther, 21 E. 4.38.
Improper words ≈øhall not vitiate a Condition; words, by which the intention of the parties may appear, are ≈øufficient to make the Condition of a Bond.

A Condition to ≈øtand to an Award, ita quod the Award be made on or before, &c. but if the Arbitrators ≈øhall not agree upon the Award, that then they ≈øhall choo≈øe and elect an indifferent Man, and they ≈øhall ≈øtand to his final end, &c. Per Cur. the Condition is good enough though not ≈øo properly expre≈ø≈øed. And that the Defendant had forfeited his Obligation for Non-performance of the Award of the Umpire; and though ≈øuch con≈øtruction will prejudice the Defendant (and Conditions being for the benefit of the Defendant ≈øhall be con≈øtrued favourably) yet the Law may not be altered.

But no intention of the parties ≈øhall be con≈øtrued contrary to the expre≈øs words 39 H. 6.10. a. The Condition was that if the Defendant do not pay ≈øo much Mony, the Obligation ≈øhall be void, it was naught, though the intention was he ≈øhould pay the Mony, 1 Sanders 66. B ‚Ä¢ er and Wigg.

The Condition was to appear, &c. and the Conclu≈øion was, then the Condition of this Obligation ≈øhall be void, and ≈øo no words to make the Obligation void; but per Cur. It is a good Condition, though the≈øe words ‚Ä¢ id been omitted, 2 Sanders p. 78. Maleverer and Hawksby.

div.head: Conditions con≈øtrued according to Intent.
div.p: NO intention of the parties ≈øhall con≈øtrue ‚Ä¢ e contrary to the expre≈øs w ‚Ä¢ ds, Vid. a ‚Ä¢ a, 9 H. 7.20.17.22.
Conditions ought to be con≈øtrued according to the intent of the parties, if it may con≈øtare, and Conditions of Obligations are not broken unle≈øs the intent be broken.

A Condition to appear ≈øuch a day in ≈øuch a Term, and the Obligo ‚Ä¢ appears at a day in the ≈øame Term before the day mentioned in the Condition, at the Suit of another Man, which is „Äà‚óä„Äâ appearance in Law for all Suits which ≈øhall be commenced again≈øt him the ≈øame Term, yet becau≈øe this is but an appearance by fiction in Law and not an actual appearance at this day, the Condition is broken; for peradventure had he appeared actually, ≈øpecial Bail might have been required, 1 Ro ‚Ä¢ Abr. 426. Sir Richard Bullers Ca≈øe.

If the Le≈ø≈øee of an Hou≈øe covenant not to lea≈øe the Shop, Yard or other things pertaining to the Hou≈øe, to one that ≈øells Coals; and after he lets all the Hou≈øe to one that ≈øells Coals, he had broken the Condition, for he had broken the intent, 1 Rolls Abridg. 427. Bonner and Langley.

A Condition that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall not do any wa≈øt, and the Le≈ø≈øe ≈øuffers the Hou≈øe to fall for want of covering and repairing, though this is not a Fea≈øance, but only a permi≈ø≈øion; yet the Condition is broken, 1 Rolls Abr. 428. Qu.

The Condition of the Obligation was, if the ≈øaid R. ‚Ä¢ . ≈øhall not at any time or times be aiding or a≈ø≈øi≈øting to T. E in any Actions, Suits, Vexations, &c. The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns a Breach, that before the Obligation he brought Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt the ≈øaid T. E. and R. T. and that he had Judgment again≈øt both and that after the making the Obligation T. E. and R. T. brought Error. Per Cur. it is no Breach for it is not the intent no ‚Ä¢ rea≈øon he ≈øhould be barred to defend him≈øelf by joyning with T. E. again≈øt the unju≈øt proceedings of the Plaintiff. And ≈øo if after Verdict the Plaintiff had relea≈øed and yet took Judgment by Execution, they two might have joyned in Audits Que ‚Ä¢ el, Hobart p. 30 ‚Ä¢ , 1 Rolls Abr. 429. Lamb and Tomp≈øon. This is not properly „Äà‚óä„Äâ Action, but a Suit to di≈øcharge him of a ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ tio Action wherein they mu≈øt joy‚ñ™

A Condition if the Plaintiff might quietly take and enjoy Woods ≈øold; and if the ground, where upon it groweth, be four Miles di≈øtant from Rye, &c. then, &c. The Defendant pleads, the Plaintiff
had quietly, &c. and that the ≈øaid Land by the next high and u≈øual way for Carriages is 4000 Paces from the Town of Rye. Per Cur. the intent was that the Plaintiff by ≈øelling that Wood ≈øhould not inour the danger of the Statute of 23 Eliz. c. 4. And it ought to be pleaded that it is every way di≈øtant four Miles from Rye, and not not by u≈øual ways, and the four Miles by 4000 Paces is well, 2 Leon. p. 113. Ming ‚Ä¢
and Barl.

The Condition was, that if the within bounden J. L. ≈øhall happen to dye without I≈ø≈øue of his Body lawfully to be begotten, that then if the ≈øaid J. L. by his la≈øt Will, or otherwi≈øe in Writing ≈øhall in his Life time lawfully a≈ø≈øure, &c. The Condition being made in benefit of the Obligor ≈øhall have Con≈øtruction according to the intendment of the parties to be collected out of the words of the Condition, and the intention of the parties was, that a Conveyance ≈øhould be made by the Obligor in his Life time by his Will or otherwi≈øe of the Lands, Jones Rep. p. 180. Eaton and Laughter.

The Condition, if the Obligor pay ≈øo much then the Obligation to be void, or otherwi≈øe it ≈øhall be lawful for the Obligee quietly to enjoy ≈øuch Lands. The Defendant pleads quiet enjoyment. The Plaintiff demurs; for that the Condition depends on the Payment or Non-payment, and that concerning the Land is idle: Per Cur. Conditions are to be taken according to the intent of the parties, if it may con≈øtare; but as the≈øe words, then to be void, are placed here, it cannot refer but to that which precedes, and not to the Land which en≈øues. Regula, Words in the beginning or end
of things refer to all, but tho≈øe in the middle refer ad media tantum as Lea≈øe for Life Remainder for Life rendring Rent, this goes to both E≈øtates; but Lea≈øe for Life rendring Rent, Remainder for Life, aliter Siderfin p. 312. Ferres and Newton.

In the Condition it was recited, that the Sheriff had con≈øtituted the Defendant Bailiff of an Hundred within the County. If therefore the Defendant ≈øhall duly execute all Warrants to him directed, then, &c. Warrants ≈øhall only be intended Warrants directed to him as Bayliff o ‚Ä¢ the Hundred, Horton and Day cited 2 Sanders 414. And ≈øuch only as are to be executed within the Hundred. And the Plaintiff mu≈øt ≈øhew the thing to be done was within the Hundred, Allen p. 10. S ‚Ä¢ ang ‚Ä¢ on and Day, me≈øme Ca≈øe.
A Condition, that his elde≈øt Son ≈øhall marry the Daughter of the Obligee, and the Son lye, the ≈øecond Son ≈øhall not marry her, that was not the intent, 27 H. 4.14.

When a Man is bound to do or permit a thing, he ought to do or permit all which depends upon this in the performance of the thing, 11 H. 4. 25. b. 1 Rolls Abr. 422. Collateral things mu≈øt be done or permitted; a Covenant to levy a Fine, it ≈øhall be at his Co≈øts who levies it. A Man is bound to carry my Corn, it is no Plea for him to ≈øay, he had no Cart, for he is bound by implication to provide a Cart and all other nece≈ø≈øaries for the Carriage: So to mow my Gra≈øs, he mu≈øt find In≈øtruments; to cover my Hall, he is bound to find nece≈ø≈øary Stuff, 16 H. 7.9.

A Condition, that J. S. ≈øhall have ingre≈øs into his Hou≈øe; he ought to have a common entrance at the u≈øual Door; and ≈øhall not be put to enter in by a hole backward or by the Chimny, nor may the other make a Ditch before the Door. If a Man hath Right to a Chamber, he mu≈øt not be barred of his ingre≈øs; and yet the Doors ought not to ≈øtand open at Midnight. If I am bound to ≈øuffer J. S. to have a Way over my Land, if I lock the Gates I have broken the Condition, Latch p. 47. Clim≈øon and Pool.
A Condition is to be performed as near as may be.

The Condition is that J. S. and R. G. ≈øhall come in their proper per≈øons before ≈øuch a Fea≈øt to London, and to bring two Sureties to be bound with them to the Plaintiff in the Suit contained in the Obligation, then, &c. J. S. dyes, yet R. G. mu≈øt do this; and although „Äà‚óä„Äâ Condition be not performed in the whole, yet „Äà‚óä„Äâ he may perform this by any po≈ø≈øibility, he mu≈øt do it, 15 H. 7.2. 4 H. 7.3.

A Condition that he or his Heir ≈øhall ≈øurrender, &c. before ≈øuch a day to the u≈øe of the Plaintiffs Executors, his Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, &c. The Defendant pleads, the Plaintiffs Executor dyed after the making of the ≈øaid Bond, and before the ≈øaid Fea≈øt, (viz.) &c. The Plaintiff demurs, and Judgment for the Plaintiff, 1 Brownl. Rep. 7 ‚Ä¢ . Horn and May.
In many Ca≈øes, Endeavour ≈øhall excu≈øe. The Condition was to enfeoff Baron and Feme of Land, if Baron die, if he do it as near as he can it is good, 15 H. 7.2, & 13.
If there be an indifferent con≈øtruction which may be taken two ways, that way ≈øhall be taken which is mo≈øt rea≈øonable to make the Obligation to ≈øtand in force.

The Condition was, that whereas the Defendant had granted an Annuity to the Plaintiff, that the Defendant ≈øhould make farther a≈ø≈øurance to the Plaintiff for the enjoying thereof within one Month when he ≈øhould be thereunto required: Per Cur. the Month ≈øhall be after the Reque≈øt, and not within a Month after the date of the Bond, Stiles p. 242. Wentworth ver≈øus Wentworth.
A Man ≈øhall be ≈øuppo≈øed by the Condition to do what properly belongs to him.

The Condition of the Obligation was, that the great Bell of M. ≈øhould be carried to the Hou≈øe of the Obligor in W. at the Co≈øts of the Men of W. and there to be weighed in the pre≈øence of, &c. and of this the Obligor to make a Tenor to agree in ton ‚Ä¢ & ≈øono with the other Bells of M. In this Ca≈øe the Obligor ought to weigh this, for it belongs to his Occupation, 9 Ed. 4.3. b. 1 Rolls Abr. 465.
If a Man be bound to carry my Corn, he mu≈øt find a Cart; ≈øo to mow my Gra≈øs he mu≈øt find In≈øtruments; ≈øo to cover my Hall he is bound to find nece≈ø≈øary Stuff, 16 H. 7.9.
A Man may be ≈øaid to forfeit a Condition if he do what in him lies to break it, or if he do ≈øuch an Act which may con≈øequently produce a Forfeiture, though in ≈øtrictne≈øs it be not broken by him.

A Condition not to devi≈øe a Lea≈øe to any per≈øon but to his Child or Children, and he devi≈øeth this
to a Stranger, the Executor never con≈øents to the Devi≈øe, yet this is a Forfeiture; for he that had done all that was in his power to pa≈øs this by Will, and put it in the power of the Executor to exe
‚Ä¢ ute it, 1 Rolls Abridg. 428, 429. Burton and Horton.

The Condition is that the Grantee of a Rever≈øion ≈øhall not grant this over to J. S. If he grant the Rever≈øion to J. S. by his Deed, though the Le≈ø≈øee never attorn, yet this is a Forfeiture, Id. ibid.

A Condition not to a≈ø≈øign his I ea≈øe that ≈øo it may come to J. S. and after he a≈ø≈øigns this to J. D. the Condition is broken; for as much as by this means it may come to J. S. 1 Rolls Abr. 429. Cummin and Richard≈øon.
Where a Condition of an Obligation ≈øhall be expounded by a matter deb ‚Ä¢ rs.

The Condition was to ≈øave the Plaintiff harmle≈øs from all Actions and Damages that might ari≈øe upon the Relea≈øe of the Defendant out of the Execution (being then in Execution at the Plaintiffs Suit) from all per≈øons that might trouble him concerning the ≈øaid Relea≈øe. The Defendant pleads the Plaintiff ≈øued one N. for 100 l. and that he and Hart became his Bail; and that the Plaintiff had Judgment again≈øt N. and the Bail, and the Defendant was taken in Execution, and thought the Plaintiff relea≈øed him, &c. The Plaintiff replies, and confe≈ø≈øeth the Bail and Judgment; but ≈øaith that Hart gave him Security for his Mony, and the Plaintiff promi≈øed H. he might lay the Execution on the Defendant, and that he would not relea≈øe him ≈øans con≈øent of H. on which H.
procured him to be taken in Execution, and moved the Plaintiff to di≈øcharge him, who a ‚Ä¢
quainted him with his promi≈øe to H. ut ≈øupra, and thereupon the Defendant made him this Bond, and ≈øo he di≈øcharged him. H. brought an Action again≈øt him for Breach of Promi≈øe, and recovered 150 l. damages, and ≈øo he was damnified. The Words are apparent to ≈øave harmle≈øs from ≈øome damage that might ari≈øe not upon the Relea≈øe alone, but upon ≈øome collateral thing be≈øides the Relea≈øe, and yet by means and occa≈øion of the Relea≈øe, H ‚Ä¢ bart p. 269. Wild, and Wilkin≈øon.

div.head: Expo≈øitions of Words, Sentences and References in Conditions.
div.p: [During the Time.] THE Condition was whereas the Lord A. had deputed T. J. to be his Deputy Po≈øt-Ma≈øter to execute the ≈øaid Office from, &c. for the term of ≈øix Months following. Now if the ≈øaid T. J. ≈øhall and do for and during all the time that he ≈øhall continue Deputy Po≈øt-Ma≈øter, execute and pay ≈øuch Mony, &c. Per Cur. the Condition refers to the Recital only, whereby the Defendant was bound only during the ≈øix Months and no longer, and the indefinite time ≈øhall be con≈øtrued during the ≈øix Months, 2 Sanders 413. Lord Arlington and Merrick.

Condition faithfully to execute the Office of, and quarterly to make Accompt of all Monies by him received, &c. and pay all Monies by him received, and do Accompt ≈øuch times as he ≈øhall
he rea≈øonably required. The Defendant pleads performance to all but the Accompt, and for that he ≈øaith he was never rea≈øonably required to do this. Per Cur. this Clau≈øe (being rea≈øonably required) goes only to the payment of the Mony, bring the la≈øt antecedent, and the Accompt is limited to be made quarterly. Lit. Rep. 101. The King and Points.

[Then living] The Condition was, if it happen the ≈øaid J. M. to dye before the Fea≈øt of, &c. without I≈ø≈øue Mal ‚Ä¢ of her Body, by R. B. begotten then living, that the Obligation ≈øhall be void. The Defendant pleads, po≈øt confectionum obligationis, and before the ≈øaid Fea≈øt the ≈øaid J. M. dyed, ≈øans I≈ø≈øue Male of her Body then living: The Plaintiff replies, ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue H. B. and before the ≈øaid Fea≈øt J. M. dyed, the ≈øaid H. B. then living, and that H. B. dyed before the ≈øaid Fea≈øt, Per. Cur. the Plea is good; the words (then living) ≈øhall not refer to the time of J. M. death, but to the Fea≈øt mentioned in the Condition, 1 Ander≈øon, Bold and Molineux.

[Payments] A Condition to perform all Covenants, Payments and Agreements, contained in a Deed Poll. The Defendant pleads the Deed Poll, in haec verba; in which was contained one Grant of Lands for 100 l. and 200 l. to be paid, in which was a Provi≈øo; If the Defendant ≈øhould not pay for the Plaintiff, to one J. S. 40 l. at ≈øuch a day, the Bargain ≈øhould be void. The Defendant pleads performance of all Covenants; the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns a Breach in not payment of the 40 l. The Defendant demu ‚Ä¢ Judgment pro Defendente. The word (payment) in the Condition,
≈øhall have relation only to ≈øuch payments mentioned in the Deed, as is compul≈øory to the Defendant; but this was not, for the Defendant may, if he will, forfeit his Land, 1 Brownl. Rep. 113. Bri≈øcoe and King.

Condition to pay when the Kings Maje≈øty ≈øhall be Re≈øtored, by Conque≈øt, Accomodation, or otherwi≈øe, the difference between him and his Parliament being recited. The Defendant pleads King Charles the I. was Beheaded, and never Re≈øtored, &c. pro Defendente. This appears to be per≈øonally meant of the King, and not in his politick capacity. 1 Keb. 820. 2 Keb. 215. Grin≈øells Ca≈øe.
[Either] So as the Award ≈øhall be delivered to either of them, (either) ≈øhall be expounded (every) for each ought to have a part. Cro. Eliz. 448. Parker and Parker.

Debt upon an Obligation, dated 1. of February, 25. Eliz. The Defendant pleads a Relea≈øe, bearing date after making of the Bond, of all dues, demands what≈øoever, except an Award made between the Plaintiff and one G. W. with R. K. decea≈øed; and one Obligation of 500 l. for performance of the ≈øaid Award, bearing date 29 April, 25 Eliz. In the Replication the Plaintiff ≈øhewed the ≈øpecial matter, that the Award was made the 29th of April, and the Bond was made the 1 of February. Per Cur. (bearing date) ≈øhall have reference to the Award and not to the Bond. 1 Brownl. Rep. p. 54. Gage and Gilbert.

The Condition was to enjoy a Ship with all the Furniture, without di≈øturbance: The Ca≈øe was, after Sale of the ≈øaid Ship, a Stranger ≈øues the Plaintiff
for Mony due for certain Balla≈øt bought by the Defendant, and put into the Ship before the ≈øale of the Ship. Per Cur. Balla≈øt is no Furniture of a Ship, but Guns are. 1 Leon. Ca≈øe 59. fo. 46. Kinters Ca≈øe.
[Miles] If ≈øuch a place be 4 Miles from Rye, it ≈øhall be con≈øtrued 4000 Paces. Cro. Eliz. 412. Minge and Earl.

If I am bound to you, that J. S. (who is in truth an Infant) ≈øhall levy a Fine before ≈øuch a day, which is done accordingly, and after the ≈øame is rever≈øed by Error, ye ‚Ä¢ notwith≈øtanding the Condition is performed. 1 Leon. p.
‚Ä¢ 4. in Leigh ‚Ä¢ Ca≈øe Obiter.
A Condition to deliver 18 Barrels of Ale on Contract, the intent is the Vendor ≈øhall have the Barrels again, when he Ale is expended. 27. H. 8.27.

I am bound to given a Shoulder of every third Deer which I kill in my Park, yet I may di≈øpark it; for this comes not within the Rule, That a Man ≈øhall not by his own Act defeat or fru≈øtrate his own grant, but it is to u≈øe the liberty I re≈øerved to my ≈øelf upon my grant, ≈øtanding with the grant. Ho ‚Ä¢ . p‚ñ™ 41. in Coopers Ca≈øe.

I ≈øhall now ≈øpeak ≈øomething of Statutes and Recogni≈øances, for that they are Obligations on Record; but I intend not to handle the Learning at large as to Executions thereon and what is liable thereunto; for that is more properly to be treated of under another Title: But I ≈øhall here ≈øpeak of the Nature of them, the Form of them, and Manner and Effect of the Acknowledgment, and ≈øomething
of the Proce≈øs; and they concern Subject and Subject, or the King and a Subject; of the fir≈øt are,

div.head: Statutes and Recognizances.
div.p:
Statutes are of two ≈øorts. Statutes
Merchant,
of the Staple.

Statute-Merchant is acknowledged before Per≈øons authori≈øed, ≈øealed with the Seal of the Debtor and of the King, which is of two pieces, the greater is kept by the Mayor, &c. and the le≈ø≈øer by the Clark; this is by Stat. de Mercatoribus, 13 Ed. 1.4. Acton Bornel, the form of it vil ‚Ä¢ po≈øt. This is become now a Common A≈ø≈øurance.

Statute-Staple is founded on 27 Ed. 3.2. this is acknowledged before the Major of the Staple; but now by Stat. 23 H. 6. a Statute-Staple improperly ≈øo called, may be acknowledged before one of the Chief Ju≈øtices, before the Major of the Staple at We≈øtminster, or the Recorder of London: It is ≈øealed with three Seals, the Seals of the Conu≈øor, the King, and the Per≈øon before whom its taken; the form vide po≈øt.
They are both of one effect as to execution.
All Bonds concerning the King ≈øhall be of the nature of Statute-Staples; and ≈øo for fir≈øt Fruits, 33 H. 8.39. 26 H. 8.3.

div.head: The manner of making.
div.p: Let there be a certain day of payment limited in it. And yet one Davies acknowledged a Statute-Merchant to J. M. The Statute was formal in all Points, ≈øaving that no day of payment was limited in the ≈øaid Statute: Upon demurrer to And. Quere ‚Ä¢ , the Statute was adjudged to be good; when it appears by the Statute when the Mony is to be p ‚Ä¢ , its well enough, as it doth here, (viz.) pre≈øently; there ought to be a time certain when the Mony ≈øhall be paid, either an actual time, or a legal time; if it be to be paid at Michaelmas after J. S. ≈øhall come to Pauls; its not good, becau≈øe it may not appear to the Major judicially when to make Execution, Winch, 82. Hichford and Machin, ≈øolemnly argued by all the Judges, the ≈øame Ca≈øe in Jones Rep. 52. Bridgmans Rep. 16, 17, 18.

The Statute-Staple is to be ≈øealed with the Seal of the Conu≈øor, and the Seal of the King appointed for that purpo≈øe, and with the Seal of the Chief Ju≈øtice, Mayor and Recorder before whom it is acknowledged; and they before whom it is taken do ≈øub≈øcribe their Names to it.

If a Statute-Merchant be not ≈øealed with the Seal of the Debtor, and there be not a Seal of two pieces annexed to it; this is no good Statute, neither can it take effect as a Statute, 35 El. Hollingworth and A≈ø ‚Ä¢ l.

An Querela to avoid a Statute Merchant taken before the Mayor of N. furni≈øhing in his Writ two Cau≈øes to avoid the Statute. 1. The Mayor ‚Ä¢ e
had not any ≈øuch Authority to take the Statute. 2. Quod ≈øcriptum recognit. &c. non fuit ≈øigillat. cum ≈øigillo Reginae de duabus peciis provi≈ø. pro ≈øigillatione Statut. Mercator. and upon this Writ the Plaintiff counts and alledgeth the≈øe two matters: Per Cur. the Count is double and vitious; for though a Writ of Aud ‚Ä¢ Querela may comprehend divers Cau≈øes for the avoidance of a Statute; yet the Count ought to comprehend but one Cau≈øe; and either of the≈øe Cau≈øes alledged was ≈øufficient to avoid the Statute; and an Audita Querela lieth in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, and he ≈øhall not be put to ≈øue a Writ of Error to avoid it, Cro. El. 809. Forre≈øt and Ballard; but he cannot a≈ø≈øign want of one of the≈øe Seals for Error, if he had admitted the ≈øame in the Common Pleas, Moor n. 738, Wor≈øley and Charnock.
Tho≈øe that are meer Recognizances (as before) a Ma≈øter in Chancery, &c. need not be ≈øealed, but they mu≈øt be enrolled, Cro. El. 355. 1 Leon. 228. A≈øcue and Fotiam.

I≈ø≈øue is, whether there are two Seals; its well tryed by a Jury, and not by the Mayors Certificate. Statutes and Recognizances mu≈øt be enrolled, and being inrolled it binds Per≈øons and Lands as a Record from the day of the entry of it; upon the Roll its a Recognizance from the fir≈øt acknowlegdment, and binds as a Record from that time, 2 Rolls Rep. 382. Allen p. 12. Stiles p. 9.

And all Statutes-Merchant and Staple are to be brought to the Clark of the Recognizances within four months, and to be inrolled within ≈øix months, otherwi≈øe they will be void as to Purc ‚Ä¢ ≈øors, 27 Eliz. c. 4.

But now by the Statute of Frauds and Perjuries, the day of the month, and year of the inrolment of the Recognizances, ≈øhall be ≈øet down in the Margent of the Roll, where the ≈øaid Recognizances are acknowledged; and no Recognizance ≈øhall bind any Lands, &c. in the hands of any Purcha≈øor, bona fide, and for valuable con≈øideration, but from the time of ≈øuch inrolment, 29 Car. 2.1.

div.head: By whom acknowledged, and how.
div.p: BAron and Feme enter into a Statute or Recognizance; this binds not the Wife, albeit ≈øhe ≈øurvives her Husband, 10 Rep. 43. 2 In≈øt. 673.

If an Infant acknowledge a Statute or Recognizance, its voidable by Audita Querela during his minority; but he cannot avoid it after his full age, neither by Audita Querela nor Writ of Error, becau≈øe of Infancy only, Moor n. 206. Yelv. 88. Randale and Wale. Co. 2 Inst. 673. Dyer 132. and the way to avoid it mu≈øt be by in≈øpection, which cannot be after his full age, 1 Bul≈øt. 187, 188.

Infant acknowledgeth a Statute, and was taken in Execution, and at full Age he brought Audita Querela to avoid the Execution: Per Cur. the Audita Querela ≈øhall abate; he ≈øhall not avoid it, it being matter of Record; but if he will avoid it, it mu≈øt be during his minority, Moor n. 196. Wor≈øleys Ca≈øe. 1 Ander≈øon 25. Noy p. 16.

A Recognizance acknowledged by an Infant, and he was in≈øpected, and adjudged to be within Age, and thereupon had a Scire Fac. again≈øt the
Conu≈øee, and upon a ni ‚Ä¢ hil returned, it was adjudged the Recognizance ≈øhould be void, and he be di≈øcharged; whereupon Error was brought, for that there ought to be two nichils returned, for two nichils amount to a Garni≈øhment, and without Garni≈øhment and Oyer of the Party to whom the Recognizance was made, it ought not to be adjudged to be cancelled; and for this cau≈øe it was rever≈øed. And now becau≈øe the Conu≈øor is at pre≈øent of full Age, and cannot have a new Writ of Audita Querela to be in≈øpected, it was moved, that he may have a new Writ comprehending the fir≈øt In≈øpection, and the Judgment thereupon, and ≈øhew that the fir≈øt Judgment was only rever≈øed for Error in the Proceedings, and upon all the matter to be relieved, and ≈øo it was done, Cro. Jac. 59. Yelv. p. 88. Randale and Wale.
A Recognizance within the Statute 23 H. 8. c. 6. cannot be good except the Seal of the Party be to it.

div.head: Before whom taken.
div.p: THey may not be acknowledged before any other Per≈øons but ≈øuch as are appointed by the Statutes.

Other Recognizances (be≈øides tho≈øe on 23 H. 8.) may not be acknowledged before any, but ≈øuch as have Power ex Officio; as the Judges of the Courts at We≈øtmin≈øter, or by ≈øpecial Commi≈ø≈øion to take them, Dyer 220.

Out of the Commonalty of London there ≈øhall be two Merchants cho≈øen and ≈øworn, and before
one or both of the≈øe Merchants the Recognizances may be taken, Stat 14 Ed. 3.11. 8 R. 2.4.

The Recognizance upon the 23 H. 8. c. 6. in nature of a Statute-Staple, is always to be acknowledged before the Chief Ju≈øtice of the Kings Bench or Common Pleas (in the Term time) or in their ab≈øence out of Term, before the Mayor of the Staple at We≈øtmini≈øter, and the Recorder of London.

All the Judges may out of Term take Recognizances in any part of England: and if it be taken before the Chief Ju≈øtice of the Common Pleas, at Serjeants-Inn in Fleet-≈øtreet, out of Term, its good, Hob. 195.

Every Court of Record, of any note, hath this Authority incident to it, to take Recognizances for all things which concern the Juri≈ødiction of the Court, and of all things which ari≈øe of or by rea≈øon of the Matters there depending; ≈øo it is taken before the Mayor and Aldermen of London, 1 Leon. 384. Holin≈øhead and Kings Ca≈øe. The Cu≈øtom of London to take Recognizances, and the Form of the Declaration, Cro. El. p. 186. Chamberlein and Thorp, 1 Leon. 130, 131.

div.head: Where Actions to be brought on Statutes and Recognizances.
div.p:
H. Brought Debt again≈øt W. and declared upon a Recognizance taken before Chief Ju≈øtice Hobart at Serjeants-Inn in Fleet-≈øtreet, London, out of Term, and laid his Action in London, whereupon the Defendant demurred; The Que≈øtion was, whether the Action ought to be brought
in Middle≈øex where the Recognizance is recorded, or in London where it was acknowledged. Now in this Ca≈øe the inrolment of the Record, that the Recognizance was taken before Hobert at the time and place afore≈øaid, by which it was a Record (ip≈øo facto) then and there; and the inrolment is but a confirmation of the ≈øame Record, and makes no change; but becau≈øe they both concur to the making it a perfect Record; the Action may be brought in either County; but by Hobert, in London as the more worthy part of the Act; and a Scire fac. upon ≈øuch a Recognizance ≈øhall be directed to the Sheriff of London, and not of Middle≈øex: but if the entry of the Record were general, that the Recognizance was taken before Hobert, it ≈øhall be under≈øtood in Court, and then the Action ≈øhall be brought in Middle≈øex, Hob. Rep. p. 195. Hall and Winkfield, 2 Rolls Rep. 182.
1 Brownl. p. 69. Allen Rep. 12. Andrews and Harborn. In the Common Pleas its good both ways; in B. R. it ought to be where the Recognizance is taken, Stiles p. 9. Andrews Ca≈øe.
Debt brought in the Common Bench on a Recognizance in London, Cro. Eliz. Wilfords Ca≈øe.

Statute Staple ≈øuable in the Kings Bench or Common Pleas, as well as in Chancery, Cro. El. p. 208. Clavel and Mallory. Audita Querela in the Common Bench, for that the Conu≈øor was within Age at the time of the acknowledgment, and well brought there, me≈øme Ca≈øe, 1 Leon. 303. ≈øo in B. R. and the entry of the In≈øpection, vide Cro. El. 208.
A Recognizance taken by the Cu≈øtom of London makes the Debt local, vide 1 Leon. 130, 131, 284.

div.head: Scire Facias.
div.p: SCire Facias in the Kings Bench, on a Recognizance, may not be general without ≈øhewing the time of the Recognizance, and other particulars, for it is but a Pocket Record, therefore it is to ≈øhew what date it is, for otherwi≈øe the Party may not know what Matter to plead, and perhaps it is relea≈øed or cancelled; and a Man may not plead a Relea≈øe after nul tiel Record. Qu. 2 Siderfin p. 156, 159. B. R. Al≈øton and Body.
He that ≈øueth forth a Scire fac. in Chancery, to defeat an Execution on a Statute-Staple, ≈øhall find Surety to pro≈øecute with effect.
If the Statute hath but one Seal, it ≈øhall take effect, as an Obligation, Moor n. 520. 2 Rolls Abr. 149. Ai≈øcue and Hollingsworth. Cro. El. p. 494. contra.

A Recognizance is entire, and being di≈øcharged in part, is di≈øcharged in the whole; but if the defea≈øance be to be paid in ≈øeveral Sums, there an Acquittance of part, is not a Relea≈øe of the re≈øidue, 1 Ander≈øon p. 235 Ca≈øe. Cro. El. p. 182. Cook ver≈øus Bacon.

Sir G. Gri≈øly now Baronet was bound in a Statute-Merchant before the Mayor of Coventry to D. D. upon a Certificate made by the Mayor into Chancery, took out a Capias again≈øt him by the name of G. Gri≈øly E≈øq and Writs of extent thereon; this the Court would not amend, but
advi≈øed to ≈øue a new Writ out of Chancer ‚Ä¢ upon the fir≈øt Certificate, ≈øcil. Capias Corpus G. G. Mil. & Baronet. qui per nomen G. G. Armig. ‚Ä¢ ecognovit, &c. Hobert 129. Sir George Gri≈øleys Ca≈øe.
If three are bound to me in a Statute-Merchant, and every of them by them≈øelves, & quemlibet „Äà‚óä„Äâ . per ≈øe, I may ≈øue Execution again≈øt one of them only, or again≈øt all at my plea≈øure.

div.head: Declaration.
div.p: DEclaration is, That the Defendant per ≈øcriptum ≈øuum Obligatorium, &c. conce≈ø≈øit ≈øe teneri, &c. ≈øolvend. cum requi≈øitus e≈ø≈øet. The Defendant demands Oyer of the Obligatation which is of a Statute-Merchant, &c. ≈øalvend. at the Fea≈øt of, &c. Its an incurable Fault, Cro. Jac. op. 316. Fox and Inkes. A Statute for performance of Covenants, which perhaps ≈øhall never be broken, is no Plea in Bar by Admini≈øtrator; but a Statute for payment of Mony is allowable before Debts on Bond, and ≈øo it differs from Harri≈øons Ca≈øe, 5 Rep.

Its no good Plea to ≈øay that ≈øuch a one was bound in a Recognizance, and not to ≈øay per ≈øcriptum Obligatorium; and to conclude it was done ≈øecundum formam Statut. doth not help it; but in a Verdict it was agreed to be good, Marches Rep. p. 76. Harris and Garret, 4 Rep. 65. Fulwoods Ca≈øe. If the Jury find a Recognizance before the Mayor and Recorder, though they ≈øay not per ≈øcript. Obligat. or ≈øecundum formam Statuti, its good enough.

The Defendant pleaded to Debt on two Bonds, that the Inte≈øtate was indebted to the Plaintiff in a Statute-Merchant of 250 l. which Statute is in force, not cancelled nor annulled, and that ≈øhe hath not above 40 s. a≈ø≈øets ultra; the Plaintiff replies, that the Statute is burnt with Fire; Judgment pro Quer. on demurrer; for by the demurrer the Defendant hath confe≈øt the burning of the Statute, and then it can never ri≈øe up; for the Statute 23 H. 8. c. 6. concerning Recognizances in the nature of a Statute-Staple, refers to the Statute-Staple, that the like Execution ≈øhall be had and made, &c. and the Statute-Staple refers to the Statute-Merchant, and that to the Statute of Acton Burnel, 13 Ed. 1. which provides, that if it be found by the Roll, and by the Bill, that the Debt was acknowledged, and that the day of payment is expired, that then, &c. but if the Statute be burnt, it cannot appear that the day of payment is expired; and con≈øequently there can be no Execution. If the Conu≈øee will take his Action upon it, he mu≈øt ≈øay hic in Curia prolat. 15 H. 7.16. Mod. Rep. 186. Buckly and Haward.
If One acknowledges a Statute, and after a Judgment is had again≈øt the Conu≈øor: now again≈øt the Conu≈øor the Statute ≈øhall be preferred, but not again≈øt an Executor, 1 Brownl. 37.
If two Men claim the ≈øame Land, one by Extent upon a Statute, the other by a Judgment the ≈øame Term; he who claims by the Judgment ≈øhall be fir≈øt ≈øatisfied, Yelv. 224.

A Statute-Merchant removed by Mittimus out of Chancery in Com. p. and Execution awarded
there ≈øuper tenorem Recordi. A Writ of Error lies in B. R. though the Original be in Chancery, and the Execution in C. B. More n. 738. Wor≈øley and Charneck.

div.head: In what Courts taken and ≈øued.
div.p: REcogni≈øance taken in the Court of the Admiralty is void, Noy 24. Record and John≈øon.
How Recogni≈øances ≈øhall be taken in London, Stat. 14. E. 3.111. 8 R. 2.4, 5.5 H. 4.12.

If a Statute-Merchant be not paid at the day, the Mayor &c. ≈øhall cau≈øe the Debtor to be impri≈øoned (if he be Lay) and in their power, there to remain till he agree the Debt. If the Debtor cannot be found, they ≈øhall ≈øend the Recogni≈øance under the Kings Seal into Chancery, from whence ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue Writ to the Sheriff of the County where the Debtor is to take his Body; and if he do not ≈øatisfie the Debt within a Quarter of a Year, all his Lands and Goods ≈øhall be delivered upon extent; but his Body ≈øhall be ≈øtill in Pri≈øon, and he ≈øhall be allowed Bread and Water. And the Sheriff ≈øhall certifie the Ju≈øtices of one of the Benches, how he hath performed the Service i. e. return the Writ. If the Debtor dye, the Body of his Heir ≈øhall not be taken.
If a Statute be rightly entred into as to the ≈øub≈øtantial Form, it is ≈øufficient, though there be variance in the circum≈øtantial Form, Bendl. 144, 145.

All Statutes Merchant and of the Staple ≈øhall within ≈øix Months after the acknowledgment thereof, be entred in the Office of the Clark of the Recogni≈øances; and it ought to be brought within four Months to enter a true Copy, or el≈øe it ≈øhall be void again≈øt Purcha≈øers bona fide, and it mu≈øt be enrolled within ≈øix Month, 27 Eliz. c. 4.
A Statute is to be ≈øhewed in Court of B. R. or C. B. when its to be extended, or on Return of Cepi Corpus, el≈øe the party will be di≈øcharged, tho it be lo≈øt, 37 H. 6.6, 7.

On a Statute Merchant the Coni≈øee may bring Debt on the Stat. and wave all other proceedings; or he may have Execution after this manner: He mu≈øt bring his Statute to the Mayor, &c. and they are to impri≈øon him; if he cannot be found, they are to certifie the Record in Chancery, and if they refu≈øe to do it, they may be compelled thereto by Certiorari; and upon a nihil returned upon a Te≈øtatum e≈øt, he may have Proce≈øs in another County. Aliter of Goods, and he ≈øhall have a Cap. directed to the Sheriff, and this to be returned in the C. B. or B. R. if he be returned non e≈øt inventus, his Lands ≈øhall be extended.

Upon a Statute-Staple, or upon Recogni≈øance founded on 23 H. 8. c. 6. the Body, Lands and Goods may be taken together; and this Writ on the≈øe Statutes are returnable in Chancery, and not in B. R. or B. C. as a Statute-Merchant is.

div.head: Recogni≈øances in Chancery, Vid. ≈øupra Statutes.
div.p: CApias lies not on a Recogni≈øance in Chancery, but only a Scire Fac. per Gawdy, Yelverton and Popham, Yelv. 42. Weaver and Clifford. So Cro. Eliz. p. 576. Conier's Ca≈øe, but in Ognel and Pastons Ca≈øe, Cro. Eliz. p. 164. adjudged contra, and that it lies after a Scire Fac. and two Nihils returned. And per Windham in Dormers Ca≈øe, 1 Keb. 456. a Capias lies on a Recogni≈øance in Chancery, the Pre≈øidents are ≈øo; but in Grim≈øton and Wades Ca≈øe, 3 Keb. 221, 229. The Court conceived no Capias lies on a Recogni≈øance in Chancery.

Debt on a Recogni≈øance is brought in the Petty-Bag Office, the Court of B. R. upon motion would not alter the Plea, for if the I≈ø≈øue be joyned in the Petty-Bag, you mu≈øt try it, Stiles p. 412. Turner and Trapes.

A Verdict on a Scire Fac. on a Recogni≈øance in Chancery, and Judgment pro Grim≈øton. Grim≈øton brought a Latitat in the Kings Bench on the Recogni≈øance. The Defendant put in Bail, and prayed to be di≈øcharged on common Bail, becau≈øe there being a Verdict on Scire Fac. no Latitat can be ≈øued. Per Hales, no Latitat can be ≈øued hanging the Scire Fac. for a Scire Fac. is an Action and may be ≈øo pleaded to the Debt to be depending. But after Judgment entred Debt lieth thereon, or upon the Recogni≈øance alone, and the Rule for ≈øpecial Bail was di≈øcharged, 3 Keb. 221, 229. Grim≈øton and Wade, Vid. Lit. Rep. p. 89, 90.
That a Scire Fac. is not an Action, but an Execution, Arguendo in Melvin and Reeves Ca≈øe.

If a Man be bound in a Recogni≈øance to pay 100 l. at five ≈øeveral days, pre≈øently after the fir≈øt day of payment he ≈øhall have Execution upon the Recogni≈øance for that Sum, and ≈øhall not tarry till the la≈øt be pa≈øt, for that it is in the Nature of ≈øeveral Judgments, Co. Lit. fo. 292. b. Aliter of a Bond.
Meer Recogni≈øances are not ≈øealed, but enrolled they mu≈øt be.

In a Recogni≈øance in Chancery the Proce≈øs is Scire Fac. and this being returned with a Nihil, another Scire Fac. which being ≈øo returned al≈øo, he ≈øhall have a Judgment, and may have a Levar. (but no Capias) 8 Rep. 141.

The Tran≈øcript of a Recogni≈øance in Chancery came into the B. R. and was not allowed there to have a Scire Fac. on it, 5 Eliz. Dyer 217. So in C. B. the Goods only which he had at the time of the Execution awarded, will be ≈øubject to Execution.
Upon a Recogni≈øance in Chancery Execution ≈øhall be of the Moiety of the Lands.
The Execution by this, is by Scire Fac.

div.head: Bail. Recognizance. The Nature of it.
div.p:
THE Recogni≈øance is conditional (that is to ≈øay) to render his Body to Pri≈øon if he were condemned, or to pay the Condemnation, Jones 138. The end of the Bail is not only to bring
the Body, but that he come ≈øubject to the Court according to the meaning of the Bail; (and there-Bail cannot render the Body of the Defendant after Writ of Error brought by him, Qu.) for the Entry in the di≈øcharge of the Bail mu≈øt be, that the Defendant reddidit ≈øe to the Court to be in Execution, if the Plaintiff will, which cannot be ≈øo in that Ca≈øe, Hob. p. 116. Wick≈øteads Ca≈øe.

The Bail in the Common Bench is always in a Sum certain according to the debt or damages in the Writ; but in the Kings Bench there is not any Sum mentioned, but to pay whatever the Principal ≈øhall lo≈øe, 1 Keb. 18. Cro. Jac. 645. Sir John Ape≈øley's Ca≈øe.

The Words of the Bail are conditional, ≈øcilicet ≈øi contingeret praedictum Defendentem debita & damna ill praefat. Querenti minime ≈øolvere, aut ≈øe pri≈øonae non reddere, &c. 5 Rep. Hoe and Mar≈øhals Ca≈øe 70. b.

Special Bail by Recogni≈øance was (as the manner is) that F. & B. conce≈ø≈øerunt & uterque eorum conce≈ø≈øit, that the ≈øaid debt and damages ≈øhall be levied upon them, if the Defendant do not pay, aut ≈øe pri≈øonae Marr. doth not render, Siderfin p. 339. Gee's Ca≈øe.

The Recogni≈øance in the disjunctive, to render the Body to Pri≈øon or to pay, &c. By death the one becomes impo≈ø≈øible, and ≈øo ≈øhall excu≈øe the other, Jones p. 29. Winch p. 61. Sparrow and Sowgate.

Recogni≈øance to have the Plaintiff in Chancery ad ≈øtandum juri in hac parte, and that the Plaintiff ≈øhall pro≈øecute with Effect, though he doth not ≈øhew the Plaintiff did not appear in Chancery
at the day (for the Condition here is parcel of the Recogni≈øance) which is one of the Conditions; for the words in the beginning include all, as well the Cour≈øe of the Pro≈øecution as the Effect of the Suit, Yelv. p. 59. Cro. Jac. 69. Barnes and Worlych.
Form del Mainpri≈øe en Det, Vid. Ra≈øt. Entr. 177. b.

div.head: Proce≈øs. Scire Fac.
div.p: AFter Judgment a Cap. is awarded again≈øt the Defendant, and upon a Non e≈øt inventus returned, they awarded a Scire Fac. again≈øt the Bail. Capias mu≈øt be delivered to the Sheriff before a Te≈øtatum, 2 Keb. 424. Robin≈øon's Ca≈øe.

A Latitat is taken again≈øt two, one is taken and puts in Bail in Michaelmas Term, and afterwards the other is taken, and he puts in Bail in Hill. Term; it was prayed that the Bail of Michaelmas Term might be taken off the Filer of that Term and put upon the File of Hill. Term, for otherwi≈øe the Plaintiff cannot proceed again≈øt them joyntly upon Bail put in in ≈øeveral Terms, and it was ≈øo done, Noy p. 90.

Scire Fac. again≈øt the Bail; the Scire Fac. recited that Judgment was given again≈øt the Principal in Debt, but mentions not therein that the Capias was awarded, yet per Cur. it is good; it may be omitted or recited, Cro. Jac. 97. Ju≈øtice Williams ver≈øus Vaughan.

Per Cur. If one be arre≈øted in this Court and puts in Bail, and after the Plaintiff recovers, and the Defendant renders not him≈øelf according to
Law in ≈øafeguard of his Bail, the Plaintiff may at his Election take Execution either again≈øt the Principal or Bail: But if he arre≈øts the Bail, tho he had not full ≈øatisfaction, yet he ≈øhall never afterwards meddle with the Principal: But if two be Bail, and one is in Execution, yet he may al≈øo take the other; but if the Principal be in Execution, he cannot take the Bail, Cro. Jac. 320. Higgins Ca≈øe.
When the Plaintiff in the Action hath Judgment, he hath Election to ≈øue a Scire Fac. again≈øt the Principal upon the Judgment, or again≈øt the Bail and Principal joyntly upon the Recogni≈øance.

Scire Fac. brought again≈øt three Bails upon a Recogni≈øance acknowledged by them and the Principal jointly and ≈øeverally; and upon Demurrer the Writ was abated, becau≈øe this being founded upon a Record, the Plaintiff ought to ≈øhew forth the variance from the Record, as that one is dead, Allen p. 21. Blackwel and A≈øhton.
