By the Cour≈øe of the Court a Scire Fac. again≈øt the Bail mu≈øt have ≈øeven days between the Te≈øte and the Return; el≈øe all Proceedings after are void, and one cannot be taken out returnable more, and the other within le≈øs than ≈øeven days, 1 Keb. 182. Gifford and Smith.

Bail in B. R. by John Bennet E≈øq and the Declaration was on a Recogni≈øance by the Name of John Bennet Gent. and on Nul tiel Record of the Recogni≈øance by J. B. E≈øq, Per Cur. it is all one Name, and the Court takes no notice of Heraldry here, 1 Keb. 293. Bennet and Dean.

Scire Fac. on a ≈øingle Recogni≈øance of Bail was excepted to, becau≈øe returnable at a day certain; and ≈øo agreed by per Cur. to be qua≈øht, and the party left to a new Scire Fac. or to Debt on Recogni≈øance. Where there is a Condition, it may be returned at a day certain, and ≈øo may a Scire Fac. to revive a Judgment, 2 Keb. p. 396, 397. Allen ver≈øus the Manucaptors of Cutler.

Debt lies on the Recogni≈øance of Bail, 3 Keb. 707, 734. Miles and Bateman; but not before a Cap. and ≈øecond Scire Fac. returned and filed; on Judgment in Term Cap. may be at any time on Rule four days after Judgment.

W. recovered again≈øt B. in Debt, and B. was brought to the Bar by Habeas Corpus procured by his Bail, and the Plaintiff prayed he might be committed in Execution, and al≈øo the Bail, that he might be received in their di≈øcharge; but B. having brought a Writ of Error, it could not be, hanging that, Hob. 116. Wick≈øteds Ca≈øe.
The Scire Fac. was to ≈øhew cau≈øe why Execution ≈øi ≈øibi viderit expedire (not ≈øaying) fieri non debet. Per Cur. it is ill, and it is not amendable, 3 Keb. 190. Mannel and Coltlowe.

After the Return of the ≈øecond Scire Fac. it is too late to bring the Principal in, and that is the rea≈øon that in ≈øuch ca≈øe a Writ of Error for the Bail to rever≈øe the Judgment again≈øt the Principal.

Debt again≈øt the Principal, and Judgment on Nihil dicit, but no Ca. ≈øa. i≈ø≈øued again≈øt him; afterwards two Scire Fac. were taken out again≈øt the Bail, and two Nihils thereon returned, and on that Judgment given again≈øt the Bail: The Judgment is erroneous, but the Bail cannot bring
a Writ of Error, cau≈øa qua ≈øupra; but he ≈øhall have an Audita Querela, Stiles p. 323, 288. Barcock and Thomp≈øon. When the Judgment is grounded upon a Scire Fec. the Bail is remedile≈øs, 2 Keb. 51. Reynolds and Duel.
There ought to be a Cap. again≈øt the Bail, before he can be charged, and it ought to be ≈øhewed that the Capias was returned and filed again≈øt the Bail, 3 Bul≈øtr. p. 341. Calf and Bingly.
If the Principal be dead before the Return of the Capias, this mu≈øt be avoided by an Audita Querela in Judgment again≈øt the Bail, 2 Keb. 51. Reynolds and Duel.

The Cour≈øe of the Kings Bench is, that Default ought to be a≈ø≈øigned in the Principal upon the Return of the Capias before the Bail ≈øhall be charged; (≈øo in Com. Banc. Qu.) which cannot be if the Principal be dead. If the Principal render his Body, though the Plaintiff refu≈øe to take that, yet that is a di≈øcharge of the Bail, Winch p. 61. Sparrow and Sowgate.

div.head: How and when the Bail is di≈øcharged; and of the rendring the Principal, and the time of doing it.
div.p: THE rendring of the Principal to Pri≈øon is no di≈øcharge of the Bail till the Bail-piece, which remains with the Secondary, be di≈øcharged, &c. 2 Keb. p. 2. Booth and Nortrop.

One may plead reddidit ≈øe well enough without averring prout patet, &c. for that is only filed with the Bail-piece entred into at the Judges Chamber, upon which the Secondary writes a reddidit
≈øe, and ≈øo the party goes to the Mar≈øhal into Cu≈øtody, and thence returns to the Secondary, and he enters a Committimus in exonerationem manucaptorum; and if this Render be before the Return of the ≈øecond Scire Fac. on the Bails Recogni≈øance, it may be well enough pleaded, prout patet, &c. and this is the Cour≈øe of the Court, 2 Keb. p. 237. Anonymus.

Per Rolls, Out of Indulgence to the Bail, it hath been the u≈øe of later times, that if the Bail do bring in the Principal before the Return of the ≈øecond Scire Fac. which was taken out again≈øt the Bail, thereupon to di≈øcharge the Bail: But anciently it was not ≈øo; but then it was counted too late to bring him in, Stiles p. 134. M. 24 Car. 1. B. R. Quatermans Ca≈øe.

The manner of Entry upon the yielding of the Body upon the Bail; and if the party or his Attorny be pre≈øent, he mu≈øt make his Election to take him in Execution or refu≈øe him, whereof Entry is to be made. Qu. If he may after take him by Ca≈øa. Hob. p. 210. Welby and Canning.

Judgment again≈øt a Bail on Scire Fac. which was ≈øued out, and two Nichils returned after the Party had rendred him≈øelf in Execution on the fir≈øt Judgment. Scrogs moved to have the ≈øaid Judgment ≈øet a≈øide: Per Cur. there is cau≈øe of an Audita Querela; but otherwi≈øe no remedy. But the Attorny ought not to ≈øue any Scire Fac. again≈øt the Bail, after the Bail-piece di≈øchaged, but before, he may, 2 Keb. 475. Goreham and Boxham ‚Ä¢ .

On affirmance of Judgment again≈øt the Principal: Jones prayed the Bail may render the Principal before any Scire Fac. which the Court granted;
and his Render here is a Render below the Recogni≈øance being removed; and it may be done before any Judge in di≈øcharge of the Bail, 2 Keb. 635. Bodam's Ca≈øe.

Gardner prayed that the Principal may be accepted to tender him≈øelf, there being no Capius i≈ø≈øued again≈øt the Principal, yet a Scire Fac. and two Nichils again≈øt the Bail are returned. Sed non allocatur; this is cau≈øe for an Aundita Querela. And were there a Scire Fac. returned, the Defendant may plead it; but the Bail cannot otherwi≈øe be relieved, 2 Keb. 536. Staunton's Ca≈øe.

Duport recovered Debt again≈øt Wildgoo≈øe: Upon this a Capias i≈ø≈øued out again≈øt Wildgoo≈øe, and the ≈øame returned, and before it was filed a Scire Fac. i≈ø≈øued out again≈øt the Bail; the Bail for his di≈øcharge did ≈øugge≈øt an Action again≈øt Wildgoo≈øe the Principal, and had his Body in Court; and being in Court he moved to have Wildgoo≈øe delivered in Execution for the Debt of Duport in di≈øchage of him≈øelf, in regard that if he ≈øhould die before next Term, he could not plead this to the Scire Fac. but ≈øhould be then charged with the Debt, which was granted. Note, that Duport did not intend to pray the Body of Wildgoo≈øe in Execution for his Debt, though pre≈øent in Court, but his purpo≈øe was to have had his Surety in Execution for the ≈øame; the Bail perceiving this, for prevention did bring the Body of Wildgoo≈øe into Cour, and prayed him to be committed in Execution for the Debt in exonerationem of him which the Court did, 2 Bul≈øtr. p. 352. Duport and Wildgoo≈øe.

Capias mu≈øt fir≈øt be awarded again≈øt the Principal, before Scire Fac. again≈øt the Bail; for the Recogni≈øance is, that the Principal ≈øhould tender him≈øelf, &c. which is intended upon Proce≈øs awarded again≈øt him, Cro. Eliz. 597. Hobs and Tedca≈øtle.

The Mainpernors brought Error, becau≈øe there was not any Cap. ad ≈øatisfac. awarded again≈øt the Principal before the Scire Fac. Per Cur. a Writ of Error lies well upon the Statute of 27 Eliz. but being certified upon diminution, that a Ca. ≈øa. had been awarded, the Judgment was affirmed, Cro. Eliz. p. 730. Cokerin's Ca≈øe.

One was bound by the Chief Ju≈øtice to appear in B. R. the Court was moved to di≈øcharge him of his appearance, becau≈øe he was before the day arre≈øted and impri≈øoned at the Suit of another, and it was done, 1 Bul≈øtr. 170.

Scire Fac. again≈øt the Bail for Non-appearance of the Principal, and it is not mentioned that Proce≈øs was awarded again≈øt him, but that it was prayed, & ei conceditur, but it is not ideo raecept. e≈øt Vicecomiti, &c. as it ought to be, and although he that was Bail doth not afterwards appear, this might be without Proce≈øs, and ≈øo nor good, Cro. Eliz. p. 177. Herd and Bur≈øtow.

The Bail cannot render the Principal on the day of the Return of the ≈øecond Scire Fac. though before the Sheriff hath actually made his Return; and this is the Pleading of the Render that ≈øuch a day ante retornum, and after Nul tiel Record pleaded the Bail cannot take advantage of this Render, 1 Keb. 450, 456. Hooper ver≈øus the Manucaptors of Gibbon.

The Bail mu≈øt render the Principal ≈øitting the Court the day of the Return of the ≈øecond Scire Fac. So it is on a Declaration by the by, which mu≈øt be ≈øitting the Court the la≈øt day of the Term, 1 Keb. 899. Nicholas and Stokes.

Judgment was given again≈øt the Principal, and after a Scire Fac. is brought again≈øt the Bail, who appeared and pleaded Nul tiel Record of the Judggiven again≈øt the Principal, and on the day given for bringing in the Record, the Principal rendred his Body in di≈øcharge of the Bail, Qu. if he might, March Rep. p. 154. pl. 223. The Condition of the Bail is, that they render his Body indefinitely without limiting any time in certain when they ≈øhall do it, or pay the condemnation; and by ≈øome, if they plead ≈øuch a Dilatory Plea as this, they have thereby waved the benefit of bringing in the Body, and by this trick the Plaintiff ≈øhould lo≈øe all his Co≈øts of Suit which he had expended in the Suit again≈øt the Bail.

Judgment again≈øt the Principal in B. R. upon this Judgment a Writ of Error is brought in the Exchequer-Chamber according to the Statute of 27 H. 8. Hanging this Writ of Error, the Principal reddidit ≈øe pri≈øonae in exoneratione of his Bail, the Bail may plead this in their di≈øcharge (the Record of the Bail is a di≈øtinct Record of it ≈øelf) hanging the Writ of Error, the Bail may bring in the Body of the Principal at any time when he will, but he ≈øhall not be prayed in Execution before Judgment be affirmed or di≈øaffirmed: Before the Return of the Scire Fac. again≈øt the Bail the Principal renders him≈øelf, and hanging the Writ of Error, dies, by this the Bail is di≈øcharged, 3 Bul≈øtr. 341. Calf and Bingly, Stiles and Seagar, Hobbs and Donca≈øter cited there.
A Committitur (though no Judgment) mu≈øt be entred hanging the Writ of Error; but if Judgment be affirmed the Party mu≈øt pray to have him in Execution, Jones p. 128. me≈øme Ca≈øe.

At any time before the Capias awarded, if the Defendant dye, this di≈øchargeth the Bail; for the Recogni≈øance is conditional, ≈øcilicet, to render his Body to pri≈øon if he were condemned, or to pay the Condemnation: And before a Capias he is not bound to render his Body, and therefore by the Act of God being impo≈ø≈øible by death to render his Body, the Bail is di≈øcharged. And before Capias awarded the Principal is not bound to render him≈øelf, for the Plaintiff had Election to take out Execution by Elegit or Fieri Fac. as well as Capias, Jones Rep. p. 138. Calf and Bingly.

div.head: Pleading and Execution.
div.p: IN Scire Fac. or Recogni≈øance again≈øt the Bail; the Defendants Plea was venit & dicit, &c. Per Cur. he mu≈øt ≈øay, venit in. propria per≈øona or per Attornatum, and neither ≈øhall be intended, e≈øpecially this being after a Demurrer, though general, 2 Keb. p. 388. Bolton and Clark.

When Scire Fac. i≈ø≈øues upon the Recogni≈øance, the Bail and Principal have two ways to defeat this, either by tender of the Body of the Principal, or by Plea; and if at the Return they appear by Attorny they have cho≈øen to avoid the Recogni≈øance by Plea, 2 Rolls Rep. 382.

Scire Fac. again≈øt C. as Bail for D. and ≈øhews he had ≈øuch a Term Judgment again≈øt D. and
that he did neither render the Body nor ≈øatisfie the Debt. The Defendant pleads, D. came into Court and rendred his Body to the Fleet in Execution, and in di≈øcharge, &c. and that the Plaintiff did refu≈øe to take him in Execution, and the Plaintiff denied yielding of the Body, and ≈øo I≈ø≈øue: Per Cur. it is not well pleaded; for the yielding of the Body being an Act in Court and in di≈øcharge of his Bail which is of Record, mu≈øt be it ≈øelf of Record, and therefore ought to be concluded, prout patet per Recordum, Hobart p. 210. Welby and Canning.

In Scire Fac. again≈øt the Bail, they plead reddidit ≈øe of the Principal before the Return of the ≈øecond Scire Fac. (viz.) 11 May. The Plaintiff prays Oyer of the reddidit ≈øe, and the Return which was the 6th of May. The Defendant demurs; Judgment pro Quer. 2 Keb. 542. Turner and Lufton.

In Scire Fac. again≈øt Bail, or Judgment in Debt on Oyer of the Judgment: The Defendant demurred, becau≈øe Scire Fac. is of a Judgment or Bill in Michaelmas Term, whereas the Bail appears to be in Hillary; but the Bill being again≈øt the Defendant as in Cu≈øtodia, the Bail may be at any time; and heretofore the Bail was never put in before appearance, as now u≈øed. But in B. C. Bail is precedent to the Original in Habeas Corpus and is conditional to appear to the Original in two Terms, 3 Keb. 124. Segar and Brome.

Executor brought Scire Fac. againg the Bail, and declares that the Plaintiff did recover, and that afterwards the Plaintiff dyed, the Defendant not brought in by them. The Defendant pleads
no Capias was ≈øued out by the Te≈øtator; a good Plea, 3 Keb. 190. Manuel and Coltlowe. The Plaintif cannot have a Capias without a Scire Fac. Qu. And if the Defendant principal dye before the return of the Capias, the Bail are di≈øcharged; but not ≈øo on death before a ≈øecond Scire Fac. Yet Cro. Jac. p. 97. Ju≈øtice Williams again≈øt Vaughan. The Defendant in Scire Fac. pleaded the principal was dead before the Scire Fac. brought: ill Plea; becau≈øe he alledgeth not when he dyed, nor that he dyed before the Capias Awarded: and if once on a Capias, non e≈øt ‚Ä¢ nventus is returned, the Recognizance is forfeited, becau≈øe there was default in the party; and though it be u≈øual if the principal render his Body upon the fir≈øt Scire Fac. to accept it, yet that is of grace, not of nece≈ø≈øity; therefore the death at the time of the Scire Fac. brought is not material, if he were alive at the Capias returned, Cro. Jac. p. 165. Timperly and Coleman.

If the principal dye before the Capias returned, the Bail may be di≈øcharged, but never where he dyeth after, though before the return of the fir≈øt Scire Fac. for hereby the Plaintiff is put by his debt, and the Executors may be in≈øolvent, 2 Keb. p. 127. Coopers Ca≈øe.

Scire Fac. again≈øt B. and others, as Bail for P. P. being Condemned, and not rendring his Body to Pri≈øon. Scire Fac. was brought again≈øt them, upon this Recognizance they pleaded, that P. ≈øuch a day, before the day in the Recognizance, paid the Mony; this is a good Plea in it ≈øelf, for the Recognizance, as to them is but an Obligation upon a Condition, upon which they might
well plead performance; but the party in the Scire Fac. upon this Recovery cannot plead it, except ≈øatisfaction be acknowledged on Record; for by nude payment he ≈øhall not avoid matter of Record, Cro. Eliz. p. 233. Brunckhorns Ca≈øe. Cro. Eliz. 31. Ordway.

Manucaptors in Scire Fac. plead, that the principal was taken by Capias, and deteined till he paid the Mony; payment is a good Plea, but no place of payment being alledged, its ill, and Judgment pro querente, 2 Keb. 577. Farrel and Sheen. Mod. Rep. 14. Me≈øme Ca≈øe.

Payment before the return of the Scire Fac. by the principal, is no Plea; yet before the Writ of Scire Fac. brought, it is by the Bail. Bail pleads payment by the principal; before the Scire Fac. viz. the ≈øame day: after Capias taken out, its no Plea, nor ≈øaves the Recognizance, 3 Keb. 349. Barford and Peel.

In Scire Fac. Bail pleads, that the principal had entred him≈øelf before Tho. Twi≈øden Ju≈øtice, &c. in di≈øcharge of his Bail, and the entry was, Quod reddidit ≈øe in exonerationem manucaptorum, & hoc Paratus e≈øt verificare: The Plaintiff demurs, becau≈øe it ≈øhould be, prout patet per Recordum. Pre≈øidents are both ways, Siderfin p. 216. Midleton and the Manucaptors of Silve≈øter.

P. M. was Bail for the Defendant, and before any judgment given, the Plaintiff relea≈øeth to P.M. all Actions, Duties and Demands; afterwards Judgment was given again≈øt the Defendant, and upon his default Scire Fac. i≈ø≈øues again≈øt P. M. who pleads the ≈øaid General Relea≈øe. The Plaintiff demurs.
Per Cur. This Relea≈øe ≈øhall not bar the Plaintiff, for the Words of the Bail are conditional, Scilicit ≈øi contingeret predict. debita & damna illa praefat. querenti minime ≈øolvere, aut ≈øe pri≈øonae non reddere, &c. and its not any duty certain till Judgment given; and note, diver≈øity between a duty certain upon condition ≈øub≈øequent, for this may be relea≈øed before the day of the performance of the Condition, and a duty uncertain at fir≈øt, and upon condition precedent to be made certain afterwards; this in the mean time is but a meer po≈ø≈øibility, and may not not be relea≈øed; this Recognizance doth not create a duty pre≈øently, but ≈øhall produce a duty after on a contingence, 5 Rep. 70. Hoe and Mar≈øhal.

Audita Querela by the Bail after judgment again≈øt him for debt on Scire Fac. becau≈øe he was within Age at the time of the Bail; and by the Audita Querela he was di≈øcharged; cited in Sir John Ap≈øleys Ca≈øe, Cro. Eliz. 645. Yelvertons New Book of Entries, p. 87. p. 155. Markam and Turner. He cannot plead his Infancy to the Scire Fac. for this Suit goes in affirmance of the Recognizance, and demands Execution of this at the day of the ≈øecond Scire Fac. The Bail pleads nul tiel Record, and then brings the Body of the principal into Court, and prays that his Body may be taken in Execution. Per Cur. if the Bail before or at the return of the ≈øecond Scire Fac. bring in the Body of the principal, his Body ≈øhall be put in Execution only; but here they have pleaded, and therefore if the party Plaintiff do not pray to have the Body in Execution, he is not compellable to take him, 2 Rolls Rep. 367. Cage and Doughty.

Second Scire Fac. is joint again≈øt the Bail. Capias may i≈ø≈øue out again≈øt one only; for the nature of the Recognizance is not changed by the judgment in the Scire Fuc. brought upon this, but that the Execution may be joint or ≈øeveral, according to the Recognizance, although the Scire Fac. was joint, Siderfin p. 339. Gee ver≈øus Sir Francis Fane.

If three bind them≈øelves jointly in a Recognizance, Execution mu≈øt go again≈øt them all; and if they are bound ≈øeverally, there if the Scire Fac. be again≈øt all, the Execution mu≈øt be ≈øo too; for by the Judgment they have made their election, 2 Siderfin p. 12.

Capias agin≈øt the Principal and Judgment; and after Scire Fac. again≈øt the Bail, and Judgment thereupon; the Plaintiff cannot take out one Execution of Scire Facias again≈øt ihe Goods and Chattels of the principal and Bail, for there ought to be ≈øeveral Executions upon the ≈øeveral Judgments, Stiles Rep. p. 290. Newton and Goddard. Trin. 1651. Banc. ≈øup.

div.head: Removal, Error, Hab. Corpus.
div.p: IN Scire Fae. again≈øt Bail, on removal of the principal by Error; the Defendant pleaded the Writ of Error is yet depending (this was on Bail below) no Scire Fac. will be again≈øt the Bail, e≈øpecially out of an Inferior Court, till the principal be determined. Scire Fac. cannot be until Judgment be affirmed, 3 Keb. 396, 424. Caul and Bezar.

Debt brought in Inferior Court of Record, and i≈ø≈øue pro Quer. and Judgment given and had again≈øt the Manucaptors, and Error brought in redditione judicii, and the Record and Plea removed to this Court, but not the Recognizance nor Judgment again≈øt the Manucaptors; per Doddrige; they have well done in removing only the Record and the Judgment again≈øt the principal, and that they may well proceed to Execution; and if judgment was not had again≈øt the Manucaptors, after the Error brought, then it ought to be removed by ≈øpecial Writ of Error, 2 Rolls Rep. 494. Anonymus.

A. is Bail for B. Judgment in B. R. is given again≈øt B. B. ≈øues Error in Exchequer Chamber; there the Judgment is affirmed, and Co≈øts a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. A. ≈øhall be charged with the Judgment in B. R. but not for the Co≈øts on the Writ of Error, Noy p. 18.

The Defendant was Bail in Inferior Court, in Action of Debt. Scire Fac. again≈øt him, becau≈øe the Principal did not render nor pay: The Defendant pleaded, that after the fir≈øt Action brought, and Bail found, the Cau≈øe was removed by Habea ‚Ä¢ Corpus, and new Bail here accepted; and afterwards the Cau≈øe was ‚Ä¢ manded by procedendo, and then Judgment given again≈øt the Principal. The Que≈øtion was, if the old Bail be di≈øcharged by the Record removed? Per Cur. If the Bail be here Recorded, ≈øo as the Court is fully po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of the matter, and the Term is pa≈øt, there the old Bail is ab≈øolutely di≈øcharged; but if in the ≈øame Term the Record is remanded by procedendo, it is as if it never had been removed, and there is no Record of
the removal thereof, and the matter doth re≈øt in the inferior Court, Statu quo prius, the fir≈øt Bail is revived, 2 Bul≈øtr. 287. Cro. Jac. 363. 1 Roll 64. Be≈øton and Buller.

Mainpri≈øe or Recognizance may be taken before an Action brought, where the Cau≈øe is removed by Habeas Corpus, and ≈øo is the cour≈øe in B. Com. The u≈øual and be≈øt cour≈øe to remove the Record, is by Mittimus out of Chancery, Cro. Jac. p. 97. Hargrave and Rogers.

Judgment is given in B. R. again≈øt the principal, and afterwards by Scire Fac. again≈øt the Bail: Principal and Bail cannot join in a Writ of Error upon the≈øe ≈øeveral Judgments; and the Bail cannot have a new Writ of Error by him≈øelf, Quod coram vobis re≈øidet, becau≈øe the Scire Fac. is none of the Actions wherein the Writ of Error is given in the Exchequer Chamber, Hobart p. 72. Forre≈øt and Sir James Sandland. Judgment is in Scire Fac. which is a Judicial Writ, and it is not expre≈øsly named in Stat. 27. Eliz. Yel. p. 157. Prow≈øe and Turner.

Judgment is given in the Scire Fac. upon the Recognizance; Error was brought upon that Judgment, and the Judgment affirmed: Afterwards a Writ of Error was brought upon the principal Judgment, which was rever≈øed: hereupon Audita Querela is brought. Per. Cur. the fir≈øt Judgment rever≈øed, is no rever≈øal of the Judgment in the Scire Fac. becau≈øe it is a collateral Judgment by it ≈øelf; yet it is a good cau≈øe for Audita Querela, for it is qua≈øi dependent on the fir≈øt Judgment, and the fir≈øt Judgment is the cau≈øe that he is charged by this Recognizance, and its but rea≈øon the Bail
≈øhould have remedy to be di≈øcharged from the Execution, Cro. Jac. p. 645. Sir John Ap≈øley and Ive. 2 Roll. Rep. 354. Legris Ca≈øe.

Action was for 23 l. 18 s. The Bail on Recognizance was 23 l. 18. Judgment again≈øt the principal, and Scire Fac. again≈øt the Bail for 23 l. 10 s. it was held Error for this mi≈øtake, Cro. Eliz. p. 855. Kilborn and Trot.

Judgment was given in Scire Facias again≈øt the Bail, that the Plaintiff ≈øhall recover ≈øuper recuperationem praedictam, where it ≈øhould be ≈øuper recognitionem praedictam; No Writ of Error lyes in Exchequer Chamber, Cau≈øa qua ≈øupra, neither in this Ca≈øe in the Kings Bench, for this is no Error in proce≈øs, i. e. where one proce≈øs is taken for another; but the Error is only in point of Judgment, and no remedy but in Parliament, Yel. p. 157. Prow≈øe and Turner.

D. brought a Writ of Error in Camera Scac. and found Sureties to pro≈øecute with effect; and for default a Scire Fac. was brought again≈øt him, who appears and is in Execution. Qu. If the Bail be di≈øcharged by the appearance of the Plaintiff in the Writ of Error, 1 Rolls Rep. 361. Asker and Downs.

Mainpernors were in Action of Debt, pro damnis & mi≈øis; and Scire Fac. i≈ø≈øueth de debito & damnis, and Judgment again≈øt the Mainpernors, and now a Super≈øedeas quia erronice fuit, for they were not Sureties pro debito. D ‚Ä¢ ddrige, ye are put to Aud. Quer. 2 Rolls R ‚Ä¢ p. 431. Cola and Yarnon.

Scire Fac. again≈øt Bail, upon 3 Jac. c. 8. in a Writ of Error; the Defendant pleaded that the Principal did pro≈øecute with effect, and that the
Judgment was rever≈øed; he ought to plead pr ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
ret per recordum, and not hoc paratus, &c. 1 Keb. 185. Maire and Spencer. and p. 318. Bor ‚Ä¢
and Hammond.

The Bail pleads the Recognizance was on Condition to pro≈øecute Error, and alledgeth performance; the Plaintiff ≈øhews that Judgment was affirmed prout patet by Record, and ≈øaith not unde petit debitum or executionem; this being ≈øpecially alledged as form in demurrer, is ill, 2 Keb. 581. Barret and Millward.
In Bail upon a Writ of Error upon the Sta ‚Ä¢ e of 3 Jac. c. 8. Its not ≈øufficient to render the Body, but he ought to pay the Debt, Cro. Jac. p. 402. Au≈øten and Monk.

The not a≈ø≈øigning of Errors is a breach of the Recognizance to pro≈øecute with effect according to the Statute 16 and 17 Car. 2. c. 8. Siderfin p. 294. Cooper and Price. But if the Party will come in and tender the principal Debt and Co≈øts, the Court will relieve him, and not ≈øuffer the Plaintiff to take Execution again≈øt both; and no ‚Ä¢
≈øtitution ≈øhall be of this Mony on this Recognizance, in Ca≈øe the Plaintiff do after a≈ø≈øign Errors, 2 Keble 75. Cooper and Price.

Scire Facias on Recognizance, on 10 and 17 Car. 2. c. 8. to pro≈øecute a Writ of Error returnable 6 May, in Ea≈øt-Term, the Defendant pleads that „Äà‚óä„Äâ died 18 Augu≈øt, and that until his death he pro≈øecuted with effect; the Plaintiff replies, that the Defendant did not cau≈øe the Record of B. R. to be certified into the Exchequer-Chamber in his life-time; the Defendant rejoins, he was ≈øtopt by Injunction in Chancery. Per Cur.
the Recognizance is not forfeited, 2 Keble 53, 70. H ‚Ä¢ chman and Corbet.
If one of the Principals renders him≈øelf, this is no di≈øcharge of the Bail, vide 3 Keble 766, 776. A≈øtree and Ballard.

div.head: Defea≈øance, the noti ‚Ä¢ of it, It ≈øignifies to defeat or undo.
div.p:
THere is a diver≈øity between Inheritances executed, and Inheritances executory; as lands executed by Livery, &c. cannot by Indenture of Defea≈øance be defeated afterwards; ≈øo if a Di≈ø≈øei≈øee relea≈øe to a Diffei≈øor, it cannot be defeated by Indenture of Defea≈øance made afterwards; but at the time of the Feoffment, Relea≈øe, &c. the ≈øame may be defeated; but Rents, Annuities, Conditions, Warranties, and ≈øuch like Inheritances executory, may be defeated by Defea≈øances made either at that time, or any time after, Co. Lit. p. 237. ‚Ä¢ . And ≈øo may Statutes, Recognizances, Obligations, and other things executory. And of Statutes, Judgments and Obligations, it is the u≈øual practice to make a Defea≈øance of them afterwards. A Defea≈øance is a conditional Relea≈øe, and a Relea≈øe is an ab≈øolute Defea≈øance; and the difference is as afore≈øaid between the Defea≈øance of a thing ve≈øted, and of a thing excutory; as in a Feoffment of Lands, the Condition ought to be contained in the ≈øame Charter of Feoffment, or in another Deed ≈øealed at the ≈øame time with the Feoffment, or otherwi≈øe the Condition is void, for by the Feoffment
the E≈øtate of the Land is ve≈øted, and executed „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Feoffee; otherwi≈øe of Judgments, Obligations, &c. therefore the Judgment given, Hill. 21 and 22 Car. 2. B. R. in the Ca≈øe of Fowel and Forre≈øt was again≈øt Law; it was thus. Debt on Bond dated the 8th of Apr. 16 Car. 2. The Defendant after Oyer of the Condition, pleads‚ñ™ That after the making of the Obligation, (viz.) the ≈øame day and year the Plaintiff by his Deed of Defea≈øance ≈øhewed forth, had promi≈øed and engaged, that if before the la≈øt day of J.
„Äà‚óä„Äâ next en≈øuing, he ≈øhould not produce Te≈øtimonie ‚Ä¢ to prove that the Monies mentioned in the Condition ‚Ä¢ was a true Debt, and that the Defendant before the making of the ≈øaid Obligation, had promi≈øed to pay this, then the Obligation ≈øhould be void, &c. and avers, that the Plaintiff did not pro ‚Ä¢ any Te≈øtimonies to make ≈øuch proof as afore≈øaid, the Plaintiff demurs; Judgment was given for the Plaintiff upon this point, Becau≈øe the Defea≈øance was pleaded to be made after the Obligation; and if it would avoid the Obligation, it ≈øhould be made at the ≈øame time, quod mirum, Sand ‚Ä¢ s 2 Rep. 47. I ≈øhould rather have conceived the Rea≈øon of their Opinion for the Plaintiff to have been, for that it was an Obligation with a Condition; and the Condition is it ≈øelf a Defea≈øance, and that a Defea≈øance upon a Defea≈øance is improper and confu≈øed; but qu. ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ c ratione.

B. acknowledges a Statute to S. There was a Defea≈øance, That if his Lands in the County of S. ≈øhould be extended, the Statute ≈øhould be void: Per Cur. the Defea≈øance is good, and not repugnant, becau≈øe its by another Deed; but the Condition
of a Bond not to ≈øue the Obligation, is void, „Äà‚óä„Äâ
n. 1035. Trot and Spurling.

div.head: What amounts to a Defea≈øance, and what not.
div.p: THat the Bond ≈øhall not be ≈øued before ≈øuch a Fea≈øt; if he be ≈øued it ≈øhall be void, 21 H. 7. 23, 30.

The Defendant pleads in Bar, That the Plaintiff by his Deed indented after the making of the Obligation, grants to the Defendant, that he will not pro≈øecute or mole≈øt the Defendant, by force of the ≈øaid Obligation, before the Fea≈øt of, &c. and demurs; Per Cur. its no Bar, but a Covenant, and if it were that he will not ≈øue him at all, that may be pleaded in Bar to avoid circuity of Action, 1 Ander≈øon p. 307. Dow≈øe and Jeoffreys.

An Obligation from A. of 20 l. to T. B. with Condition, if he paid T. B. 40 s. at ≈øuch a day then it ≈øhould lo≈øe its force; and after B. was bound to A. in another Obligation which was indor≈øed on performance of Conditions ≈øpecified in an Indenture; and after the end of the Conditions endor≈øed on the la≈øt Obligation, were the≈øe words, Provided always, that where the ≈øaid A. is bound to the ≈øaid B. in a Bond of 20 l. the ≈øaid B. ≈øhall not ≈øue for the Sum compri≈øed in the ≈øaid Obligation, until the Condition ≈øpecified in the ≈øaid Indenture, mentioned in this pre≈øent Obligation, be performed; after A. ≈øued the fir≈øt Bond, and B. pleaded this matter, and averred that the Conditions in the Indenture are not yet performed: Per Englefield and Shelly, This is not a
good Plea; the Condition to defeat another Obligation is impertinent, and the fir≈øt Obligation ‚Ä¢ had an Indor≈øement on it, which ≈øhall ≈øerve for the Defea≈øance of it, 26 H. 8. fol. 9.

Several Bonds were ≈øealed for the payment of Monies; and after by Indenture the Plaintiff did agree with the Defendant, that if the Defendant ≈øhould pay to Elizabeth the Daughter 500 l. and ≈øhall perform the other things, &c. that all the Obligations ≈øhall be void, and be delivered up; its was agreed; this was a good Defea≈øance of the Obligation; but for other Faults in the Plea, Judgment pro Quer. Bridgmans Rep. 116. Lee and Wood.

Memor. I William I. do owe and am indebted to E. H. 10 l. for the payment whereof I bind my ≈øelf, &c. In witne≈øs, &c. Memor. That the ≈øaid W. I. be not compelled to pay the ≈øaid 10 l. until he recover 30 l. upon an Obligation again≈øt A. B. Per Coke, That which comes after (in witne≈øs) is not part of the Deed, but ≈øhall have its force as a Defea≈øance; but then the Defendant mu≈øt plead it, 2 Brownl. Rep. 98. Hammond and Jethro.
Per Coke, A Man without a Defea≈øance, may plead that the Statute was acknowledged for payment of a le≈ø≈øer Sum, 1 Brownl. 51. in Brok≈øbys Ca≈øe.

The Statute was defea≈øanced on this Condition, If R. E. ob≈øerve, perform and accompli≈øh the la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament of Sir J. E. his Father, and pay and content all the Beque≈øts and Legacies according to the true intent and meaning of the ≈øaid la≈øt Will. Sir J. E. devi≈øeth Land in Capite
in Fee; after his death R. E. enters into a third part of the ≈øaid Lands; by the major-part of the Judges, the Statute is not forfeit, Jones p. 267. Sir Rowl. Egertons Ca≈øe in Chancery.

If the Defea≈øances on a Statute be by Indenture, and vary; the words of the Defea≈øance are the Act and Words of the Conu≈øee only, and not of any other; and if his part of the Indenture vary from that part delivered to the Conu≈øor, in that that it varies its utterly void, 2 Ander≈øon p.
‚Ä¢ 8. Holling≈øworth and Wheeler, Cro. El. 532. Hollingworth and A≈øcue.

H. in Aud. Querela upon a Statute ≈øurmi≈øeth, that there was an Indenture of Defea≈øance, if he pa ‚Ä¢ yearly for ≈øix years 50 l. to one J. B. at the Fea≈øt at St. Michaelmas, at ≈øuch a place, &c. the Statute ≈øhould be void; and avers that it was to J. B's u≈øe, and that he tendred at every of the ≈øaid Fea≈øts 50 l. at the place, and that J. B. was not there to receive it: Per Cur. 1. Though J. B. was a Stranger to the Recognizance, yet fora≈ømuch as it is averred to be made to his u≈øe, he ought at his peril to be ready at the place every day to receive it; otherwi≈øe the Recognizance is not forfeit, when the other doth tender it. 2. Though he ≈øaith not, nec aliquis alius ex parte ≈øua; was there to receive it, its good; for it ought to come on the other part, if any were there to receive it. 3. He ≈øaith at one of the days he was ready, and offered to pay it; and J. B. was not there ad exigend ‚Ä¢ & recipienil. (≈øo the copulative (&) made the demand material, which needed not,) yet the ≈øurmi≈øe was good; for the matter is, whether he tendred or not, C ‚Ä¢ o. Jac. 13, 14. Phillips
ver≈øus Rice ap Hugh Cro. Eliz. 754. vide this Ca≈øe well reported, Yelv. p. 38. by the Name of Hughs and Phillips.
A Defea≈øance unle≈øs made the ≈øame day of a Statute, and delivered uno flatu, cannot be pleaded in Bar, 1 Keb. 111. Sir Rich. Belli≈øon, Qu.
In the next place I ≈øhall ≈øhew ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Bonds; as a Bond ≈øued again≈øt the Heir, Arbitrament Bonds, Apprentices Bonds, Bonds for the Good Behaviour, &c.

div.head: Debt on Bond again≈øt the Heir.
div.p: HOW an Heir ≈øhall be charged on the Obligation of his Father; at the end of Popham, Jones p. 87, 155. Bowyer and Rovil, vide Siderfin p. 342.

It mu≈øt be brought in the debet & detinet, Lach. p. 203. Anonymus. The Bill was on the File debet & detinet; but the Declaration on the Roll was detinet only, which could not be amended after Verdict; but leave was given to the Court to declare upon the old Bill; being within three Terms he may declare, becau≈øe the Debt el≈øe had been lo≈øt, becau≈øe the Heir after the Bill entred had aliened the Term, ibid,
Debt again≈øt an Heir in the detinet only, is aided after a Verdict, by the Statute 16 and 17 Car. 2. cap. 8. but not otherwi≈øe, 2 Keble 259, 290. Siderfin p. 342. Comber and Waltoe.
Its good again≈øt the Heir tho the Executors have A≈ø≈øets; he may have his Election, 1 Ander≈øon p. 7. Sir Ed. Capels Ca≈øe.
Debt lies again≈øt the Heir of an Heir upon Obligation of the Ance≈øtor, to the 10th degree, Noy 56. Dennyes Ca≈øe.
The Obligee ≈øhall have a joint Action again≈øt all the Sons in Gavel-kind, 11 H. 7.12. b.

Debt again≈øt three Heirs in Gavel-kind; the Defendant pleads C. one of the Heirs is within Age. The Heir of an Heir ≈øhall be chargable with an Obligation ≈øimul cum the immediate Heir, and ≈øuch Heir ≈øhall have his Age, Moor n. 194. Hawtree and Auger, 1 Ander≈øon p. 10. n. 22. id. Ca≈øe.

If a Man bind him≈øelf and his Heirs in an Obligation, and leaves Land at Common Law and Gavel-kind, the Creditors mu≈øt ≈øue all the Heirs; and if there be Land on the part of the Father, and on the part of the Mother, and both have Land by de≈øcent, he ≈øhall have ≈øeveral Actions, and Execution ≈øhall cea≈øe till he may take it again≈øt both; ≈øo that the Con≈øtruction of Law is ≈øtricter where the Heir is charged with Warranty real, than when he is charged with a Chattel, Hob. p. 25.

div.head: Riens per de≈øcent pleaded, and what ≈øhall be A≈ø≈øets.
div.p: J. S. by Will devi≈øeth his Land to his Heir at 24. and if he die without Heir of his Body before 24. the Remainder over; he attains 24. a Fee-≈øimple de≈øcends, for no Tail ≈øhall ari≈øe before his ≈øaid Age, which Tail ≈øhall never take effect, 2 Leon. p. 11. Hind and Sir John Lion, id. Ca≈øe. 3 Leon. p. 70.

The Father bound in Obligation, and devi≈øeth his Lands to his Wife till his Son comes to 21 years of Age, the remainder to his Son in Fee and dies; the Son ≈øhall be adjudged in by de≈øcent,
2 Leon. 123. fol. 101. Ba≈øhpooles Ca≈øe. 3 Leon. p. 118.

The Ance≈øtor was ≈øei≈øed in Fee, and by his Will devi≈øeth them to the Defendant, being his Son and Heir, and to his Heirs, on Condition to pay his Debts within a year, and if he failed, his Executors ≈øhall ≈øell; he entred and paid no Debts, the Executors after entred and ≈øold: Its not A≈ø≈øets in Heirs hands, for though the Heir hath a Fee, yet he hath it as a Purcha≈øer being clogg'd with ≈øuch a Condition, Cro. M. 5 Car. p. 161. Gilpins Ca≈øe.

Two things requi≈øite to bind an Heir, 1. Lien expre≈øs. 2. Lands by de≈øcent. In Debt again≈øt an Heir, he is charged as Heir, and the Writ is in the debet and detinet, and its not in auter droit, but taken as his proper Debt; from 18 Ed. 2. till 7 H. 4. If the Executor had A≈ø≈øets, the Heir was not chargeable, but now the Law is changed in that Point; if the Heir ≈øell the Land before the Writ purcha≈øed, he is di≈øcharged of the Debt in regard he is not to wait the Action of the Obligee.

Tru≈øts de≈øcending ≈øhall be A≈ø≈øets by the Statute of Frauds and Perjuries; ≈øo Lands of ≈øpecial Occupancy, vid. Stat. The Defendant pleads, his Father was ≈øeized in Fee, and covenanted with J.S. &c. to ≈øtand ≈øeized to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for Life, the Remainder to the Defendant in Tail, &c. the Father had cau≈øed a Deed to be engro≈ø≈øed, and delivered the Deed to a Scrivener to the u≈øe of J. D. and M. ≈øo as J. D. would agree to it; J.D. died never having notice of the Deed: Per Cur. the Father never covenanted, becau≈øe the Agreement of J. D. was a Condition precedent to the e≈ø≈øence of the Deed, and ≈øo no Deed to rai≈øe the
U≈øes; contra the Defendant, Moor n. 426. Dego ‚Ä¢
and Rowes Ca≈øe, id. Ca≈øe. 1 Leon. 152. n. 211.

The Heir pleads riens per de≈øcent; ≈øpecial Verdict find, the Father was ≈øci≈øed in Fee, and enfeoft J. S. of the Mannor of P. excepted and re≈øerved to the Feoffor for life two Acres only, (the Lands in que≈øtion,) and after limited all to the Feoffees, to the u≈øe of the Defendant in Tail: Per Cur. the Lands do de≈øcend to the Son, (the Exception being void,) 2 Keb. p. 667, ‚Ä¢ 19. Wil≈øon and Armorer.

Upon riens per de≈øcent pleaded; ≈øpecial Verdict find M. ≈øei≈øed in Fee de Saliva Anglice a Salt-pan, died, and his Son entred and was ≈øei≈øed, and the Defendant entred as Heir per po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. fratris, this is A≈ø≈øets by de≈øcent, and ≈øuch Heir per po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion' is chargable to the Debt of the Ance≈øtor, 3 Keb. Tr. 28 Car. 2. f. 659. Clinch and Butler.

The Heir pleads riens per de≈øcent; the Defendant had levied a Fine, but becau≈øe no Deed of U≈øes was produced at Trial, the U≈øe was to the Conu≈øor and his Heirs, and ≈øo the Heir in by de≈øcent, Mod. Rep. p. 2.
Riens per de≈øcent pleaded; Feoffment pleaded; at the Trial it appeared to be fraudulent; it need not be pleaded, but may well be given in Evidence, 5 Rep. 60. Gooches Ca≈øe.

Debt vers l'Heir, he may plead in Bar a Relea≈øe made by the Obligee to the Executors; and though the Deed belongs to another, yet he mu≈øt ≈øhew it forth, for both of them are privy to the Te≈øtator, Co. Lit. 232. a.

Upon riens per de≈øcent pleaded, it was found he had A≈ø≈øets in the Cinque-ports, Judgment was general again≈øt the Defendants; and as to the Moleties
of the Lands in the Cinque-Ports the Plaintiff „Äà‚óä„Äâ have a Certiorari to remove the Records into Chancery, and thence by Mittimus to ≈øend to the Con≈øtable to make Execution, 1 Ander≈øon n. 65. p. 28. Hicker and Harri≈øon ver≈ø. Tirrel, 3 Leon. p. 3.

The Heir pleads riens per de≈øcent; the Plaintiff replies, he ≈øued a former Writ vers l'heir, and the Defendant was outlawed, which was rever≈øed, and he fre≈øhly brought this Writ by journeys accompts, and avers he had A≈ø≈øets the day of the fir≈øt Writ purcha≈øed, Hob. p. 248. Spray and Sherrat, Cro. Jac. 589. id. Ca≈øe cited.

Debt vers l'heir; the Defendant pleads his Ance≈øtor died Inte≈øtate, and that one J. S. had admini≈øtred, and had given the Plaintiff a Bond in full ≈øatisfaction of the former: upon I≈ø≈øue joined, it was found pro Def. If the Obligor had given this Bond, it had not di≈øcharged the former, but being given by the Admini≈øtrator, ≈øo that the Plaintiffs ≈øecurity is bettered, and the Admini≈øtrator chargable de bonis propriis, its a good di≈øcharge, Mod. Rep. 225. Blith and Hill.

He pleads riens per de≈øcent, but 20 Acres in D. in Com. Warwic. The Plaintiff replies, more by de≈øcent in S. (viz.) ≈øo many Acres; and found pro Def. and a di≈øcontinuance in the Record of the Plea from Term P. to Term M. a≈ø≈øigned for Error; and per Cur. its Error, and not deins Stat. 18 Eliz. becau≈øe the Judgment was not founded on the Verdict, but upon the Confe≈ø≈øion of the Defendant of A≈ø≈øets, Yelv. p. 169. Hill. 7 Jac. B. R. Molineux Ca≈øe.
The Heir pleads the Obligor died Inte≈øtate, and J. S. admini≈øtred, and he had given the Plaintiff another Bond in full ≈øatisfaction of the former, vide Mod. Rep. 221, 225. Blith and Hill.

div.head: Declaration.
div.p: IN the Declaration is omitted (& ad eandem ≈øolation, faciend. obligo me & haeredes meos) it was amended, Cro. Jac. 147. Forger and Sales. Alit. if one declare in debet & detinet, where it ought to be in the detinet only, ibid. Winch p. 20.

If I declare on Obligation again≈øt a collateral Heir, the Declaration mu≈øt be ≈øpecial; as Debt again≈øt the Brother and Heir; the Defendant pleads riens per de≈øcent from his ≈øaid Brother; but he had A≈ø≈øets by de≈øcent from the Son of his Brother, but he mu≈øt be charged by ≈øpecial Declaration; and ≈øo Judgment pro Def. Cro. Car. 151. Hill. 4 Car. 1. Jenkes Ca≈øe.

div.head: Judgment and Execution.
div.p: DET port en Lichfield again≈øt the Heir; he pleads riens, &c. the Plaintiff replies A≈ø≈øets, but ≈øhews not in what place, whether within the Juri≈ødiction; Judgment was erroneous; yet per Dodderidge, If the Jury find the A≈ø≈øets to be deins Juri≈ødiction its ≈øufficient, though not ≈øo alledged. Q. if Co≈øts and Damages ≈øhall be given to the Plaintiff on ≈øuch Judgment, 2 Rolls Rep. p. 48. Brown and Carrington.
In all Courts he mu≈øt ≈øhew the place of A≈ø≈øets, Q. Cro. Jac. 502. id. Ca≈øe. Co. Rep. 6.46 Dowdales Ca≈øe.

Det vers l'heir, pendant le Action another Action was brought again≈øt the ≈øame Heir upon another Obligation of the Ance≈øtor; Judgment is given for the Plaintiffs in both Actions, but the Plaintiff in the ≈øecond Action obtains Judgment fir≈øt; he for whom the fir≈øt Judgment was given, ≈øhall be fir≈øt ≈øatisfied; but if the Heir after the fir≈øt Action brought had aliened, and the Plaintiff in
the ≈øecond Action commenced his Suit after ≈øuch Alienation had obtained Judgment before the fir≈øt Plaintiff; in that ca≈øe the Plaintiff in the fir≈øt „Äà‚óä„Äâ on ≈øhould be ≈øatisfied, and he in the ≈øecond Action not at all, Mod. Rep. 253. Anonymus.

In Det vers l'heir by Bill, after riens per d ‚Ä¢ ≈øm pleaded, tempore exhibitionis Bills; the Defendant excepted at the Trial, becau≈øe the Bill was not ≈øhewed; and the Plaintiff was non-≈øuit: Per C ‚Ä¢
the Bill is confe≈øt, and need not be ≈øhewed, 1 K ‚Ä¢ b. p. 793. Rogers and Rogers.
The Heir ≈øhall put in Bail on a Writ of Error, per Stat. 16 Car. 2. c. 2 Keb. 320. Co ‚Ä¢ ber and Walton.

Det vers tres Co-heirs; two confe≈øs A≈ø≈øets, the other pleads to I≈ø≈øue and is non-≈øuited; its a Non-≈øuit again≈øt them all, though the two have confe≈øt; and ≈øo the Plaintiff lo≈øt his Debt, there being ‚Ä¢ n Alienation before a new Original, Siderfin p. 378 Blacks Ca≈øe.

He ought to confe≈øs the A≈ø≈øets that truly de≈øcend to him, otherwi≈øe his own Land ≈øhall be charged with the Debt, Plow. 440. Pepyes Ca≈øe. Dyer
‚Ä¢
Henninghams Ca≈øe, Dyer 344. Qu. if upon
‚Ä¢ il dicit or non ≈øum informatus, Judgment ≈øhall be general: but in Sc. fac. ≈øur Recognizance of the Ance≈øtor again≈øt the Heir, he pleads riens per de≈øcent, which is fal≈øe; here Judgment ≈øhall be ≈øpecial, for he is not charged as Heir, but as Terre-Tenant; at the end of Popham, 1 Car. B. R. 153. Bowyer and Ricots.
After Imparlance one is e≈øtopt to ≈øay that he is not Heir, (being charged in Debt as Son and Heir,) ≈øo to ≈øay he is a Ba≈øtard, 35 H. 6. 36, 37.

The Heir pleads riens per de≈øcent, be≈øides one Acre; if the Plaintiff plea≈øe he may have Execution of that one Acre; or if the Plaintiff plead that he hath A≈ø≈øets beyond that Acre, and it be found that he hath ten Acres more, the Plaintiff ≈øhall have Execution of the Land only, and not of his Per≈øon. Where the Heir pleads he hath nothing by de≈øcent generally, and its found again≈øt him, the Land and all other Land that he hath, and his Body, are ‚Ä¢ iable to judgment by Ca. ≈øa. Fi. fat. or Elegit,
‚Ä¢ 1 Brownl Rep. 254. Qu. what difference between a fal≈øe Plea and nil dicit, 2 Keb. 343.

Riens per de≈øcent after the death of the Ance≈øtor. Pri≈øt. Such I≈ø≈øue ≈øhall be good in a Formedon; for if he have A≈ø≈øets at any time, he ≈øhall be charged and barred of his Formedon intirely: in this Ca≈øe it mu≈øt be riens jour de brev ‚Ä¢ purcha≈øe nec un ‚Ä¢
p ‚Ä¢ is, 10 H. 7.8. b.

In Det vers 4 Co-heirs on ≈øeveral I≈ø≈øues on riens per de≈øcent, A≈ø≈øets was found as to one only; Judgment given again≈øt her that had A≈ø≈øets, quod re ‚Ä¢ uperes debitum & dam ‚Ä¢ ≈øua generally, „Äà‚óä„Äâ
de hunis propriis, 2 Keb. p. 588. Cary and Brickm ‚Ä¢ r ver≈øus Lock.
On nil dicit the Heirs own Lands and Goods ≈øhall be charged, i. e. a general Judgment.

The Heir pleads Lands ≈øet out for Portions, be≈øides a Rever≈øion of which he hath nothing; replies, a third part de≈øcended; Judgment ≈øpecial, 1 Keb. 156. Cudmo ‚Ä¢
and L ‚Ä¢ wis.

Judgment again≈øt the Heir upon nil dicit ≈øhall be general, and ≈øhall extend to his own Lands, as well as to tho≈øe which ≈øpecially de≈øcend, Poph. 154. Bowyers Ca≈øe. M ‚Ä¢ or n. 657. Bar ‚Ä¢ r and Bor ‚Ä¢ e.
Capias lies too again≈øt the Heir in Ca≈øe of a fal≈øe Plea, 2 Leon. p. 11. Sir John Lyons Ca≈øe.

The Defendant confe≈ø≈øeth he hath a ≈øeck Rever≈øion, beyond which he had no A≈ø≈øets; the Plaintiff ≈øaid he had ou≈øter, and were at I≈ø≈øue; the Plaintiff comes and prays leave to wave this I≈ø≈øue, and to have Judgment of the Rever≈øion, quod fuit conce≈ø≈øum quando accideret, 1 Rolls Rep. 57. Anonymus.

The Jury find the Defendant had divers Lands in Fee by de≈øcent, and ≈øhews not what; yet Judgment good; for upon his fal≈øe Plea Judgment ≈øhall be given generally again≈øt him if he have any A≈ø≈øets; and ≈øo the quantity of the A≈ø≈øets is not material; but otherwi≈øe in Ca≈øe of Executors, for there they mu≈øt find the value of the A≈ø≈øets, for he mu≈øt there recover according to the A≈ø≈øets found, 1 Rolls Rep. 234. Evet and Sucliff. M. 13 Jac. 1. B.R.
The Judgment and Execution ≈øhall be general, unle≈øs the Heir acknowledgeth the Action, and ≈øhews that he hath ≈øo much by de≈øcent, Cro. M. 41 and 42 El. 692. Barker and Bourne.

If the Heir pleads riens per de≈øcent, and it be a faux Plea, it ≈øhall be a general Judgment again≈øt him, and no Writ of Enquiry need to be to enquire what Lands he hath, and need have no ≈øpecial Judgment, for the Judgment ought to be, that the Defendants Body and Goods ≈øhall be liable, and half his Lands, Stiles p. 287, 288. Allery and Holden.
If the Jury find he hath Lands by de≈øcent, and name them, and Judgment accordingly, its erroneous, Stiles p. 327. Subgrave and Bo≈øvil.
Cro. Jac. p. 236. Molineux Ca≈øe. Armourer ver≈øus Willis, 2 Keb. 642, 643, 667, 719. What Bail the Heir ≈øhall put in, 3 Keb. 803. Lawrence and Blith.

div.head: Bonds of Arbitrament.
div.p: I Shall not here run into the Learning of Awards, which is a curious and large Title in our Law, and of which Mr. March hath compo≈øed a very Methodical Treati≈øe, but take notice of ≈øome few ≈øelect Ca≈øes, which re≈øpect the Nature of ≈øuch Obligations and Conditions, and of avoiding them.

An Award was, that the party ≈øhall pay unto a Stranger, or his A≈ø≈øigns, 200 l. before ≈øuch a day‚ñ™ the Stranger befor the day dieth, and B. takes Letters of Admini≈øtration; Per Cur. the Obligor ≈øhall pay the Mony to the Admini≈øtrator, for he is the A≈ø≈øignee; and ≈øo if the A≈ø≈øignes had been left out, 1 Leon. p. 316.
Mony awarded to be paid to a Stranger, if the Stranger will not accept of the Mony the Obligation is ≈øaved, 3 Leon. 62. Norwich and Norwich.

If the Award be ill of your own ≈øhewing, then you have no cau≈øe of Action, and ≈øo you cannot have Judgment, though the Defendants Bar be not good, Stiles 136. Wood and Clemenee. If the Plaintiff ≈øhews the Award, but a≈ø≈øigns no Breach, he ≈øhall not have Judgment though he hath a Verdict; for the Obligation is not for any Debt, for this is guided by the Condition which goes in performance of a collateral thing (viz.) of an Award. And though the Defendant had not an≈øwered to the Breach, if it had been a≈ø≈øigned, yet the Court ought to be ≈øatisfied, that the Plaintiff had cau≈øe to recover, otherwi≈øe they ≈øhall not give Judgment; and though the Verdict is found for the Plaintiff, yet this fault in the Replication is matter of Sub≈øtance not aided, Yelv. p. 152, 153. Barret and Fletcher.
An Obligation to perform a void Award is void, Latch 207. 10 Rep. 131. b.

If a Man be bound to perform an Award of Arbitrators, and they make an Award accordingly that one ≈øhall pay Mony; he may have his Action of Debt for the Mony, and declare upon the Award, and afterwards he may have another Action upon the Obligation for not performing the Award, per. C ‚Ä¢ r. 1 Brownl. Rep. 55.
If one countermand the Authority of his Arbitrator, as he may, he ≈øhall forfeit his Obligation, 8 Rep. 82. a. Vynior's Ca≈øe.
A Condition is annexed to the Award, as paying ≈øo much Rent, yet Debt upon Bond lies „Äà‚óä„Äâ Non-payment, Cro. El. 211. Par≈øons and Frowd.

A Condition to ≈øtand to the Award of J. S. The Defendant pleaded, the ≈øaid J. S. had arbitrated that the Defendant ≈øhould pay to the Plaintiff 10 l. and he ≈øaid he had paid it to the Plaintiff Wi≈øe, who had received it. The Plaintiff demurs, and Judgment pro Quer. Payment to the Wi≈øe not being good, 1 Leon. 320. Frowd and B ‚Ä¢ .

Recogni≈øance to ≈øtand to the Arbitrament of A. and B. who awarded that Robins ≈øhould have the Land, yielding and paying 10 l. per ann. Rent is behind. The Plaintiff brought Debt. The Defendant pleads the ≈øpecial matter, and concludes Judgment if the Plaintiff ≈øhall have Execution again≈øt him: Per Cur. it is ill, for here is not any Execution of the ≈øame Debt, but an Original Action of Debt port, and he ought to conclude Judgment, ≈øi actio. The≈øe words yielding and paying
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ not a Condition, for its not kn ‚Ä¢ to the Land by the Owner him≈øelf, but by a Stranger (≈ø ‚Ä¢ ) the Arbitrato ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ But it is a good clau≈øe to make the ≈øame an Article of the Arbit ‚Ä¢ ment, which the Parties are bound to perform upon the penalty of
the Recogni≈øance, and this Rent ≈øhall not cea≈øe by Eviction of the Land, 3 Leon. p. 58. Tre≈øhal and Robins.

An Award was that the Defendants Brother J. (for whom the Defendant was bound to perform the Award) ≈øhould pay the Plaintiff 30 l. (viz.) 20 l. at the Annunciation and 10 l. at Michaelmas after, and ≈øhewed that the ≈øaid J. had payd the 20 l. and as to the 10 l. he pleaded that J. died before the Fea≈øt of M. The Plaintiff demurs. Per Cur. the Bond is forfeited, becau≈øe the Sum awarded by the Arbitrament is now become a Duty, as if the Condition of the Bond had been for payment of it, 2 Leon. f. 155. Kingwel and Chapman.

Debt on Bond to ≈øtand to an Awards; and the Defendant pleads Nil debet. On Demurrer it was excepted; the Action is grounded on the Award, and therefore the Award ought to have been brought into Court, which is not done for ought appears here. Per Glyn, It is not nece≈ø≈øary to produce it in Court, though he mu≈øt plead the Award in Writing; for the Action is not brought upon the Award, but upon the Submi≈ø≈øion, for the Award is but the Inducement; and the Court hath nothing to do with the Award, but to ≈øee whether it be in writing or not. For a Deed, that I confe≈øs, mu≈øt be produced in Court, that the Court may judge whether it bind the party or not; and you your ≈øelves have here ≈øet forth the Award in Pleading. In all Ca≈øes where things cannot be demanded but by Deed, the Deed mu≈øt be produced; but here is no Deed in this Ca≈øe, for an Arbitrament under Seal is no Deed, it is but a Writing under Hand and Seal, Stiles p. 455. Dod and Herbert.

Condition to ≈øtand to the Arbitrament of J. S. If the Defendant pleaded Nullum fec. arbitri ‚Ä¢ ; the Plaintiff by Replication ought to ≈øhew the Arbitration in certain, and a≈ø≈øign a Breach; for the Plea of the Defendant is ≈øo general it doth not offer any I≈ø≈øue, therefore the Plaintiff in his Replication ought to lay a Breach, or el≈øe there appears no cau≈øe of Action to the Court, and the offer of the I≈ø≈øue comes from the Plaintiff. Award is, if J. pay to D. 10 l. then D. ≈øhall a≈ø≈øure to J. the Mannor of Sale. D. pleads in Debt upon this Bond, J. paid him not 10 l. it is a good Replication for J. to ≈øay he had paid him 10 l. without ≈øaying over that J. D. had not a≈ø≈øured the Mannor, for the Plaintiff had given a direct An≈øwer to the ≈øpecial matter alledged in Bar, Yelv. 24. Baily and Taylor. But this was after a Verdict, Vid. 1 Sanders p. 103. Hayman and Gerrard.

The Plaintiff ought to a≈ø≈øign a Breach in his Replication, becau≈øe the Defendants Plea Nul tiel award is general; but if in ≈øuch Ca≈øe the Defendant plead a Relea≈øe of all Demands after the Arbitrament, by which he offers a ≈øpecial point in I≈ø≈øue‚ñ™ there it ≈øufficeth if the Plaintiff an≈øwer to the Relea≈øe or other ≈øpecial matter alledged by the Defendant without a≈ø≈øigning a Breach, 1 Brownl. Rep. 89, 90.

Condition to perform an Agreement already ≈øet down by J. S. The Defendant pleads, no Agreement was made; ill Plea, Aliter, had it been to perform all Agreements, 1 Rolls Rep. 430. King and Per≈øeval.

Condition to perform an Award; they awarded the 24th of March, the Defendant to pay at Mich. following 20 l. The Defendant pleads the Plaintiffs Relea≈øe of all Actions and Demands made to him
the 10th of Apr. Per Cur. the Relea≈øe is no Ba ‚Ä¢ of the Plaintiffs Action. Aliter, if had been a Deb ‚Ä¢ or Duty pre≈øently, Cro. Jac. 300. Tynan and Bridges.

In Debt on Bond to perform an Award. Defendant pleads no Award; Plaintiff ≈øets it forth, which was, that the Defendant ≈øhould pay Mony, and they give mutual Relea≈øes to the time of the Award: Per Cur. its well enough, and all being intended to be done at one time, the Obligation is not thereby relea≈øed, 2 Keb. 163. Gulthorp and Meers.

The Defendant in Oyer pleads the intermarriage of the Feme with the Plaintiff before the Award. The Defendant demurs: Per Cur. Marriage was her own Act, and was a Revocation of the power given to Arbitrators, 2 Keb. 865.

In Debt on an Obligation to perform an Award, there all the Arbitrament ought to be pleaded; but in Debt on the Award he may ≈øhew part of the Arbitrament, which is the ground of the Action, Lit. Rep. 312, 313. Leak and Butler.
After Con≈øilium, on Demur the Court gave leave to di≈øcontinue, 2 Keb. 618. Roberts and Marriot.

In Debt on Bond to perform Award or Covenant. If Mony be awarded or covenanted to be paid of value, they require ≈øpecial Bail. Aliter, if to do any Act, which is of it ≈øelf uncertain, as to have frees, 1 Keb. 450.2 Keb. 73. Keind and Carter.

div.head: Apprentices Bonds.
div.p:
A Condition that his Son ≈øhould render 10 C. his Ma≈øter a ju≈øt account de omnibus monetis, bonis, &c. without imbezilling any away; and that if he did imbezil any thing, upon due proof made of this,
he would pay the ≈øame to him within three Mo ‚Ä¢ after demand. Per Cur. before payment ought „Äà‚óä„Äâ precede Account and Arreares, and in this A ‚Ä¢ Proof ought to be made, and he mu≈øt give notice to the Defendant, 1 Bul≈øtr. f. 40. Cockain and Go ‚Ä¢ dloge.

On Covenant, and declared that the Defendant by his Deed ≈øhewed in Court, did covenant to ≈øati≈øfie him all ≈øuch Sums of Mony, &c. as J. his Son the Plaintiffs Apprentice ≈øhould imbezil from him within three Months after Requ≈øt, and then lays the Imbezelling and Reque≈øt, &c. The Defendant prays Oyer of the Deed, which was entred in haec verba; and there the Covenant was to ≈øatisfie within three Months after Reque≈øt and due Proof made of ≈øuch embezelling. I≈ø≈øue was whether he embezilled; and found pro Quer. Judgment was arre≈øted, becau≈øe it appears by the Entry of the Deed, that the Plaintiff ought not to have brought his Action till the 3 Months were encurred as well after Proof as after Reque≈øt; whereas the Plaintiff had averred no Proof in the Declaration. And per Cur. the word Proof generally laid ≈øhall be under≈øtood a Proof judicial, by Jury, Confe≈ø≈øion, or Demurrer in Court; but if the form of Proof were by the Writing appointed otherwi≈øe, that ≈øhould prevail; as by Witne≈ø≈øes, before two Aldermen, by Certificate, &c. Which Proof ≈øhall be ≈øet down in the Plea with all the Circum≈øtances, and then it ≈øhall be given in di≈øcretion of the Court, whether that Proof were competent according to the meaning of the Writing. But in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe the word Proof is left at large, and may be made in Court judicially in an Action brought again≈øt the Apprentice, before the Action brought on this Covenant made by another; it may be well in
this Ca≈øe taken of a Proof by Tryal in Court, and ≈øo i ‚Ä¢ every way again≈øt the Plaintiff, Hob. p. 217. Crookhay and Woodward, Vid. 2 Rolls Rep. 40. Le ‚Ä¢
and Finch, Cr ‚Ä¢ . Jac. 488. Lee and
‚Ä¢ dge.

Condition was, that if he did wa≈øte his Ma≈øters Goods, and that this ≈øhould be proved by Confe≈ø≈øion under his Hand in Writing or otherwi≈øe, and if within three Months after ≈øatisfaction was not made to him, then the Bond to be in force. Per Cur. where the Proof is general there it mu≈øt be by Jury in the Action; otherwi≈øe where the Proof is with a reference to time and before per≈øons certain, or he did confe≈øs it, in this Ca≈øe, Judgment pro Quer. Cro. ‚Ä¢ l. p. 723. Cardinal and Hesket, Cro. Jac. 381.1 Rolls Rep. 222, 261. Hob. p. 91.3 Bul≈øtr. 55. Gold and Death, 1 Leon. n. 344. f. 206. Cro. Eliz. 236. Tedca≈øtle and Hallywel. Though he confe≈ø≈øeth, yet it mu≈øt be averred that he did embezil, 2 Rolls Rep. 40. Vid. Cro. Jac. 488. Lee and Fidge.

The Contract or Indenture for having or retaining an Apprentice contrary to the Statute is void; but if ≈øuch Apprentice give Bond to deliver up a true and ju≈øt account of Merchants Wares, the Bond is good; it being for a collateral matter the Bond is good and out of the Statute, 3 Bul≈øtr. p. 179. Bennet and Benfield.
In ≈øome Ca≈øes it is Wi≈ødom to pray the Court leave to di≈øcontinue the Suit, otherwi≈øe the party would be utterly barred of his Bond, Cro. Jac. p. 488. Lee and Fidge.

A Bond not to u≈øe a Trade in D. if good, Vid. pri ‚Ä¢ . A Stranger is bound that ≈øuch an Apprentice ≈øhall tran≈øport Wa ‚Ä¢ make Accompts and pay Mony. The Obligee re ‚Ä¢ th by Deed to the Apprentice and
not to the Obligor. By this the Obligation is ≈øaved if the Relea≈øe be made before any Forfeiture, aliter, if after, becau≈øe the Obligation once forfeited cannot be ≈øaved by any Relea≈øe made to a Stranger, 3 Leon. p. 45. Anonymus.

Though an Infant may voluntarily bind him≈øelf Apprentice, yet neither at Common-Law nor by Stat. 50 Eliz. a Covenant or Obligation of an Infant ≈øhall bind him; if he misbehave him≈øelf the Ma≈øter may correct him, or Ju≈øtices puni≈øh him, Cro. Hill. 5 Car. fo. 179. Gilbert and Fletcher.

The Condition was of three parts. 1. If he well ≈øerved the Plaintiff. 2. If he duly accounted. 3. If he ≈øhould make ≈øatisfaction in three Months after notice. Breach is, that upon account he was found 60 l. poli≈øh Mony in arrears, which he converted to his own u≈øe, and ≈øo not well ≈øerved him, and good, for it is a Breach of the fir≈øt part, for every part is ≈øeveral by it ≈øelf, Cro. Eliz. p. 830. Cutler and Brew≈øter.

Condition was, that if an Apprentice turned over ≈øhould wa≈øt the Goods of his Ma≈øter, the Defendant would pay what the Ma≈øter is dampnified, and plead Nul damage. The Plaintiff ≈øets forth Breach in wa≈øting Goods; no notice need to be given to the Defendant. If any one undertakes for a third per≈øon he mu≈øt an≈øwer for him at his peril, and the particulars of the Goods wa≈øted need not be ≈øet forth, but ≈øay to ≈øuch a value, 1 Keb. Hill. 14 & 15 Car. fo. 467, 471. French ver≈øus Paito ‚Ä¢ .

Condition to teach and employ his Apprentice in his Hou≈øe and Service in the Art of Chirurg ‚Ä¢ for eight years. The Ma≈øter ≈øends him a Voyage to the Indies. The Defendant pleads he did it for the ‚Ä¢
ter in≈øtruction of his Servant. The Plaintiff „Äà‚óä„Äâ
m ‚Ä¢ ; and Judgment pro Qu ‚Ä¢ r. That the Defendant could not ≈øend his Apprentice out of England, except he went with him, but to any other part of England he may, 1 Bul≈øtr. p. 67. Coven ‚Ä¢ ry and Weedal, 1 Rol ‚Ä¢ Abr. 427. ≈øect. 2. Id. Ca≈øe.

C. as Executor of C. port Det ≈øur Oblig. vers S. the Ca≈øe was; The Te≈øtator had put him≈øelf Apprentice to S. for ≈øeven years, and S. bound him≈øelf to pay to his Apprentice his Executors, &c. 10 l. at the time of the end or determination of his Apprenti≈øhip: The Apprentice ≈øerves ≈øix years and dies; Per Cur. The Obligation is di≈øcharged, and the Mony ≈øhall not be paid, 1 Brownl. 97. Cheyny and Sell, Cro. Eliz. p. 723. Cardinal and Hesket, About embezelling.

div.head: Bo ‚Ä¢ ds for the Good Behaviour.
div.p: THE Condition of this Recogni≈øance ≈øtandeth upon two Points. 1. For appearance at the time. 2. For keeping the Peace in the mean while.

div.head: The Form of the Recogni≈øance for the Good Behavior
div.p:
Mem. quod quinto die men≈øit, &c. Anno Regni, &c. venit coram me A. B. Ar' uno Ju≈øticiatiorum Domini Regis ad pacem nunc, &c. R. C. de, &c. in propria per≈øona ≈øua & a≈ø≈øump≈øit pro ≈øcip≈øo ≈øub poena 200 l. & H. C. de L. &c. & J. S. de, &c. tunc & ibid. in propriis per≈øonis ≈øuis ≈øimiliter vener. & manuceper. pro praedict. R. G. (viz.) quilibet eorum ≈øeparatim ≈øub poena 100 l. quod idem R. G. per≈øonaliter
comparibit coram Ju≈øticiarii ‚Ä¢ dicti Domini Regis ad pacem, &c. ad proximam generalem S ‚Ä¢
≈øionem, &c. & quod ip≈øa interim ≈øe bene geret ‚Ä¢ a Dominum Regem & cunctum populum ≈øuum, & praecipue erga J. B. de C. &c. Et quod ip≈øe non inferret nec inferri procurabit per ≈øe nec per ali ‚Ä¢ d ‚Ä¢ aliquod ≈øeu gravamen praefat. J. B. ≈øeu alicui de populo ip≈øius Domini Regis de corporibus ≈øuis per in≈øidias in≈øultus ≈øeu aliquo alio modo quod in lae≈ø ‚Ä¢ onem ≈øeu perturbationem pacis dicti Domini Regis cedere valeat quovi≈ømodo, quas quidem ≈øeparales ≈øummas 100 l. uterque praedictorum H. C. & J. S. ut praedicitur pro ≈øe a ‚Ä¢ praedict. R. G. dictas 200 l. recognoverunt ≈øe debere dicto Domino Regi de terri ‚Ä¢ & tenementis, bonis & catallis ≈øuis & quor umlibet & cuju≈ølibet eorum ad opus ip≈øius Domini Regis fieri & levari. Si contingat praefatum R. G. in aliquo praemi≈ø≈øorum deficere & inde legitimo modo convinci, &c. In cujus rei Te≈øtimonium ego praedict. A. B. ≈øigillum meum impo≈øui, dat. &c. Dalton 3 ‚Ä¢ 0. c. 123. Kilby's Pre≈øid. 191. is more full, but to the ≈øame purpo≈øe.

And this may be done al≈øo by a ≈øingle Recogni≈øance in Latin with a Condition added or endor≈øed in Engli≈øh for the keeping of the Peace, or for the day and place of appearance at the Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, or in Latin.
The Obligation ≈øhall be made in the Kings Name by the words Domino Regi, per Stat. 33 H. 8.39. ≈øect. 52. And ≈øuch Bonds ≈øhall be of the Nature of a Statute Staple.

Per Stat. 3 H. 7.1. Every Recogni≈øance taken for the Peace ≈øhall be certified at the next Se≈ø≈øions
of the Peace, that the Party thereupon may be called, and his Default, if any happen, may be recorded. The Ju≈øtice of Peace mu≈øt ≈øend or bring it in at the next Se≈ø≈øions to the Cu≈øtos Rotulorum, whether the Recogni≈øance were taken by his own di≈øcretion, or at the ≈øuit and de≈øire of another. Altho the Party that prayed the Peace do not then appear at the Se≈ø≈øions, yet the default of the Recogni≈øor is not thereby di≈øcharged; and the Ju≈øtices may then of di≈øcretion bind him over again.

If the Recogni≈øance be ver≈øus cunctum populum & praecipu ‚Ä¢ ver≈øus A. A. may relea≈øe it either before the ≈øame Ju≈øtice or any other that will certifie the Relea≈øe, which Certificate being of Record will di≈øcharge it, but to relea≈øe it by his Deed is nothing worth. But the Recogni≈øance may not be cancelled, le≈øt perhaps the Peace was broken, and con≈øequently the Recogni≈øance forfeited before the Relea≈øe.
Therefore it will be be≈øt in ≈øuch Ca≈øes to ≈øend to the Se≈ø≈øions the Recogni≈øance and the Relea≈øe together, and that may be done in a few Lines under the Recogni≈øance it ≈øelf, as,

Memorandum, Quod primo die, &c. praefatus C. D. venit coram me S. L. & gratis remi≈øit & relaxavit quantum in ≈øe e≈øt praedictam ≈øecuritatem pacis per ip≈øum coram me ver≈øus ≈øupranominatum A. B. petitam. In cujus rei te≈øtimon ‚Ä¢ um, Igo praefat. S. L. &c. dat. &c.

If a Man be bound to the Peace, and to appear at next Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, and do afterwards procure a Super≈øedeas out of Chancery te≈øtifying that he hath found Surety there again≈øt all the Kings
People for ever; this will di≈øcharge his appearance at the Se≈ø≈øions. And it is be≈øt for the Ju≈øtice of Peace to ≈øend in, as well the Recogni≈øance as Super≈øedeas, for perhaps the Recogni≈øance was broken before the Super≈øedeas purcha≈øed.

The death of the King di≈øchargeth the Recogni≈øance of the Peace; ≈øo doth the death of the Recogni≈øor; ≈øo doth the death of him at who≈øe Suit it was taken. But though the Sureties die the Recogni≈øance ≈øtandeth; for if the Peace be broken after death, their Executors ≈øhall be charged with it.
In the Relea≈øe of Surety of the Peace, the≈øe words are, Securitatem pacis; but for the good Behavior, Securitatem de ≈øe bene gerendo.
The Informer again≈øt a Pri≈øoner for Felony, may be thus bound in a ≈øingle Recogni≈øance.

Kanc. ≈ø≈ø. Memorand' Quod tertio die Apr. Anno, &c. D. E. de B. &c. per≈øonaliter coram me T. S. uno Ju≈øticiariorum, &c. ad pacem, &c. a≈ø≈øignator' con≈øtitutus apud B. praedict. recognovit ≈øe debere dicto Domino Regi 10 l. bonae, &c. de bonis & catallis, terris & tenementis ≈øuis fieri & levari ad opus dicti Domini Regis, Herod. & Succe≈ø≈øorum ≈øuorum ≈øi defecerit in conditione indor≈øata.

The Condition of this Recogni≈øance i ‚Ä¢ ≈øuch, whereas one A. B. late of G. Labourer, was this pre≈øent day brought before the ≈øaid Ju≈øtice by the above bounden D. E. and was by him charged with the felonious taking of 20 Sheep of him the ≈øaid D. and thereupon was ≈øent by the ≈øaid Ju≈øtice to the Kings Maje≈øty's Gaol. If therefore he the ≈øaid D. ≈øhall and will at the
next general Goal delivery to be holden in the ≈øaid County, prefer or cau≈øe to be framed and preferred one Bill of Indictment of the ≈øaid ‚Ä¢ elony again≈øt the ≈øaid A. B. and ≈øhall and will then al≈øo give Evidence there concerning the ≈øame, as well to the Jurors that ≈øhall then enquire of the ≈øaid Felony, as al≈øo to them that ≈øhall pa≈øs upon the Tryal of the ≈øaid A. B. that then, &c.

div.head: A Recogni≈øance to appear and an≈øwer for Felony.
div.p: Memorandum, Quod vice≈øimo die &c. R. C. de I. Gen. E. C. de &c. J. B. de &c. venerunt cora ‚Ä¢ me J. H. Armig. uno Ju≈øticiariorum dicti Domini Regis ad pacem in Comitat. praedict. con≈øer ‚Ä¢ nd. a≈ø≈øignat. & man ‚Ä¢ osperunt pro R. B. de &c. (viz.) Quilibet eorum corpus pro corpore quod idem B. R. per≈øonaliter comparebit coram praefat. Ju≈øticiariis & ≈øociis ad prox. general. Se≈ø≈øion; pacis in Comit ‚Ä¢ . praedict. tenend. ad. ≈øtand. ‚Ä¢ ct. in Curia ≈øiquis ver≈øus cum loqui voluerit de diver≈øis feloniis & tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionibus unde idem R. B. judicatus exi≈øtit ut dicitur, & ad re≈øpondend. dicto Domino Regi de ii≈ødem prout debet, dat. &c.

div.head: Recogni≈øance of Bail.
div.p:
Kanc. ≈ø≈ø. Memorandum, Quo ‚Ä¢ quinto die A. D. de &c. G. H. de &c. J. K. de &c. per≈øonaliter venerunt coram nobis. C. D. & E. F. Ju≈øticiar. dicti Dom. Regis ad pacem ≈øuam in Com. ≈øuo praedict. con≈øervand. a≈ø≈øignat ‚Ä¢ & recogneverunt ≈øe deber ‚Ä¢ eidem Dom. Regi modo & forma ≈øequen. (viz.) praedict. A. B. 20 l. legalis, &c. & uterque praedictorum
G. & J. 10 l. confi ‚Ä¢ lis ‚Ä¢ nita, de ≈øeperalibus bonis & catalli ‚Ä¢ terris & tenementis ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ≈øeperalis. fieri & le vari ad opus & u≈øum dicti Dom. Regis hared. & ≈øucce≈ø≈øor. ≈øuorum, ≈øi defult. fieret in performatione conditionis indor≈ø.

div.head: Condition for appearance for Felony or ≈øu≈øpicion of Felony.
div.p: The Condition of the Recognizance is ≈øuch, That if the within bound A. B. do per≈øonally appear before his Maje≈øties Ju≈øtices of Gaol-delivery, at the next general Gaol-delivery to be holden for the within named County of Kent, then and there to an≈øwer to our Sovereign Lord the KING for and concerning the felonibus taking and ≈øtealing of, &c. (or for ≈øu≈øpicion of his felonious taking, &c.) wherewithal he ≈øtandeth charged before, &c. and to do and receive, &c. and do not depart the ≈øaid Court without licence for the ≈øame, then, &c.

If it be to appear at Se≈ø≈øions, ≈øay, Do per≈øonally appear before his Maje≈øties Ju≈øtices a≈ø≈øigned to keep his Peace in the within named County of K. at the next General Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace to be holden for the ≈øaid County of T. in the County afore≈øaid, then and there to an≈øwer, &c.

If the Party th ‚Ä¢ is bound to appear on Surety for the Peace, be ≈øo ≈øick that he cannot appear, the Ju≈øtices in their di≈øcretion have forborn to certifie or record ≈øuch Forfeiture or Default, and that they have taken Sureties for the Peace of ≈øome Friends of his pre≈øent in the Court till the next Se≈ø≈øions.

If the Husband be bound that he and his Wife ≈øhall appear at ≈øuch a Se≈ø≈øions, and that they ≈øhall keep the Peace in the mean time, &c. and at the day the Husband appears alone; Qu. if the Recognizance be forfeited.

A Supplicavit out of Chancery directed to the Sheriff and Ju≈øtices to bind F. and two others to the Good Behaviour; the Sheriff returns, that the two non ≈øunt inventi, and quoad F. that ≈øuch a Recognizance was taken before the Ju≈øtices and that he had broken the Good Behaviour; and F. pleaded to I≈ø≈øue in Chancery; the Record being ≈øent into the Kings Bench per manus Dom. Cancellaris; thereupon a Writ of Ni≈øi Prius i≈ø≈øued, and found for the Defendant; this Recognizance was not well certified into the Chancery, for they who take the Recognizance ought to certifie it, Cro. Jac. 669. Ford again≈øt the King.

If a Man find Sureties for the Peace before the Ju≈øtices of the Peace in the County, yet if the ≈øame Party come in B. R. and there make Oath, that he was afraid he ≈øhall be hurt by the ≈øaid Party, he may have ≈øurety of the Peace there again≈øt the Party, and a Super≈øedas to the Ju≈øtices to di≈øcharge the Bond taken before them for the Peace and Behaviour, Moor n. 126.
Upon motion on Affidavit, that he was bound to the Peace for Malice; his Recognizance was di≈øcharged, Stiles p. 364 Sir Tho. Revels Ca≈øe.

Its the Cour≈øe of the Court, when any are bou ‚Ä¢ d over to appear in B. R. and in the mean time to keep the Peace, or be of Good Behaviour; the Cau≈øe is to be expre≈øt in the Recognizance; al≈øo when ever the Court binds any Man to the Peace or Good Behaviour, its always for a year, 1 Keble.
Hill. 16 and 17 Car. 2. B. R. Sandford ver≈øus Atkin≈øon.

div.head: What is or amounts to a Breach or Forfeiture.
div.p: THE Surety of the Peace is not broken without Affray made, or Battery, & buju≈ømodi, 2 H. 7.2. b.
Words which threaten a Battery of the Body may forfeit a Recognizance; but not to call one Lyar, Drunkard, and to ≈øay I will make him a poor Kirton, Moor n. 378.
If he threaten to beat him to his Face, its a Forfeiture, or if he threaten in his ab≈øence, and afterwards lies in wait to beat him, Keb. In≈øt. 615.

If he that is bound do but command or procure another to break the Peace upon any Man, or to do any other unlawful Act again≈øt the Peace, if it be done, its a Forfeiture of his Recognizance, 7 H. 7.34. a.

There is a Surety of the Peace, and a Surety of the Good Behaviour; the Surety of the Peace cannot be broken without ≈øome Act; as an Affray or Battery, or the like; but the Surety de bono ge≈øtu con≈øi≈øteth chiefly in doing nothing that may be cau≈øe of the Breach of the Peace: the word Lyar, Drunkard, &c. are not Breaches, nor entring his Clo≈øe, nor taking Goods; What is a Breach of the Peace, is a Breach of the Behaviour, riding with War-like Weapons, (but that is not Law now,) or in Company with riotous Malefactors, Cro. El. 86. k. 4 In≈øt. 180, 181. Kings Ca≈øe.

In Sc. Fac. upon a Recognizance for the Good Behaviour taken in the Crown Office; the Breach is a≈ø≈øigned,
becau≈øe he a≈ø≈øaulted land b ‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢ ne on the Way, and he ≈øaith not vi & a ‚Ä¢ , and for this Cau≈øe after Verdict Judgment was ≈øtayeth, Cro. Jac. 412. The King and Hutchings.

Scire Facias upon a Recognizance of the Good Behaviour; Breach a≈ø≈øigned was, That he ≈øaid to a Con≈øtable in executing his Office, thou art a lying Ra≈øcal, and to a Woman that ≈øhe was a Whore and a Jade, &c. The Defendant pleaded not guilty, and found for the Defendant, though the manner of ≈øpeaking may be good cau≈øe in di≈øcretion, to bind one to his Good Behaviour; yet one being bound, words only which tend not to the Breach of Peace, terrifying others, or to ≈øedition, &c. ≈øhall not be ≈øufficient cau≈øe of Forfeiture.
Nota, In this Ca≈øe the Witne≈ø≈øes in the behalf of the King, did not prove that the≈øe words were i ‚Ä¢ di≈øturbance of the Execution of his Office, Cro. Car. 498. The King ver≈øus Hayward.
Farther Con≈øiderations of Bonds in re≈øpect of A≈ø≈øignment, Statute of Bankrupt and Forgery, &c.

div.head: A≈ø≈øignments of Obligations. Vide Creditors as to Statute of Bankrupcy.
div.p:
IF a Man a≈ø≈øign an Obligation to another for a precedent Debt due by him to the A≈ø≈øignee, that is not Maintenance; but if he a≈ø≈øign it for a Con≈øideration then given by way of Contract; this is Maintenance, Noy 53. Harvey ver≈øus
‚Ä¢
man, Alit. in Ca≈øe of the King. 3 Lion. 234. Scoth and Mar≈øh.

Upon the Statute of 33 H. 8. cap. 39. the Ca≈øe was. If Tenant in Tail of the Mannor of D. be bound in a Recognizance to J. S. which Recognizance after comes to the King by the Attaind ‚Ä¢ of J. S. of High-Trea≈øon, and after Tenant in Tail dies, and the I≈ø≈øue in Tail alien the Lands, bona fide; whether the King may extend the Lands in the Hands of the Alience: It was re≈øolved, That if Tenant in Tail become indebted to the King by Judgment, Recognizance, Obligation, or other Specialty, and dies before any Proce≈øs or Extent, and the I≈ø≈øue in Tail alien the Land bona fide, this Land ≈øhall not be extended by force of this Statute. And al≈øo that in this Ca≈øe, in as much as the Debt was originally due to a Subject, it is not within the Act to charge the Lands in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion or ≈øei≈øin of the Heir in Tail, or of his Alience; for this Act extends only to Debts immediately due to the King originally, and not to tho≈øe which accrew to him by way of A≈ø≈øignment, Outlawry, Attainder, Forfeiture, Gift of the Party or any other collateral way, 7 Rep. 21. Lord Ander≈øons Ca≈øe.

The Statute of 7 Jac. makes A≈ø≈øignments of Debts void, other than ≈øuch as grow originally to the Kings Debtor, bona fide; it re≈øtrains A≈ø≈øignments of Debts which are not due to the Debtors them≈øelves, but a≈ø≈øigned to or by them to other Per≈øons. The purport of this Law was, That no Debtor of the Kings ≈øhould procure another Mans Debt to be a≈ø≈øigned, which was a common practice; but a Man may a≈ø≈øign his own Debt, tho not to his own U≈øe; for what he may him≈øelf relea≈øe and di≈øcharge, by the ≈øame Rea≈øon he may
a≈ø≈øign; as B. was bound to C. in a Stat. of 2000 l. C. dies Inte≈øtate, his Wife admini≈øters and marries, F. F. with others became bound to the King in 6000 l. F. and his Wife by Deed enrolled in Cur. Ward. a≈ø≈øign the Statute to the King by payment of the 6000 l. the A≈ø≈øignment was good, Hob. p. 253. Brediman and Coles. Cro. Hill. 16 Jac. p. 524. id. Ca≈øe.

A Duty which is not naturally a Debt but by circum≈øtance only; as Debt upon Bond for performance of Covenants, or to ≈øave harmle≈øs, may be a≈ø≈øigned over to the King for Debt; yet a pre≈øent Extent ≈øhall not i≈ø≈øue, but a Scire Fac. 2 Leon. p. 55. Beaumounts Ca≈øe.
Debt again≈øt one as Executor, and upon fully admini≈øtred pleaded, it was found pro Quer. who a≈ø≈øigned the ≈øame to the King, 2 Leon. p. 67. Noons Ca≈øe.
M. indebted to S. by a Note in writing per me‚ñ™ but not ≈øealed; ≈øuch a Debt may be a≈ø≈øigned to the Queen, 3 Leon. 234. March.
An Obligation may be a≈ø≈øigned to the King ≈øans Deed enrolled, 3 Leon. p. 234. South and Mar≈øh, 21 H. 7.19.
Where the King ≈øues for a Debt a≈ø≈øigned to him, the Obligor cannot plead nil debet, for by the A≈ø≈øignment its become matter of Record, ibid.

An Obligation forfeited to the King by the Statute 28 Eliz. c. 8.1. Q. if the King; may grant before Sei≈øure. 2. There are two Obligees, and one forfeits. Q. if the King ≈øhall have all the Bond, 1 Rolls Rep. p. 7, 12. Jac. B. R. Cullan and Bets.

In A≈ø≈øignment of a Bond to the King, the ‚Ä¢ ead ≈øhall only be liable from the time of the A≈ø≈øignment; but in A≈ø≈øignment of a Recognizance or Statute, the King ≈øhall have the Land at the time of the Judgment rendred, Lit. Rep. p. 125. Roy ver≈øus Hanton.
By the grant of bona & catalla an Obligation pa≈ø≈øeth, i. e. Paper and Wax; yet the Grantee may not have Action upon this, for that is not tran≈øferable, Lit. Rep. 87. Dyer 25 H. 8.5.
If a Debt be a≈ø≈øigned to the King, in this Ca≈øe no priority of Execution, 1 Brownl. 37.
A Condition to ≈øave harmle≈øs for a≈ø≈øigning a Bond, vide the Form, Bridgmans Pre≈øidens.

Clark was indebted to A. by Bond, and after delivers to Andrews certain Hog≈øheads of Wine to ≈øatisfie the ≈øaid Debt; and afterward Clarks Obligation is a≈ø≈øigned to the Queen for A's Debt: Per Cur. the property of the Goods by the delivery of them to Andrews, before the A≈ø≈øignment was altered, 2 Leon. 89. Bridget Clarks Ca≈øe.

A. was indebted to B. who was indebted to the Queen, B. a≈ø≈øigned his Debt to the Queen; by all the Barons, Proce≈øs ≈øhall be awarded out of the Exchequer to enquire what Goods A. had at the time of the A≈ø≈øignment, and not what he had tempore ≈øcripti praedict. fact. 3 Leon. 196.

div.head: Obligation. Of Creditors in re≈øpect of Statute of Bankrupts, and A≈ø≈øignments.
div.p: OSborn and Brad≈øhaw were Sureties pro Churchman, and had Counterbonds to ≈øave harmle≈øs; the Sureties paid the Mony, and afterwards Churchman became a Bankrupt. Re≈øolved, that they were Creditors within the Statute 13 Eliz. Cro. Jac. 127. O≈øburn ver≈øus Churchman.

If an Obligation be taken in the Name of another, to the u≈øe of a Bankrupt, the Commi≈ø≈øioners may well a≈ø≈øign that, unle≈øs the other party hath of his own Mony ≈øatisfied Debts due by the Bankrupt, Noy p. 142. Ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hman's Ca≈øe.
