Debt ≈øur Obligation, a≈ø≈øigned by Commi≈ø≈øioners of Bankrupts, and doth not ≈øhew the Obligation; he need not, becau≈øe he comes in by act of Law, and hath no means to obtain the Obligation‚ñ™ As Tenant per Statute Merchant, or Dower, ≈øhall have advantage of a Rent Charge ≈øans ≈øhewing the Deed. Cro. Jac. p. ‚Ä¢ 9. Gray and F ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lder.
R. is indebted to S. and B. joyntly; S. becomes a Bankrupt, and the Commi≈ø≈øioners a≈ø≈øign the Obligation to B. Q. 1 Keb. p. 167. Royl≈øton and Ratcliff.

If I am bound to J. S. and he before Bankrupcy a≈ø≈øigns the Bond; this is liable to the after Bankrupcy of J. S. being only ≈øuable
in his Name, 2 Keb. 331. Backwell ver≈øus Litcott.

In Debt ≈øur Bond, the Defendant pleads before Action brought, the Plaintiff became a Banrupt: Per Cur. it's an ill Plea; and until an A≈ø≈øignment made, the Debtor is defencele≈øs, and payment before Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øued out is good enough; and ≈øo it is before his Debt be a≈ø≈øigned, 3 Keb. 316. Andrews and Spicer.

In Debt ≈øur Obligat. the Defendant pleads, that it was in tru≈øt for Holt, who was a Bankrupt, & virtute Commi≈ø≈øion', &c. this Debt was a≈ø≈øigned to A≈øhly and Penning, & aliis Creditoribus. The Plaintiff replies, It was not a≈ø≈øigned. The Defendant demurs ≈øpecially for doublene≈øs. The Court conceived the Bankrupcy traver≈øable as well as the A≈ø≈øignment; yet the I≈ø≈øue is well enough, 3 Keb. 737. Jones and Bolton.
Condition to give account to the Creditors, &c. 1 Keb. 815, 843. Selby ver≈øus Walker.
The Di≈øpo≈øition by Commi≈ø≈øioners of Bankrupts, ≈øaves the forfeiture of the Obligation. 2 Keb. 202. in Robin's Ca≈øe.
I ≈øhall here ≈øubjoyn ≈øome things re≈øpecting Matters of Tort; as Forgery, Detinue, &c. of Obligations.

div.head: Forgery.
div.p: IF a Man forge a Bond in my Name, I can have no Action of the Ca≈øe yet: but if I am ≈øued, I may; tho' I may avoid it by Plea: But if it were a Recognizance or Fine, I ≈øhall have a Deceipt pre≈øently before Execution. 19 H. 6.44. cited in Hobart, p. 267.
The Penalty of Forging Deeds, 5 Eliz. c. 14. Co. 3 In≈øt. p. 171.

When the Statute ≈øaith, If any Man forge any Obligation, or Bill Obligatory, the≈øe mu≈øt be intended to be Sealed. If a man forge a Statute Staple, that is, acknowledge them, or either of them in the name of another; the≈øe are Obligations within this Act, for each of them hath the Seal of the party. Alit√®r of a Statute Merchant, or of a Recognizance, becau≈øe they have not the Seal of the Conu≈øor, Co. 3 In≈øt. p. 171.

Obligation of 10000 l. for the payment of 5000 l. per W. (who is dead) at three Months end. It was ≈øu≈øpected to be forged, and on Non e≈øt factum pleaded, at Trial at Bar, the Te≈øtimonies were examined apart. The Jury found Non est factuns; but the Obligation ≈øhall not remain in Court, but be delivered to the Plaintiff, Siderfin 15 Car. 2. B.R. p. 131. Guillim's and Huley.

Forgery may be pleaded in Bar to an Obligation; but it's no Plea to ≈øay, that there was an award in Chancery, that the Obligation
≈øhould be void for uncon≈øcionablene≈øs, 37 H. 6.13, 14.

B. was bound in 100 l. Bond to A. for the hone≈øty of his Son an Apprentice with A. and A. in the Obligation razeth out libra. and put in marc ‚Ä¢ . This is not Forgery puni≈øhable; it's not a prejudice to any but him≈øelf, for by that the Obligation is void, Noy 99. Black and Allen.
Where fal≈øe Alterations ≈øhall be a Forgery within the Stature, Co. 3 In≈øt. p. 169.

div.head: Detinue.
div.p: IN Detinue the Defendant pleads, That the Obligor and Obligee did deliver it to him ≈øub certis Conditionibus, and he knows not whether they be performed, and prays Garni≈øhment and on I≈ø≈øue found for the Plaintiff. It was moved in Arre≈øt of Judgment, becau≈øe there was not Garni≈øhment before the I≈ø≈øue, and the I≈ø≈øue is uncertain ≈øub certis conditionibus, non allocatur; it's a Jeofail, Cro. Eliz. 856. Pur≈øand and Whityer.

Detinue of a Bond, on non detinet it was found for the Plaintiff, and Damages a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed to 7 l. and Co≈øt 6 d. and if the Bond cannot be re≈øtored, then they a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed for Damages be≈øides the 7 l. 20 l. more; the Judgment ought to be Conditional, to recover the ≈øaid Bond; or if he cannot have the ≈øaid Bond, then the 20 l. and ≈øo the Di≈øtringas to the Sheriff mu≈øt be, to demand the Bond; and if it cannot be delivered, then the 20 l. for
it is not at the Sheriffs choice; therefore the Di≈øtringas Vic' for the ≈øaid Bond, or 20 l. was erroneous, Cro. Jac. p. 681. Peters and Heyward.
One Executor gives up a Bond in di≈øcharge of his own Debt, and dies, the ≈øurviving Executor ≈øhall not have Detinue for it, Croi. Eliz. p. 478, 496. Kel≈øock and Nichol≈øon.

div.head: Where, and in what ca≈øes, Notice is requi≈øite to be given before the Action brought upon an Obligation, and where not, and by whom.
div.p: WHen a Man binds him≈øelf to do or perform any thing to be awarded, &c. by a Stranger, he thereby takes upon him≈øelf to take notice at his peril of all things incident thereunto for the ≈øaving of his own Bond, 8 Rep. 92. b. Frances Ca≈øe. As,

Condition to perform the Award of J. S. and J. S. makes an Award, the Obligor ought to take notice thereof at his peril; for that he hath bound him≈øelf thereto, and no Notice is requi≈øite to be given to him.

Condition to pay 20 l. within 10 days after J. S. hath rode five times in ≈øix days from London to York, and from York to London; he ought to take notice of the doing of this at his peril; for that it is to be done by a Stranger, 1 Rol. Abr. 463. Herbye and Pope.

Condition to pay 40 l. to B. within a year after B. ≈øhall marry C. he is bound to pay it within the year after Marriage, without any Notice given of the Marriage by B. for
he hath taken it upon him; and he may have Notice by C. who is a Stranger to the Condition, 1 Rol. Abr. 463. Shephard and Fry.

A. is bound to B. that A. ≈øhall pay to B. all ≈øuch Monies, which by a true and ju≈øtifiable Bill under the Hand of B's Attorney, ≈øhall appear to be before disbur≈øed per B. or his Attorney. B. a≈ø≈øigns a breach, that 24 s. by a true and ju≈øtifiable Bill under the Hand of J. S. Attorney of B. appears to be di≈øbur≈øed, which A. hath not paid. This is a good Breach, without alledging that A. had Notice of this, or that the Bill was ≈øhewed to him; for the Attorney was a Stranger, of which A. ought to take notice at his peril, 1 Rol. Abr. 467.39. Dewell and Wilmot.

Bill Obligatory, to be paid within 10 days after J. L. went by five days undivided from thence to London, and alledges he did ≈øo; & licet ≈øaepius requi≈øitus. Quare, If there need any Notice, becau≈øe the Act is to be done by a Stranger, and his time of Return lies as well in the Notice of the Obligor, as of the Obligee, Cro. Jac. p. 150. Normanvile and Pope.

Condition to pay ≈øuch Arrears as ≈øhould be found on his Account before ≈øuch an Auditor. Defendant pleads he did account, and was always ready to pay the Arrears, if the ≈øaid Auditor had given him Notice. No Plea; for he hath bound him≈øelf thereto, and he mu≈øt take notice thereof at his peril, 1 H. 6.5.
But Condition to Account before ≈øuch Auditors as the Obligee ≈øhall A≈ø≈øign, he ought to give Notice of them to the Obligor. 8 Ed. 4. 1. b.
Regularly, it is not requi≈øite to give Notice where one is bound to do an Act by Bond.

Under≈øheriff covenants with the High-≈øheriff, to di≈øcharge and ≈øave him harmle≈øs of all E≈øcapes of Pri≈øoners that ≈øhould be Arre≈øted by him, or any Bailiff appointed by him, and a Bond of Performance: Per Curiam, The Sheriff is not bound in this ca≈øe, either to give Notice to the Under-≈øheriff of the E≈øcape, or to make reque≈øt for di≈øcharge; for the Covenant binds him to di≈øcharge at his peril, Hobart p. 14 Sir Daniel Norton's Ca≈øe.

Condition, that if the Obligee return from beyond Sea before the 22th of April next; then if the Obligor pay unto him at Ea≈øter following 200 l. then, &c. if Obligee return within the time, he is not bound to give Notice of this to the Obligor, but he ought to take Notice at his peril, for he hath bound him≈øelf to this Inconvenience, 1 Rolls Abr. 463. Eve and Dawtry.

Condition to pay 10 l. at the day of Marriage of the Obligee; the Obligee is not bound to give Notice to the Obligor before his Marriage, at what day he will be married; but the Obligor mu≈øt take Notice at his peril, for he hath taken upon him to pay it at the Day, 1 Rol. Abr. 461. Beresford and Goodzon's Ca≈øe.
So it is, if it be at the day of the Marriage of W. N. Id. ibid. 462.

A man is bound to H. to pay him 1000 l. after that he had married his Daughter, and afterwards he married her, and brought Debt upon this Bond, and it was not averred that he had given Notice to him of the marriage, but demanded the Mony. Here is no need of Notice (the Reque≈øt ≈øeems to imply Notice.) P. 2 Car. B. R. Hodges and Moore.
If I am bound to be Attendant upon you at every time that you ≈øhall come to the Manor of D. I am bound to take Notice when you come, at my peril, 8 Ed. 4.1. b.

Condition was, where the Obligor is Le≈ø≈øee for years of the Obligee of certain Lands; if he render back the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Land at the end of the term to the Le≈ø≈øor, his Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns upon reque≈øt, then, &c. and after the Le≈ø≈øor a≈ø≈øigns over his Rever≈øion, the A≈ø≈øignee at the end of the term reque≈øts him to render back the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion to to him. He is bound to do this without any Notice given, who is A≈ø≈øignee, 1 Rol. Abr. 465. Linghen and Paine.
Condition to pay the Damages which ≈øhall be recovered by J. S. again≈øt him; there needs no Notice, 1 Rol. Abr. 468.3.

Condition was to pay the Second day of May at the Defendant's Hou≈øe, giving Thirty days warning. Defendant pleads, the Plaintiff did not give thirty days Warning. The Plaintiff demurs: Fir≈øt, Becau≈øe no Notice is requi≈øite, but ≈øurplu≈øage, the day and place
of payment being certain without it. Secondly, If Notice be nece≈ø≈øary, the Obligor mu≈øt give it; to which the Court agreed, 3 Keb. 222. John≈øon and Muller.

Condition of Obligation, is to acquit of ≈øeveral Bonds entred into, &c. Defendant pleads performance. Plaintiff replies, He was ≈øued and retained, and Attorney, &c. Defendant demurs, for that the Plaintiff had not alledged to him particular Notice of the Suit per Cur. particular Notice is not requi≈øite in this ca≈øe, becau≈øe he hath taken upon him to acquit him, Siderfin p. 442. King and Atkyns.

div.head: Where by common Intendment the thing to be paid or done cannot lye in the conu≈øance of the Conizor, there Notice is requi≈øite.
div.p: A Man is bound to pay an 100 l. two Months after A. returns from Rome. He ought to give Notice of his Return, before A. can have an Action on this Bond; for he may land at Newca≈øtle or Plimouth. Agreed per Cur. in More and Hodges, p. 2 Car. B. R.
If I am bound to enfeoff ≈øuch per≈øons as the Obligee ≈øhall name, he ought to give Notice to me whom he will name. 8 Ed. 4. Arbitrement 15.
Vide pluis ≈øub titulo, Who to do the fir≈øt Act.

div.head: Who is to do the first Act.
div.p: WHere the Obligor is to do ≈øuch an Act by the direction of a Stranger, he ought to procure the Stranger to give the direction, Lit. Rep. 13, 14. Vide ≈øupr√† ≈øpar≈øim, & Kelw. p. 53. a, b.
One is bound to carry all the Timber in ≈øuch a place before ≈øuch a time, and lay it in ≈øuch a place by the direction of a Stranger, he ought to procure the Stranger to give the direction.

Condition to give ≈øuch a Relea≈øe as the Judge of the Prerogative Court ≈øhall direct. Defendant pleads, Dr. L. was Judge of the ≈øaid Court, and quod idem Judex, nec devi≈øavit, nec appunctuavit aliquam relaxationem, &c. ≈øecundum formam, &c. its no Plea, for the Judge is a Stranger to the Condition, and the Condition is for the benefit of the Obligor, and the performance thereof ≈øhall ≈øave his Bond; he hath taken upon him to perform it at his peril, and he ought to have procured the Judge to have devi≈øed it, and directed it. Otherwi≈øe, if it had been as the Obligee or his Coun≈øel ≈øhould devi≈øe. 5 Rep. 23, b. Lamb's Ca≈øe.

Condition to levy a Fine to the Obligee, he is not bound to levy it, if the Obligee doth not ≈øue a Writ of Covenant again≈øt him, 5 Rep. Palmer's Ca≈øe 127. 1 Rol. Abr. 458, 5. 5 Rep. 22, b. Halling's Ca≈øe.

Condition is, A. ≈øhall deliver to B. a certain quantity of Hops well pick'd, and that B. ≈øhall have election of them out of 204 Bags of Hops of A. of his own growth; B. ought to do the fir≈øt Act, i. e. he ought to require A. to ≈øhew him the 204 Bags; for he cannot make election without view of the 204 Bags which are in A's cu≈øtody, 1 Rol. Abr. 466. Brook and Booth ver≈øus Woodward, March 24. id. Ca≈øe.

Condition, that the Obligor being a Par≈øon, ≈øhall re≈øign to the Obligee within a certain time for a Pen≈øion, as they ≈øhall agree. The Obligee mu≈øt agree and tender a Deed of this to the Obligor, before he is bound to re≈øign. Q. 14 H. 4.18, b. cited in 5 Rep. 21. b.

div.head: What things will excu≈øe the performance of a Condition, and what not.
div.p: Act of God, Vide ≈øupra.
Act of Law, ≈øupr.
Act of the Obligee, ≈øupr.

div.head: Acts of a Stranger.
div.p: REgularly, If the Condition be to be performed by a Stranger, and he refu≈øe, the Obligation is forfeit; for the Obligor hath taken upon him that the Stranger ≈øhall do it, or accept it.

Condition is, that the Son ≈øhall marry the Daughter of the Obligee; if the Daughter
refu≈øe, yet the Condition is broken, 1 Rol. Abr. 452. 5 Rep. 23, b. Lamb's Ca≈øe.

A. and B. ≈øubmit to the Arbitration of C. by Bond. C. awards A. to pay 10 s. to B. who tenders this, and B. refu≈øeth: The Obligor is not excu≈øed, for B. is not a meer Stranger, but is privy, 22 Ed. 4.25. b. cited 1 Rol. Abr. 452. Q. I take the Law to be otherwi≈øe.

Condition to a≈ø≈øure a Copyhold to A. and B. his Wife (who are Strangers to the Obligation) for the Life of C. and the Obligor at the reque≈øt of A. ≈øurrenders this to A. to the u≈øe of ≈øuch per≈øons as he ≈øhall nominate; this is not any Performance: For A. who is a Stranger, may not di≈øpen≈øe with or alter the Agreement; but to do as limited in the Condition, 1 Rol. Abr. 457, T. Stile and Smith.

Defendant is bound, that his Son that is a Stranger to the Bond ≈øhall ≈øeal a Relea≈øe: He mu≈øt ≈øeal it at his peril, and ≈øhall not have time to con≈øult it, or demand it to be read, if he be not Lettered him≈øelf, 2 Rep. Man≈øer's Ca≈øe.

div.head:
Suits upon Obligations. How they are to be brought: In re≈øpect of the per≈øons
who bring the Action,
against whom it is brought.
Action brought by a Body Politick.
div.p: THey mu≈øt be named by the true Name of their Corporation; yet if the E≈ø≈øential part of a Corporation be named, it is ≈øufficient in an Action: As, ad re≈øpondend' Majori & Burgen≈øibus de Lyn Regis in Com' N. and it was found they were Incorporated Majores & Burgen≈øes burgi de Lyn, & non peraliud nomen. Per Cur. The omi≈ø≈øion of this word [Burgi] ≈øhall not bar the Plaintiffs, 1 Brownl. Rep. 57. Mayor and Burge≈ø≈øes of Lyn, ver≈øus Paine.

On a Bond, made to a Bi≈øhop, Par≈øon, Vicar, Ma≈øter of an Ho≈øpital, or other ≈øole Body Politick, the Executor or Admini≈øtrator ≈øhall have this Action. Except in the ca≈øe of the Chamberlain of London, where it goes to the Succe≈ø≈øor; and ≈øo in the ca≈øe of a Corporation aggregate, Dean and Chapter, Mayor and Comminalty, the Succe≈ø≈øor ≈øhall have the Action. 4 Rep. 65. Fulwood's Ca≈øe. Cro. Eliz. 480. Bird and Wilsford.

div.head: Per two or three to whom the Obligation is made.
div.p: IF Obligation be made to three, and two bring their Action, they ought to ≈øhew the third is Dead. Siderfin p. 238. Osborn and Cro≈øsborn.

But in Whelpdales Ca≈øe, This advantage was waived on non e≈øt factum pleaded. Al≈øo the Obligation being Obligamus nos, it ≈øhall not be intended the others did not Seal; but if they had not, the Count ≈øhould have been on writing by three, whereof two did not Seal, 1 Keb. 840. Me≈øme Ca≈øe.

If two or three are bound joyntly, and one dies, the Executor of him that is dead is altogether di≈øcharged. And the Action may not be brought again≈øt the Survivor and the Executor. Siderfin p. 238. Osborns Ca≈øe.

Debt ver≈øus Excutor. Plaintiff profert joynt Obligation without ≈øaying jam defunct. Q. if this be ≈øaved upon a General Demurrer. If the Executor had been Plaintiff in Debt upon ≈øuch Obligation, he ought to have ≈øaid jam defunct. to entitle him≈øelf to this his Action. Siderfin p. 272. Osborns Ca≈øe.

Obligation made to three to pay Mony to one of them, they ought all to joyn in the Suit, for they are all as one Obligee; and if he which ought to have the Mony dye, the Survivors ought to Sue, tho' they have no intere≈øt in the ≈øum contained in the Condition. Yelv. p. 177, Rolls and Yate.

div.head: By Baron and Feme.
div.p: THe Husband (after ≈øhe Marries mu≈øt joyn with her in the Suit) where the Bond was made to the feme d√πm ≈øola fuit; for if cau≈øe of Action ari≈øe before Coverture, tho' but Tre≈øpa≈øs, where damages are only recoverable, they mu≈øt joyn, 1 Keb. p. 440. Hardy and Robin≈øon.
Upon ≈øuch Bond made to the Wife d√πm ≈øola fuit by the Husband only. Judgment ≈øtaied. 37 A≈øs. 11.

If Bond be made to a Feme-covert, and the Husband di≈øagree, in Action brought, the Obligor may plead non e≈øt factum, for by his di≈øagreement the Obligation is no Deed. 10 Rep. 119. Whelpdales Ca≈øe.

On Bond made to Baron and Feme, Feme Admini≈øters and brings Debt upon the Bond as Admini≈øtratrix, ≈øhe dies before Judgment, her Executors cannot bring Debt upon that Obligation, for ≈øhe hath waved it, and that per≈øonal duty being a thing in action, may well lie in Joynture between Baron and Feme; aliter of other per≈øons. Noy, p. 149. Norton and Glover.

div.head: By Alien.
div.p: ON Bond made to an Alien Enemy, he may have an Action for per≈øonal things, More n. 852. Walford and Mar≈øham.

F. makes a Bill of Debt to A. by which F. acknowledges to have received of one P. 40 l. to be equally divided between A. and B. and to their u≈øe: Per Cur. B. need not joyn in the Action (tho' Tenants in Common ought to joyn in per≈øonal Actions) for they are ≈øeveral Debts, as 20 l. to one and 20 l. to the other. Yelv. p. 23. VVhorewood and Shaw.

div.head: By Executor or Admini≈øtrator.
div.p: AS to Suits brought by or again≈øt Executors, that more properly belongs to another Title in our Law, and the Pleadings ≈øtand altogether upon other Rea≈øons. Yet I ≈øhall ≈øay ≈øomething here, ≈øo far as refers to Obligations, as to Payment, Satisfaction, Relea≈øe, Gi≈øt of the Action, and the like.
Two Men made an Obligation joyntly for Debt, the principal made his Surety his Executor, who pays the Mony generally, Q. if he paid it as Executor, or as Obligor. 3 Leon. p. 197. Carter and Marten.

B. As Executor brought Debt upon Obligation made to his Te≈øtator; the Defendant Pleads, he paid a le≈ø≈øer ≈øum to the Te≈øtator, and that he did accept thereof in full ≈øati≈øfaction; per Rolls you may Traver≈øe either the payment or the acceptance of the Mony, but more proper to joyn I≈ø≈øue on the payment. Stiles p. 239. Bois and Cranfeild.

Executor port Debt on Bond in the deb ‚Ä¢ t & detinet, and had Judgment by Default, but it was Rever≈øt, becau≈øe it ought to have
been brought in the detinet only. Stiles p. 278. Lydall and Li≈øter.

Admini≈øtrator Sues J. S. upon Obligation, and had Judgment, and after the Admini≈øtration is revoked; yet the Plaintiff took the Defendant in Execution: And upon motion the Execution was adjudged void, and the ≈øecond Admini≈øtrator ≈øhall not have Execution, for he is no party to the Record. Yelv. p. 83. Barnhur≈øt ver≈øus Sir Charles Yelverton.

Six Executors brought Debt named in the Writ; after three were ≈øummoned and ≈øevered, the other three bring Debt upon a Bond; the Defendant Pleads non est factum, and found again≈øt him: Per Cur. there needs no mention of the other three who were ≈øevered, Cro. Car. 420. Price and Parkhur≈øt.

Debt port by Executors upon an Obligation; the Defendant pleads payment of the Principal and Intere≈øt to one of the Executors, of 18 years, and a Relea≈øe by him; no good Plea; for he not being at Age could not Relea≈øe, except he had the entire Forfeiture; the Chancery in ≈øuch ca≈øe will releive. Cro. Car. M. 13. p. 490. Kniveton and Latham.

Debt by Baron and Feme, Exacutrix upon a Bond made to the Te≈øtator: Upon non e≈øt factum pleaded, its found to be made to the Te≈øtator and another: Judgment pro Querente. The matter of variance goes but in Abatement, and cannot be pleaded in Bar, 5 Rep. 119. If the Defendant in this Ca≈øe had demanded Oyer, and cau≈øed it to be entred
in haec verba; he might have D ‚Ä¢ murred to the Declaration, and the Court ex offici ‚Ä¢
ought to have abated the Bill. Allen p. 41, 42 Holdwych and Chafe.
In Debt by Executor, after imparlance the Defendant ≈øhall not have Oyer of the Te≈øtament, or of the Obligation or other Deeds. Q. de hoc. doct. placitandi. 272.

Two Executors made Partition of the Te≈øtators Specialties, and then one of them did relea≈øe to the Debtor an Obligation, which did appertain to the part of the other, the Debtor having notice of the Partition between them, the other Sued in Chancery for relief: Chancery would not relieve him; but if the relea≈øe were obtained by Covin for a le≈ø≈øer ≈øum than the Debt was, the Debtor ≈øhould ≈øatisfie the overplus, More n. 802.

A. Admini≈øtrator of B. de bonis non per G. again≈øt H. and Avers that H. had not paid it to B. nor to A. (not ≈øaying he had not paid it to C.) its good enough; for the Declaration is, quas ei inju≈øte detinet, which per Cur. cannot be if it were paid to C. Al≈øo this lieth on the part of H. to plead in di≈øcharge of him≈øelf, 1 Keb. 232.

In Debt on Bond per B. Admini≈øtrator de bonis non of G. The Plaintiff ≈øaith, the Executors of G. naming them, were dead (not ≈øaying inte≈øtate) and if any Executor made his Executor, the Plaintiff is not ≈øufficiently intituled: Non allocatur; per Cur. the Defendant ought to ≈øhew there were Executors. Judgment pro Quer. 1 Keb. 480. Burge≈øs ver≈øus Clayton.

div.head: Against Executor or Admini≈øtrator.
div.p: DEbt on Bond again≈øt B. Executor; Defendant acknowledgeth the Bond, but ≈øaith, he gave another Bond in ≈øatisfaction of that Bond unto the Te≈øtator, which the Te≈øtator did accept in ≈øatisfaction: Ill Plea, one cho≈øe in Action cannot be in ≈øatisfaction of another. Stiles p. 339. Crook and Vernon.

Debt again≈øt J. B. and M. his Wife Executrix of her fir≈øt Husband, upon Bond ‚Ä¢ Defendant Pleads thus, praed. J. and M. per Atternat ≈øay, that they were divorced before the Writ purcha≈øed: On Demurrer adjugded that the Writ ≈øhall abate. Crook Eliz. 352. Underhil's Ca≈øe.

The Plaintiff brings two Obligations of 20 l. a piece again≈øt the Executor, whereas one was not due, and Damages were given for both entirely; but its no Error; for it was only an allegation of the Defendant, and it did not appear; and the Defendant re≈øted not upon it, but pleaded another Plea. (viz.) a reque≈øt to make a Relea≈øe, and I≈ø≈øue upon that. If the Plaintiff Sue one as Executor joyntly with the true Executor, who is not Executor, this is not in Abatement of the Bill or Writ, but only that he ≈øhall be barred again≈øt him, and ≈øo not Error, Crook Eliz. p. 110. Thi ‚Ä¢ kettle again≈øt Reve.

The con≈øtant difference is, where Executors bring the Action, all mu≈øt be named; but an Action brought again≈øt them, may be again≈øt ≈øuch only who do Admini≈øter; and unle≈øs it be averred that he did Admini≈øter, the Defendant cannot plead this Plea in Abatement; and therefore in 1 Keb. p. 865. Swallow again≈øt Emer≈øon. In Debt upon a Bond, the Defendant pleaded that there was another Executor not named, and yet living, and doth not ≈øay that he did Admini≈øter: The Plaintiff Demurred, and Judgment for the Plaintiff.

Debt again≈øt the Defendant Executor of one joynt Obligor; Defendant pleaded in Abatement, that it appears the Obligation was joynt, ≈øed non allocatur; for it appears not that the other Sealed, nor that the other Survived, in which ca≈øe the Executor would be di≈øcharged; the Plea was concluded quod billa ca≈ø≈øetur, and it begins with Judgment de billa, but the body of the Plea is a general Demurrer, which per Cur. is a plain bar to the Declaration, here being no Plea in Abatement, only, the form begins and ends in Abatement, but there is no other form to a Demurrer to a Declaration: In Abatement it ≈øhould be ≈øi ad billam prad re≈øpondere debet; for praecludi non is replication to a Plea, 3 Keb. 672. Bager and A≈øh.

div.head: Again≈øt Baron and Feme.
div.p: ON Obligation made by a Feme Covert, ≈øhe ≈øhall plead ≈øhe was Feme Covert, ‚Ä¢ nd conclude I≈ø≈øint non e≈øt factum, becau≈øe it was void. 14 H. 4.30.

Debt port again≈øt J. S. and Elianor his Wife, upon Bond made by the Wife; Defendants plead, quod tempora confectionis, and ‚Ä¢ ew the day, ≈øhe was Feme Covert: Plaintiff confe≈ø≈øeth this, but ≈øaith ≈øhe Sealed the ‚Ä¢ ame Deed, the ≈øame day of her Marriage, before her E≈øpou≈øals in the Morning. Defendant Demurs: Plaintiff had Judgment. 2 Rolls Rep. 431. Jack≈øons Ca≈øe.
Feme Obligor of full Age, takes Baron within Age; In Debt on Obligation they pray his Age; but denied. Noy p. 96.

On Obligation made by the Wife dum ≈øola; I≈ø≈øue is found again≈øt them; per Popham the Capias ≈øhall only be again≈øt the Wife, Noy 13. Am≈øon and Stockburne, on non e≈øt factum, Judgment mu≈øt be quod capiantur, More n. 93 ‚Ä¢
Bardolph and Perry.

Plaintiff declares of Obligation made by the Wife dum ≈øola fuit, the Writ mu≈øt be in the debet & detinet, for the Baron hath the Goods of the Wife in his own right. 5 Rep. 136. 3 Leon. p. 206. Walcotts Ca≈øe.

div.head: Again≈øt an Infant.
div.p: Vid. ≈øupra titulo, What Per≈øons may, „Äà‚óä„Äâ may not make Obligations.

div.head: Again≈øt a Body politique.
div.p: IF one will charge Mayor and Comminalty, they mu≈øt both be Bound. If one oblige him≈øelf by the name of Major and Comminalty, the Comminalty is not Bound, and no Goods of the Comminalty ≈øhall be put in Execution: So it is of Dean and Chapter; aliter of Abbot and Prior, for they are Bound tho' the Covent be not Bound, 3 H. 7.11.
Prior Obligor is made Abbot, Action of Debt is maintainable again≈øt him, 9 H. 7.16. b. Prior of Baths Ca≈øe.

div.head: Again≈øt two or three Obligors.
div.p: IF three are bound, and the Action is brought again≈øt two, the Plaintiff ought to ≈øhew that the third is dead.
If two or three are Bound Joyntly, and one dies, the Executor of him that is dead is altogether di≈øcharged, Siderfin p. 238. Ofborn's Ca≈øe.

Debt on Obligation again≈øt one, and upon Oyer he and two others were Joyntly Bound; Demurrer, and Judgment pro Querente, that the Declaration is good; and it ≈øhall come on the other part to ≈øwear, that there
is another named in the Lien, who is not named in the Writ, Siderfin p. 420. Chappel and Uaughan. Though two others are named, yet it appears not that they put their Seals to it, and ≈øo the Obligation is ≈øingle; but if the truth were, that the other two had Sealed as well as the Defendant, then the Defendant if he would take advantage of this, ought not to have Demurred upon the Oyer, but he ought to have pleaded in Abatement, that the two other Per≈øons Sealed the Obligation who are yet in full Life, and ≈øo pray Judgment of the Bill. 1 Sanders Trin. 21 Car. 2. f. 291. the ≈øame Ca≈øe 3 Crook 494. 5 Rep. 119.

Three are bound joyntly and ≈øeverally; upon Action brought again≈øt two, the Defendants ought to ≈øhew that it was made by them and others in full life, not named in the Writ; becau≈øe the Court ≈øhall not intend the Bond was ≈øealed and delivered by all that are named in it; therefore the Defendants cannot demur upon it, though it be entred in haec verba. So it is if an Action be brought upon a Recognizance taken before the Mayor and Recorder, &c. by Stat. 23 H. 8. becau≈øe there the parties mu≈øt ≈øeal. But in Scire facias again≈øt three Ballees upon a Recognizance acknowledged by them and the Principal joyntly and ≈øeverally: Upon Demurrer the Writ abated, becau≈øe this being founded upon a Record, the Plaintiff ought to ≈øhew forth the cau≈øe of the Variance
from the Record, as that one was dead, Allen p. 21. Blackwell and A≈øhton.

Four are bound by the≈øe words [Utrumque nostrum] the Obligee may charge any of the≈øe ≈øeverally; but if he will have a Joynt Action again≈øt two of the four, the Writ ≈øhall abate. Three are bound joyntly and ≈øeverally, Obligee cannot bring Debt again≈øt two, 10 H. 7.16.27 H. 8.6.

Debt on joynt Bond again≈øt the Survivor. The Defendant pleads, one of the Obligors died, and the Plaintiff afterwards relea≈øed to the Executor; the Relea≈øe is void. Aliter, had the Obligation been joynt and ≈øeveral, 1 Keb. 936. Scot and Littleton.

When two are joyntly bound in an Obligation, tho' none of them is bound by him≈øelf, yet none of them ≈øhall plead Non e≈øt factum, for they had ≈øealed and delivered it; but he may plead in Abatement of the Writ, and every of them is bound in the Entirety; therefore if they two are ≈øued, and one appears, and the other makes default, and by proce≈øs of Law he is Outlawed, he which appeared ≈øhall be charged with the whole. 5 Rep. 119. Whelpdale's Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads he was bound ≈øimul cum R. G. to whom the Plaintiff had relea≈øed all Actions the ≈øaid fir≈øt day of May (that being the date in the Declaration) The Plaintiff by Replication ≈øhewed, that after the Obligation ≈øealed by R. G. he relea≈øed to him; and after (viz. the ≈øame day) the Plaintiff ≈øealed the Bond, ab≈øque hoc quod ≈øimul
tenetur cum R. G. The Plaintiff demurs; this Relea≈øe doth not di≈øcharge the Defendant: And per Cur' the Traver≈øe is ill, becau≈øe R. G. was bound with the Defendant. But becau≈øe the Defendant had not taken advantage of it, to ≈øhew it on Demurrer, but confe≈øs'd it: Judgment pro Querente, Cro. Eliz. p. 161. Mannings and Town≈øend.

div.head: Again≈øt a Servant or Receiver.
div.p: GOdb. ≈øealed a Bill to E. T. thus: Mem. that I have received of E. T. to the u≈øe of my Ma≈øter, &c. the Sum of 40 l. to be paid at Michaelma≈øs following. E. T. brought an Action upon this Bill. The Defendant demurs to the Declaration, ≈øuppo≈øing that he receiving it as a Servant to anothers u≈øe, he ≈øhall not be charged as a principal Debtor: Per Cur', The la≈øt Clau≈øe of the Bill is for payment of the Mony generally, (and doth not ≈øay, to be repaid by his Ma≈øter,) and ≈øo ≈øhall bind him that ≈øealed it, 1 Brownl. Rep. 103. Talbot and Godbolt.

div.head: Of Actions and Suits. Action brought before Cau≈øe of Action.
div.p:
THe Writ was dated Mich. 30 Eliz. The Condition was, if F. died before the Age of 21 years; then if the Defendant cau≈øed an 100 l. to be paid to H. within three Months after the death of F. then, &c.
F. died 30 Septemb. 30 Eliz. The Plaintiff hath no cau≈øe of Action, as appeareth by the Record, 1 Leon. 186. Wood≈øhaw and Fulmer≈øton.

Condition to pay an Annuity at Lady-day, or within twenty days after. I≈ø≈øue being joyned on a Collateral matter, and found pro Quer'. It was moved in Arre≈øt of Judgment, that the Original was brought the 8th of April; and he alledgeth the Breach to be Lady-day la≈øt pa≈øt, which was within the twenty days, and ≈øo the Action brought before he had cau≈øe of Action: Apparent fau ‚Ä¢
Cro. Eliz. 565. Blunden's Ca≈øe.

After Verdict and Judgment, it was a≈ø≈øigned for Error, that the Te≈øte of the Original was before the day of payment in the Condition, Judgment was rever≈øt, M ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢
N. 776. Williams and Buckley, Cro. Eliz. 325, me≈øme Ca≈øe.
If there had been no Original, it had been good after Verdict; but this is not aided by Stat. 18 Eliz.
Bill Filed before the Obligation dated, the Record was amended, Siderfin p. 252. Manning and Warren.
Joynder in Action, Vid. ≈øupra ≈øpar≈øim.

div.head: Bond where ≈øuable.
div.p: BOnd made in Virginia, in partibus tran≈ømarinis; it may be ≈øued in the Admiralty, 2 Rol. Rep. 497. Tucker and Caps.

p.hi: Vid. ≈øupra. Et ≈øupra tit. Pleading to the Juri≈ødiction.

div.head: Declarations.
div.p: PEr Stat. 6 R. 2. its provided, the Original ≈øhall not be laid in one County, and the Declaration upon a Bond made in another County; if ≈øo, the Writ ≈øhall abate. Therefore if one plead the Bond was made in another County, than where it was alledged in the Declaration, its an ill plea, Allen, Hill. 22 Car. p. 17. Shalmer and Slingsby.

In Debt on Bond, the place of the making of the Obligation ought to be ≈øhewed in the Count; but if the Defendant plead Dure≈øs or Acquittance (by which he confe≈ø≈øeth the Deed) this makes the Count good, 28 H. 8. Dyer 14.

In Debt on Bond, Annuity or Praecipe of a Rent-charge, the place where the Deed bears date, ought to be alledged. Aliter of a Relea≈øe of Lands or Rent, for this is Executory upon the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, 5 H. 7.14. 28 H. 8. Dyer 14. 14 H. 8.16. a.
To be paid at his Man≈øion-hou≈øe, &c. this may be paid at any place, 3 Bulstr. 244. Meletine and Hall.

Surrey was in the Margent, and the Defendant in the Declaration was named of D. in the County of Su≈ø≈øex, and that he made that Obligation at D. in Geni. pr ‚Ä¢ d. and on Non e≈øt factum it was tryed in Surrey, and Error a≈ø≈øigned; becau≈øe Com' praed' refers to the County la≈øt named: Non allocutur; for it ≈øhall have relation to the County where the
Action is brought, and that named in the Margent: For the other County mentioned was by way of Recital, and ≈øo it ≈øhall not relate thereto, Cro. Eliz. 481. Shirly and S ‚Ä¢ c ‚Ä¢ vile.

div.head: Time.
div.p: A Declaration upon an Obligation, made ultimo die Augu≈øti; upon Oyer of the Bond it bore Date the 19th of Augu≈øt. The Defendant pleaded Non est factum, the Jury found it his Deed, and the Plaintiff had Judgment: For the Count was not of the date, but of the making, and the Jury have found the Deed, Hobart p. 249. Thorp and Taylor.
A Bill Filed before the Obligation dated, the Record was amended in B. R. Siderfin p. 252. Manning and Warren.
An Obligation made to accord with the Indenture of Covenants in point of Time, with Averment there was no other Indenture, 3 Keb. 117. Counte≈øs of Falmouth.

div.head: Form of the Declaration.
div.p:
IN the King's Bench it is ≈øaid, Sigillo ≈øuo ≈øigillat'; but in the Common Pleas it is, Per ≈øcriptum ≈øuum Obligatorium conce≈ø≈øit ≈øe teneri, &c. without ≈øaying, Sigillo ≈øuo ≈øigillat'; delivery is never alledged; and when it's ≈øaid, Per ≈øcriptum ≈øuum Obligatorium, all nece≈ø≈øary Circum≈øtances are intended to concur, viz. Sealing and Delivery, otherwi≈øe it is not a
Writing Obligatory, Cro. Eliz. fo. 737. Pen≈øon and Hodges. 2 Keb. 630. Cubitt and Green.
Three bring Debt, and declare that the Mony was not paid to them, and ≈øay not, Nec alicui eor ‚Ä¢ m; yet it's good; For payment to one, is payment to all the Obligees, Noy p. 69. Warner's Ca≈øe.
Debt of 300 l. upon two Obligations, dated 20 December, to pay 150 l. &c. and averred he had not paid it, and did not ≈øay [Nor any part of it;] yet good, Winch p. 72. Fo≈øter's Ca≈øe.

The Plaintiff declared, that the Defendant ≈øuch a day, conce≈ø≈øit ≈øe teneri, &c. & profert hic in Curia ≈øcriptum praedictum quod debitum praed', &c. The Defendant demands Oyer of the Condition, and pleads payment; after a Verdict, Judgment pro Querente. It was a≈ø≈øigned for Error, becau≈øe he doth not declare according to the u≈øual Cour≈øe, Quod per ≈øcriptum ≈øuum Obligatorium conce≈ø≈øit, nor any Writing mentioned in the former part of the Declaration, Sed non allocatur. The Writings are produced, and the Defendant by his Plea ≈øhews, it's an Obligation with Condition; and it appears to the Court, that the Plaintiff hath a ju≈øt Debt, and good cau≈øe to recover. Cro. Car. 209. Sir William Courtney's Ca≈øe.

In Debt ≈øur Bond, the Defendant confe≈øs'd the Action; and becau≈øe it's not ≈øaid in the Declaration, Hic in Curia prolat', it was adjudg'd a fault in Matter, and Error, Cro. Jac. 32. Dawbenny and Banni≈øter. Vid. le nove ‚Ä¢ Statute.

If a Bond be made to one, and he doth not ≈øay in the Bond, it ≈øhall be paid to the Obligee, in this ca≈øe the Plaintiff mu≈øt ≈øhew that it is to be paid to him, tho' not expre≈ø≈øed in the Bond, 1 Brownl. 72. Anonymus.
If any of the Bond be received, it mu≈øt be acknowledged in the Declaration.

Debt on two Obligations, one was 100 l. the other 110 l. and he brought an Action generally of 200 l. upon the≈øe Obligations, and acknowledgeth ≈øatisfaction of 10 l. but ≈øheweth not of what Obligation it was that he acknowledgeth the payment of 10 l. its no Error, 1 Rols Rep. p. 423. Hale and Maly ‚Ä¢ . vid. 3 Bul≈øtr. p. 244.
Plaintiff declares upon a Statute Obligatory, Solvendum upon Reque≈øt, and on Oyer it appears to be payable at a day certain‚ñ™ Incurable fault, Crook Jac. 316. Fox and Inkes.

Debt upon a Bill of 14 l. Solvendum
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
cum 6 l. upon Account between them, the Plaintiff only declares for 14 l. and good for that which comes after the Solvendum is void, Crook Eliz. 537. Woodward and Parry.

Declaration is upon three ≈øeveral Obligations, and upon Oyer of the ≈øeveral Conditions, it appears one of the ≈øums in the Condition, was payable after the Bill exhibited. I≈ø≈øue was joyned on Conditions performed, and Verdict for the Plaintiff, and intire Damages; and upon Relea≈øe of Co≈øts
and Damages, Judgment was given for the two fir≈øt Bonds only: For tho' the Bill be an entire ≈øum, yet by the Court it appeareth, they be as ≈øeveral Demands and Suits, Hobart p. 178. Andrews and Delahay. 1 Brown. 68. Me≈øme Ca≈øe.
One Declaration is naught: After appearance the Plaintiff pleads de novo, Noy p. 63. Ro≈ø≈øiter and Bu≈ø≈øey.

In B. R. the fir≈øt Declaration was in Debt on Obligation, 5 Feb. and the ≈øecond was on an Obligation dated 15 Feb. and the pleading and Judgment was thereupon, and held good, for it was held as a Declaration without an Original, which being after Verdict was ayded, Crook Jac. p. 89. cited in Sir Michael Dormers Ca≈øe.

Debt on Bond dated 13 Feb. The Defendant imparles, and after a ≈øecond Declaration was made, and therein he declares on an Obligation dated. 15 Feb. Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum; it was amended and made according to the fir≈øt Declaration; for the fir≈øt is the principal, and the Plea always refers thereto, Crook Jac. p. 105. Burrel ver≈øus Sir William Bowes.
Debt by Baron and Feme on an Obligation made to the Feme dum ≈øola fuit, and the Declaration is ad damnum ip≈øorum, its good, Stiles 134 Anonymus.

In Debt due upon a Bond or Contract, there needs not a ≈øpecial Demand to be laid, but licet ≈øaepius requi≈øitus is ≈øufficient. Aliter if it were due by Arbitrement cum requi≈øitus
fui≈ø≈øet, for then there mu≈øt be a ≈øpecial demand, Cro. Jac. 640. Waters and Bridges 1 Brownl. 30.
In inferior Court of Record 50 l. in figures is Error, Stiles p. 165. Jo≈øon and Beale.

A thing that doth not intitle the Plaintiff to Action, need not be contained in the Count. If the Condition be Endor≈øed or Sub≈øcribed, it need not be contained in the Count; but if it be contained before the (in Witne≈øs) then it ought to be contained in the Count. If a Man be bound to pay 10 l. when the Obligee carries 200 Load of Hay to his Hou≈øe; there the Condition is precedent, and it ought to be contained in the Count: What comes after the in Witne≈øs, be it a Provi≈øo or Memorandum, it may be as a Condition or Defe≈øance, and need not be contained in the Count, 2 Brownl. Rep. 97. Hammond and Jethro. Be it known that J. C. bind me to R. in 40. l. to di≈øcharge and ≈øave harmle≈øs the ≈øaid R. again≈øt W. Solven ‚Ä¢ tali die, &c. there the Count is good, generally, without ≈øaying the Defendant had not ≈øaved harmle≈øs, 22 Ed. 4.42. One ought to declare ≈øpecially according to the Bill; the Bill was, to pay as I pay my other Creditors: The Plaintiff declared generally, that he was indebted to him in 5 l. Solvend' upon reque≈øt: Its ill, Cro. Eliz. 256. Bright and Metcalf.

div.head: Declaration for Outlandi≈øh Mony.
div.p:
DEclares upon a Bill Obligatory, wherein the Defendant was obliged to pay him ‚Ä¢ 00 Gilders of legal Mony Poloni≈øh (viz,) ad valorem 220 l. legalis monetae Angliae, and that the Defendant had not paid unto him the ≈øaid 220 l. monetae Angliae, nor the ≈øaid 600 Gilders monetae Poloniae, per quod A ‚Ä¢ ti ‚Ä¢ accrevit, &c. Defendant pleaded non, e≈øt factum, and found pro Querente, and the value of the Mony was enquired by the Jury (viz.) that the value of the 600 Gilders Poli≈øh, was at the time of the Bill and now, 220 l. The Action is well brought in the de ‚Ä¢ in ‚Ä¢ , becau≈øe he is to recover the value, and the demand is not of any ≈øum certain, Cro. Jac. 617. Rands and Peck. Cro. Eliz. 536. Bay≈øhaw and Plaine. Latch p. 4.77.8 ‚Ä¢
Wards Ca≈øe.

The Court cannot compel the Plaintiff to ≈øet forth the Condition in his Declaration, but till he doth it on Oyer demanded, the Defendant ≈øhall not be compelled to plead, Stiles 125. Sir Charles ‚Ä¢ ot and Plunket. On Oyer demanded unle≈øs the Plaintiff will ≈øhew the Bond, the Court will ≈øet a≈øide the Judgment as irregular, 2 Keb. 275. Beadly and Beach.

When the Plaintiff counts on Bond, it ought to remain in Court, unle≈øs the Defendant after Oyer demanded ≈øuffer it to be delivered out, then on non e≈øt factum, the Court will not order it to remain there on prayer of the Defendant, although anciently it hath been ≈øo, 1 Keb. 486. Williams and Hulle ‚Ä¢ .

In Debt on Bond to deliver up Goods in a Schedule annexed; per Cur. on demand of Oyer of the Condition, they ≈øhall have al≈øo Oyer of the Schedule, being all as one D ‚Ä¢ ed; but Oyer of Indenture for performance of Covenants, ≈øhall not have Oyer of the Covenants, but yet mu≈øt ≈øet them forth, and if he have no counterpart he may move the Court and obtain it, 2 Keb. 4. Waterman and Adams.

div.head: Variance between the Obligation and Declaration.
div.p:
DEbt on Bond, the Plaintiff declares of a 1000 l. to be paid to him, and the Defendant demands Oyer, and he was bound to J. R. to be paid to J. K. to the u≈øe of J. R. The Defendant Demurs; the Solvend' to the Stranger is void, and the Court ≈øeem'd pro Querent ‚Ä¢
On non e≈øt factum pleaded, it had been well enough ≈øo, if this had been a Condition to pay. Qu. if there be no ≈øufficient words of Obligation to the Plaintiff, Siderfin p. 290. 2 Keb. 81. Queen Mother ver≈øus Challoner.
Variance between the Obligation and Count ≈øhall not be ≈øhewed after imparlance, 1 Brownl. 95. Percher and Vaughan.

div.head: Variance in the Sum.
div.p:
THe Declaration was, the Defendant ≈øtood bound to him in Septingent' & quinquagent' libris, and produced his Writing Obligatory, and upon Oyer the words were
Septuagint' and quinquagint' libris: The Defendant pleads the Variance, and demurs thereupon: Per Cur. that is no cau≈øe to abate the Writ. The Defendant then pleaded non e≈øt factum; and the Jury found that the afore≈øaid Writing Obligatory, de ≈øumma Septuagent' & quinquagint' librarum per quod praedict W.W. per breve ≈øuum exegit de praefat' T.P. infra≈øcript ≈øeptingent' & quinquagint' libras was ≈øealed, &c. ≈øed utrum ≈øuper tota materia, &c. the Court awarded the Plaintiff ≈øhould recover the 750 l. and Co≈øts, Hobart 116. Walter and Piggots Ca≈øe.
The Obligation was octigint' and the Declaration octogint', and Variance pleaded: See the form of Pleading and entring Judgment, Hobart p. 19. Fitzhughes Ca≈øe.

Upon Oyer it appears no ≈øum is mentioned in the Condition, and the Declaration is to pay ≈øo much: Per Coke, its a material Variance, and the Obligation is ≈øingle, and no day being ≈øet down its payable on reque≈øt, and ≈øo the Declaration is good, 2 Bulstr. 156. Dorrington and VValler.
Debt in York on Obligation of 13 l. Plaint was in plicito debiti 14 l. which variance was a≈ø≈øigned for Error, 2 Keb. 590. Vavi≈øor again≈øt Bellingham.

div.head: Variance in the Names and Additions; Mi≈ønomer.
div.p: MOlineax enters his Original in the Common-Bench again≈øt Mar ‚Ä¢ ham, in Debt on a Bond per name of J. Markham Alderman, de D. and declares again≈øt him by the name of Markham de D. E≈øq and Judgment was given pro Quer. ≈øur Verdict, it was adjudged Error, Yelv. p. 120. Molineax and Markham.

The Plaintiff in the Obligation was named J. Thorney de Fenton in Com' Not' Armig' and in the Declaration he was named J. Thorney Armig', To (de Fenton in Com' Noi') were left out: The Defendant demands Judgment of the Bill for this Variance Per Cur. re≈øpondeas ouster; for this is no Variance to abate the Bill, when he is well named is his proper Name and Sirname, the addition is not material; otherwi≈øe, if it were of the part of the Defendant, Cro. Eliz. p. 312. Thorney and Di≈øney.

Declaration is on a Bond by Edmund Shephard, (for ≈øo it was ≈øigned) and ≈øhews a Bond of Edward Shepard, Noverint, &c. me Edwardum Shephard, &c. Upon non e≈øt factum, the Jury found it the Deed of Edmund Shepard, and Judgment was Arre≈øted, for they are di≈øtinct names. And though it be ≈øub≈øcribed by the name of Edmund, yet that is no part of the Bond, he ought to have brought his Action according to the Bond, Cro. Jac. 640. Maby and Shepard, Cro. Jac. 558. Watkins and Oliver.

Count quod praedict' Jacobus per nomen Jo
‚Ä¢ annis W. per quoddam ≈øcriptum, &c. upon Oyer, the Defendant by the name of John W. fecit ≈øcriptum. The Condition was, if James W. paid. The Defendant Demurs: Per Cur. the Action lay not, for John cannot be James, Crook Eliz. 897. Feild and Winlowe.

W.S. is bound by the name of J. S. Action brought again≈øt him by the name of J. W. alias J. On non e≈øt factum, adjudged the Plaintiff ≈øhall not recover; the Action ≈øhould be again≈øt J. as he is named in the Obligation, 11 Eliz. Dyer 279. The Defendant pleaded variance between the Obligation and the Declaration; for the Obligation was Randal, and the Declaration was ad re≈øpondend' Randulpho alias Randal. Q. if Randulphus be Latin for Randal, 3 Leon. p. 232. Babington's Ca≈øe.
In the Writ he was named Son and Heir apparent, and in the Declaration Son and Heir generally; for this variance the Judgment was rever≈øed, Crook Eliz. 333. Annesby and Stokes.
When a Man appears and pleads, he hath lo≈øt the advantage of Mi≈ønomer, 2 Rolls Rep. 50. Sir Francis Forte≈øcue's Ca≈øe.

If he is named Saxex in the Original, and Saxey in the alias dict', its variance; for he ought to declare again≈øt him, by the name he was at the time of Sealing the Bond, and as he is named in the Condition, and the alias dict' is for no other purpo≈øe, but to make the name agree with the name in the Bond. If Action be brought again≈øt J. S.
who at that time was E≈øquire, and afterwards he is made a Knight; there he ≈øhall declare again≈øt J. S. Armig. alias dict. J. S. Mil. But in the fir≈øt ca≈øe it was no Error, it being an ea≈øie Mi≈øtake, 1 Bul≈øtr. 216. Saxey and Whem≈øon.

div.head: Variance in time of payment of Entry.
div.p: THe Bill was, Be it known, &c. to be paid at two payments, that is to ≈øay, 5 l. to be paid the 19th day of November, which is the pre≈øent of this Month, and the other 5 l. the 10th day of December; and the Bill was dated 17th Nov. 1604. The Plaintiff declares, the Defendant did acknowledge him≈øelf to owe the Plaintiff 10 l. to be paid to the Plaintiff at two payments, viz. 5 l. to be paid the 19th of November then next following, and the other 5 l. to be paid the 10th day of December then next following. On non e≈øt factum the Jury found the Special Matter. The Que≈øtion was, Whether the Bill maintain the Count for the fir≈øt payment, and adjudg'd it did, Brownl. 1 Rep. 74. Pre≈øt and Cee.
The Count is of a Bond dated 1 May, and the Entry is of 2 May; on a Relea≈øe pleaded, and I≈ø≈øue thereon, it's good enough. Aliter on non e≈øt factum, 1 Keb. 426. Billage and Blake.

div.head: Oyer, mon≈øtre des faits.
div.p: IF no Oyer be demanded, it's intended a ≈øingle Bill, 1 Keb. 937. Coxall and Sharp.

In Debt on Obligation, the Defendant avers the Obligation was for ≈øecurity of certain Rent, &c. without demanding Oyer of the Condition; it's but as a ≈øingle Bill, and he cannot aver a Condition; and ≈øo upon Demurrer adjudged pro Querente, 1 Rol. Rep. 425. Baylee and Harrington.
The Law in Henry the Seventh's time was, That the Defendant need not ≈øhew forth the Indenture of Covenants, on Oyer demanded, 6 H. 7.12, 13. 9 H. 7.17. 13 H. 7.18.

The Defendant craves Oyer of the Obligation, & ei legitur; and then of the Condition, & ei legitur: And this was for performance of Covenants in an Indenture, and after Oyer of the Condition the Entry on the Roll was, That the Defendant prays Oyer of the Indenture mentioned in the Condition, which was not brought into Court, & ei legitur. The Plaintiff demurs, for that the Defendant hath prayed Oyer of an Indenture, which was not brought into the Court by the Plaintiff, nor appears to be in Court omnino: Per Cur', This is aided per Stat. 27 Eliz. c. 5. upon general Demurrer; but per Cur' the Defendant ought to have ≈øhewed the Deed, and not the Plaintiff, by Law, although the Court ≈øometimes will compel the Plaintiff to give a Copy of an
Indenture to the Defendant, if he ≈øwear that he never had a part, or had lo≈øt it: But this is ex gratia Curiae, not ex debito Ju≈øticiae, for the Entry always ≈øuppo≈øeth this to be brought in Court by the Defendants; and ≈øo 7 H. 4.1. that the Plaintiff in ≈øuch ca≈øe ought to ≈øhew the Indenture, is no Law at this day, 1 Sanders 8, 9. Jevans and Harridge, 2 Keb. 1 16. me≈øme Ca≈øe. Demand Oyer, to ≈øave the advantage of Demurrer pur. Variance, 1 Keb. 426. Billage and Blake.

The Defendant prays Oyer of the Condition, which is for performance of Covenants, in an Indenture made between the Plaintiff on the one part, and H. H. on the other part, on the part of the ≈øaid H. H. to be performed, and upon Oyer of the Condition the Defendant pleads, that the Indentures were made between the Plaintiff and the ≈øaid H. H. ≈øuch a day and place, and one part under the Seal of the Plaintiff the Defendant brought in Court; and further, that there were not any Covenants in the ≈øaid Indenture, of the part of the ≈øaid H. H. to be performed, Et hoc paratus, &c. The Plaintiff prays Oyer of the Indenture per the Defendant brought in Court, which is entred in haec verba; and upon this it appears that there are divers Covenants to be performed on the part of H. H. and upon Oyer of the ≈øaid Indenture, being ≈øo entred, the Plaintiff demurs. It was urged for the Defendant, That the Plaintiff ought to have ≈øhewed a breach of one of the Covenants, to maintain his Action: But per Cur. when
the Defendant brought the Indenture into Court, and ≈øaith there are no Covenants in it, &c. Now upon Oyer of this, the Indenture is made parcel of the Plea; and by this it appears Judicially to the Court he had pleaded a faux Plea, and had taken an Averment again≈øt the truth of that that appeared to the Court by the Indenture it ≈øelf; and ≈øo the Plaintiff need not ≈øhew any matter of Fact in his Replication to maintain his Action, but a Demurrer was more proper, 1 Sander's 316. Smith and Yeomans.

Condition to perform Covenants in an Indenture, i. e. to pay 300 l. and to Repair as three ≈øhall award. The Breach was, that Award was made, and the Defendant had not Repaired. The Defendant prays Oyer of the Indenture, which was well, and of the Award, and ≈øets it forth untruly. The Oyer was ≈øet a≈øide, becau≈øe Irregular; and if the Award be not at fir≈øt truly ≈øet forth, the Defendant might traver≈øe it, but cannot pray Oyer of any thing not in Curia prolat', 3 Keb. H. 28 Car. 2. p. 716. Sands and T ‚Ä¢ mlin≈øon.
Le Defendant demand Oyer del Oblig', & de Condition; la form, 2 Sanders 75.
Le Defendant demand Oyer des 2 Oblig', & Demur', 1 Sanders 282.
Defendant ad Oyer de Condition de Oblig', & apres ad Oyer des Instructions, 2 Sanders.
Le Defendant ≈øur Oyer del' Condic' a performer Covenants ame≈øne en Court le Indenture, & plede Conditions performe, 1 Sanders 52.
Monstrans de Obligation, Ra≈øt Entr. 180. b.

div.head: Condition. Where a Recital in a Condition ≈øhall be an E≈øtoppel.
div.p: BY a bare Recital in an Obligation, one ≈øhall be E≈øtopped, 13 Ed. 4.4.
A Recital by a ≈øingle Bill ≈øhall e≈øtop the party, 25 Ed. 4.54.
Recites by an Obligation, that he made a Will, he is e≈øtopped to ≈øay the contrary, 2 & 3 El. Dyer 190.

As to E≈øtoppel by Recital, there is a difference where it goeth in the generality, and where in the particularity: For where it is in the generality, as to enfeoff one of all the Lands de≈øcended to him, or to be Non≈øuit in all Actions depending in the Common Pleas, he ≈øhall not be e≈øtopped to ≈øay that he hath not any Land, or that he hath not any Action depending there, 18 Ed. 4.4.
Again≈øt a Condition to perform all Covenants, a man may ≈øay there were not any Covenants, 21 H. 4.54.

Condition to pay Rent re≈øerved upon a Demi≈øe, according to ≈øuch Articles. The Defendant pleads, he hath not any thing in the Land demi≈øed by ≈øuch Articles: Per Cur. upon demand he ≈øhall be e≈øtopped to plead that, Cro. El. 3. p. 362. Strowd ver≈øus Willis. Popham p. 114.

Condition, whereas E.W. hath commenced divers Suits in B. R. again≈øt W. H. If the ≈øaid W. H. ≈øhall without delay by his lawful
Attorney appear, and make an≈øwer to all Actions and Declarations commenced again≈øt him, that then, &c. The Defendant pleads, That po≈øtea (viz.) ≈øuch a day W. H. appeared, and paratus fuit re≈øpondere C. but that there were not any Actions there depending. Upon Demurrer; per Court, ill Plea. He is e≈øtopt to plead, that there were not any Actions there depending. As if a man be obliged to perform the Covenants in the Indenture on his part to be performed; it's no Plea to ≈øay, there were not any Covenants on his part to be perform'd, 3 Eliz. Dyer 196, & 279. Cro. El. p. 756. Willoughby ver≈øus Brook, p. 42 Eliz. C. B.

Condition to perform Covenants in Indentures between W. S. and A. his Wife of the one part, and the Plaintiff on the other part. The Defendant pleads the Indenture, as the Indenture of W. S. and A. his Wife; whereas, in truth the Feme never ≈øealed. The Plaintiff replies, That the Indenture ≈øhewn by the Defendant non fuit fact' inter W. S. & A. his Wife, on the one part, and the Plaintiff on the other. Per Cur. the Plaintiff is not e≈øtopped to ≈øay, that the Deed ≈øhewn, is not the Deed of the Baron and Feme; but he is e≈øtopped by the Condition to ≈øay, that there is not any ≈øuch Indenture, Cro. El. p. 769. Ship ver≈øus Steed.

Condition was, Whereas the Plaintiff had carried ≈øo many Thou≈øand of Billets for the Defendant to D. amounting at ≈øo much a 1000 to 100 l. If the Defendant therefore ≈øhould
pay the 100 l. The Defendant pleads upon Oyer, that the Plaintiff did not carry and deliver ≈øo many Thou≈øand of Billets, &c. Per Cur. this Recital in the Obligation, is an E≈øtoppel to the Defendant to plead the contrary, Stiles 103. Allen 52. Hill. 23 Car. 1. Hart ver≈øus Buckmin≈øter.

The Defendant pleads in Abatement, that he is Earl of Nova Albion in Ireland, and ought to be impleaded by that Name, and not by the Name of Edmund Plowden Kt. Per Cur. He pleads he was Earl of Nova Albion in Ireland, before he entred into the Bond, which he cannot now plead, for he is e≈øtopped to plead ≈øo by his own Deed, which te≈øtifies the contrary, Stiles p. 187. Weston ver≈øus Plowden.

Condition, If the Defendant and his Wife ≈øhould appear ≈øuch a day at the Palace Court, &c. The Defendant upon Oyer pleads, That he him≈øelf did appear at the day, prout patet per Record', and that he was not Married at the time of the Obligation, nor ever after. Per Cur. it's no Plea, for he is e≈øtopped to deny that he had a Wife, Allen p. 13. Paine and Shelltrop.

Recital in a Bond, is an E≈øtoppel to ≈øay the contrary; but if I≈ø≈øue be tried contrary, it's good: As, Non damnif. pleaded in Debt on Bond, with Condition to pay for Meat, Drink, &c. The Plaintiff replies, Quod ho≈øpitavit, on which the Defendant takes I≈ø≈øue, quod non ho≈øpitavit, and Ruled good after Verdict, 1 Keb. p. 344. Holt and Harder.

Debt on Bond to perform Covenants, ≈øpecified in an Indenture betwixt A. and B. The Defendant pleads, there was no Covenants. Per Cur. this being generally of all, is well. Contra, If it were to perform any certain Covenants; but the party is e≈øtopt to ≈øay, there is no Indenture, but he mu≈øt ≈øet forth the Indenture it ≈øelf: But the Plaintiff ≈øhewing the Indenture, if any Covenants be therein, the Jury mu≈øt find for the Plaintiff, 1 Keb. p. 381. Brazier and Acton.

Condition, That a Stranger ≈øhall relea≈øe all his Right to the Plaintiff. The Defendant pleads, that the Stranger had no Right. The Plaintiff demurs: Per Cur. he is e≈øtopt, and the Plaintiff mu≈øt relea≈øe whether he have Right or no, 2 Keb. p. 471. Doughty and Neale

Debt on Sheriff, Bond, to appear in B. R. according to cu≈øtom, at the Suit of M. in Debt. The Defendant pleads, there is no ≈øuch cu≈øtom in B. R. to appear to an Ac etiam Billa. He is e≈øtopt to plead this, 3 Keb. 160. Forth and Ward ver≈øus Walker.

Condition, to pay and ≈øatisfie out of the Profits of the Coal-Mines clear. The Defendant pleads, there were no clear Profits. The Defendant is not e≈øtopt by the Bond to plead this, being general, 3 Keb. p. 466. Howard and Wych.

Condition to pay a Legacy devi≈øed by the La≈øt Will of J. S. The Defendant pleads, it's true J. S. did by his La≈øt Will give the ≈øaid Legacy; but ≈øaith, that J. S. did revoke that La≈øt Will, and after died, and by the
later left nothing to the Plaintiff. Demurs; becau≈øe being intended a Bond made after the death of J. S. the Defendant is e≈øtopt by the Condition of the Bond to ≈øay, there was no ≈øuch La≈øt Will, e≈øpecially no time of either Will being mentioned. Which the Court Agreed. And if the Bond were before J. S. died, the Defendant hath undertaken, and mu≈øt pay it at his peril, 3 Keb. 303. Bachwell and Barjew. Mod. Rep. 113.

Condition to pay Mony yearly, according to the form and effect of the Indenture, made between the Plaintiff and Defendant. The Defendant pleads, there was no ≈øuch Indenture. He is e≈øtopt to plead ≈øo, 1 Brownl. 57. Fitch and Bi≈ø≈øye.

The, Defendant was obliged to make an Obligation to appear in B. R. at a day prefixed in the Writ: The Defendant pleads, there was no day prefixed in the Writ for his Appearance. He is e≈øtopt to plead thus, 1 Brownl. 91. Andrews and Robins.
If a man be bound to pay an hundred Pounds that J. S. owes to him; he cannot plead that J. S. doth not owe him 100 l. Per VVilliams in Andrews's Ca≈øe, 1 Brownl. 41.
Condition to perform things for which he was bound in a Recognizance: He is concluded to plead, that he is not bound in any Recognizance, 2 Rep. 33. Doddington. 1 Rol. Rep. 83. Fletcher and Farrer.

Condition was, That if the Defendant do not commence and pro≈øecute any Suit in any Court, Spiritual or Temporal, again≈øt the ≈øaid A, his Wife; but ≈øhall from henceforth, during the Natural life of him and A. his Wife, u≈øe and maintain the ≈øaid A. as his lawful Wife to all intents, that then, &c. The Defendant pleads, he had not brought any Action, &c. after the Obligation; and that before the ≈øaid A. was married to him, ≈øhe was married to J. S. who is yet alive; for which cau≈øe he cannot maintain and u≈øe the ≈øaid A. as his lawful Wife. Upon which he Demurs. Per Cur. The material part of the Condition did con≈øi≈øt in the fir≈øt part, and the Defendant having pleaded an i≈ø≈øuable Plea to that, it's not material if he plead to the Later part or not: And if his Ju≈øtification be in≈øufficient, the Plaintiff ought not to have demurred upon it. But the Court held the Ju≈øtification good, and he is not E≈øtopped to plead the ≈øpecial Matter of her former Marriage; becau≈øe ≈øhe is called Wife in the Condition, for he may confe≈øs and avoid it: For ≈øhe may be his Wife to ≈øome purpo≈øes, but not to u≈øe her as his lawful Wife, Mo. N. 652. Phratt and Planner.

One is bound to J. S. to enfeoff him of the Manor of D. in Debt upon this Bond, he ≈øhall not ≈øay, he had not ≈øuch a Manor of D. Aliter if one be bound to enfeoff me of all his Lands in ≈øuch a County, 21 Ed. 4.54. b.

div.head: Pleadings.
div.p: IN treating on this, I ≈øhall lay down ≈øome general Rules and Diver≈øities, and apply ca≈øes thereunto, and afterwards ≈øpeak of ≈øpecial Pleas, as Acceptance, Relea≈øe, Payment, &c. and particularly how and where Non est factum may be pleaded; and al≈øo of Foreign Pleas. Though in all the precedent Ca≈øes, I have had an Eye ≈øtill to the Pleadings under the proper Titles, and ≈øhall make reference thereto as occa≈øion ≈øhall be.

As to the Rules of Pleading: I ≈øhall con≈øider,
Of Pleading or Performance generally, and where it mu≈øt be pleaded ≈øpecially and particularly.
In what ca≈øes it mu≈øt be ≈øhewed, how and where performed and done.
Of the Certainty of Pleading, and where it mu≈øt be pleaded according to the expre≈øs words of the Condition or Covenant, and where further than the expre≈øs words.
Of the partes Placitorum.
I ≈øhall ob≈øerve ≈øome diver≈øities, which will better be under≈øtood in the application of the following Ca≈øes. Qui bene di≈øtinguit, bene docet.
1. There is diver≈øity between Pleading in the Negative and in the Affirmative.
2. Between Pleading to Negative Covenants, and to Affirmative Covenants.
3. Between a Condition precedent and ≈øub≈øequent.
4. Between a Condition to do a Collateral act; as to make a Feoffment, render Account, &c. and where it is to pay Mony.
5. Where the Mony in the Condition is a collateral Sum, and where it is parcel of the Obligation.
6. Between a Condition Copulative and Disjunctive.
7. Between payment or performance by or to a Stranger, and payment or performance by the Obligor to the Obligee.
8. Where an Obligation is void, and where voidable.
9. Between a delivery to the party him≈øelf, and delivery as an E≈øcrow.
10. Between acts to be done by a Condition, which are Tran≈øitory or Local.
11. Between a Condition void again≈øt Common Law or Stature Law.
12. Between where the Obligation is void, and where the Condition is only void, and the Obligation ≈øingle.
13. Between a Bargain and a Loan.
14. Between a Bill Obligatory, and an Obligation with a Condition. Vid. ≈øupra titulo Bill.

div.head: Where Performance generally may be pleaded, and where it mu≈øt be ≈øhewed ≈øpecially, and how performed.
div.p: IF a man be bound to perform all the Covenants in an Indenture, if all be in the affirmative, he may plead General performance of all; but if any be in the negative, to ≈øo many he ought to plead Specially, (for a Negative cannot be performed) and to the re≈øt Generally, Doct. pla ‚Ä¢ itand. 57, 58.

So if any of them are in the Disjunctive, he mu≈øt ≈øhew which of them he hath performed; and if any are to be done of Record, he ought to ≈øhew this Specially, and may not involve it in General pleading, Ibid. But,

If the Defendant pleads Performance generally, and the Plaintiff demurs, and ≈øhews ≈øome Covenants are in the Negative, and ≈øome in the Affirmative: As to the Covenants in the Affirmative, he ought to plead a Special performance, and to ≈øhew how he hath performed them. Judgment pro Quer. Stiles M. 1649. p. 163. Fines and Dell. Allen, Hill. 23 Car. p. 72. Ellis and Box, Lit. Rep. p. 2.
Upon a Bond for Performance of Covenants generally, H. may plead General performance; but when to does any particular act, he mu≈øt an≈øwer certainly, 1 Keb. p. 111. Sir George Belli≈øon's Ca≈øe.

‚òû A diver≈øity between the Condition of an Obligation which con≈øi≈øts of ≈øeveral parts, and Covenants in an Indenture which con≈øi≈øt of ≈øeveral parts in the Affirmative: For in the ca≈øe of Covenants, Performance generally, is a good Plea; but in the ca≈øe of the Condition of an Obligation, the Defendant ought to ≈øhew in pleading, that he had performed the ≈øeveral things comprized in the Condition particularly: As the Condition was, that the Defendant ≈øhall deliver ≈øuch Briefs to all Churches, &c. before ≈øuch time, &c. and to deliver the Mony collected. The Defendant pleads Performance generally: Ill Bar; for he ought to have pleaded particularly what Sums he had received, to the intent he may give an account: And ≈øo, if in his Bar he had ≈øaid, He delivered the Briefs, and ≈øaith not at what time, Siderfin p. 215. Woodcook and Cole.
On Affirmative Covenants general pleading and Performance is ≈øufficient; and ≈øo on Negative; per Twi≈øden, 1 Keb. 413. Nicholas and Pullen. Qu. Vide Palmer's Rep. 70. Ley and Luttrel, contra.
See more of this Learning of Covenants, being in the Negative and the Affirmative, in 10 H. 7.12, b. 16 H. 7.11, a. 4. H. 7.12. & ≈øupra.

Covenant, that he ≈øhall go in ≈øuch a Ship to, &c. and the words are, Quod decederet, procederet, & non deviet. The Defendant pleads Performance generally, it's not a good Plea. As to a Negative Covenant,
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
which is only in affirmance of the Affirmative Covenant precedent, Performance is a good Plea. But as to a Negative Covenant, which is additional to an Affirmative Covenant, as here, he ought to plead Specially, Siderfin p. 87. Laughter and Palmer.

If a Man Plead in the Affirmative, he hath ≈øaved the Plaintiff harmle≈øs, he ought to ≈øhew how; aliter if he Plead in the Negative non damnificatus, 5 Rep. 24. Broughtons Ca≈øe. 2 Rep. Man≈øers Ca≈øe. 4 H. 7.12 Cro. Eliz. 916.

Conditions is, that the Defendant ≈øhall ratifie and confirm ≈øuch a Demi≈øe, its not ≈øufficient to ≈øay, he had ratified and confirmed it, but he ought to ≈øhew how, and Plead the confirmation by Deed, 6 Eliz. Dyer 229. b.

Condition is to pay all ≈øuch Arrears, &c. its not ≈øufficient to ≈øay, that he had paid all, &c. but he ought to expre≈øs it certain, how much Arrears he had paid amounting to ≈øuch a ≈øum, 20 H. 6.31.
Condition to perform ≈øuch a Will, he Pleads he had performed the Will, and recited it not, nor ≈øaith how, and not good, Litt. Rep. p. 2.

Condition to ≈øave O. harmle≈øs, &c. and to deliver up the Bond, and to acknowledge ≈øatisfaction of a Judgment when paid; The Defendant prote≈øtando he hath ≈øayed O. harmle≈øs, pro plit' dicit, he hath performed all the Conditions: The Plaintiff replies, he had not delivered up the Bond: The Defendant Demurs, no Averment being that the Mony thereon was not paid; ≈øo no breach. Per Cur. the Bar is naught by general performance, and the Replication not de≈øtroying the cau≈øe of Action ≈øhewed in the Count is well enough, 2 Keb. 720.
If I am bound to enfeoff J. S. of the Mannor of D. in Debt ≈øur Obligation if the Defendant Plead performance, he ought, to ≈øhew where the Mannor of D. is, 15 Edward 4.14. b.

If the Condition be to di≈øcharge the Plaintiff, &c. then the manner of the di≈øcharge ought to be ≈øhewed: But if it be to ≈øave harmle≈øs only, then non damnificatus generally is good enough, 1 Leon. Ca≈øe, 95. p. 71. Bret and Audard. So where the words are, Acquit, Di≈øcharge, and ≈øave harmle≈øs, &c. non damnificatus is an in≈øufficient Plea, and its not ≈øufficient only to an≈øwer to the Damnification, ibid.

If I am bound to convey to you the Mannor of D. in Pleading the performance of the Condition, its not ≈øufficient to ≈øay, I have conveyed the ≈øame Mannor, but to ≈øhew by what manner of conveyance, 22 Ed. 4.43. cited 1 Leon. p. 72.

Condition to pay ≈øo much yearly for an In≈øtrument of Weaving, and to deliver it up at the end of the Term; the Defendant Pleads, general performance; per Cur. they mu≈øt be ≈øpecially an≈øwered, 2 Keb. 387. Brown and Tadderby.

But in many Ca≈øes, the Law allows general Pleading, to avoid prolixity, and the particulars ≈øhall come of the other part, as Cro. Eliz. p. 253. Acton and Hill. And therefore, he who Pleads in the Affirmative, ≈øhall alledge performance of Covenants generally: As Condition was, if the Defendant at all times upon reque≈øt, delivered to the Plaintiff all the Fat and Tallow of all Bea≈øts, which He or his Servants ≈øhould Kill, or Dre≈øs before ≈øuch a day, that then, &c. The Defendant pleaded, that upon every reque≈øt made unto him, he delivered to the Plaintiff all the Fat and Tallow of all Bea≈øts which were Killed by him, &c. Per Cur. the Plea is good, Cro. Eliz. 749. Mints and Bethel. In the ca≈øe of Sheriffs, one need not ≈øhew how he ≈øaved him harmle≈øs, becau≈øe of the infinitene≈øs.
Condition to pay a Moiety of Charges at Suits in Law, &c. the Defendant pleads payment generally, 2 Keb. 762. Cantor and Hurtwel.

Bond to collect all the Amerciaments; he Pleads he collected all, and good, being in the Affirmative, aliter if the Condition be of matter of Record, as to be Non-≈øuit in all the Kings Courts, 2 H. 7.15. a. 4 H. 7.12. b.

div.head: Certainty.
div.p: THe expre≈øs certainty (regularly) ought to be pleaded, according to the expre≈øs words of the Condition, and to ≈øhew the performance, 15 Eliz. Dyer 318. vid. Kel. p. 60.

Covenant in a Lea≈øe, that he hath full Power and Authority to Demi≈øe the Land. Le≈ø≈øee brought an Action on this Covenant, it ≈øufficeth him to ≈øay, the Le≈ø≈øor had not full Power, and lawful Authority; and this A≈ø≈øignment of breach is good, for he per≈øues the words of the Covenant Negative, and the Le≈ø≈øee is a ≈øtranger to the Le≈ø≈øors Title; and therefore the Defendant ought to ≈øhew what E≈øtate he had in this Land tempore dimi≈ø≈øionis, by which it may appear to the Court, he had full Power and lawful Authority to Demi≈øe, 9 Rep. 60, 61. Brad≈øhaws Ca≈øe.
A Man is bound in the Copulative, that he and his A≈ø≈øigns per≈øolverent omnia onera: He ought to Plead that he and his A≈ø≈øigns have done this, 28 H. 8 Dyer 27. b.

Condition to pay 10 l. within ≈øix Months after the Marriage of the Plaintiff; the Defendant Pleads, the Plaintiff was not Married; the Plaintiff replies he was Married. Defendant
demurs, becau≈øe it doth not appear, but the Defendant hath paid the 10 l. Adjudged for the Defendant, he ought to an≈øwer the Condition. Aliter after Verdict, Siderfin p. 340. in Hayman and Gerards Ca≈øe.

Though it be a good Plea regularly to the Condition of a Bond, to per≈øue the words of the Condition, and to ≈øhew the performance: Yet Coke ≈øaid, there was another Rule, that he ought to Plead in certainty the time and place, and manner of the performance of the Condition ≈øo as a certain I≈ø≈øue may be taken. As Condition to pay 30 l. to H. S. J. S. and A. S. tam cito as they ≈øhould come to the Age of 21 years: The Defendant Pleads he paid tho≈øe ≈øums tam cito, as they came to Age; The Plaintiff Demurs, becau≈øe its not ≈øhewed when they came of Age, and the certain time of the payment; Its an ill Plea. So if the Condition be for performance of Legacies in ≈øuch a Will; he Pleads performance generally, not ≈øhewing the Will nor what the Legacies are, Cro. Jac. 359, 360. Hally and Carpenter.

If I am bound to enfeoff you of all the Acres in ≈øuch a Fine, and I ≈øhew the Record of the Fine, and averr that I have enfeofft you; this is good: But if it be of Acres in Middle≈øex, he ought to ≈øhew the Acres in certain, 28 H. 8. Dyer 28.

Conditions to deliver all Writings concerning ≈øuch Lands; its a good Plea to ≈øay generally, that he has delivered all the Writings; Doct. placitandi. 62.4 H. 7.12. vid. pluis for Conditions performed pleaded generally, and not ≈øhewing the certainty, 12 H. 8.6. b. Sir John Cutts Ca≈øe, 12 H. 7.14. b.

In pleading Negatively, he ought to Traver≈øe all the Condition; as if a Man be bound to pay for ≈øo much Bread as the Defendant ≈øhall deliver at the common Hall, when≈øoever he ≈øhall be requ≈øted by C. he ≈øhall ≈øay he was not reque≈øted by C. to pay to him any Mony for any Bread delivered at the Common Hall, &c. 4 H. 7.12.
Where the Party is bound with Condition to warrant Land, the Defendant ≈øhall ≈øay expre≈øsly, that he had warranted the Land; for pacific√® gavi≈øus is no Plea, 30 H. 8. Dyer 42.

Condition was, if neither J. S. nor J. B. nor J. G. did not di≈øturb the Plaintiff in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Lands by any indirect means, but by due cour≈øe of Law, then, &c. The Defendant Pleads that neither J. S. nor J. B. nor J. G. did di≈øturb the Plaintiff by any indirect means, but by due cour≈øe of Law. Q. if it be not a Negative Pregnant, i. e. a Negative which implies an Affirmative. Not di≈øturbed by any indirect means, ≈øuch a Plea had been good; or not di≈øturbed contra formam conditionis. Adjurn'.

If I am bound I ≈øhall not go out of We≈øtmin≈øter Hall till night, but tarry in the Hall till night; or that I will not return to Serjants Iun the direct way, but by St. Giles, in an Action brought on that Bond, I may plead in totidem verbis, 2 Leon. p. 197. Dighton and Clark.

Where a certain Duty accrews by the Deed at the beginning, as by a Covenant, Bill or Obligation to pay Mony, this ought to be avoided by a matter of as high a nature (viz.) by Deed, vid. ≈øupr√† tit' Accord pleaded, and, 9 Rep. 78. Peytoes Ca≈øe. Sometimes matter un fair ≈øhall avoid an Obligation, as well as a matter in Writing, as to ≈øay the Feme was Covert de Baron, &c. 4 H. 7.15.

The Defendant Pleads after the Mony became due, he and the Plaintiff did by parol ≈øubmit to an Award, and ≈øets forth the Award and performance per tender: Per Cur. its an ill Plea. Submi≈ø≈øion by parol cannot di≈øcharge a Debt by Specialty, Stiles 350. Ludding and White, Coxal and Sharp. 1 Keb. 937.

Inter alia a Bond may be put in Arbitrament; yet, in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Arbitrament cannot be pleaded in Bar of the Obligation, Q. if the party hath his remedy on the promi≈øe to perform the Arbitrament.
A Bond inter alia may be Arbitrated, and mixt with other things: And where the Award is good, the party mu≈øt re≈øort to Action thereon, 2 Keb. p. 734. Morris and Creech.
A Special Plea in Bar is always to be an≈øwered, with a Special Replication in the point.

Whereas, ≈øuch a Mortgage was made of ≈øuch Land to J. S. &c. if therefore the ≈øaid Land at the day, be redeemed and di≈øcharged from all Tithes, &c. the Defendant Pleads the Clo≈øe was not Mortgaged to J. S. The Plaintiff replies it was Mortgaged; he need not alledge it was not redeemed.

J. S. is Bound to Marry the Daughter of B. at Ea≈øter next. J. S. Pleads in Bar ≈øhe died before Easter, its a good Replication to ≈øay, ≈øhe was living at Ea≈øter day, without ≈øaying he had not Married her, Yelv. p. 24. Bayly and Taylor.
Vid. good Learning as to this Rule ≈øupra Titulo A≈ø≈øignment of a Breach.

In Monox and Warleys Ca≈øe, It was taken as a Rule, that the Replication ought to contain ≈øufficient Cau≈øe of Action, and ≈øufficient Breach of the Condition; or el≈øe the Plaintiff ≈øhall not have Judgment, altho' the I≈ø≈øue be found for him, as in Debt on Bond again≈øt A. and B. A. Pleads Non e≈øt factum, B. Pleads the Relea≈øe of the Plaintiff, and its found the Deed of A. and the Plaintiff hath Relea≈øed to B. The Plaintiff ≈øhall never have Judgment; for upon the Verdict it appears, he hath no Cau≈øe of Action, 2 Leon. p. 100.

div.head: Pleas in Abatement.
div.p: IN Debt on Bond, the Defendant demands Judgment of the Bill; for that the Plaintiff in the Obligation was named J. Thorny de. F. in Com. N. Armig', and in the Declaration was named J. Thorny Armig. and no more. Re≈øpond. ou≈øter awarded, Cro. Eliz. 312. Thornough and Di≈øney.
After Imparlance one cannot plead in Abatement of the Writ, Stiles 187. Weston and Plowden.

Per Stat. 6 R. 2. c. 2. it's provided, that the Original ≈øhall not be laid in one County, and the Declaration upon a Bond made in another County, if ≈øo, the Writ ≈øhall abete: But its no good Plea to ≈øay, that the Bond was made in another County than where its alledg'd in the Declaration, Allen p. 17. Shalmer and Slingsby.

If the Defendant pleads a Plea in Abatement, as in Debt upon Bond, that another was joyntly bound with him, who is in full life not named, and concludes in Bar; Judgment ≈øhall be final again≈øt him, Siderfin p. 189. Burden and Ferrars.

Debt on Obligation again≈øt the Defendant, Knight and Baronet. The Defendant pleads, he never was a Knight, in Abatement. No Amendment granted, but in Nil Cap. per Billam awarded; becau≈øe tho' the Defendant after Bail put in by him≈øelf, generally he cannot plead in Abatement; yet when the
Bai is Special, or put in by another, he may plead in by Abatement. Judgment pro Def. 2 Keb. 824. Sir William Hicks's Ca≈øe.
Pleads, that the Plaintiff, puis darrein continuance, was made a Baronet, Cro. Car. p. 104. Simon Bennet.
A Plea may be a good Plea in Abatement, though it contain Matter that goes in Bar, Med. Rep. 214.
In Debt ≈øur Oblig' again≈øt J. S. de S. it's a good Plea to ≈øay, that there are two Vills S. within the County, and none without Addition, 14 H. 6.8. a.

In Debt ≈øur Bond. The Defendant pleads, that after the Writ purcha≈øed, the Plaintiff had received parcel, and ≈øhews the Acquittance, the Writ ≈øhall abate in the whole; and notwith≈øtanding it's a good Plea in bar, as to this part, Doctrina placitandi p. 5.
Vide pluis in titulo Payment. infra, Payment of parcel, pendant le Suite.

Two bring Debt on Obligation, the Defendant pleads the Obligation was made to them and to one B. and that they three had an Action of Debt depending again≈øt him, and demands Judgment ≈øi actio. Demur. And becau≈øe the Obligation was made to two, upon which they counted, it cannot be intended an Obligation made to three; and if it be a Plea, it's in Abatement of the Writ, and not in Bar. Judgment pro Querente, Cro. Eliz. I≈øham's Ca≈øe.

Debt again≈øt J. S. de D. Yeoman. It's no Plea to ≈øay there are two, J. S. of D. Yeom Sen. and Jun. and none without addition: For the Action accords with the Obligation, which is J. S. de D. Yeoman without di≈øtinction, 9 H. 7.21.

div.head: Pleas after Imparlance.
div.p: IN Debt on an Obligation, the Defendant imparles till next Term, after he may plead, that the Plaintiff is Outlawed: For the King ≈øhall have the Debt on Bond. Aliter in Tre≈øpa≈øs, or Debt, or ≈øimple Contract, 16 Ed. 4.4. a. per Bryan.
Debt again≈øt J. S. de D. The Defendant imparles; he may after ≈øay by Attorny, Upper D. and Nether D. and none without addition, 18 Ed. 4.9. 21 Ed. 4.1. b. contr.

Variance between the Obligation and the Writ, may be pleaded after Imparlance in another Term, for the Bond always remains in Court; but after Imparlance, Variance between the Te≈øtament and Letters of Admini≈øtration ≈øhall not be pleaded; for the Te≈øtament ≈øhall be but once ≈øhewed in Court, 36 H. 6. 32, 33. 38 H. 6.2. 19 H. 6.7.

The Defendant Imparles till another Term, and then he pleads Tender of the Mony at the day and place, and that no per≈øon was there to receive it, and that he is now ready, and ≈øaith not Touts temps pri≈øt; yet it's a good Plea: For he had excu≈øed
him≈øelf of the Forfeiture by this Plea, and no E≈øtoppel ≈øhall be by the Imparlance, to plead that he is now ready, Doct. placitand. 388, 389.

In Debt on Bond, the Defendant imparles Specially, ≈øcil.‚Äî≈øalvis omnibus & omnimodis advantagiis‚Äîand after he pleads the priviledge of the Exchequer, that he was Surveyor there: Per Cur. he cannot plead ≈øo, Siderfin p. 318. Tru≈ø≈øel and Maddin. 2 Keb. 103.
