A Plea in Abatement ought to be pleaded before Imparlance: As, the Defendant to Debt on Bond appears and imparles, and after Imparlance pleads, that he is Earl of Nova Albion in Ireland, and ought to be impleaded by that Name, Stiles p. 187. We≈øton and Plowden.
After Imparlance, the Defendant pleaded in Abatement, that one Vincent, not named, ≈øealed, &c. It's no Plea after Imparlance, and a Re≈øpond' u ‚Ä¢ ≈øter awarded, 2 Keb. 795. Putt and No≈øworthy.

Debt for 300 l. The Defendant after a general Imparlance demands Oyer, and pleads Specially it was but for 30 l. Non allocatur after general Imparlance; then the Defendant pleaded Non e≈øt factum, which was the proper Plea in the Ca≈øe, 1 Brownl. p. 70.
It was Ruled, that after Imparlance in Debt upon Bond, the Defendant ≈øhall be received to plead, that he was always ready to pay; tho' 13 Eliz. 306. Dyer ≈øeems contrary, and was ≈øo urged.
Replicatio Querentis, That the Defendant ought not to be admitted to plead a Variance between the Declaration and the Bond, in abatement, after Imparlance general, Modus Intrandi, p. 200.

div.head: Obligations. Pleadings. Acceptance, Coneord.
div.p: COndition to deliver twenty Quarters of Wheat: The Defendant pleads, that pendente billa the Plaintiff had accepted fifteen Quarter, and demands Judgment of the Bill: No Plea, for it's Collateral, and not parcel of the Sum contained in the Obligation; and if it be a Plea, it is in bar, and not in abatement, Cro. M. 33, & 54 El. Stone ver≈øus Radi≈øh.

I≈ø≈øue is taken, that he had not accepted; now though its no Plea, and ≈øo no I≈ø≈øue; yet its helped by the Statute of Jeofails; and the Plaintiff had Judgment, Cro. El. p. 260. M. 33 & 34 El. Andrews and Kinck.

Debt pro. 7 l. the Defendant pleads ≈øolvit ad diem. The Jury find 50 s. parcel of it paid, and that the Defendant then delivered to the Plaintiff certain Hats to the value of the re≈øidue, which he accepted. It was Adjudged again≈øt the Defendant, for this is no payment, he might have pleaded it ≈øpecially, Cro. M. 35 & 36 El. Tiblethorp and Hunt.

Debt fur ≈øingle Bill: The Defendant pleads, he enfeoffed the Plaintiff of Lands in ≈øatisfaction of that Debt. The Plaintiff demurs: Per Cur. it's a naughty Plea to a ≈øingle Bill; otherwi≈øe, had it been upon a Bond with a Condition to pay Mony, 1 Brownl. 70. Glyver and Lea≈øe.

Debt ≈øur Bond: The Defendant pleads another Bond given to the Plaintiff in ≈øati≈øfaction of that Bond, and acceptance at the day of payment. Ill Plea; for one cho≈øe in Action cannot be given in ≈øatisfaction of another, unle≈øs it were payable at a day before the other Debt, 2 Keb. p. 804. Street and Buckner. 1 Brownl. p. 47. Lovelace's Ca≈øe, Stiles p. 339. Brock and Vernon, More N. 1147. 2 Keb. p. 804. Street and Buckner, Vid. pluis Litt. p. 58. Ene's Ca≈øe, 5 Rep. 44. Lord Cromwell's Ca≈øe, cited in Higgin's Ca≈øe. No, though a Stranger give the Bond, 1 Brownl. p. 71. Hawes and Birch.

If I≈ø≈øue be joyned on the acceptance, and the Plaintiff be Non≈øuit. Q. If this Plea be ≈øuch a Confe≈ø≈øion of the Action, as the Plaintiff ≈øhall have Judgment, Hobart p. 68, 69. B. R. Lovelace and Colket, Randiff and Strutt.

The Defendant pleads, that the Plaintiff after the day of Payment, and before the Writ brought, did accept of a Statute-Staple for the ≈øame Debt, in full ≈øatisfaction of the Obligation. It's an ill Plea; for a Statute is but an Obligation of Record, and cannot drown another which is not of Record, Sir R. Brainthwait's Ca≈øe, cited in 6 Rep. 44. b.
Higgin's Ca≈øe. Vid. Co. Lit. 212. b. 5 Rep. 117. b. contra.

Payment of a le≈ø≈øer Sum, and acceptance in full ≈øatisfaction pleaded; you may either traver≈øe the payment, or the Acceptance; but its more proper to joyn I≈ø≈øue upon the payment, Stiles p. 239. M. 1650. Boys and Cranfield.

Condition to pay 10 l. to a Stranger by Michaelma≈øs. The Defendant pleads payment of a le≈ø≈øer Sum before the day to him. The Plaintiff demurs; the Plea is ill as to a Stranger, 2 Keb. p. 628. P. 22 Car. 2. Chapman and Win.

Debt pro 43 l. The Defendant pleads 39 l. paid before the day, which the Plaintiff accepted in ≈øatisfaction: The Plaintiff joyns I≈ø≈øue, Non recopit in ≈øatisfactionem: The Defendant Demurs, it's ill. He ≈øhould have ≈øaid, Non ≈øolvit, 3 Keb. p. 28 Car. 2. fo. 629. Percival and Colthowe.

The Defendant pleads, the Condition was to pay a le≈ø≈øer Sum at a day, and that before the day he paid in ≈øatisfaction: Per Cur. It's an ill Plea, not having demanded Oyer of the Condition, 3 Keb. p. 708. Mich. 28 Car. 2. Clatch.

The Defendant pleads, That the Plaintiff before the day accepted a le≈ø≈øer Sum in full ≈øatisfaction of a greater. It is a good plea; but then he mu≈øt plead, he paid that le≈ø≈øer ≈øum in full ≈øatisfaction, and that the Plaintiff received it in full ≈øatisfaction, Pinnel's Ca≈øe. 5 Rep. 117. More N. 847. Penny and Cote.

For the manner and tender of Payment it ≈øhall be directed by him that made it. I am bound to pay you 10 l. at We≈øtmin≈øter, and you reque≈øt me to pay you 5 l. at the day in York, and you will accept it in full ≈øati≈øfaction of the whole 10 l. its a good ≈øati≈øfaction of the whole, 5 Rep. 117. Pinnel's Ca≈øe.

Condition is for payment of 20 l. the Obligor at the time appointed, cannot pay a le≈ø≈øer Sum in ≈øatisfaction of the whole. But if the Obligee do receive part at the day, and thereof make Acquittance under his Seal in full ≈øatisfaction of the whole, its ≈øufficient; for the Deed amounteth to an Acquittance of the whole, Co. Lit. 212. b. Pinnei's Ca≈øe, 5 Rep. 117. b.
If the Obligor pay a le≈ø≈øer Sum either before the day, or at another place than is limited by the Condition, and the Obligee receive it; this is a good Satisfaction, Ibid.
Not only things in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion may be given in Satisfaction; but al≈øo if the Obligee accept a Statute in Satisfaction of the Mony, its a good Satisfaction. Ibid.

Obligor is bound to pay 100 Marks at a day, and at the day the parties Account together, and for that the Obligee did owe 20 l. to the Obligor, the Sum is allowed, and the re≈øidue of the 100 Marks paid: This is a good ≈øatisfaction, tho' the 20 l. was a cho≈øe in Action, and no payment was made thereof but by way of Retainer or Di≈øcharge, Co. Lit. 213, &c.
Condition to make a≈ø≈øurance of Lands to ≈øuch u≈øes. The Defendant pleads, he made a Feoffment to other u≈øes, which the Plaintiff accepted. Ill Plea, 1 Brownl. 60. Potter and Tomp≈øon.

Where the Condition is for payment of Mony, if the Obligee accept an Hor≈øe, &c. in ≈øatisfaction, its good: But if the Condition were for the delivery of an Hor≈øe, &c. there tho' the Obligee accept Mony or other thing for the Hor≈øe, &c. its no performance of the Condition: So a Condition is to acknowledge a Recognizance of 20 l. &c. if the Obligee accept 20 l. in ≈øatisfaction of the Condition, yet the Condition is broken. So of all other Collateral Conditions, Co. Lit. 212. b.

If a Condition be to pay Mony to a Stranger, if the Stranger accepts an Hor≈øe, or other Collateral thing in ≈øatisfaction, its no performance of the Condition; for there the Condition mu≈øt be ≈øtrictly performed: But if the Condition be, that a Stranger ≈øhall pay to the Obligee a Sum of Mony, the Obligee may receive an Hor≈øe in ≈øati≈øfaction, Co. Lit. ibid.

To Debt on Bond, the Defendant pleads, it was agreed, (before the Forfeiture of the Bond for 300 l.) between the Plaintiff and divers other Creditors of the Defendants, that the Defendant ≈øhould a≈ø≈øure divers Lands to be ≈øold, and the Mony to be paid, and he a≈ø≈øigned ≈øeveral ≈øums of Mony to them, which they accepted, and avers in
facto that he ≈øold the Lands to them, and made a letter of Attorny to them to receive the Sums of Mony. The Plaintiff demurs; becau≈øe the Indenture ≈øounds in the nature of a Covenant, and if ≈øo, it ≈øhall not be in ≈øatisfaction, being in it ≈øelf no ≈øatisfaction, nor pleadable in ≈øatisfaction of that Debt. Al≈øo admitting it had been a good ≈øati≈øfaction, if performed, yet part thereof not being performed, its no bar to this Action, Cro. Car. 193. Simonds and Mend≈øworth.

A Concord or Verbal Agreement cannot di≈øcharge a Specialty: As a Condition for the performance of Covenants in Articles of Agreement. The Defendant pleads an Agreement between the Plaintiff and him, that he ≈øhould grant 5 l. per Annum for life in di≈øcharge, which Grant he made, and the Plaintiff accepted. Judgment pro Querente, being only a Verbal Agreement.

Cro. Jac. fo. 649. Noys and Hopgood, and ≈øo Cro. Eliz. pag. 697. Hayford and Andrews. If the Defendant pleads before the day of payment, the Plaintiff in re≈øpect of a Tre≈øpa≈øs made by his Bea≈øts in the Defendants Lands, gave him longer day. Its no Plea; for an Agreement by Parol cannot di≈øpence with an Obligation.

Condition to pay 40 l. on Michaelma≈øs-Eve. The Defendant pleads Concord, that if he gave him an Hawk and 20 l. at Michaelma≈øs-day, the Obligation ≈øhould be void; and avers he did ≈øo, and the Plaintiff accepted it. Its an ill Plea; for it appeareth
for Non-payment of the Mony at the day the Bond was forfeited, and ≈øo became ≈øingle, which cannot be di≈øcharged by ≈øuch naked Averment en fait of ≈øuch Acceptance. But,
Acceptance before the day had been a good Di≈øcharge, Cro. Eliz. p. 46. Anonymus.

Condition to pay 11 l. on the 12th of February; the Defendant pleads Accord the 8th of February, that if he paid 8l. on the ≈øaid 12th of February, that he would accept it for 11 l. and pleads Tender at the day, & uncore pri≈øt: Per Cur. Concord is no Plea without ≈øatisfaction, Cro. M. 32 & 33 Eliz. Ta≈ø≈øal and Shaw.
Agreement to pay part, and promi≈øe to pay the re≈øt, no Plea to a Bond, Cro. M. 35 & 36 Eliz. Bal≈øton and Baxter.
Had he pleaded a le≈ø≈øer Sum paid before the day, and at another place, in ≈øati≈øfaction of a greater ≈øum, it had been good, Ibid.

Condition to deliver twenty Quarters of Barly; the Defendant pleads in Abatement, that pendente billa, that the Plaintiff had accepted fifteen, parcel of the ≈øaid twenty. Ill Plea; for it is Collateral, and not parcel of the Sum contained in the Obligation; and if it be a Plea, its a Plea in bar, and not in abatement, Cro. Eliz. 253. Doct. pla. 6. Vid. pluis in titulo Payment infra.

Condition to make a ≈øufficient account of all Rents, Revenues, &c. The Defendant pleads, That before the Fea≈øt, he Let to the Defendant an Hou≈øe, &c. in full ≈øati≈øfaction of all manner of Accounts; to which he agreed and entred. Nul Plea, Dyer 1. Ca≈øe 1. Vid. pluis ibid.

div.head: Payment pleaded.
div.p: OF payment and acceptance of a le≈ø≈øer Sum before the day, in ≈øatisfaction of a greater. Vid. ≈øupra tit. Pleading, Acceptance, Concord, &c.

Payment of parcel, hanging the Writ, is a good Plea to the Writ, 5 H. 7.4.1. an Acquittance of the receipt of part, hanging the Writ, goes to all the Writ. Et Nota, Where payment is not a Plea in bar, receipt pendant the Writ, is no plea to the Writ, Doct. placit. 108.

The Defendant pleads acquittance for parcel; if the Plaintiff acknowledge his own Acquittance, he abates the whole Writ: Per Cokaine, the Plaintiff ≈øhall recover all that the Defendant acknowledged; and as to what he had received, the Plaintiff is to be amerced, 3 H. 6.48.

The Defendant pleads after the day of the Writ purcha≈øed, (viz. ≈øuch a day) he paid to the Plaintiff 60 l. parcel thereof, which he received. Judgment of the Writ. The Plaintiff demurs ≈øpecially, becau≈øe he ≈øhewed not any Acquittance or Relea≈øe te≈øtifying
it. Judgment for the Plaintiff, Cro. Eliz. p. 884. Colbroke and Fo≈øter.
In Debt on a ≈øingle Obligation, payment without acquittance is no plea. Otherwi≈øe in Debt on Obligation with Condition, 28 H. 8. Dyer 25. b. 15 Ed. 4.6. a. 33 H. 8. Dyer. 50. b. 51. a.
Payment with acquittance, pleaded in an Action of Debt on a Bond, is not double; becau≈øe the Acquittance only is i≈ø≈øuable, and the payment is but Evidence, 1 H. 7. 15. b.
If the Plaintiff by Deed had confe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf to be ≈øatisfied of the Debt, though he had received nothing; yet this a good bar, 30 H. 6. tit. Bar 37.5 Rep. Pinnel's Ca≈øe, fo. 117. b.

Condition to pay 70 l. (viz.) 35 l. at one day, and 35 l. at another day, at the Temple-Church. The Defendant pleads payment of the 70 l. at Ludlow, ≈øecundum formam & effectum Conditionis praedict. Verdict pro Querente.

A≈ø≈øigned for Error, for that he ought to have pleaded ≈øeveral payments; but per Cur. its good enough, reddendo ≈øingula ≈øingulis ≈øecundum formam & effectum, &c. Cro. Eliz. p. 281. Fox ver≈øus Lee.

Condition was, to pay 20 l. the 7th day of Mdy, 1558, at the Hou≈øe of the Defendant in S. It was found by Verdict, that the Defendant paid the 20 l. before the 7th day of May, at the ≈øaid Hou≈øe; but not ≈øolvit the 7th day of May. It was Adjudged a good
payment, More N. 400. Bond and Richard≈øon.

Debt on Bond by a Bi≈øhop; the Defendant pleads, he paid the Mony at the day to J. S. Bailiff of the Plaintiff, and by his commandment, and avers that this came to the u≈øe of the Bi≈øhop. This Averment makes the plea double; for if the Bayliff receives this by command from the Bi≈øhop, notwith≈øtanding this doth not come to his own u≈øe; yet this is a ≈øufficient di≈øcharge to the Defendant, 22 Ed. 4.25. a. But,
In Debt on Obligation, payment of the Mony to J. S. by commandment of the Plaintiff, is no plea, without ≈øhewing that the Plaintiff was indebted to him, 27 H. 6. 6. b.

div.head: Where mi≈øtake in pleading the Sum, or the Time, is aided, and where not.
div.p:
IN Debt on Bond of 200 l. Condition to pay 105 l. &c. The Defendant pleads payment of the afore≈øaid 100 l. at the day. The Plaintiff replies quod non ≈øolvit praedict' 105 l. Et hoc petit, &c. and it was found he did not pay the 105 l. Judgment pro Quer', and Error a≈ø≈øigned, for that there is not any I≈ø≈øue joyned, and ≈øo the Verdict ill, and Judgment erroneous: The ≈øaying, Secundum formam & effectum Conditionis ≈øhall not help it, as if it ≈øhould be intended the afore≈øaid 105 l. Cro. Jac. p. 585. Sandback and Turvey. Such a Ca≈øe was in Cro. Car. fo. 593. Derby
and Hemming; and no Repleader could be granted, but Judgment was rever≈øt.

But where the Defendant pleaded to Debt on Bond, payment of 50 l. on the 14th of Jun. 11 Jac. The Plaintiff replies, he did not pay it the ≈øaid 14th day of Augu≈øt, Anno 11. ≈øupradicto quas ei ad eundem diem ≈øolvi≈ø≈øe debui≈ø≈øet, and Verdict found that he did not pay it the 14th day of June; yet 'twas no Error; For the Defendant's Plea was according to the Condition; and the Plaintiffs Replication, quod non ≈øolvit the ≈øaid 14th day was good, and the mi≈ønaming the Month [August] is idle and ≈øuperfluous, & praedicto quarto decimo die had been ≈øufficient. But in the other ca≈øes of mi≈øtaking the Sum, there was another Sum in the Plea of the Defendant, than was in the Condition; and another Sum in the Replication, than is in the Bar; and ≈øo no I≈ø≈øue.

In Debt on an Obligation, the Defendant pleads, Solvit ad diem, & de hoc ponit, &c. where it ≈øhould be hoc paratus, &c. for then the Plaintiff ≈øhould have replied, Non ≈øolvit; Et hoc petit, &c. ≈øo there had been an Affirmative and a Negative. Per Cur. fora≈ømuch as the Plaintiff joyns I≈ø≈øue, and the Jury find he hath paid, its good enough, and aided per Stat. Jeofails; and Judgment was not arre≈øted, Cro. Car. 316. Parker and Taylor. So 3 Keb. 29 Car. 2. p. 764. Helder and Brudnall.

Condition to pay a Stranger at three payments; the Defendant on Oyer pleads payment according to the Condition of another Obligation to the Stranger. The Plaintiff demurs; and the Plea is Ill, becau≈øe the other Bond to the Stranger, is not ≈øet forth, as the particular days of payment, 3 Keb. 612. Nichols and Nichols.

div.head: Relea≈øe Pleaded.
div.p: J. S. makes an Obligation dated and delivered on the fir≈øt of May, and on the fir≈øt of June following, the Obligee makes a Relea≈øe to the Obligor, dated the fir≈øt of March, and delivered the fir≈øt of June, by which he relea≈øeth all Actions ab origine mundi, until the date of the Relea≈øe: Per touts Ju≈øtices, the Obligation is not relea≈øed, Cro. Eliz. p. 14. Sir William Druries Ca≈øe.

T. J. Doth acknowledge him≈øelf fully ≈øatisfied and di≈øcharged of all Bonds, Debts or Dues what≈øoever by T. O. this acknowledgment by Deed is in Judgment of Law a Relea≈øe of all Bonds, tho' the word Di≈øcharge is not properly ≈øaid of the part of Obligee, but of the Obligor, 9 Rep. 52. b. Hickmots, Ca≈øe.

Debt on a Bond not forfeited at the day of payment, being not then come; the Defendant Pleads a Relea≈øe, and found again≈øt him in Arre≈øt of Judgment, it was adjudged for the Plaintiff, for the Defendant did not take advantage of it as he might, but waved
it, and pleaded a collateral matter, which was found again≈øt him, Cro. Eliz. 68. Frishi Ca≈øe.

Debt on Bond, dated the 24 of June, 9 Cor. The Defendant pleads that the Plaintiff the 22 of Feb. 10 Car. Relea≈øed to him all Actions and Demands which he had, &c. to the day of the date thereof: The Plaintiff demands Oyer of the Relea≈øe, which was a Relea≈øe of all Actions unto the 14 of January, before the date of the Relea≈øe; for this mi≈øpri≈øion the Plea was adjudged ill, Cro. Car. 426. Dyer and White.

A Man may not relea≈øe a per≈øonal thing, as an Obligation upon a Condition ≈øub≈øequent, but the Condition will be void, becau≈øe a per≈øonal thing once ≈øu≈øpended is extingui≈øhed perpetually; but a Man may relea≈øe it upon a Condition precedent, for there the Action is not ≈øu≈øpended, until the Condition performed, 1 Rols Abr. p. 412. Barkley and Parkes, adjudged on Demurrer. Where the Relea≈øe was of an Obligation, with a Provi≈øo that he who relea≈øeth this might enjoy 120 l. due by J. S. to the Obligor at a day to come then after; which the Court adjudged a Condition precedent, becau≈øe the 120l. was not due at the time of the Relea≈øe, but at a day to come, 1 Rols Ab. 415. Me≈øme Ca≈øe.

In Debt on a Bond of 200 l. for payment of 104l. at a day, on Oyer and Entry of the Bond and Condition; The Defendant Pleads, the Plaintiff did Relea≈øe praedictum
≈øcriptum Obligatorium, by the name of an Obligation in 200 l. for the payment of an 100 l. Its not a good Plea, tho' it was averred there was no other Bond made, by the Defendant to the Plaintiff; for tho' a greater ≈øum includes a Le≈ø≈øer as to tender, yet the Debt and Duty is entire, and therefore cannot be di≈øcharged by a Relea≈øe of a le≈ø≈øer Sum, Allen p. 71. Chace and Gold.

T. G. Covenants with another, that B. A. a Stranger ≈øhall pay to A. a Stranger and the Covenantee 10 l. per Annum, A. the Stranger takes Buck to Husband, who relea≈øeth the payment; he cannot Relea≈øe it; for this was not any Debt or Duty in Buck or his Wife; they had nothing in it, nor remedy; but for non-payment the Covenantee ≈øhall have an Action of Covenant, Rols Rep. 196. Quick and Harris.

Bond taken in the name of the Plaintiff as Tru≈øtee, for the younger Brothers, from the elder Brother, Conditioned to pay younger Brothers Portions; The Defendant pleads a Relea≈øe of all Actions, Suits, and all Debts on the Plaintiffs account: Per Cur. it mu≈øt be intended of all Debts whereof he hath the ≈øole di≈øpo≈øition, and ≈øo he had not here. Judgment pro Querente, 2 Keb. 530. Stokes and Stokes.

Debt on Obligation, Conditioned to perform Covenants in a Lea≈øe for years: The Defendant pleads Conditions performed: The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns a Breach of non-payment of Rent: The Defendant to this rejoyns
a Relea≈øe of all demands, and per Cur. the Rent is not relea≈øed by this, being a Rent Executory, and not a ≈øum in Gro≈øs; and Judgment pro Querente, Siderfin. Hen and Han≈øon.

Two are bound joyntly and ≈øeverally, a Relea≈øe to the one Obligor is a Di≈øcharge to the other; but a Relea≈øe to an Executor of a joynt Obligor is void, Cro. Car. 551. Dennis and Paine, 1 Keb. 936. Scot and Littleton.

The Defendant pleaded, that he was bound in the Bond, ≈øimul cum R. G. to whom the Plaintiff had relea≈øed all Actions and demands the ≈øaid fir≈øt of May, (which was the date of the Obligation;) the Plaintiff by Replication ≈øhewed that after the Obligation Sealed by R. G. he relea≈øed to him, and that afterwards the ≈øame day the Plaintiff Sealed the Bond: This Relea≈øe per Cur. doth not di≈øcharge the Defendant, Cro. Eliz. p. 161. Mannings and Town≈øend.

Two are ≈øued joyntly and ≈øeverally; the Obligee brings Action again≈øt the one, and makes a Retraxit of his Suit, Q. if this Retraxit is in nature of a Relea≈øe, and ≈øo if pleaded it be a Bar to Sue the other. But in Cro. Jac. 211. Beechers Ca≈øe, its an ab≈øolute Bar, had it not not been for other faults in the entry, Cro. Car. 551. Dennis and Paine, March 95. Me≈øme Ca≈øe.
Two are Bound, Obligee relea≈øeth to one, provided, that the other ≈øhall not take benefit of this Relea≈øe, its a void provi≈øo, Lit. Rep. 191.

Debt on Bond, the Defendant pleads a Relea≈øe of all Actions and Suits in Bar. The Plaintiff demands Oyer, and an exception of one Bond was therein contained: The Defendant replies, that was the Bond in Suit, and that the ≈øum excepted and the per≈øon are all one; the Defendant demurs; for Actions and Suits being relea≈øed ≈øerve to no purpo≈øe, the Obligation being excepted: Per Cur. the Obligation it ≈øelf being excepted, all Actions and Suits concerning it are al≈øo excepted, Cro. Eliz. 726. Brook and Wheeler.

The Defendant pleads a Relea≈øe and ≈øets it forth, &c. to be fully ≈øatisfied all Bonds, Debts and dues, &c. and that he (the Obligee) is to deliver all ≈øuch Bonds as he hath yet undelivered to T. O. (the Obligor) except one Bond of 40 l. yet unforfeited, which is for the payment of 22 l. and wherein the ≈øaid T. O. and R. O. his Brother ≈øtand bound to him, and ≈øaith, that he ought not to be barred, for the Obligation of 40 l. ≈øo excepted, and the ≈øaid Obligation hic in Curia prolat' are one and the ≈øame. Re≈øolved, that the ≈øaid exception ≈øhall extend to all the Premi≈ø≈øes, and not only to the clau≈øe of delivery: But by the Plaintiffs confe≈ø≈øion in his Replicacation, it appearing the Bond excepted was joynt, and he bringing it again≈øt the Defendant only, hath abated his own Writ, 9 Rep. 52. Hickmots Ca≈øe.
Relea≈øe of an Obligation, bearing date the ≈øame day, and the Relea≈øe is of all, &c. u≈øque ad diem datus, this doth not di≈øcharge the Obligation, 2 Rol. Rep. p. 255. Green and Wiloox.

The Plaintiff and Defendant ≈øubmitted them≈øelves to Arbitrament; and it was Awarded, that there ≈øhould be a Relea≈øe made of all Reliefs, Duties and Amerciaments, and this Relea≈øe pleaded in Bar to Debt upon the Bond. Per Cur', [Duty] extends to the Obligation, and it ≈øhall be a di≈øcharge of it, Cro. El. p. 370. Rotheram and Crawley.

Condition to pay 71. upon the Birth-day of the Child of J. L. which God ≈øhould ≈øend after the date of the Bond. This is a contingent Debt, and the Condition may not be di≈øcharged; and a Po≈ø≈øibility may not be relea≈øed: Qu. if the Obligation may be, Yelv. p. 192, Neale and Sheffield.

Sir H. Stile, and Tho. Brooke, were joyntly and ≈øeverally bound to W. Tully: After the day of payment incurred, Tho. Brooks makes his Will, and makes Mary Brooks his Wife Executrix, and dies; and after William Tully makes his Will, and by his Will relea≈øeth unto Mary Brooks all the Debts which Thomas Brooks her Husband did owe to him at the time of his death. Per Cur. a Will cannot relea≈øe a thing created by Deed, and ≈øo di≈øcharge Creditors. Q. Stiles p. 286. Stile and Tully. Sir H. Stile could have no Relief in Chancery.

G. was bound to R. with Condition to pay 100 l. but this was in tru≈øt to the u≈øe of M. W. during her life, and after to G. P. G. P. may not relea≈øe the Bond, neither in Law nor Equity, during the life of M. W. But had it been to his own ≈øole benefit, it had been good in Equity, Lit. Rep. 144. Ganford's Ca≈øe.
An Obligation to perform all Covenants in a Lea≈øe. The Le≈ø≈øor relea≈øeth to him all demands before any Covenant broken, this is no relea≈øe of the Obligation, Lit. p. 87.
Two are joyntly and ≈øeverally bound in an Obligation; if the Obligee relea≈øeth to one of them, both are di≈øcharged, Co. Lit. 132. &c.

A relea≈øe of all Actions by the Obligee before the day of payment, he ≈øhall be barred of his Duty for ever; for it is debitum in prae≈øenti, &c. and the right of the Action is in him. So by a relea≈øe of all demands, Co. Lit. 291. b. 292. b.

The Defendant pleads, that the Plaintiff by Indenture, &c. did Covenant, that he would not ≈øue the Bond before Michaelma≈øs. Judgment ≈øi actio. Cur. pro Querente. its only a Covenant, and ≈øhall not enure as a Relea≈øe; and is not to be pleaded in bar, but the party is put to his Writ of Covenant. Had it been a Covenant he would not ≈øue at all, it might have mounted to a Relea≈øe, Cro. Eliz. p. 352. Deux and Jeffreys, 1 Ander≈ø. 307. me≈øme Ca≈øe.

But if the Defendant pleads, that the Plaintiff by Indenture ≈øhew'd, Covenanted, that if he paid 100 l. at, &c. that then the Obligation ≈øhould be void, and avers he paid it; its a good Plea in bar, and he ≈øhall not be put to his Writ of Covenant by circuity of Action, Cro. Eliz. p. 623. Hodges and Smith.

An Obligation bears date the 1st of May, and is delivered 20 days after, and the Obligee makes a Relea≈øe the 2d day of May, and delivers this the ≈øame day, this Relea≈øe is no bar of the Obligation: But in this ca≈øe, if the Obligee will bring his Action, and count on an Obligation bearing date the 1≈øt of May, and doth not ≈øay that this was primo deliberat' the 20th day, the Defendant ≈øhall bar him by the Relea≈øe; for that the Relea≈øe was made after the fir≈øt day, ≈øcilicet the ≈øecond: And the Plaintiff ≈øhall not reply and ≈øhew the fir≈øt delivery of the Obligation was the 20th day, for that this is a departure; for he ought to have alledged this at the beginning, and ≈øo it ≈øhall be taken, that the Obligation was delivered according to the purport of the Obligation, 5 H. 7.27. a.

J. S. was bound, that J. D. the Apprentice ≈øhould make an account, and pay Moneys; and afterward the Obligee per Deed relea≈øeth to the Servant, and not to the Obligor. If the Relea≈øe were made before any Forfeiture, the Obligation is ≈øaved, and the Relea≈øe may be pleaded; but otherwi≈øe if after Forfeiture, becau≈øe an Obligation once forfeited,
cannot be ≈øaved by any Act or Relea≈øe made or done to a Stranger, 3 Leon. 45. Anonymus.

div.head: Pleadings. Tender, & Uncore prist.
div.p: TEnder at the day and place, of the Mony; and the Plaintiff refu≈øed it, and the Mony brought into Court. The Plaintiff joyns I≈ø≈øue, that there is no Tender and Refu≈øal. Verdict pro Def, the Plaintiff hath lo≈øt his Mony, for it is a Refu≈øal on Record, and the Defendant mu≈øt have his Mony out of Court, Stiles p. 388. M. 1653. Benikin and Herrick.

If the Obligor tender the Mony at the day and place, and the Obligee refu≈øeth it, In debt ≈øur ceo Oblig'. if the Defendant pleads Tender and Refu≈øal, he mu≈øt al≈øo plead he is yet ready to pay it and tender the ≈øame in Court. Aliter, if it were to be paid to a Stranger. But if one is bound in 200 Quarters of Wheat, to deliver 100 Quarters, if the Obligor tender at the day 100 Quarters, he ≈øhall not plead Uncore pri≈øt, for they are bona peritura; but the Sum of Mony is not lo≈øt per Tender and Refu≈øal, becau≈øe its a Duty and part of the Obligation. Where the Condition is collateral to the Obligation, (that is) not parcel of it, there Tender and Refu≈øal is a perpetual bar, and he ≈øhall not be driven to plead Uncore pri≈øt: As a man is bound in 100 l. to deliver Corn or Timber, to perform Award; as a man is bound by
Award to pay 20 l. &c. Co. Lit. 207. Ander≈ø. p. 4. Pannel and Neal. Dyer 1 Eliz. 167. 9 Rep. 97. Peytoe's Ca≈øe. Vid. Doct. placitand', p. 389, 390, 391. 1 Brownl. 61.

If a man make a ≈øingle Bond or acknowledge a Statute or Recognizance, and afterwards makes Defeazance to pay a le≈ø≈øer Sum at a day, if the Obligor or Conizor tender it at the Day, and the Obligee or Conizee refu≈øe it, he ≈øhall never have any remedy by Law to recover it; becau≈øe no parcel of the Sum contained in the Obligation or Statute, the Defeazance being made at a time after, Co. Lit. 207. Vid. More N. 114.

Condition to perform Covenants by a Stranger, one whereof was to pay 20 l. to the Obligee. The Defendant ≈øaith, The Stranger tendred, and the other refu≈øed, & ne dit Uncore pri≈øt. Bon Plea, 27 H. 8.1. 19 H. 8.12.
If one be bound, that a Stranger ≈øhall make an Obligation to the Obligee, it ≈øufficeth to ≈øay that the Stranger tendered this and the Obligee refu≈øed it, without ≈øaying Uncore prist, 10 H. 6.16.

Condition was, If a Stranger paid the Mony at T. then, &c. He pleaded a Tender by the Stranger, and ≈øaith not Uncore prist: per Cur. its no bar; but if they were joyntly bound, it would be well enough, 2 Keb. 178 Browne's Ca≈øe.

If Mony be tendered, and none ready to receive it; and after he to whom the Mony is paid, demands the Mony, and the other
refu≈øeth, an Action is brought and Tender pleaded; yet the Defendant ≈øhall pay Damages from the time that the Mony was demanded, 1 Brownl. p. 71.
After Imparlance, in Debt ≈øur Bond, the Defendant ≈øhall be received to plead, he was always ready to pay, Winch. p. 4. Doct. placitandi 388, 389.

A Bond to pay 500 l. The Defendant pleads (after Imparlance) Tender at the day place, and that none was there to receive it, and that he is yet ready to pay. The Plaintiff demurs, becau≈øe he doth not plead touts temps prist; and although he tendered it at the day, whereby he ≈øaved it for the time; yet if he doth not plead touts temps pri≈øt, it ≈øhall be intended he hath forfeited his Obligation. Q. If it be a good Plea. Vid. Cro. Jac. p. 617. Steward and Coles.

The Defendant pleads Tender at the day, and Touts temps pri≈øt. The Plaintiff received the principal ≈øum in Court, and Judgment to acquit the Defendant of the ≈øum received. And the Plaintiff to have Damages alledgeth a demand of the Mony from the Defendant; and thereupon it was demurred, and Adjudged again≈øt the Plaintiff: For if the Plaintiff would have Damages, he ought not to receive the Mony, but to ≈øuffer it to remain in Court; for after Judgment, Quod eat inde ≈øine die, no I≈ø≈øue can be taken, Cro. Jac. 126. Harrold and Clothworthy.

Cro. El. p. 73. Allen and Andrews; where he need not plead Uncore pri≈øt, where an Obligation is made, and afterwards a Defeazance is made thereof, if he pay a le≈ø≈øer ≈øum, &c. he needs not ≈øay Touts temps pri≈øt; for by the Tender he was di≈øcharged of all, Cro. Eliz. 755. Cotton's Ca≈øe.

Debt on Bill to pay 50 l. on demand, and on Non-payment the Defendant to pay 100 l. Action is brought for the 100 l. The Defendant pleads there was no demand. The Plaintiff demurs; and per Cur. the Action is a demand of the 50 l. but no cau≈øe to forfele the 100 l. But the Defendant ≈øhould have pleaded tender of the 100 l. and Uncore pri≈øt. But on Bond on Award, to pay on demand, being Collateral, its lo≈øt ≈øans demand, therefore no Uncore prist need be. But where the Condition of an Obligation is to pay on demand, that is a di≈øtinct Deed from the Bond, and there is no Title to the Forfeiture ≈øans. demand; but the Debt of 50 l. here is not lo≈øt per not demanding, 3 Keb. 577. Rem≈øee and Rutter.

Condition was, that whereas the Defendant was Executor to M. D. that if the Defendant ≈øhould perform, fulfil, &c. the Will of M.D. in all Points and Articles, according to the true intent and meaning thereof, that then, &c. and pleaded further, that the ≈øame M. by his Will bequeathed to J. S. 3 l. He pleads as to the ≈øaid 3 l. he is, and always was ready to pay the ≈øame to J. S. if he had demanded it. The Plaintiff Demurs: Per Cur.
the Plea is well: For this Obligation (the Condition being general to perform the Will) had not altered the nature of the payment of the Legacy, but the ≈øame remains in ≈øuch manner as before, payable ≈øur Reque≈øt, and not at the peril of the Defendant, 1 Leon. p. 17. Fringe and Lewis.

A. is bound to B. to pay 10 l. to C. and A. teners to C. he refu≈øeth, the Bond is forfeited; for the Obligor having taken upon him to pay it, his Refu≈øal cannot ≈øatisfie the Condition. So to enfeoff a Stranger, and he offers to enfeoff him, and the Stranger refu≈øeth, the Obligation is forfeit. Aliter if the Feoffment had been by the Condition to be made to the Obligee, or to any other for his benefit or behoof, there tender and refu≈øal ≈øhall ≈øave the Bond. But if A. be bound to B. with Condition that C. ≈øhall enfeoff D. if C. tender, and D. refu≈øeth, the Obligation is ≈øaved; for the Obligor hath undertaken to do no act, but that a Stranger ≈øhall enfeoff a Stranger. Co. Lit. 209. a.

div.head: Non e≈øt factum. In what ca≈øes Non e≈øt factum is a good Plea; and in what ca≈øes, and where a ≈øpecial Non e≈øt factum may be found.
div.p: IN every ca≈øe where the Obligation is void, he ≈øhall conclude Non e≈øt factum: As a Feme Covert ≈øhall plead Non e≈øt factum; for its void by her. So where a Deed is razed or interlined; ≈øo where the Obligor was not Lettered. Otherwi≈øe, where the Deed is only voidable, for there he ≈øhall ≈øhew the Special Matter, and conclude Judgment ≈øi actio, 1 H. 7.15. Downe's Ca≈øe. As an Infant pleads at the time of making the Bond he was within Age, he ≈øhall not conclude i≈ø≈øint Non e≈øt factum; but Judgment ≈øi actio.

When the Deed is voidable, and ≈øo remains at the time of the Pleading (as in ca≈øe of Sealing a Bond by an Infant, or Dure≈øs) here he cannot plead Non e≈øt factum, but it mu≈øt be avoided by Special Pleading, with conclu≈øion of Judgment ≈øi actio, 5 Rep. 119. Whelpdale's Ca≈øe.

When an Obligation, or other Writing, is by Act of Parliament enacted to be void, the party who is bound cannot plead Non e≈øt factum; but mu≈øt plead this Special Matter, and conclude Judgment ≈øi actio. As on Bond made to the Sheriff again≈øt 23 H. 6. cap. 10. or a Bond made again≈øt the Statute
of U≈øury, 5 Rep. 119. Whelpdale's Ca≈øe. Hob. p. 72, 166.

In all ca≈øes, when the Obligation was once a Deed, and after before Action brought becomes no Deed, either by razure, addition‚ñ™ or other alteration of the Deed, or by breaking off the Seal: In the≈øe ca≈øes the Defendant may ≈øafely plead Non e≈øt factum; for at the time of the Plea, which is in the Pre≈øent Ten≈øe, it was not his Deed, 5 Rep. 119. Whelpdale's Ca≈øe.
If the Condition of an Obligation be altered, or interlined, this ≈øhall avoid the Obligation, as well as the Condition. Aliter in a Defeazance, 28 H. 8. Dyer 27. b.

In Debt on Bond: The Special Verdict was, That the Defendants were bound to the Plaintiff, being Sheriff, in 60 l. Noverint nos, &c. teneri B. Winchcombe Armig', in 60 l. &c. with Condition to appear; and after the Delivery the≈øe words [Vic' Com' Oxon'] were interlined without Notice or Command of the Plaintiff; Et utrum factum praedict' ≈øit factum praedict' Henrici, and Re≈øolv'd per Cur.
1. When a lawful Deed is razed, by which it becomes void, the Obligor may plead Non e≈øt factum, and give the Matter in Evidence; for at the time of the Plea pleaded, it is not his Deed.

2. When any Deed is altered in a Point material by the Plaintiff him≈øelf, or by any Stranger, without the privity of the Obligee, be it by addition, razing, interlineation, or tractation of a Pen through the mid≈øt of
any Material word; by this the Deed becomes void: As, if one be bound in 10 l. and after Sealing 10 l. is added, to make it 20 l. its void. So if the Obligee him≈øelf alter the Deed by any of the ≈øaid ways, though it be in words not Material, yet the Deed is void. But if a Stranger without his privity alter it in a place not Material, it ≈øhall not be void; and ≈øo in the Principal Ca≈øe, the Addition being in a Point not Material per a Stranger. Judgment pro Querente, Benedict Winchcombe's Ca≈øe.
If the Deed be razed in the Date, after the Delivery, it goes to the whole, 5 Rep. 23. Mathew≈øon's Ca≈øe.
If two are bound in a Bond, and the Seal of one is broken off, this Misfeazance, ex po≈øt facto, ≈øhall avoid the Deed again≈øt both, 11 Rep. 27. Henry Piggot's Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleaded Non e≈øt factum Te≈øtatoris: A Special Verdict was, the Te≈øtator was bound in that Bond with two others joyntly and ≈øeverally, and that afterwards the Seals of the two others were eaten with Mice and Rats: The whole Deed is avoided by this, for it is not the ≈øame Deed; and whereas it was joynt at the fir≈øt, now if the Deed ≈øhould ≈øtand good again≈øt the Defendant only, it ≈øhould be his Bond only. It is not an Obligation joynt and ≈øeveral, but joynt or ≈øeveral at the Election of the Obligee, for he cannot u≈øe both, and when by his own Lache≈øs he hath deprived him≈øelf of his Election, the whole Bond is gone:

But in Mathew≈øons Ca≈øe, 5 Rep. the 100 l. are ≈øeveral and not joynt, and therefore if the Seal of one is torn off, it ≈øhall not avoid the Deed as to the others; and there if the Covenantee Relea≈øe to one of the Covenantors, it ≈øhall not di≈øcharge the others, March Rep. 125. Bayly and Garford.

The Defendant pleads, that it was Sealed by him and one W. C. and that after the Sealing the Seal of W. C. was worn off, and after reaffixed, per quod ≈øcriptum praedictum vacuum in lege exi≈øtit: Per Cur. its better to plead this Special matter, than non e≈øt factum: Noy p. 112. Gomer≈øal and Wood.

The Defendant pleads, that at the time of the delivery there was not any day written in the Deed, but a ≈øpace left, and after the delivery the Plaintiff put in a day, and i≈ø≈øint non e≈øt factum: The Plea had been better to have ≈øet forth the Special matter, per quod ≈øcriptum praedict' perdidit effect'; Judgment ≈øi actio Moren. 8.

The I≈ø≈øue was non e≈øt factum; the Jury did find the Defendant did Seal and Deliver it, but that after the day of the I≈ø≈øue joyned, the Seal was pulled off from the Obligation. Judgment pro Querente, Cro. Eliz. p. 120. Michels Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads quod factum praedict' was made and delivered without a date, and afterwards the Plaintiff put a date thereto, and i≈ø≈øint non e≈øt factum; its an ill Plea. For he fir≈øt confe≈ø≈øeth it to be his Deed, by ≈øaying factum praedictum, and afterwards denies it; he might have ≈øaid non e≈øt factum generally,
Cro. Eliz. p. 800. Co≈øper and Turner.
If one confe≈øs an Obligation, and pleads acquittance; he ≈øhall not conclude i≈ø≈øint non e≈øt factum; but Judgment ≈øi actio. 1 H. 7.15.

The Plaintiff counts on Bill Obligatory, made by the Defendant to him, the Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum; the Jury find the Bill was a joynt Bill made by the Defendant, and another to the Plaintiff: Per Cur. its an ill plea, but he might have pleaded in Abatement of the Writ, 5 Rep. 119. Whelpdales Ca≈øe.
The Defendant pleads the Obligation was made to another and not to the Plaintiff; its ill, for it amounts to non est factum, Siderfin p. 450. Gifford and Perkins. 2 Keb. 633. Me≈øme Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum; Jury in Special Verdict find the Bill in haec verba. Whereby it appears, that the Defendant and J. S. Sealed the Bond and were joyntly obliged, and the ≈øaid J. S. yet alive; Per Cur. adjudged pro Querente, Cro. Jac. p. 152. Stead and Moone.
Three are bound conjunctim and divi≈øim; in an Action again≈øt two of them, they may plead non est factum, 14 Eliz. Dyer 310.

A Stranger to a Deed ≈øhall not plead a Special non e≈øt factum, as that the Seal is ≈øevered from the Deed and i≈ø≈øint, &c. but he ought to plead riens pa≈ø≈øa per le fait. 1 Rols Rep. 188. More and Waldron. If the Deed of another be pleaded again≈øt a Stranger, he may not plead non e≈øt factum, 20 Ed. 4. 1. a.

If an Obligation be delivered to another to the u≈øe of the Obligee, and this is tendered to him, and he refu≈øeth it; now the delivery hath lo≈øt its force, and the Obligee may never after agree to this, and therefore the Obligor may ≈øay non e≈øt factum. So if the Obligation be made to a Feme Coverr, and the Baron di≈øagree to it, the Obligor may plead non e≈øt factum; for by the refu≈øal the Bond hath lo≈øt its force, and becomes no Deed, 5 Rep. 119. Whelpdales Ca≈øe, 1 Ander≈øon 4 Tawes Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads that he was Illiterate, and that the Bond was fa≈øly read to him; and further, that this was delivered as an E≈øcrow, and the Condition not performed, and i≈ø≈øint non e≈øt factum, this per Cur. is not double, becau≈øe he concludes non e≈øt factum, 38 H. 6. 26, 27.
Pleading non est factum upon delivery as an E≈øcrow, and Conditions not performed, vid. ≈øupra. Title Delivery.

If a Man be Illitered, and the Deed is not read to him, or read in other words, or the effect declared in other form then is contained in the Writing; he ≈øhall avoid this, and plead non e≈øt factum, 2 Rep. 9. Thoroughgoods Ca≈øe.
If a Man be Lettered and is Blind, and the Deed is read to him in other manner, he ≈øhall avoid the Deed.

C. is bound to pay Mony to two joyntly, one dies, the other Survives and dies, and makes Executors. Executors brings Action
ver≈øus C. and declares on the Bond made to the Te≈øtator and another, and Avers not the the Te≈øtator Survived. The Defendant pleads non est factum: Ill Plea, for it was his Deed, and the matter of variance goes to the Abatement of the Writ, and not to the Action; and its too late for the Defendant to take advantage of it, Stiles p. 78. Holdich and Chace.
If the Defendant had demanded Oyer of the Deed and entred it, he might have demurred as to the Declaration, Allen p. 41. Me≈øme Ca≈øe.

Debt on Bond, the Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum; The Jury find Specially, the Plaintiff declares on an Obligation dated the 24 day of the Month, and they find the Obligation was ≈øealed and delivered the 27 day, but bears date the 24 day; & utrum this ≈øhall be accounted the ≈øame Obligation on which the Plaintiff declares: It ≈øhall be accounted the ≈øame, and this is a Plea in Bar, and not in Abatement, Stiles p. 414. Hill. 1654. Leake and Reynolds. So

Goddard port Debt on Obligation made to his Inte≈øtate dated the 4 of Apr. 24 Eliz. The Defendant pleads, the Inte≈øtate died before the date of the Obligation, and ≈øo not his Deed; the Jury found, the Defendant declared this as his Deed the 30 July, 23 Eliz. But that this was dated as before, and that the Inte≈øtate was living the 30 July, but not the 4 of Ap. Per Cur. it is his Deed; for tho' the Obligee in pleading may not alledge the delivery before the date, for that
he is e≈øtopt to take Averment again≈øt a thing expre≈øt in the Deed, yet the Jury are not ≈øo e≈øtopt; Mi≈øtake of the date of an Obligation ≈øhall not hurt upon non e≈øt factum pleaded, 2 Rep. 4. Goddards Ca≈øe.

Debt on Bond, which was ≈øet forth to be made the 15 of Nov. 25 Eliz. The Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum; the Jury find Specially, that it was dated the 15 of Nov. 23 Eliz. but it was not ≈øealed and delivered till the 18 of Nov. 26 Eliz. Et ≈øi, &c. Per Cur. this Verdict is found for the Plaintiff, the I≈ø≈øue being Generally non e≈øt factum, it appears to be his Deed; but peradventure by Special Pleading, he might have helpt him≈øelf, Cro. Jac. 136. Lady Lane ver≈øus Pledal.

Special Verdict find, the Plaintiff hath declared on an Obligation made to him≈øelf only, without ≈øpeaking of any other joynt Obligee, and that the Plaintiff as Survivor hath brought the Action; on non e≈øt factum pleaded, if it ≈øhall be ≈øaid, the Deed of the Defendant in manner as the Plaintiff hath declared: Per Cur. the Plaintiff ought to have declared of the Special matter; non est factum in this ca≈øe is no good Plea; for he hath not pleaded it re≈øpective as to the Obligation, but Generally non est factum ≈øuum; which refers to the Obligor only; and the I≈ø≈øue is not whether he made the Deed to the Plaintiff or not, but Generally whether he made it at all; this Plea non est factum hath not any re≈øpect to the Obligee; for if the
Obligee be a Monk, and be another per≈øon who bears the Name of the Obligee, yet in ≈øuch ca≈øes, the Obligee cannot ≈øafely plead non est factum: Aliter Where one is Sued who bears the Name of the Obligor, 1 Leon. p. 322. Ca≈øe 453. Dennis and St. John.

W. S. was bound to H. by the Name of J. S. and on that Obligation the Action was brought again≈øt him by the Name of W. S. and he pleaded non e≈øt factum, and the Special matter was found, and it was Ruled, that upon the Verdict the Plaintiff ≈øhould not recover; but the be≈øt way for the Plaintiff was, to Sue the Defendant by the Name by which he is bound, and then if he appear and plead ut ≈øupra, he ≈øhall be concluded by the Obligation, 10 Eliz. Dyer 279.
Bond on Covenants, ≈øome are void, and ≈øome are not; how he ≈øhall conclude his Plea, 14 H. 8.27, 28.

Sir Edward A. was bound in an Obligation by the Name of Sir Edmond, and ≈øub≈øcribed that with the Name of Edward: In Debt brought again≈øt him he pleads non e≈øt factum, Per Cur. he might well plead that, for it appears that he is not named Edmund; and the Original again≈øt him was Command Edward alias Edmond, and that's not good, for a Man cannot have two Chri≈øtian-names; but if he hath another Name at Confirmation, he mu≈øt be ≈øued by that, 2 Brownl. p. 48. Sir Edward A≈øhfeilds Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads it was delivered as an E≈øcrow, and i≈ø≈øint non est factum, & hoc paratus e≈øt verificare: The Plaintiff demurs, per Cur. this is a Plea that may conclude either way, and is mo≈øt u≈øual with this conclu≈øion; tho' generally upon a general Negative Plea, mu≈øt be to the Country, as non a≈ø≈øump≈øit infra ≈øex annos. Judgment for the Defendant, 3 Keb. 142. Manning and Bucknal.

The Defendant ≈øaith, tempore confectionis ≈øcripti, there was J. P. the Father, and J. P. the Son, the Plaintiff in full life, and that he ≈øealed and delivered to J. P. the Father, and not to J. P. the Son; Judgment ≈øi actio; its a good Plea, and he need not ≈øay non e≈øt factum again≈øt the Son, 16 H. 7.7. vid. ≈øupra; Siderfin 450. Giffords Ca≈øe, contra.

A Man was bound to Randolf, and in Action brought, he declares he was bound Randulfo: The Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum, and adjudged it was not his Deed, for that Randulf and Randolph are two Names di≈øtinct, per Co. in 1 Rols Rep. 271. cited in Lumlies Ca≈øe.
Debt brought upon two Obligations, the Defendant pleads non ≈øunt facta, or per minas, its good by one Plea, Noy. 132. Dentons Ca≈øe.
If the Defendant pleads non est factum, and further demurs upon the Obligation, the Demurrer is void, per Pri≈øot. 35 H. 6.9. b.
After non e≈øt factum pleaded, the party ≈øhall give the Special matter in Evidence, 11 Rep. 26. Piggots Ca≈øe, 2 Mary Dyer 112.

Debt ver≈øus G. B. Executor of S. B. on a Bond made by S. B. the Defendant vim & injur', &c. & dicit quod ≈øcriptum praedictum non est factum ≈øuum. There is no mention made of S. B. in all the Bar, and therefore ≈øuum cannot refer to him, but being after a Verdict, and found to be his Deed. Pro. Querente, Latch. p. 123. Bakers Ca≈øe.
Where a Deed is Enrolled, the party may not plead non est factum, but he may ≈øay Riens pa≈ø≈øa per le fait, 9 H. 6.60.

Upon non e≈øt factum pleaded, and found again≈øt him that it was his Deed; the Judgment was entred, quod ≈øit in mi≈øericordia, where it ought to have been quod capiatur: Per Cur. this is a manife≈øt Error. If the Executor plead non e≈øt factum, mi≈øericordia ≈øhall be entred, 2 Bul≈øt. 230. Jones and Cro≈øs, 1 Keb. 196. Elli≈øons Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum, and at the Ni≈øi prius relict√¢ verifications cognevit actionem. Judgment that the Plaintiff ≈øhall recover, and the Defendant in mi≈øericordia and not quod capiatur, Noy. p. 4. Bavage and Clarke.

div.head: E≈øtoppels in Pleading.
div.p: Vid. Supra tit' E≈øtoppells.

COndition, if Obligor pay all ≈øuch ≈øums which he was obliged to pay by his ≈øeveral Writings Obligatory: The Defendant ≈øaith, there was not any Wrintings Obligatory, by which he was to pay any ≈øum. No Plea, he is e≈øtopt to ≈øay ≈øo again≈øt the Condition, More n. 75.

Condition to pay all Legacies which J. S. had Bequeathed by his Will; the Defendant ≈øhall be e≈øtopt to ≈øay J. S. made no Will; but he may plead, he gave not any Legacies by his Will, More n. 555. Paramor and Daring.
Plea per dure≈ø≈ø. vid. title dure≈ø≈øe ≈øupra.
Pleas by the Heir to the Bond of his Ance≈øtor
Vid. ≈øupra titulo. Actions of Debt again≈øt the Heir.

div.head: Outlawry Pleaded.
div.p: THe Defendant pleads Outlawry to the Plaintiff, and concludes in Abatement. The Plaintiff pleads null tiel Record; the Defendant had a day to bring in the Record and failed; and becau≈øe it was in Debt on Obligation, in which Outlawry goes in Bar, he failing of the Record, the Plaintiff had Judgment, Cro. Eliz. 203. Smith and Bernard.

The Defendant pleads Outlawry in the Plaintiff, and ≈øhews it in certain; the Plaintiff pleads nul tiel Record; in the mean time the Plaintiff rever≈øeth the Outlawry: The Defendant ≈øhall not be condemned, but a Re≈øpondeas ou≈øter. Failer of the Record not peremptory, the Defendants Plea being true at that time, Yelv. p. 36. Green and Ga≈øcoigne, 1 Browel Rep. p. 83.

The Defendant pleads Outlawry of the Plaintiff, and ≈øhewed the Outlawry in certain, by the name of J. S. of D. in the County of, &c. The Plaintiff ≈øhewed, that at the time of the Suit begun again≈øt him, the ≈øaid J. S. upon which the Outlawry was pronounced, was dwelling at S. ab≈øq' hoc that he was dwelling at D. Per Ander≈øon, its a good Replication to avoid the Outlawry without a Writ of Error; for he cannot be intended the ≈øame Per≈øon, 1 Leon. p. 87. Anonimus.

In Debt on Bond: The Defendant Imparles till next Term; after he may plead that the Plaintiff is Outlawed, for the King ≈øhall have the Debt on Bond; aliter in Tre≈øpa≈øs or Debt on ≈øimple Contract, 16 Ed. 4 4. a. per Brian.

The Defendant pleads Attainder of him≈øelf, after a Debt due to the Plaintiff; its no Plea, More n. 982. Hall and Tru≈ø≈øel, Bro. Eliz. 516, Bani≈øter and Tru≈ø≈øel. 2 Ander≈øon, 38, 45. Me≈øme Ca≈øe.
The Defendant pleads, at the time of the Obligation made he was non ≈øanae memoriae; its non Plea, Cro. Eliz. p. 398. Stroud and Mar≈øhal.
The Defendant pleaded, that the Plaintiff is a recu≈øant Convict, in Bar, Litt. Rep. 235. Rooksby ver≈øus Bridge.

Debt upon Obligation in Norwich: The Defendant confe≈øt it to be his Deed, but according to the Cu≈øtom there prayed quod inquiratur de ‚Ä¢ debito; and the Inque≈øt was awarded and returned, and found to a certain ≈øum, for which ≈øum the Plaintiff had Judgment to Recover; this was a≈ø≈øigned for Error: But becau≈øe it was done according to the Cu≈øtom it was not Rever≈øible, Cro. Eliz. 894. Grice's Ca≈øe.

In Debt on Obligation again≈øt the Lord Monteagle: The Defendant pleads his Peerage, and prays to be Di≈øcharged: Per Cur. Plead in chief, this is but a Dilatory Plea, Stiles p. 257. Lord Monteagles Ca≈øe.
Arbitrament pleaded in Bar.
Vid. Supra titulo, Rules of Pleading.

div.head: Foreign Plea.
div.p:
THe Condition was, that in ca≈øe the Ship were Ca≈øt-away in the Voyage, and did not return, it ≈øhould be void. The Action was laid in London, and the Defendant pleaded ≈øhe was Ca≈øt-away at Falmouth: Its ill; had the Plea been local it ought to be ≈øworn: The Action being Tran≈øitory,
the Defendant ≈øhall not by any thing Tran≈øitory alter the Venue; but ought to alledge the Ship was Ca≈øt-away at St. Maria de Arcubus in Warda de Cheap, in the ≈øame County the Action is brought, 1 Keb. 750. Collins's Ca≈øe.

The Declaration is, that the Obligation was at Barn≈øtable, and the Plea is, that it was at Chichly, and payment alledged there, which is a Foreign Plea. The Plea was not ≈øworn, nor demurred to, but received, and Day given to ≈øwear it; and for not ≈øwearing it accordingly, Judgment is given by default, whereas it ought to have been by Nihil dicit for want of a Plea. And per Rolls, If one plead an In≈øufficient Plea, although it be a Foreign Plea, its not nece≈ø≈øary it ≈øhould be ≈øworn. Stiles p. 200. Wyatt and Harbye.

In a Corporation Court, if the Defendant plead a Foreign Plea, which is Collateral, (as in Debt on Bond) he pleads a Relea≈øe made in a place out of the Juri≈ødiction, it need not be received without Oath. But if in Covenant or Debt, for Mony to be paid in another place, he pleads payment accordingly, or the Covenants performed in a place limited, which is out of the Juri≈ødiction, it ought to be received without Oath, Lit. p. 236 Corporation Court.

Condition for performance of Covenants: Breach a≈ø≈øigned for Non-payment of Rent. The Defendant pleads performance till ≈øuch a day, and that the Plaintiff entred in Surry, where the Lands are lea≈øed. But the Action
being in B. R. the Court made him ≈øwear his plea; yet becau≈øe the Council offered to try it by Nil debet, which is no Plea, but by Con≈øent, which the Plaintiff refu≈øed, the Court allowed the Plea, 2 Keb. p. 386. Jones and Comport.

Debt on Bond in Bri≈øtol; Recovery pleaded in the Kings Bench, the Plea mu≈øt be ≈øworn; and though it be ≈øworn, if they have cau≈øe to pre≈øume it not true; they may refu≈øe it, Siderfin in Knights and Pitt's Ca≈øe, fo. 330.

div.head: Foreign Attachment pleaded.
div.p: THe Defendant pleads Foreign Attachment in London to Debt on Bond: The Plaintiff demurs;
1. Becau≈øe the Defendant had Attached Mony in his own hands by way of Retainer.

2. The Cu≈øtom is in London, that the Recoveror ought to find Sureties, that if the Defendant be di≈øcharged within a year and a day, then to pay the Mony, and it did not appear by the Record that he found Sureties. This was held an incurable Fault, 1 Brownl. Rep. p. 60. Hope and Holman.

L. brought Debt again≈øt H. on Obligation: H. pleads how one J. J. affirmed a plaint of Debt in London again≈øt the ≈øaid L. and by the Cu≈øtom there Attached that Debt now demanded in the Hands of the ≈øaid H. and pleaded the Recovery and Judgment there. The Plaintiff replies, that before
Attachment J. J. brought Debt in the King's Bench again≈øt the ≈øaid L. for the ≈øame Debt; whereupon he made an Attachment whil≈øt the Suit was depending. Et hoc, &c. H. demurs: Per Cur. notwith≈øtanding this that J. J. had commenc'd a Suit in B. R. for his Debt, and the Suit there depending, yet the Debt in the Hands of H. may be Attached: For tho one cannot Attach a Debt in London, for that a Suit is here depending in the King-Bench, as Cro. Eliz. 691. Humfrey and Barnes; yet one who hath conceived an Action here, may affirm a plaint in London for the ≈øame Debt, and may make Attachment of the parties Debt, according to the Cu≈øtom: For there the Debt in que≈øtion is not touched by the Attachment; and the Plaintiff might now have pleaded this Attachment in Bar for ≈øo much of his Debt in the Action brought in the King's Bench, Cro. Eliz. 593, 712. Leuknor and Huntly.

The Defendant pleads, that the Plaintiff was Indebted to him, & conce≈ø≈øit ≈øolvere, and pleads a Foreign Attachment in London. The Plaintiff prote≈øtando quod non habetur tale Record', pro placito dicit, that he, pro diver≈øis denariorum ≈øummis per ip≈øum prafat R. prius debit', non conce≈ø≈øit ≈øolvere the ≈øaid Sum, modo & forma prout: Adjudg'd a good Plea in Bar, for the Debt is well Travelable, Cro. Eliz. 830. Coke and Brainforth.

The Defendant pleads Tender, and ≈øo to I≈ø≈øue; and after the Defendant pleads, that after the Darrein Continuance, Foreign Attachment: Per Cur', its ill; and per Curiam, the Action for the Debt depending in this Court cannot be Attached, 3 Leon. 210. After Imparlance, Foreign Attachment not to be pleaded, 3 Leon. 322. Babington's Ca≈øe.

The Defendant pleads to Debt on Bond of 80 l. that the Plaintiff pendant the Bill brought again≈øt him a Plaint in London, and there by Cu≈øtom had attached 40 l. of a Debt due to the Defendant in the hands of J. S. in ≈øatisfaction of 40 l. due on this Bond, and demanded Judgment of the Bill. Per Cur. its a Plea in Bar, and not in Abatement, for the Plaintiff for this part is to be barred for ever; and this receipt of parcel is lawful, and a Recovery in Law. Aliter of a bare Acceptance, Cro. Eliz. p. 342. May and Middleton.

The Debt follows the per≈øon, and its therefore called a Foreign Attachment, becau≈øe let the Debt ri≈øe where it will, its attachable, if the Debtor cometh, or the Mony be brought into London, 2 Keb. 320. Mollam and Hern.

W. was bound to K. in a Recognizance of 400 l. and K. was bound to W. in a Bond of 100 l. W. (according to the Cu≈øtom of London) affirmed a Plaint of Debt in the Guild-Hall again≈øt K. upon the ≈øaid Bond of 100 l. and attached the Debt due by him≈øelf
to W. in his own hands; and now K. ≈øued Execution again≈øt W. upon the Recognizance, and W. brought Audita Querela, and it was allowed, 1 Leon. 297. Wallpool and King.

An Obligation for an 100 l. on Condition to pay 50 l. before the 25th of March. The Defendant pleads a Foreign Attachment of the 50 l. the 17th of February in the hands of Watts, and a Retorn that it was attach'd; but there was no Scire facias till April after. (Before the day of payment, a Creditor of the Plaintiffs, ≈øcilicet, &c. attaches the 50 l. and gives Security in the Court, according to the Cu≈øtom, to pay the Debt if it be di≈øproved within the year and day.) The Plaintiff demurs, as being no ≈øufficient Attachment being before the Mony was due. The cu≈øtom of London is to attach a Debt before its due, (contrary to 3 Cro. 184) yet it may not be levied till after the time of payment of the Obligation; there is only a ≈øeizure, and a Ce≈ø≈øet Executio till the Mony be due. Al≈øo the party again≈øt whom the Execution is ≈øued, is not to give Security, but to pay the Mony; but the party that ≈øueth the Execution is to give it, to return the Mony, if the Debt be di≈øproved within a year and a day; Al≈øo the Judgment had there is pleadable: Al≈øo per Cur' its a good Bar for the whole; but if it were for part, as 20 l. this Record of the Attachment ≈øhall be pleaded in Bar for part, i. e. pro tanto, Siderfus p. 327. 2 Keb. p. 202. Robins and Standard. Vide Co. Intr. 142. Ra. Entr. 158.

div.head: Pleading to the Juri≈ødiction.
div.p: IN Debt on an Obligation in the Palace-Court, averring neither of the parties were of the King's Hou≈øhold. After Judgment on Non e≈øt factum, the Defendant a≈ø≈øigns for Error, that the Plaintiff was the King's Brazier: To which the Plaintiff demurred; becau≈øe the Defendant by the Record is e≈øtopt to ≈øay that, but ≈øhould have taken I≈ø≈øue on the Averment: Which the Court agreed; as on alledging a Cau≈øe infra, that was out of the Juri≈ødiction; this mu≈øt be pleaded, and cannot be a≈ø≈øigned for Error, 3 Keb. 372. Newnan and Rivet.

Condition to deliver a certain quantity of Tin at a certain place within the Juri≈ødiction of the Stannary: And the Defendant pleaded to the Juri≈ødiction of the Court, that it was a Tin Cau≈øe: The Charters are to the Cau≈øe, and ≈øhall not be re≈øtrained to per≈øons, though the Defendant be not alledged in the Plea, to be a Tinner: It was allowed, 1 Rol. Rep. Pin≈øon and Smale.

div.head: Obligations, Conditions. Recovery pleaded in Bar.
div.p: THree are bound pro toto & in ≈øolido: the Obligee had Judgment to recover again≈øt one of them, and afterwards ≈øues an Action again≈øt the others; this Recovery is not a Bar, becau≈øe no ≈øatisfaction of the Duty; but Execution is a good Plea, 4 H. 7. 8. b. Co. Rep. 6.46. a. Higgin's Ca≈øe.
As long as Judgment remains in force, a man ≈øhall not have an Action on the ≈øame Bond; for the Debt is changed into a higher nature of Record, Cro. El. p. 817. Pre≈øton's Ca≈øe.

An Action of Debt brought by the Executor, on Bond made to the Te≈øtator: The Defendant pleads, that the Te≈øtator in vita ≈øua in Curia de Banco hic recuperavit debitum praedict' cum 40 s. pro mi≈øis (without alledging the Execution) quod quidem Recordum recuperationis, was removed per breve d'Error, & ibid. remanet minim√® rever≈øat'. The Plea was good, 6 Rep. 44. Higgin's Ca≈øe. Aliter if Recovery be by Debt ≈øur Bond in the Courts per Ju≈øtices, Ibid. And though the Recovery be erroneous; yet ≈øo long as it remains in force, it ought to be executed, and when it is Rever≈øed, the Obligee is re≈øtored unto his new Action upon the ≈øaid Obligation. Ibid.

If a man bring Debt upon Bond, and he is barred by Judgment, ≈øo long as the Judgment ≈øtands in force he cannot have a new Action. So when he hath Judgment in an Action upon the ≈øame Bond, ≈øo long as the Judgment remains in force, he ≈øhall not have a new Action. Ibid.

The Defendant pleads, the Plaintiff brought another Action upon the ≈øame Bond in London; to which the Defendant there pleads Non e≈øt factum, and ≈øo found there: And upon this Verdict the Entry was, That the Defendant ≈øhould recover Damages again≈øt the Plaintiff, and the Defendant be without Day; but no Judgment that the Plaintiff Nil capiat per Billam: And ≈øo per Cur', no Judgment to bar the Plaintiff, 1 Brownl. p. 81. Levet and Hall. Vid. 7 Cro. Jac. p. 284.

Debt ≈øur Bond of 600 l. ver≈ø. K. in Bri≈øtol The Defendant pleads a Recovery in B. R. upon the ≈øame Bond, again≈øt the ≈øame Defendant per the Plaintiff. Et hoc paratus e≈øt verificare. The Plaintiff Replies, Nul tiel Record, unde petit Judicium & debitum ≈øuum praedict' ≈øibi adjudicari. The Defendant Rejoyns, Quod habetur tale Record' prout per Record' in B. R. apparet. Per Cur' he that will joyn I≈ø≈øue ≈øur Record, ought to ≈øay, Et hoc paratus e≈øt verificare, prout per Recordum illud‚Äîvel verificare prout Curia hic con≈øideravit‚Äîand ≈øo are all the Pre≈øidents; yet in Error Judgment was affirmed for the Defendant in the Writ of Error, and that the
fir≈øt Judgment ≈øhould be affirmed, notwith≈øtanding it was prout per Record' illius plenius liquet. Siderfin p. 329. Knight and Pitt. Vide 2 Keb. 250, 278.

Two were joyntly and ≈øeverally bound: In Debt brought the Defendant pleads, the Plaintiff recovered again≈øt the other the ≈øame Debt, and had Execution. Its a good Plea, notwith≈øtanding it was not ≈øhewed by what Proce≈øs he had Execution, becau≈øe the Execution is on Record, and ≈øhall be tried by the Record; but if he paid the Monies in Pais to the Plaintiff, and not in Court, it is not an Execution of the Judgment, Mo. N. 91.

The Defendant pleads, That the Plaintiff in the King's Court at Penwarth, brought Debt upon this Obligation again≈øt T. who was bound with him in the ≈øaid Bond joyntly and ≈øeverally, and recovered, and had him in Execution; and that the Gaoler voluntarily ≈øuffered him to go at large. It was Demurred, 1. Becau≈øe he doth not ≈øhew, the Court had power to hold Plea. 2. The Plea is not good in ≈øub≈øtance, for this E≈øcape is no di≈øcharge of the Debt, and therefore the Action lies again≈øt the other, 5 Rep. 86. Blumfield's Ca≈øe. Cro. Jac. 531. Pendavis's Ca≈øe.

Two bound joyntly and ≈øeverally; the Obligee brought Action again≈øt one, and retraxit his Suit. Q. If this be a Bar to ≈øue the other Obligor: But the Retraxit being pleaded in the Court of Record in Poele,
and it not being alledged, that this Court had power to hold Plea per Patent, or Pre≈øcription, It is an ill Plea, Jones p. 451. Denn ‚Ä¢
and Paine.

If a man be bound by an Obligation, and afterwards promi≈øeth to pay the Mony; A≈ø≈øump≈øit lies upon this Promi≈øe, and if he recover all in Damages, this ≈øhall be a Bar in Debt ≈øur le Bond, Co. Lit. p. 240. A≈øhbroke and Snape.

div.head: Venue, Bond where Triable. When the Obligation is made beyond Sea.
div.p: AN Obligation made beyond Sea, may be ≈øued here in England in what place the Plaintiff will; as if it bears date at Bourdeaux in France, it may be alledged to be made in quodam loco vocat' Bourdeaux in France, in I≈ølington in the County of Middle≈øex, and there it ≈øhall be tried; for whether there be ≈øuch a place as I≈ølington, or not, is not Traver≈øable, Co. Lit. p. 261 b.

One ≈øues in the Admirals Court, upon a Bond made in partibus Maritimis Virginiae; and ≈øo he may, if he will, ≈øuppo≈øe the Contract in Virginia; and if he will ≈øuppo≈øe the Contract in England, he may ≈øue here: But if part of the Contract be here, and part beyond Sea in Virginia, or upon the Sea, the Common Law ≈øhall have Juri≈ødiction, 2 Rol. Rep. 492. Capp's Ca≈øe.
Where part is to be done‚ñ™ within the Realm, and part out of the Realm, the Plea ought to be Triable within the Realm.

Condition was for 40 l. to be paid within 14 days next after the Return of one Ru≈ø≈øel into England, from the City of Venice. The Defendant pleads in Bar, that the ≈øaid R. was not at Venice. The Plaintiff demurs; and it was Adjudged a naughty Plea, 1 Brownl. p. 49. Hales and Bell.
Where the Condition contains Matter not Triable, the Condition is void, Mo. N. 201.
The I≈ø≈øue was, the Obligor was never at Rome; but if the Matter is parcel Triable, its good enough. Molineux.

A Declaration upon a Bill dated in patoch' Sanctae Mariae de Arcubus in Lond'; and upon Oyer it bore date at Hamborough: Its triable here, Latch p. 4, 77, 84. Ward and Kid≈øon. Cro. Jac. fo. 76. Higham and Flower.

An Obligation ≈øued in the Admiralty, ≈øuppo≈øed to be made and delivered in Chancery. Per Cur' ≈øuch a Bond may be ≈øued here; but being begun there, we cannot prohibit them: For the Plaintiffs Witne≈ø≈øes may be beyond Sea, 3 Leon. p. 232. Delabreche's Ca≈øe.

Debt on Obligation dated in Surry, brought in London. The Coun≈øel pleaded Stat. 6 R. 2. cap. 2. that all Obligations ought to be ≈øued in their proper Counties, as dated, and prayed Judgment of the Writ. Per Cur' its a frivolous Plea; the Law being clear, that unle≈øs the Obligation appear in the Count,
or on the Pleading, to be out of the County, although it bear date out, its not material where its brought, 1 Keb. 593. Pretty, and Roberts.

Debt on a Bond of 60 l. for the payment of 30 l. 10 s. at Coventry; I≈ø≈øue was taken that the Mony was paid at Coventry; yet by con≈øent of Parties and Paper on the Rule of Court, I≈ø≈øue was found pro Querente at London, and Judgment, but it was rever≈øed for this Error. Con≈øent of parties cannot change the Law, Hobart p. 5. Crow and Edwards.

Recognizance taken before a Judge at Serjeants Inn in Fleet≈øtreet, London, out of Term; the Action was laid in London, and not in Middle≈øex, and good; and the Scire facias ≈øhall be directed to the Sheriff of London; but if it were taken in Court or generally, it ≈øhall be in Middle≈øex, Hob. p. 195, 196. Hall and Winckfield.

div.head: Place of Payment in the Condition.
div.p:
DEbt in Havering in E≈ø≈øex: The Condition was for payment of 20 l. to the Plaintiff at his Hou≈øe at S. in Kent. The Defendant pleads payment at the day, &c. Secundum formam & effectum indor≈øamenti pradict'; and Error was a≈ø≈øigned, for that the I≈ø≈øue was tryed at Havering, and not at S. in Kent. Non allocatur: For when a thing I≈ø≈øuable is alledged, and no place, this ≈øhall be tryed where the Action is brought; and Secundum formam, &c. refers only to the Time, and not
to the Place: For the Place is not material, payment being made to the Obligee; and it appears not but S. in Kent may be in the Juri≈ødiction of Havering, Cro. Eliz. p. 105. Newe's Ca≈øe.

Condition was, if he pay 50 l. at his Hou≈øe at Lockington, in the Pari≈øh of Kilmer≈øton, that then, &c. The Defendant pleads payment, &c. and the Venire i≈ø≈øues of the Venue of Lockington; and good; for it ≈øhall be intended a Village in the Pari≈øh of Kilmerston, for divers Villages may be in one Pari≈øh: But if it had been at his Hou≈øe in Lockington in Kilmer≈øton, then it ≈øhall not be intended a Village, but a place known, Cro. Eliz. p. 117. Pike and Cottington. 3 Leon. 193. Cro. Eliz. 804. Kerchever and Wood.
Payment pleaded apud domum man≈øionali ‚Ä¢ Rectoriae de M. Venue was de M. and good, and M. ≈øhall be intended a Vill.

Condition for the payment of 100 l. at his Hou≈øe in Cheap≈øide, the 21 of June next en≈øuing the date hereof. The Defendant pleads, that on the 21th of January then next following the date of the Condition of the Obligation afore≈øaid, he paid the 100 l. at the Plaintiff's Hou≈øe in Cheap≈øide, Secundum formam, &c. Its good enough, though the Condition hath no date, for the Condition and Obligation are as but one Deed: But becau≈øe its not alledged in what Pari≈øh or, Hou≈øe the Ward is, its Ill, becau≈øe of a Venue and Trial, a Pari≈øh and Ward in London, are as a Vill and Hamlet in other Countries,
Cro. Eliz. pag. 372. Forth and Harri≈øon.

Condition was, that the Defendant ≈øhould pay ≈øo much Mony in an Hou≈øe of the Plaintiffs at Lincoln. The Defendant pleads payment at Lincoln afore≈øaid, and I≈ø≈øue, &c. The Venire was De vicineto Civitatis Lincoln', the Trial is good; and its a Rule, where it doth not appear upon the Record that there is a more proper place of Trial, than where the Trial was, that there the Trial is good; but here is not a more proper place; and it could not be, tryed in the Body of the County, becau≈øe the payment was to be in the City, March. Rep. 124 Thorndike and Turpington.

Debt upon an Obligation in London, again≈øt J. S. of Wakefield in Com' praedicto, Conditioned for the payment of 100 l. at Wakefield. The Defendant pleads payment at Wakefield afore≈øaid in Com' Ebor'. The Plaintiff ≈øaith, Non ≈øolvit, and ≈øo at I≈ø≈øue. The Trial was, De vicineto de Wakefield in Com' Eborum. It was Error, becau≈øe he is named of Wakefield in Com' prad', which ≈øhall be intended London; and the payment at Wakefield afore≈øaid ≈øhall be ≈øo intended; and the words added [in Com' Ebor'] are idle. Cro. Eliz. 867, Sackvill and Roades.

div.head: Venue.
div.p: THe Margent of the Count is Nott', and the Count it ≈øelf contains, that the Obligation was made at the Town of Nott', (which is a County it ≈øelf) on Non e≈øt factum, Venue was of the Town of Nott', and tryed by a Jury of the County: Per Cur' in arre≈øt of Judgment, though the Town of N. be a County of it ≈øelf; yet it may be ≈øome part of the Town may be within the County; and for that po≈ø≈øibility they would not arre≈øt Judgment, 2 Brownl. p. 165. Browning and Shelly.

The Plaintiff declared on a Bond made in London: The Defendant pleads an U≈øurious Contract in Stafford≈øhire, and the Bond made for the ≈øame Contract. The Plaintiff replied, the Bond was made bond ≈øide & non pro u≈øura. The I≈ø≈øue was tryed in the County of Staff. And per Cur' it was well tryed, 1 Leon. pag. 148. Ca≈øe 206. Kinner≈øley and Smart.

The Plaintiff Lea≈øed to the Defendant certain Lands in Cambridg≈øhire, rendring Rent, and the Defendant became bound in a Bond for the payment of the Rent. Debt on the Bond is brought in the County of Northampton, to which the Defendant pleads payment of the Rent, without ≈øhewing the place of payment. It was tryed per Ni≈øi prius at Northampton, and well, 2 Leon. 146. Coney and Beveridge's Ca≈øe.

Debt brought in London, which on Oyer was to perform Covenants, which were to enjoy a Walk in a Fore≈øt. On pleading, the Venue was of the Walk; though the Venue be ill, yet its aided after Verdict, per Stat. 16 ‚Ä¢ 17 Car. 2. cap. 8 2 Keb. 212, 216. Sterk and Bates.
Condition was, that if he appeared ≈øuch a day, it may be tryed per Pais, Cro. Eliz. 131. Hoc and Mar≈øhall.

Debt on a Bond: In the Imparlance-Roll, the Bond was alledged to be made at Newca≈øtle, and in the I≈ø≈øue-Roll it was alledged to be made at York, and tryed; Error was brought. The Court would not grant that the Imparlance-Roll might be amended, 1 Brownl. Rep. 66. Fether≈øton and Tap≈øale.

A Bill Obligatory to be paid within ten days, after J. L. went by five days undivided from London to York, and returned from York, to London. The Defendant pleads, that J. L. did not go five days immediately from London to York, and return from York to London. I≈ø≈øue and Venue was awarded from the Pari≈øh of Bow in Warda de Cheape, where the Bill was alledged to be made, and found pro Quer. Judgment was arre≈øted, becau≈øe it is not alledged to what Pari≈øh in London he Returned; but to London generally, that ≈øo a Venue might have been. 2. As this ca≈øe is, the Venue mu≈øt be from London; ≈øo de corpore Comitatus, and not of the Pari≈øh where the Bill was made, Cro. Jac. 137, 150. Normanvile and Pope.

Debt on Bond, Conditioned to pay 20 l. and ≈øaith not where. The Defendant pleads Solvit ad diem, and Verdict and Judgment: The Court denied to affirm the Judgment, becau≈øe here is no Venue, and ≈øo no Trial. This was in Durham, on Error brought, 2 Keb. 620. Norcliffe and Ander≈øon.

Condition to pay a Moiety of Charges, &c. The Defendant pleads Payment, and ≈øaith not where. The Plaintiff demurs, becau≈øe no Venue can be. Per Hales, no place is here nece≈ø≈øary, the Pleading being in the Affirmative, 2 Keb. 762. Cantor and Hurtnell.
Condition to be paid at his Man≈øion hou≈øe, &c. this may be paid at any place, 3 Bul≈øtr. 244.

In Debt on Bond: Trial in I≈ø≈øue ≈øhall not be ≈øtayed on infra aetatem, but this mu≈øt be pleaded; and the party cannot be aided on Non est factum; but a Feme Covert may, 3 Keb. p. 228. Cole and Delawne.
Debt on Bond in Norwich, and Cognovit Actionem; by cu≈øtom a Writ of Enquiry was awarded de vero debito, and good, 3 Keb. 212. Brightman and Parker, 251. Roger≈øon and Jacob≈øon.

A Man recovers Debt on Bond: If A man will bring Action of Debt for the Sum recovered, he mu≈øt lay it in the County of Middle≈øex, and where the Judgment was given, which hath made Novationem contractus, Hob. p. 196. in Hall and Winkfield's Ca≈øe.

div.head: Joyning I≈ø≈øue on payment.
div.p: COndition to pay tantas denarionum ≈øummas, as he ≈øhould receive by ≈øuch a day: The Defendant pleads payment generally. The Plaintiff replies he did not pay 50 l. ≈øuch a day, & hoc paretu ‚Ä¢ , &c. and good, for the Defendant mu≈øt rejoyn and conclude, Et hoc petit, &c. 2 Keb. 230. Tr. 19 Car 2. Han≈øal and Nur≈øe.

Condition to pay a le≈ø≈øer ≈øum the 24 of June, in ≈øuch a year: The Defendant pleads he paid this praedicto 24 die Junii, quod ei ≈øolvi≈ø≈øe debuit ≈øecundum formam & effectum Conditionis: The Plaintiff replies, quod non ≈øolvit praedictam ≈øummam, &c. pradicto 14 die Augusti, quod ei ≈øolvi≈ø≈øe debui≈ø≈øet; & hoc petit, &c. The Jury find the Defendant non ≈øolvit praedicto 14 die Junii: And the Plaintiff had Judgment: Error a≈ø≈øigned, becau≈øe no I≈ø≈øue joyned: The Plaintiff ought to have replied, quod non ≈øolvit praedicto 14 die Junii, and not 14 die Augu≈øti. Per Cur. its good. Had the Plaintiff replied, quod non ≈øolvit praedicto 14 and omitted Augu≈øt; this had been good; then the addition of Augu≈øt is idle and ≈øurplu≈øage, 2 Rols Rep. 135. Hal≈øe and Bonithan.
Condition, to pay 10 l. 10 s. The Defendant pleads payment of 10 l. Secundum formam, &c. upon which I≈ø≈øue and Verdict pro Querente, and yet Repleader Awarded, Hob. p. 113. Kent and Hall.

div.head: On Colateral Point.
div.p: COndition that the Obligor ≈øhall find three men to go with him to Y. and he ‚Ä¢ urmi≈øeth they went with the Obligee, if the Obligee ≈øaith they did not go with him; this is no I≈ø≈øue; for if one of them fail, the Obligation is forfeited, 4 H. 7.8. per V ‚Ä¢ vi≈øor.

Condition, If M. W. (the Plaintiff) doth not depart out of the Service of the Defendant without Licen≈øe of the Defendant, nor Marry her ≈øelf but with his con≈øent; then if the Defendant ≈øhall pay to the Plaintiff within 28 daies after demand by her made at his Hou≈øe 100 l. that then, &c. The Defendant pleads, that the Plaintiff on the 4 of May, 30 Eliz. departed out of his Service without Licen≈øe: The Plaintiff replies, that 6 of Sept. the ≈øame year, ≈øhe departed out of his Service with Licen≈øe, and that the 4 of Octo. after ≈øhe demanded the 100 l. and he refu≈øed; ab≈øque hoc that ≈øhe departed out of his Service the 4 of May, 30 Eliz. Sans Licen≈øe, and the Writ bear date the 18 of Octob. next after the demand; fo that the Defendant hath not 28 days after the demand, to pay the 100 l. Per Cur. the I≈ø≈øue is taken upon the departure out of the Service, and the Defendant in his Plea hath relied upon it, and the demand is not material, 2 Leon. p. 100. Monings and Warley.

Condition to pay a Robe and an Hor≈øe; one cannot make ≈øeveral I≈ø≈øues, as he paid not a Robe, & hoc petit, &c. he paid not an Hor≈øe, & hoc petit, &c. aliter in Covenant, 2 Keb. 69. Young and Go≈øling.

div.head: Verdict.
div.p:
DEbt on Obligation again≈øt C. per min ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
pleaded, and Verdict, and Judgment in the Court of B. The Jury in a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing off Damages ≈øay, pro mi≈øis & cu≈øtagiis, but do not ≈øay, circa ≈øectam expenditis; and there is no Verdict to warrant the Judgment, and it was Error, Stiles 164. Crible and Orchard.
After non e≈øt factum by one pleaded, the Jury find the Bond ≈øealed by two, it alters not the Bond, but they are as di≈øtinct Deeds, 2 Keb. 872. 881. Zouch and Clay.

Condition for the payment of 300 l. within ≈øix Months after the Death of the E. of Huntingdon: The Defendant pleads the 1 of May. 39 Eliz. the Earl died, and that within ≈øix Months after (viz.) the 1 of Dec. 41 Eliz. he paid the ≈øum: I≈ø≈øue was he did not pay it mode & forma: The Jury found he did pay it the 1 of Dec. 41 Eliz. and ≈øo for the Plaintiff; this was Error; the payment alledged the 1 of Dec. 41 Eliz. is void, it ought to have been enquired, whether he had paid it within the ≈øix Months; and Judgment ≈øhall not be given on his implicit confe≈ø≈øion of Non-payment within the ≈øix
Months, Cro. Eliz. 823. E. Huntington ver≈øus Hall.

The Verdict was non ≈øolvit, the ≈øaid 40 l. ≈øuper quartam dem Octobris, where it ought to have been ≈øupra quartam decimam; Judgment on this Verdict, and Error brought; yet amended, Cro. Jac. 185. Harri≈øon again≈øt Ful≈øtowe.

Condition for the payment of 100 l. by J. A. J. C. and J. V. or any of them, J. A. pleads, that he paid it at the day; the Plaintiff replies, that neither the ≈øaid J. A. J. C. nor J. V. nec eorum oliquis had paid it at the day; the Jury find, that the ≈øaid J. A. had not paid the ≈øaid 100 l. Judgment pro Querente; Error a≈ø≈øigned, becau≈øe the Verdict was not according to the I≈ø≈øue, for it might have been paid by any of the others: Per Cur. its a good Verdict, the addition of J. C. and J. V. not mentioned in the Bar was but Surplu≈øage, and their finding J. A. did not pay the Mony, its ≈øufficient; and if it had been proved that any of the other two had made the payment, the Jury ≈øhould have been directed to find, that the Defendant had paid it by ≈øuch, Cro. Jac. p. 6. Ar≈øcott and Heale.

div.head: Judgment, Co≈øts and Damages.
div.p: WHere the Plaintiff had a Verdict for him, there Judgment is quod recuperet debitum & dampna, and Co≈øts a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Jury, and further de increment' per Cur. But if he had Judgment on non ≈øum informatus, Demurrer, or nihil dicit, the Judgment is, quod recuperet debitum & damna, which include the Co≈øts. In the Common Bench it is, quod recuperet debitum & damna occa≈øione detentionis, 2 Rols Rep. 470. Broad and Nur≈øe. Judgment quod recuperet debitum & 6 s. 8 d. pro damnis occa≈øione, &c. and no mention pro mi≈øis & cu≈øtag. & quod inquir' damna includes both, and ≈øo is the cour≈øe of Entry, Cro. Jac. 420. A≈øhmores Ca≈øe.

The Judgment was, quod recuperet debitum ≈øuum, and doth not ≈øay praedict', its good enough; there is but one Debt, and the ideo in the Record, implies it to be the ≈øame Debt, Stiles 251. Port and Midleton.
