The Court may tax Damages without a Writ of enquiry in Debt on a Judgment upon Bond, Siderfin p. 442. Roo and Ap≈øley, H. 21. and 22. Car. 2.

Action of Debt on ≈øeveral Obligations, having but one Count and ≈øeveral I≈ø≈øues, ≈øome found for the Plaintiff, and ≈øome for the Defendant, and ≈øeveral Damages, but intire Co≈øts. It was prayed that Judgment may be rever≈øt as to part: But a Judgment cannot be rever≈øt in part, neither as
to per≈øons or things, and Hobart p. 6. Miles and Jacob denied to be Law, 1 Keb. 232. Anonymus.

Debt ≈øur Obligation of 16 l. Plantiff declares ad damnum 10 l. On non est factum, found pro Querente: The Jury gave the Plaintiff Damages 9 l. be≈øides the 16 l. and he declares but to his Damages of 10 l. and ≈øo it exceeded: But Judgment pro Querente, for the Court may increa≈øe Co≈øts, Noy 61. Wolf and Meggs.

The Plaintiff Demurs on the Defendants Bar, and the Court awarded the Plea good; upon which Judgment the Plaintiff ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rt Error, and therein the Bar awarded in≈øufficient, and ≈øo the Judgment rever≈øt, and the Judgment was that the Plaintiff ≈øhould recover his Debt and Damages, as if he had recovered in the fir≈øt Action, and not to be re≈øtored to his Action only, Yel. p. 41. Taylor and More.

div.head: In Mi≈øericordia, or Capiatur.
div.p: WHere the Party denies the Deed of his Ance≈øtor, and it is found again≈øt him by Verdict, Mi≈øericordia ≈øhall be entred again≈øt him, and not a Capiatur. Where the Party denies his own Deed, and it is found again≈øt him by Verdict, a Capiatur ≈øhall be entred again≈øt him, 2 Sanders 191. Mortlack and Charlton.

Where the Defendant pleads non e≈øt factum, and after diver≈øe Continuances relictd verificatione confe≈ø≈øeth the Action, Qu. if Judgment ≈øhall be given on the Plea, or on the Confe≈ø≈øion. 8 Rep. Beechers Ca≈øe is, that a Capiatur ≈øhall be entred; but the better Opinion is, that the Defendant ≈øhall not be fined, but amerced, and a Mi≈øericordia ≈øhall be entred again≈øt him on his own Confe≈ø≈øion; and ≈øo is the cour≈øe to enter in Com. B. and B. R. al≈øo 2 Sanders 191, 192. The rea≈øon is good in Cro. Jac. 64. Davis and Clark, and 2 Rols Rep. Gerard and Warren. For tho' the Defendant by his fal≈øe Plea hath delayed the Plaintiff of his Action; yet the Capiatur is not for the delay but for the fal≈øity rather: And then when he comes in, and before Verdict confe≈ø≈øeth the truth, he ≈øaves his Fine, for he hath put the Court to no trouble, 2 Keb. 694. Rowel and Roo. The Court ≈øeemed in doubt, tho' the Secondary ≈øaid it was in mia' generally, Cro. Jac. 420. A≈øhmore and Ripley. Precedents are both ways, 2 Keb. 704. Mortlock and Charlton.

Judgment in Debt, where the demand is in the debet & detinet, is to recover Debt, Damages and Co≈øts of Suit, and the Defendant in mia', but if the Defendant denies his Deed, then a Capias pro Fine i≈ø≈øues out, 1 Brownl. p. 50.

The Earl of L. pleaded non e≈øt facium, and found again≈øt him: The Judgment was, ideo Capiatur and good, tho' he be a Peer of the Realm; for a Fine is due to the King, and
none ≈øhall have Priviledge, again≈øt him, Cro. Eliz. 503. Earl of Lincoln again≈øt Flower.

Condition, If Henry and Robert H. pay, &c. The Defendant Robert pleads ≈øolvit ad diem, and found again≈øt him, and Judgment pro Querente quod recuperet debitum & damna again≈øt the ≈øaid Robert, & praed' Henricus in mi≈øericordia, where it ≈øhould have been Robert, for Henry was no party to the Record; this was ore tenus a≈ø≈øigned for Error, and it being a mi≈øpri≈øion of the Clerk, it was amended. Cro. Car. 594. Pelham and Hemming.

The Defendant confe≈øt the Action, and it was entred, non pote≈øt dedicere actionem quis non ≈øolvet: Per Cur. he having confe≈øt the Action, the words quin non ≈øolvet are not material, but ≈øurplu≈øage, and the Plaintiff had Judgment, Cro. Eliz. p. 144. Long and Woodliff.

The Defendant pleads per minas; the Plaintiff ≈øaith he did it ≈øpontanea voluntate, and Traver≈øeth the minas, and at the Ni≈øiprius the Defendant cognovit actionem, & non pote≈øt didicere, but that he made it at large, which is to a Plea per dure≈øs: But per Cur. in regard it is entred, quod cognovit actionem, it is not nece≈ø≈øary for him to acknowledge the point in I≈ø≈øue; and that which comes after the the cognovit actionem, is but ≈øurplu≈øage, Cro. Eliz. p. 840. Brown and Holland.
Debt again≈øt Baron and Feme on Obligation on made to the Wife, dum ≈øola: On non e≈øt factum, and found pro Querente, Judgment ≈øhall be Capiantur for both, Cro. Eliz. p. 381. Perey's Ca≈øe.

The Plaintiff declares upon a Bill quod reddat ti imum dolium ferri deliberand. within ≈øuch a time; and on, non e≈øt factum pro Querente: Judgment was quod Querens recuperet dolium ferri vel valorem ad damna, &c. and upon this a Writ I≈ø≈øues ad di≈øtringend' the Defendant quod reddat praedictum dolium ferri vel valorem eju≈ødem, & ≈øi non reddat dolium, tunc per Sacramentum inquiratur quantum idem dolium valet: And before any return of this Writ of enquiry, the Plaintiff takes out a Capias upon the Judgment: Its Error, 1. becau≈øe the the Judgment is in the Disjunctive; it ought to be quod recuperet dolium ferri, & ≈øi non, valorem inde, as in detinue, for the Plaintiff is not to have Election which he will have. 2. The Judgment is not perfect before the Writ returned, and ≈øo nothing certain to ground a Capias, or other Execution on. Yelv. p. 71. Paler and Bartlet ver≈øus Hardyman.

In old times, after Judgment given in Debt, the Obligation was demanded, becau≈øe the Duty was changed into another Nature; but ≈øince Writs of Error and Attaints have been ≈øo frequent, the Judges thought it dangerous to Cancel the Deed, 6 Rep. 46. Higgins Ca≈øe.

div.head: Execution.
div.p: IN Scire fac' on Judgment in Debt upon a Bond, Cour≈øe of the Rings-Bench is never to recite the Term of the Judgment given; aliter in the Common-Bench, 1 Keb. Tr. 13 Car. 2. fo. 104. Hatton and Jack≈øon.
A Writ of Error is no Super≈øedeas to ≈øtay Execution, without Special Sureties, to pay the Condemnation Mony, Cro. Jac. 350. Gold≈ømith ver≈øus Lady Platt.

The Action was laid in Comberland, in Debt on Bond, and Judgment to Recover again≈øt Admini≈øtrator: The Plaintiff cannot bring a Scire facias in We≈øtmorland, but in the ≈øame County where the fir≈øt Action was laid, Hobart p. 4. Mu≈øgrove and Wharton.

Two are bound in an Obligation joyntly and ≈øeverally, and the Obligee Sues one of them in the Common-Pleas, and the other in the Kings-Bench; and a Capias again≈øt him in the Kings-Bench, and took him in Execution, and after took Elegit again≈øt the other, and had Lands and Goods delivered in Execution, as he might; the other who was in Execution by his Body, had an Audita Querela and was delivered; and becau≈øe the Judgment in that ca≈øe mu≈øt be, that he be Di≈øcharged of the Execution, he ≈øhall never be taken again, tho' the Land taken in Execution be Evicted, Hob. p. 2. Q. tho' in Elegit the pernancy of the profits be Executory, yet its a pre≈øent Intere≈øt, and ≈øo a Satisfaction,
1 Rolls Rep.
‚Ä¢ . Cowley and Lydiat ‚Ä¢ .

If Debt be brought upon an Obligation again≈øt two, upon a joynt Praecipe, and the Plaintiff hath Judgment to Recovery a joynt Execution ought to be ≈øued again≈øt both: But if the Suit were by one Original and ≈øeveral Praecipe's. Execution may be ≈øued again≈øt any of them, 1 Leon. 288. agreed per Cur. 1 Rols. Rep. 44. B ‚Ä¢ nks Ca≈øe.

A. and B. are joyntly and ≈øeverally bound to C. C. took-out a Proce≈øs, again≈øt them by ≈øeveral Praecipe's, and had two ≈øeveral Judgments, and took out two ≈øeveral, Executions of one Te≈øt (viz.) Fieri facias again≈øt A. and Ca. Sa. again≈øt B. Q. if the Writs are well awarded; here the Fieri facias was Executed for all, and therefore no Ca. Sa. ≈øhall I≈ø≈øue out, Winch Rep. p. 112. Holts Ca≈øe.

If two are bound joyntly and ≈øeverally to me, and I Sue them joyntly, I may have a Capias again≈øt them both, and the death or e≈øcape of the one, ≈øhall not di≈øcharge the other: But I cannot have a Capias again≈øt one, and another kind of Execution again≈øt the other; becau≈øe, tho' they be two ≈øeveral per≈øons, yet they make but one Debtor, when I Sue them joyntly: But if I Sue them ≈øeverally, I may ≈øever them in their kinds of Executions: But yet ≈øo, if once a very Satisfaction is had of one, or, again≈øt the Sheriff upon an e≈øcape of one, the re≈øt may be releived upon an Audita Querela, Hobart p. 59. in Fo≈øters Ca≈øe.

One of the Obligors was in Execution by Ca. Sa. and the Sheriff voluntarie permi≈øit ad Lurgum: This was pleaded by the other Obligor: Judgment pro Querente, for the Execution again≈øt one is no Bar, but that he may Sue the other; and tho' he e≈øcaped, ≈øo as the Plaintiff is entitled to an Action again≈øt the Sheriff, yet that ≈øhall not deprive him of his remedy again≈øt the other, aliter if he had pleaded the Sheriff, &c. by the Licen≈øe or Command of the Plaintiff, Cro. Car. 75. Whittacre and Hamkin≈øon.

Two are bound joyntly and ≈øeverally in an Obligation, one was Sued, and taken in Execution, and afterwards the other was Sued and taken in Execution, and afterwards the fir≈øt e≈øcaped, and the other brought Audita Qu ‚Ä¢ rela, it lies not: And though the entry be quod ∆≤nica fiat Executio, yet that ≈øhall be intended to be an Execution with Satisfaction; and tho' one dye in Execution, yet the taking of the other is lawful. And the difference is, where one is di≈øcharged out of Execution, by the act of the party him≈øelf, to whom he was indebted, as by a Relea≈øe, making him Executor, &c. there its a di≈øcharge of both, but not where one is di≈øcharged by his own act or the act of a Stranger, 5 Rep. 86. b Cro. Eliz. 573. Blomfeilds Ca≈øe.

Tho' the≈øe words are not entred (where two Obligors are Sued by ≈øeveral Pracipes, and ≈øeveral Declarations and Jugdments) vnica tantum fiat Execution, yet its no Error, 1 Rols Rep. 44. Banks and Chamberlain.

Smith recovered again≈øt C. in Debt on Bond 40 l. and 110 l. in another Action, and in another Action C. recovers again≈øt Smith 100 l. Smith de≈øirous to be out of trouble moved the Court, that all ≈øhall be defaulted out of his Damages, which he had recovered again≈øt C. but C. would not con≈øent, and becau≈øe C. was not dwelling in any certain place, Chamberlein and Doddrige Order, that Smith ≈øhall pay his Mony to the Sheriff, and the Sheriff to bring it into Court to remain there, ≈øo that Smith might have his Execution as well again≈øt C. as C. again≈øt him, 2 Rols Rep. 327. Smith≈øon and Cage.

div.head: Where and by what means an Obligation is good in its Creation, may be defeated, gone, extinct, or di≈øcharged by matter ex po≈øt facto, in deed or Law.
div.p: By Concord or Agreement. Vid. ≈øupra.
By Defea≈øance. Vid. tit. Defea≈øance.
By Relea≈øe in Fait. Vid. titulo Pleading Relea≈øes.
By Relea≈øe in Law.

IF a Feme Obligee takes the Obligor, or one of the Obligors to Husband, its a Relea≈øe in Law of the Debt; but if Feme Executrix takes the Debtor to Husband, its no Relea≈øe in Law; but only ≈øu≈øpended during the Coverture: For otherwi≈øe, it might be a Deva≈øtavit, which is a wrong
the Law will not ≈øuffer, 8 Rep. 136. Sir John Needhams Ca≈øe, Cro. Litt. 264. b.
If there are two Women Obligees, and one of them take the Obligor to Hu≈øband, its a good Relea≈øe in Law, Co. Litt. 264. b.

If the Obligee make the Obligor, or one of the Obligors his Executors, its a Relea≈øe in Law of the Debt; yet it is not ab≈øolutely a Di≈øcharge of the Debt, for the Debt remains as A≈ø≈øets in the Hands of the Debtor Executor; and is qua≈øi a Relea≈øe in Law, becau≈øe he cannot be Sued, but its a meer ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of the Action: But where Feme Debtee takes Debtor to Husband, or a Man Debtee takes the Debtor to Wife; this is a Relea≈øe in Law for ever; and per≈øonal Actions once ≈øu≈øpended, are ever ≈øu≈øpended.

But when the Obligee makes the Executor of one of the Obligors, (who is chargable to that Debt) his Executor, its not a Relea≈øe in Law of that Debt; for he hath nothing thereby in his own Right, but is only to u≈øe an Action in Right of another, Cro. Car. 372. Dorche≈øter and Web.

The granting of Letters of Admini≈øtration to one or more of the Obligors, is no Di≈øcharge of the Obligation; or if the Obligor make the Obligee his Executor, its no Di≈øcharge, 8 Rep. 136. Sir John Needhams Ca≈øe, 1 Keb. 313. Locker and Smith.

When its ≈øaid, if once ≈øu≈øpended, ever ≈øu≈øpended, that is meant where the Action is ≈øu≈øpended by the act of the Obligee: Obligee makes the Wife of one of the Obligors Executrix, and dies; the Action is ≈øu≈øpended and extinct. The Relea≈øe and Di≈øcharge in Law of one Obligor, Di≈øchargeth the other, Hob. p. 10. Fryer. and Guildridge.
If Obligee makes the Obligor Executor, this is a Relea≈øe in Law of the Action, but the Duty remains, for which the Executor may retain ≈øo much Goods of the Te≈øtator, Co. Litt. 264. b.

div.head: In what Ca≈øes Extingui≈øhment, or Di≈øcharge of part of the Condition, ≈øhall be a Di≈øcharge of the whole.
div.p: IF a Man be bound to Build an Hou≈øe, and the Obligee Di≈øcharge him of part, its a Di≈øcharge of the whole, 4 H. 7.6. b. So if a Man be bound to go with A. B. and C. and the Obligee Di≈øcharge him of C. he is Di≈øcharged by this to go with A. and B. the Condition is entire. ibid.

If the words con≈øi≈øt of two parts in the Disjunctive, &c. and both are po≈ø≈øible at the time of the making; and before the time of performance, one of the things becomes impo≈ø≈øible to be done by the act of God, of the Law, or of the Obligee, in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Obligation is di≈øcharged for ever. Vid. ≈øupra ≈øub titulo Disjunctive Conditions, and Tender and Refu≈øal.

If the Condition be in Advantage of the Obligor, there if be di≈øcharged of part, he ≈øhall do the remainder: As one is bound to Till all my Land in D. and I di≈øcharge him of parcel, he ≈øhall do the remaining; but if I let 20 Acres to a man rendring Rent, and after an Obligation is made for payment of it; if Obligee enter into parcel, the Obligation is di≈ø≈øolved in the whole for all this is in Advantage of the Obligee 4 H. 7. b.

If the Obligation depends upon ≈øome other Deed, and that the Deed becomes void, in this ca≈øe the Obligation is become void al≈øo; as Bond conditioned for performance of Covenants in an Indenture, and afterwards the Covenants are di≈øcharged or become void, by this means the Obligation is di≈øcharged for ever: So Condition to pay Rent on a Lea≈øe pur Ans, and the L ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øee is evicted by Eigne Title, whereby the Rent in Law is gone, the Obligation is gone al≈øo; but aliter if Eviction be of part of the Land. Vid. ≈øupra.

div.head: Bond void by Interlineation.
div.p: Vid. ≈øupra ≈øub titulo non e≈øt factun, 2 Bal≈øt. 247. 11 Rep. 27. 1 Rols p. 39, 40. Cro. El. 626.

div.head: By breaking off one of the Seals.
div.p: Vid. ≈øupra ≈øub titulo non est factum.

div.head: By Ra≈øure.
div.p: Vid. ≈øupra tit. non e≈øt factum, & 1 Leon. 182.

div.head: Di≈øcharged by Act of Oblivion.
div.p: DI≈øcharge of part, is a di≈øcharge of the whole, 2 Keb. p. 788. Vere and Langley again≈øt Cumbden, &c.
If a Deed be delivered to be Cancelled to the party him≈øelf, yet if it be not Cancelled, and the other gets it again, it remains a good Deed, Cro. 38. Eliz. Trin. Cro≈øs and Powel.
